The study investigated the role of eosinophils in the growth of Trichinella spiralis larvae in skeletal muscle. The study found that eosinophils from IL-4 competent mice are sufficient to support growth of the larvae, and that eosinophil-mediated effects on larval growth are independent of adaptive immunity. The study also showed that eosinophils promote larval growth by an IL-4-dependent mechanism that limits local interferon-driven responses. These findings provide evidence for a host-parasite relationship in which the recruitment of eosinophils promotes a nutrient-rich environment that facilitates larval growth.
Our work provides a comprehensive analysis of genome-wide replication kinetics in human and mouse embryonic stem cells. We analyze DNA replication timing profiles from massive sequencing of newly replicated DNA, and replication origin maps generated by a novel chromatin immunoprecipitation-based method. We find that most replication origins are activated synchronously in early S phase, but activation is delayed and less efficient in late replicating domains. We find that replication forks move faster than the mean apparent replication speed of single forks, and that the mean apparent replication speed varies between cell lines, likely due to changes in chromatin structure. These findings are compatible with a model of origin activation in which origins are activated in a wave-like fashion, with the replication fork stimulating activation of neighboring origins. We also find that replication origins are embedded in regions of open chromatin and are correlated with the timing of origin activation. Our analysis of DNA combing data reveals that the replication fork velocity varies in different regions of the genome, and that a large fraction of replication forks replicate at speeds faster than the mean velocity of single forks, including in regions of the genome that are thought to replicate by a single fork. This suggests that origins are often activated sequentially in regions of the genome that replicate by a single fork, and that the mean velocity of the replication fork is not a good estimate of the velocity of the earliest fork in the region. These results provide evidence that replication initiation is not a stochastic process but is regulated by chromatin structure, and that replication forks stimulate origin activation in adjacent domains.
The nervous system is very good at recognizing objects, even when the context in which they are seen changes. This is because we mostly see objects from slightly different angles or under different lighting conditions. The ability to recognize objects is learned from experience, not innate. The slowness principle is a way of learning to recognize objects by focusing on features that change slowly over time. The principle is based on the idea that it is likely that an object seen at one moment will be present again at the next moment. Therefore, the goal of the slowness principle is to learn about features of the input that change slowly. To do this, the brain needs to adapt to the sensory input in order to extract slowly varying aspects, thus creating a representation of an object that is not strongly affected by irrelevant changes in the sensory input. The slowness principle is used in a type of learning called slow feature analysis. This technique finds the function that changes the slowest over time in the input signal. To do this, it uses the variance of the time derivative of the signal as the objective function. In this paper, we show that the slowness principle can be implemented in a model of a spiking neuron using a modified version of Hebb's learning rule. We also show that the same principle can be implemented in a spiking neuron using spike-timing–dependent plasticity. The two methods are equivalent in terms of their ability to implement the slowness principle, but spike-timing–dependent plasticity is more biologically realistic.
This study explores how tumor cells interact with each other to resist cancer treatment. The authors found that cancer cells exposed to treatment can induce resistance in nearby cells by sharing resistance traits. This behavior, termed "cooperative adaptation to therapy," is not well understood, and this study provides new insights into this process. The authors used a three-dimensional in vitro culture platform to study this phenomenon and found that drug-induced cell state transitions play a key role. They also developed a mathematical model to simulate how this cooperative behavior affects population growth over time. These findings may help us better understand how tumors develop resistance to treatment and inform the development of new therapies.
The paper is about a study on rickettsioses, a group of bacterial infections that can cause fever and other symptoms, in the Mbeya region of Tanzania. The authors randomly selected 1,228 people from nine communities in this region to test for antibodies against rickettsiae using a dilution of 1:64. They found that 67.9% of the people were seropositive for rickettsiae. The authors then analyzed the data to identify potential risk factors for rickettsioses, such as age, temperature, population density, and livestock density. They used regression analysis to determine the association between these factors and seropositivity. The authors concluded that rickettsioses are common in the Mbeya region of Tanzania and that spread of the infection is limited by temperature and elevation. They suggested that a prospective study of rickettsioses should be conducted to estimate the disease burden in the population.
Fatty acids have many important roles in the body, including making up the building blocks of cells and energy storage. They can also act as signals for cellular communication and affect cell membrane fluidity. In this study, researchers found that a specific type of fatty acid called oleate is important for immune defense in the worm Caenorhabditis elegans. They found that the production of oleate is needed for the body's immune response to be activated when it is infected by bacteria. The researchers found that worms that cannot make oleate are more likely to be killed by the bacteria. They also found that adding oleate to the worms' environment can help protect them from the bacteria. This study suggests that oleate has an important role in the body's defense against infections.
Researchers have found that certain compounds that bind to a type of genetic element called a riboswitch can kill bacteria. These riboswitches are involved in the regulation of the production of certain chemicals that are important for the cell's "nucleotide pool." When these compounds, called PC1, bind to the riboswitch, they cause the bacteria to stop making these chemicals and ultimately die. This effect is only seen when the bacteria are not starved for these chemicals. The researchers have also shown that PC1 is effective against a number of different strains of bacteria, including some that are resistant to other antibiotics. They have used a mouse model to demonstrate that PC1 can reduce the number of bacteria causing infections in mice. The researchers suggest that PC1 could be developed into a new type of antibiotic.
The hippocampus plays an important role in the construction of mental space, or the way we navigate and remember our environment. In primates, hippocampal place cells seem to encode the target of gaze, meaning what the animal was looking at, rather than the animal's position or direction. However, some previous studies in macaques and humans have shown that place cells also code for position and direction. To understand how gaze informs the construction of mental space during wayfinding, researchers have examined navigation behavior, visual exploration, and hippocampal activity in macaque monkeys as they searched a virtual reality maze for a reward. They found that some cells in the hippocampus fired at the sight or in anticipation of a single landmark in a viewpoint- or task-dependent manner, simultaneously encoding the animal's logical situation within a set of actions leading to the goal. In addition, hippocampal activity was best fit by a fine-grained state space comprising current position, view, and action contexts. These findings suggest that the counterparts of rodent place cells in primates embody multidimensional, task-situated knowledge pertaining to the target of gaze, which supports self-awareness in the construction of space.
The isthmic organizer is a group of genes that helps to shape the central nervous system during vertebrate development. We studied the interactions between the genes involved in this group by analyzing their spatial patterns of expression at the mid-hindbrain boundary (MHB) in mice. We found that the IsO is responsible for the maintenance of the MHB, and we predicted that Fgf8 has a maintaining rather than inducing effect on Wnt1 expression. We also found that the spatial expression patterns of these genes are not random, but are due to the action of transcription and secreted factors. Our results have implications for the study of the development of the central nervous system in vertebrates.
The paper describes a study of a protein called p104 from the parasite Theileria annulata that is found on the surface of the transforming schizont. The schizont is a stage of the parasite that enters into the host cell and causes it to grow and divide. The paper suggests that p104 can bind to a protein called end binding protein 1 (EB1) from the host cell. EB1 is important for the host cell to properly divide. By binding to EB1, p104 may help the schizont to cause the host cell to divide and produce more schizonts. The paper also explains how p104 interacts with EB1 and provides evidence for their binding.
Broken replication forks can cause DNA damage. Mild insufficiency of the replicative ligase Cdc9 in yeast resulted in persistent DNA damage and longer telomeres. Telomere lengthening required the BIR repair pathway, which is promoted by the DNA damage-induced phosphorylation of Pif1. The DNA damage-induced phosphorylation of Pif1 promotes potentially telomere-stabilizing telomere extension while repressing deleterious de novo telomere addition events at DNA breaks. The study suggests that the DNA damage-induced phosphorylation of Pif1 promotes genome-preserving repair pathways.
The study tested the use of a new diagnostic tool called LIPS (luciferase immunoprecipitation systems) for onchocerciasis, a disease caused by the filarial nematode Onchocerca volvulus. LIPS uses recombinantly produced Onchocerca volvulus antigens (Ov-FAR-1, Ov-API-1, Ov-MSA-1, and Ov-CPI-1) and measures the antibody response to these antigens to diagnose onchocerciasis. The study found that using a mixture of all four antigens simultaneously in the standard format or a quick 15-minute format (QLIPS) could distinguish between Ov-infected and uninfected control sera with 100% sensitivity and specificity. Additionally, the study found that patients infected with other filarial parasites, such as Wuchereria bancrofti, Loa loa, and Strongyloides stercoralis, had markedly lower antibody titers to each of the Ov antigens compared to patients with Ov infections. Overall, the LIPS assay is a rapid, high-throughput, and specific tool that can be used to diagnose individual Ov infections and potentially detect recrudescent infections in areas under control and for mapping new areas of transmission of Ov infection.
The study investigated the effectiveness of iron-folic acid supplementation and regular deworming to reduce anemia, iron deficiency, iron deficiency anemia, and soil-transmitted helminth infections in women of reproductive age in a rural setting in Vietnam. The study found that after 54 months, mean hemoglobin levels rose from 122 g/L to 131 g/L, anemia prevalence fell from 38% to 18%, iron deficiency fell from 23% to 8%, and iron deficiency anemia prevalence was reduced to 4%. Additionally, the prevalence of hookworm infection was reduced from 76% to 11%, and the level of moderate or heavy infestation of any soil-transmitted helminth was reduced to less than 1%. The study concluded that population-based interventions can effectively reduce anemia and practically eliminate iron deficiency anemia and moderate to heavy soil-transmitted helminth infections in a rural setting. The study also identified predictive factors for hematological outcomes.
Herpesviruses are viruses that establish a lifelong infection in their host, but they also have ways to avoid the host's immune response. One way that EBV does this is by expressing a protein called gp150 during the late phase of the viral life cycle. This protein blocks the presentation of antigens by HLA class I, HLA class II, and CD1d molecules, which are important for the host's immune response. gp150 does this by shielding the surface molecules with glycans, which makes them less likely to be recognized by the immune system. This is a novel immune evasion mechanism in herpesviruses, which means that it has not been seen before.
Chlamydia trachomatis is a bacterium that causes sexually transmitted disease and is the leading cause of preventable blindness worldwide. This bacteria undergoes a developmental cycle between an infectious form (EB) and a replicative form (RB) inside a membrane-bound compartment called inclusion. It has been found that chlamydiae recruit actin to the site of attachment inside the host cell, and this recruitment is important for bacterial entry. However, the mechanism of this recruitment is unclear. Researchers have found that C. trachomatis harbors a protein called Tarp, which can directly induce actin polymerization. The protein Tarp has three domains: an N-terminal tyrosine-rich repeat domain, a proline rich domain, and a G-actin binding domain. The proline rich domain and G-actin binding domain are conserved among all known Tarp orthologs. The research shows that Tarp orthologs from Chlamydia pneumonia, C. caviae, C. muridarum, and various C. trachomatis serovars all harbor at least one and up to four functional actin binding domains and that purified recombinant Tarps from all chlamydial species were capable of nucleating actin filament formation in vitro. Additionally, a peptide antiserum with affinity to the actin binding domain prevented Tarp mediated actin nucleation and, when delivered into host cells, significantly reduced host cell susceptibility to chlamydial infection. These findings show that Tarp mediated actin polymerization is a conserved feature among diverse chlamydial species and suggest that the actin binding domain plays an important role in bacterial entry.
Schistosomiasis is a type of intestinal disease caused by parasitic worms. It is common in Asia and affects many types of mammals, including water buffaloes. Determining the prevalence and intensity of the disease in these mammalian reservoirs is important for calculating transmission rates and environmental contamination. A new procedure called the formalin–ethyl acetate sedimentation-digestion (FEA–SD) technique has been developed to improve microscopic visualization of schistosome eggs in fecal samples from bovines and other ruminant reservoir hosts. The FEA–SD technique involves several steps, including filtration, sedimentation, potassium hydroxide digestion and centrifugation, prior to microscopy. The technique removes nearly 70% of bulk debris from the fecal samples, making it easier to see the eggs. The FEA-SD technique is a valuable tool for monitoring the spread of schistosomiasis in animal reservoirs, particularly in areas with low to high infection intensity, or where there is suspected elimination of schistosomiasis.
Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) is a bone disorder caused by mutations in genes that encode proteins responsible for collagen formation. These proteins are important for maintaining bone mass and bone strength. Two of these proteins, prolyl 3-hydroxylase 1 (P3H1) and cartilage associated protein (CRTAP), are part of a complex that modifies a specific proline residue on collagen molecules. Recent research has shown that this modification is not necessary for collagen stability, but it may play a role in collagen interactions that are important for proper collagen folding. P3H1 and CRTAP stabilize each other, so when one of these genes is mutated, it can lead to loss of the entire complex and its associated functions. In this study, researchers created a knock-in mouse model that carried a single amino acid substitution in the catalytic site of P3H1. This substitution abolished P3H1 activity but retained the ability to form a complex with CRTAP and chaperone collagen trimer assembly. The knock-in mice showed no prolyl 3-hydroxylation at the modified proline residue, but there was no significant over-modification at other collagen residues. The mice were normal in appearance, had no growth defects, and normal cartilage growth plate histology, but they had decreased trabecular bone mass. The study showed that the knock-in mice recapitulated some of the bone phenotype of OI but not the cartilage and growth phenotypes caused by loss of the prolyl 3-hydroxylation complex. The observations suggest that inactivation of P3H1 hydroxylase activity may have different tissue consequences than complete ablation of the prolyl 3-hydroxylation complex.
Transposable elements (TEs) are genetically simple but highly successful genetic elements that insert copies of themselves into new genomic locations faster than they are eliminated. TEs can be beneficial, harmful, or neutral to their host. The mutagenic properties of transposons have been harnessed by molecular geneticists to disrupt thousands of Drosophila genes. The P-element, a DNA transposon, was horizontally transferred from a distant relative, D. willistoni, into D. melanogaster. The element spread rapidly through the species, as evidenced by its absence from old laboratory stocks. In its native species and current D. melanogaster populations, the P-element is not associated with any gross defects. However, when males from strains collected after the invasion (P strains) are crossed to females from old laboratory stocks (M strains), the F1 offspring suffer a number of abnormalities, including sterility, recombination in males, increased mutation rates, and abnormally small (dysgenic) gonads. These abnormalities are collectively known as "hybrid dysgenesis" and are due to DNA damage caused by actively transposing P-element in the germline. In the reciprocal direction, the F1 offspring, though genetically identical, are normal because they are protected by piRNAs (PIWI interacting RNAs) homologous to the P-element, which target the P-element mRNA for degradation. In a recent study, the P-element was found in D. simulans, apparently horizontally acquired from D. melanogaster. The P-element causes a hybrid dysgenesis-like phenotype in crosses between strains from different D. simulans populations, and this phenotype occurs in crosses between strains collected before and after a rapid invasion of the P-element.
Scientists have developed a new method to mark male mosquitoes to study their mating success during field releases. The method involves feeding male mosquitoes on a sugar solution containing a fluorescent dye called rhodamine B, which produces a bright red colour when fluoresced. Rhodamine B has been used in the past to mark insects, such as tobacco budworm moths, fireflies, and Drosophila. However, it has not been used before to mark mosquitoes. The study aimed to determine the optimal feeding regimes for ideal body and seminal fluid marking, as well as any potential impacts of rhodamine B feeding on male survival and mating competitiveness. The results showed that feeding male mosquitoes on a sugar solution containing rhodamine B produced long-lasting body marking and that the dye had no effect on male mating competitiveness. The study concluded that rhodamine B could be a useful evaluation method for male-based SIT/IIT control strategies as well as a viable body marking technique for male-based mark-release-recapture experiments.
Superantigens are proteins secreted by some bacteria that can activate many T cells at once, causing a toxic immune response that can lead to death. These proteins bind to both major histocompatibility complex (MHC-II) and T cell receptor (TCR) molecules, which are found on immune cells. However, superantigens also need to bind to a third molecule called CD28 to cause the toxic immune response. CD28 is a costimulatory receptor that helps regulate the immune response. To stop the toxic immune response caused by superantigens, researchers found that short peptides that mimic the binding site of CD28 on superantigens can block their ability to bind to CD28. These peptides also protected mice from superantigen toxicity. These findings suggest that CD28 can be co-opted by superantigens as a receptor and that blocking access of superantigens to CD28 can be an effective way to prevent toxic immune responses.
In this study, the authors examined the role of the Wnt/β-catenin pathway in mouse embryonic stem cells (mESCs), which are pluripotent cells that can differentiate into various types of cells. They found that the Wnt pathway controls mESC proliferation through the activity of the transcription factor Tcf1. Tcf1 is recruited to the Ink4/Arf tumor suppressor locus, which encodes for negative regulators of the cell cycle, leading to a reduction in mESC proliferation. However, the Wnt pathway does not affect pluripotency in mESCs. The authors also found that Tcf1 has specialized functions that are distinct from Tcf3, another transcription factor involved in the Wnt pathway. This study sheds light on the complexity of the Wnt pathway and its role in the regulation of pluripotency and proliferation in mESCs.
Dengue virus is a single-stranded RNA virus that can cause severe symptoms, including hemorrhagic manifestations and a shock syndrome. Dengue infection can activate plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs), which are innate immune cells that produce IFN-α and express TRAIL. Our study found that pDCs were activated in mild dengue cases, characterized by increased levels of IFN-α and TRAIL in the plasma. We also found that DENV-2 exposure led to mTRAIL relocalization from intracellular compartment to plasma membrane, which was regulated by endosomal viral degradation blockade by chloroquine. In vitro experiments showed that DENV-2-infected monocytes exhibited reduced viral antigens, which was dependent on IFN-α production by pDCs. Our study suggests that pDC activation may have an important role in the outcome of dengue disease.
The role of TNF in controlling Mycobacterium tuberculosis ( Mtb ) infection has been studied extensively. The current study uses a mathematical model to explore the role and production of both transmembrane TNF ( tmTNF ) and soluble TNF ( sTNF ) in controlling Mtb infection. It also investigates the effects of two anti-TNF agents, an antibody and a receptor fusion molecule, in controlling Mtb infection. The study shows that the production of sTNF is essential for controlling Mtb infection, and that the bioavailability of TNF after anti-TNF therapy is the primary factor for causing reactivation of latent infection. The study suggests that a TNF-modulating agent could be developed to balance the requirement for reducing inflammation with the necessity to maintain resistance to infection and microbial diseases. Alternatively, the dose and timing of anti-TNF therapy could be modified to reduce the risk of reactivation of latent infection.
Retro (pseudo) genes are copies of existing genes that form through the process of reverse transcription of mRNAs and subsequent insertion into the genome. Retrocopies are often believed to be nonfunctional "junk DNA," but they may have an intact open reading frame and be protein-coding, long noncoding RNAs, or sources of short interfering RNAs or microRNA sponges. Some retrocopies can also replace their parental genes and act as phylogenetic markers. Recent sequencing technology has allowed researchers to study the variation in retrocopies within populations. Recent studies revealed 208 polymorphic retrocopies (RDVs), which can be used as genomic markers for population history. However, many questions remained unanswered, such as how old these RDVs are and what their functional aspects are. In this study, researchers used the 1000 Genomes Project and RNA-Seq data to investigate the variation in loss of ancient retrocopies among different human populations, and the expression levels of retrocopies between populations. They also developed a new approach to detect novel retrocopies absent from the reference human genome. Altogether, they were able to detect 193 RDVs, most resulting from retrocopy deletion. The frequency of their deletion was very low, and the expression, conservation, and low rate of deletion of the remaining 10 retrocopies may suggest some functionality. Additionally, they found 9 retrogenes that undergo statistically significant differential expression between populations.
Neurocysticercosis (NCC) is a disease where the larval stage (cysticercus) of a parasite called Taenia solium infects the brain. NCC causes a range of symptoms such as seizures and focal neurological signs. The symptoms of NCC depend on the number, location, and distribution of cysticerci, as well as the degree of brain inflammation and the developmental stage of the parasite. This study used naturally infected pigs as a model to compare the inflammatory response following cysticidal treatment to cysticerci located in the brain parenchyma, meninges, or both tissues. The results showed that cysticerci in the brain parenchyma caused the greatest inflammatory response following cysticidal treatment compared to cysticerci in the meninges or both tissues. This suggests that the severity of symptoms in NCC may depend on the location of cysticerci in the brain.
Yaws is a re-emerging infectious disease that is caused by a type of bacteria called Treponema pallidum ssp. pertenue. It is endemic in Ghana, but there is a lack of information about the epidemiology of the disease. A survey was conducted in two districts of Ghana where mass drug administration for trachoma had previously been conducted. Children aged 5-17 years with skin lesions that were compatible with yaws were enrolled in the study. Samples for treponemal serology and lesion PCR were collected from all children. The results showed that none of the children tested positive for syphilis, but Haemophilus ducreyi was detected in 9 out of 98 lesions. This suggests that H. ducreyi may be associated with some skin lesions, but the majority of lesions remain unexplained. The survey did not find any evidence of ongoing transmission of yaws in these communities. This study highlights the importance of integrating diagnostic testing into both pre and post-mass drug administration surveillance systems to better inform yaws control programs.
HIV infection is treated with antiretroviral therapy (ART), but this treatment does not completely eliminate the virus from the body. There is a small population of cells that harbor HIV, called the viral reservoir, which can contribute to the spread of the virus even after treatment ends. One way to form the viral reservoir is through a process called seeding, which involves the spread of HIV from infected cells to uninfected cells. Two drugs called tofacitinib and ruxolitinib, which are used to treat rheumatoid arthritis, may be able to block this process by interfering with the Jak-STAT pathway, which is involved in the spread of HIV. This study shows that tofacitinib and ruxolitinib can reduce the frequency of CD4+ T cells that harbor integrated HIV DNA, as well as reduce viral production from infected cells. Additionally, these drugs can block the reactivation of HIV from latency, which is a key step in the spread of the virus. Overall, this study suggests that tofacitinib and ruxolitinib could be potential therapeutic options for blocking the seeding and maintenance of the HIV viral reservoir.
Scientists used microarray analysis to study how the immune response of Spodoptera exigua cells to a baculovirus changed over time. They found that the number of genes that were either up- or down-regulated during the first 36 hours of the infection was similar. Many immune-related genes were down-regulated after infection, including genes related to pattern recognition, signalling, immune pathways, immune effectors, and genes that code for proteins involved in the melanization cascade. These changes were also seen in larval gut samples. The researchers then studied how gut microbiota affect the baculovirus infection process and found that gut bacteria enhance the virulence, pathogenicity, and dispersion of the virus. They concluded that the host immune response to baculoviruses plays an important role in the pathogenesis of the infection and that the gut microbiota also plays a role.
Apomixis is a form of asexual reproduction through seeds, resulting in genetic clones of the mother plant. It has the potential to greatly improve crop yields. However, few crop species are naturally apomictic and attempts to introduce it through crossing have failed. To create apomixis in a sexual plant, the genes that confer elements of apomixis must be identified. In this study, we identified a gene in Arabidopsis thaliana that controls entry into the second meiotic division. By combining this gene with two other mutations that eliminate recombination and pairing and modify chromatid segregation, we created a genotype called MiMe in which meiosis is replaced by mitosis. This is an important step towards understanding and engineering apomixis in crops.
The current paper evaluates the usefulness of incorporating tissue-specific information into a disease gene prioritization algorithm. The paper utilizes gene expression data from 60 different human tissues to construct tissue-specific protein-protein interaction networks. These networks are then used to prioritize candidate disease genes. The authors find that the tissue-specific networks yield more accurate results compared to using a generic network. The paper also highlights the importance of tissue-specific information in disease gene prioritization.
The article introduces a new, flexible model for the spread of insecticide resistance in mosquito species that transmit human diseases. The model allows for differential exposure to insecticides for males and females and allows for selection pressures and dominance values to differ depending on the concentration of insecticide encountered. The model is used to investigate the relative merits of sequential use of insecticides versus their deployment as a mixture to minimize the spread of resistance. The article demonstrates that the model can identify vector control strategies most likely to minimize the spread of insecticide resistance.
The article describes the sialome (saliva proteins) of Rhodnius neglectus, a type of bug that feeds on blood. This information can help us better understand the feeding process of these bugs, how they avoid the host's defense mechanisms, and how they transmit diseases. The data from this study will also be useful for researchers who are working on developing treatments for circulatory disorders.
In this study, researchers looked at how soil nematodes (roundworms) respond to different soil bacteria in the laboratory. They found that many of the genes that were turned on or off in response to different bacteria were involved in the nematodes' metabolism (way of breaking down food) and immune response. They then showed that changing the bacteria that the nematodes ate affected how long the nematodes lived and how well they reproduced. They also found that the amount that a particular gene was turned on or off in response to different bacteria could predict how much its mutation would affect the nematodes' lifespan and reproduction in those environments. This suggests that looking at how genes are turned on or off in response to different environments can give us information about how important those genes are in that environment. This research could help us understand how soil nematodes respond to changes in their environment, and could also help us learn more about the nematodes' genes and how they work.
The blastocyst is a stage of development in which the fertilized egg develops into an embryo. At this stage, the embryo is made up of two distinct types of cells: the inner cell mass (ICM), which gives rise to the embryo, and the trophectoderm (TE), which forms extraembryonic structures. How these cell types are determined is an important question in developmental biology. The authors investigate this question by developing a multiscale, stochastic model to investigate the design principles responsible for robust establishment of the ICM and TE in the mouse blastocyst. The model incorporates both motions and divisions of individual cells as well as gene regulatory processes influenced by cell positions and cell-cell interactions. The authors find that the inside-outside based mechanism is likely to be responsible for the high level of robustness observed, and that gene expression noise can enhance robustness of organization by promoting cellular plasticity. These results suggest that noise has a crucial role in maintaining cellular plasticity and organizing the blastocyst.
This study investigated the basis for recognition of diverse antigens by antibodies encoded by three VH gene segments. Panels of somatically mutated antibodies encoded by a common VH gene, but each binding to a different antigen, were computationally redesigned to predict antibodies that could engage multiple antigens at once. The Rosetta multi-state design process predicted antibody sequences for the entire heavy chain variable region, including framework, CDR1, and CDR2 mutations. The predicted sequences matched the germline gene sequences to a remarkable degree, revealing by computational design the residues that are predicted to enable polyspecificity, i.e., binding of many unrelated antigens with a common sequence. This process thereby reverses antibody maturation in silico. In contrast, when designing antibodies to bind a single antigen, a sequence similar to that of the mature antibody sequence was returned, mimicking natural antibody maturation in silico. The study demonstrated that the Rosetta computational design algorithm captures important aspects of antibody/antigen recognition and identified key positions in the VH gene encoding CDR1, CDR2, and the immunoglobulin framework that are critical contributors for polyspecificity in germline antibodies. The study suggests that antibodies encoded by germline VH genes are optimal for polyspecificity and that computational design of antibodies capable of binding multiple antigens may allow the rational design of antibodies that retain polyspecificity for diverse epitope binding.
Locusts are insects that can change their behavior from solitary to gregarious depending on their environment. When locusts are solitary, they avoid other locusts, but when they are gregarious, they are attracted to other locusts and form large groups. Researchers have studied how locusts switch between these two behaviors, and have developed a mathematical model that explains how gregarious groups form. The model takes into account the way that locusts interact with each other and how their behavior changes depending on their environment. The researchers found that there is a critical density of locusts above which gregarious groups form, and that these groups are made up of a higher ratio of gregarious to solitary locusts.
This research study focuses on the process of membrane fusion in viruses that belong to the flavivirus genus, such as TBE virus. The fusion process involves a series of steps driven by triggered conformational changes of viral envelope glycoproteins, commonly referred to as fusion proteins. The study shows that when TBE virions are exposed to alkaline pH instead of acidic pH, the particles are trapped in an intermediate conformation in which the E dimers dissociate and interact with target membranes via the fusion peptide without proceeding to the merger of the membranes. The study suggests that this intermediate state represents a transient conformation of the fusion protein required to convert the prefusion dimer into the postfusion trimer. The study highlights the importance of this intermediate state for the overall membrane fusion process and provides new insights into the dynamic process of viral membrane fusion.
The study aimed to understand whether plant extinctions have a significant impact on the loss of evolutionary history across the angiosperm tree-of-life. To do this, the authors analyzed the unique flora found within the Cape region of South Africa and used detailed phylogenetic information to identify which plant species are at risk of extinction and how they are distributed taxonomically. They compared the taxonomic distribution of extinction risks between the Cape and the UK floras and used detailed phylogenetic data for the Cape to identify the factors likely driving extinctions. The study revealed an unusual phylogenetic signal in extinction risks for plants and demonstrated how species' present-day vulnerabilities can be explained by their recent evolutionary past. This study provides important insights into the conservation of plant species and the importance of preserving evolutionary diversity.
Researchers have found that two proteins, Bruton's Tyrosine Kinase (BTK) and Vav1, are involved in the immune response to the opportunistic fungal pathogen Candida albicans. These proteins are recruited to phagocytic cups containing C. albicans yeasts or hyphae, but are absent from mature phagosomes. BTK and Vav1 localize to cuff regions surrounding the hyphae, while Dectin-1 lines the full length of the phagosome. These proteins colocalize with the lipid PI (3,4,5)P3 and F-actin at the phagocytic cup, but not with diacylglycerol (DAG) which marks more mature phagosomal membranes. The researchers also found that BTK contributes to DAG synthesis at the phagocytic cup and the subsequent recruitment of PKCε. Finally, BTK- or Vav1-deficient peritoneal macrophages display a defect in both zymosan and C. albicans phagocytosis, and BTK- or Vav1-deficient mice are more susceptible to systemic C. albicans infection than wild type mice.
Rift Valley Fever (RVF) is a virus that affects cattle and humans, causing symptoms such as fever and headaches in humans and abortions in cattle. RVF has been reported in various eco-climatic areas, including arid areas in Western Africa, sub-humid areas in Eastern Africa, wet forests in central Africa, and humid highlands in Madagascar. The roles of direct and vectorial transmissions are unevaluated in both humans and cattle. To better understand RVF transmission patterns in Madagascar, we used a combination of environmental, cattle, and human data. Our analysis showed that humid environments and high cattle density were associated with increased risk of RVF in both cattle and humans. We also found that frequent contact with raw milk was associated with human infection. Using mathematical modeling, we could further assess the contribution of vectorial or direct transmissions in each eco-climatic area.
In recent years, scientists have discovered that certain proteins, called prions, can infect and replicate within other cells. Prions are made up of proteins that self-propagate into an infectious form. These infectious forms of proteins are called prion-like aggregates. Prion-like aggregates can be made by many different types of proteins, including proteins found in bacteria, yeast, and humans. Scientists have found that prion-like aggregates can be infectious, even if the proteins themselves have the same amino acid sequence. This suggests that prions are more than just a specific sequence of amino acids - they are a specific protein fold that is self-replicating and infectious.
In this study, the authors introduce a novel approach to population genetic inference using deep learning. They demonstrate that deep learning can be effectively employed for population genetic inference and learning informative features of data. As a concrete application, they focus on the challenging problem of jointly inferring natural selection and demography in the form of a population size change history. The method is able to separate the global nature of demography from the local nature of selection. They apply their method to 197 African Drosophila melanogaster genomes from Zambia to infer both their overall demography and regions of their genome under selection. They find many regions of the genome that have experienced hard sweeps, and fewer under selection on standing variation or balancing selection. Additionally, they find that soft sweeps and balancing selection occur more frequently closer to the centromere of each chromosome. Their demographic inference suggests that previously estimated bottlenecks for African Drosophila melanogaster are too extreme.
High-risk human papillomavirus (HR-HPV) E6/E7 oncoproteins are necessary for the development of cervical and other genital tract cancers, and also increase the risk of head and neck cancers. HPV16 E6/E7 oncoproteins were found to impair the FA-BRCA pathway, which is involved in repairing ICLs (intrastrand or interstrand crosslinks). HPV E6/E7 oncoproteins prevent the FA pathway from repairing ICLs and make cells more sensitive to DNA crosslinkers. HPV E6 and E7 increase FancD2 monoubiquitination, but delay its deubiquitination, which is necessary for repairing ICLs. HPV E6/E7 also impair FancD2 colocalization with double-strand breaks and reduce FancN expression, which are necessary for ICL repair. These findings show that HPV16 E6/E7 oncoproteins disrupt the FA-BRCA pathway and contribute to the development of HPV-associated cancers.
Onchocerciasis, or river blindness, is caused by the parasite Onchocerca volvulus, which is spread by black flies in Latin America. The Southern Chiapas focus is one of the largest onchocerciasis foci in Latin America, with 559 communities at risk. The Mexican government has been using Mectizan (ivermectin) since the 1990s to treat the affected communities twice a year. In 2003, 50 of these communities began receiving Mectizan four times a year, and another 113 communities were added to the quarterly treatment regimen in 2009. The aim is to eliminate transmission of the parasite. In 2011, entomological surveys were conducted in six sentinel communities and three extra-sentinel communities, and no infected black flies were found. This suggests that the transmission rate in the vector population is less than one infective fly per 2,000 flies tested. Additionally, serological assays were conducted on 4,230 children, and only two individuals were found to be exposed to the parasite, with an exposure rate of less than 0.5%. These results suggest that O. volvulus transmission has been interrupted in the Southern Chiapas focus, meaning that there is a very low risk of new transmission. This is good news, as it means that the goal of eliminating onchocerciasis in Mexico is being met.
The bacterium Listeria monocytogenes is a type of bacteria that can infect animals and humans. It can survive in soil but becomes infectious when consumed by humans. When inside a host, it invades cells and replicates. A protein called PrfA controls the genes that help the bacteria survive and spread within the host. To study the role of PrfA, scientists have created mutations that make PrfA active even without the normal trigger. They found that the bacteria secrete a small peptide pheromone called pPplA, which helps the bacteria escape from host cell vacuoles and may stimulate PrfA to help them grow and spread inside the host.
This study used a tool called transposon sequencing analysis (Tn-seq) to screen for genes in the bacterium Vibrio cholerae that are important for resistance to reactive oxygen species (ROS) during infection in mice. The Tn-seq analysis was performed by comparing the gene requirements for colonization in untreated and antioxidant-treated adult mice. The study found that mutants of the methyl-directed mismatch repair (MMR) system, such as MutS, had a significant colonization advantage in untreated mice, but not in antioxidant-treated mice. This advantage was found to be due to the accumulation of catalase-overproducing mutants and rugose colony variants in antioxidant-treated mice. The study also found that the mutation rate of wildtype colonized in antioxidant-treated mice was significantly higher than that in antioxidant-untreated mice. The study suggests that V. cholerae employs a temporal adaptive strategy to battle ROS during infection, resulting in enriched phenotypes. Additionally, the study developed a strategy to study bacterial temporal hypermutation in vivo and found that hypermutators display colonization advantages in ROS-rich mouse intestines.
The study investigates the function of the protein Mlh1-Mlh3 in meiosis and mismatch repair (MMR) in yeast. Mlh1-Mlh3 is an endonuclease that plays a role in resolving DNA strand crossovers in meiosis and resolving mismatched DNA in MMR. The study used genetic analysis to analyze a large number of different mutations in the Mlh1-Mlh3 gene. The results showed that some mutations specifically disrupted MMR, while others specifically disrupted crossing over in meiosis. The authors suggest that defects in Mlh1-Mlh3 can alter the fate of meiotic recombination intermediates. The study provides a structure-function map for Mlh1-Mlh3 and suggests that defects in the endonuclease activity of Mlh1-Mlh3 can lead to errors in meiosis and MMR.
The excessive use of antibiotics has led to the rapid increase of resistant bacteria strains, requiring the discontinuation of antibiotics and the introduction of new drugs. The switch to new drugs slows down resistance, but only temporarily. Researchers have found that heterogeneity in the contact structure of the host population plays an important role in the reversion dynamics. Host contact structure affects both the phase of intense use of antibiotics and the phase after discontinuation of the drug. During intense use, heterogeneity in the contact structure results in a non-random distribution of resistant strains among the infected population, and this pattern persists even after discontinuation of the drug. The results of the study show that heterogeneity in the contact structure slows down the reversion to a sensitive population and reduces the probability of reversion occurring after treatment is stopped. The study highlights the importance of considering host contact structure in understanding the reversion dynamics of resistant strains.
The article explores the role of multiple genes in causing autism spectrum disorders (ASDs). ASDs are heritable conditions characterized by deficits in social interaction and communication, as well as restricted and repetitive behaviors. In the article, the authors describe how they used fruit flies to examine the effect of altering the dosage of unique human-fly orthologues of candidate genes that were found in individuals with ASDs. They also demonstrate that dosage changes in unique human-fly orthologues of candidate genes that were found in individuals with ASDs led to neurological defects similar to those previously reported in Drosophila models of ASD-associated variants. The authors also observed that pairwise dosage changes in orthologous pairs of candidate genes, drawn from the same single human de novo CNV, led to synergistic effects that contributed to neurological defects in Drosophila. This study shows that synergistic effects resulting from large structural variation can contribute to human diseases, such as autism spectrum disorders.
A study has looked at how certain T cells are involved in the development of a severe form of malaria called cerebral malaria. Researchers have found that these brain-infiltrating T cells accumulate within the perivascular spaces of the brain and have arrested behavior during the development of cerebral malaria. The researchers have also found that these brain-infiltrating T cells form cognitive interactions with certain immune cells in the brain, but this event is redundant for the development of cerebral malaria. The researchers have also found that these brain-infiltrating T cells do not cause apoptosis (cell death) in the brain, but extensive vascular leakage occurs during the development of cerebral malaria. Overall, the study suggests that the brain-infiltrating T cells mediate cerebral malaria via direct recognition of cognate antigen on target cells without the need for additional in situ secondary activation in the brain by professional antigen-presenting cells and without causing apoptosis.
Tungiasis is a parasitic disease caused by a tiny insect called Tunga penetrans, also known as jigger fleas. These fleas live on the skin of people and animals and can cause severe discomfort, pain, and disability. Tungiasis is most common in communities living in precarious conditions in tropical and sub-tropical countries. The study was conducted in 21 villages in western Kenya and involved examining 437 participants, 5 years old and above. The study found that the overall prevalence of tungiasis was 21.5%, and the highest prevalence was found in participants aged 14 years and below. The study also identified several factors that contribute to the occurrence of tungiasis, including low economic status, poor housing, lack of toilet facilities, and poor personal hygiene practices. The study highlights the need for further research and interventions to control and eliminate tungiasis in affected communities.
Auxin and cytokinin are two major plant hormones that interact in a negative way in several processes such as meristem maintenance, axillary branching and lateral root initiation. They also influence each other's synthesis, metabolism and signalling. Cytokinin has been shown to be an important regulator of auxin transport, which is crucial for the proper positioning of protoxylem cells in the Arabidopsis stele. This study investigates the auxin distribution and flux via the PIN transporters in the Arabidopsis root tip and explores the possible functional consequences. The authors use a parsimonious computational model of auxin transport, which takes into account cell shape, polarity and the presence of cell walls. They demonstrate that an informative spatial pattern in cytokinin levels is not necessary for correct and robust auxin patterning. Instead, auxin-dependent modifications of cytokinin response, rather than variations in cytokinin levels, are the mechanism for the necessary feedbacks, which can amplify and stabilise the auxin maximum. The model also reveals that pericycle cells on opposite xylem poles compete for auxin accumulation, consistent with the observation that lateral roots are not initiated opposite to each other.
In this study, researchers found that a protein called CREB-B is involved in the locust's behavioral plasticity. CREB-B is a type of transcription factor, which means it helps change the way that other genes are expressed in the brain. The researchers found that CREB-B is activated when the locust changes from being solitary to being in a group, and that it is regulated by a chemical called NPF2. They also found that another type of transcription factor called CREB-A is activated by a different chemical called NPF1a, and that it is responsible for the immediate change in locomotor activity. Overall, this study provides important information about the mechanisms involved in locust behavioral plasticity and how it can be regulated by different chemicals and proteins.
Researchers have found that the activation of the zygotic genome is delayed during the early stages of embryonic development in most organisms. In Drosophila melanogaster, the maternal-to-zygotic transition (MZT) occurs after the degradation of maternally provided RNAs and the initiation of widespread zygotic transcription. Several genes, including those involved in sex determination and pattern formation, are transcribed as early as cycle 8. The zinc-finger protein Zelda (ZLD) plays a key role in regulating the expression of these early genes. The researchers used chromatin immunoprecipitation coupled with high-throughput sequencing (ChIP-Seq) to map the genomic landscape of ZLD binding during the MZT. They found that ZLD binds to thousands of regions before the MZT, many of which remain bound through mitotic cycle 14. Some of the regions bound by ZLD in cycle 8 include the promoters of genes transcribed during this stage. Additionally, ZLD was found to be bound at cycle 8 to the promoters of roughly a thousand genes whose first transcription does not occur until the MZT. ZLD was also bound to virtually all known and presumed enhancers bound at cycle 14 by transcription factors that regulate patterned gene activation during the MZT. These results suggest that ZLD is not only required for the earliest wave of transcription but also plays a major role in activating the genome at the MZT.
A team of researchers has mapped protein-protein interactions (PPIs) among circadian clock proteins in a yeast-two-hybrid approach. They found 109 novel PPIs and validated a sub-fraction via co-immunoprecipitation experiments. They also predicted the interaction dynamics within their network in mouse liver cells. Genetic perturbation studies (RNAi and overexpression in oscillating cells) suggest a crucial role of dynamic regulation (via rhythmic PPIs) for the molecular clockwork. Systems analysis on a global scale regarding circadian regulation of biological processes via rhythmic PPIs suggests a time-of-day dependent organization of the interactome. The findings of this study provide a valuable resource of circadian PPIs within hepatocytes that are important for keeping the pace of the molecular clockwork and controlling cellular physiology.
Ascaris suum is a large intestinal roundworm that causes a serious infection in humans and animals. The worm produces a protein called ABA-1A, which is involved in transporting small lipids within the worm's tissues. The authors have used nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) technology to determine the three-dimensional structure of ABA-1A, which is a tandemly-repeating polyprotein. They have discovered that the protein has a novel seven-helical fold, with two discrete hydrophobic cavities that bind lipids. The authors believe that the identification of the structure and binding sites of ABA-1A will lead to a better understanding of the role of this protein in the infection caused by A. suum.
Ciguatera is a kind of fish poisoning that happens around the world, especially in places that are hot and have coral reefs. It can cause people to feel sick, sometimes very sick, for a long time. It is not easy to tell if someone has ciguatera, so it is often under-diagnosed and under-reported. A questionnaire was sent to officials in some Pacific Island countries to find out how common ciguatera is in those places. The results show that ciguatera is more common than we thought, and it is getting more common. This is a big problem that needs to be addressed. To solve this problem, we need to learn more about ciguatera and how it happens, so we can come up with ways to prevent it from happening.
Chagas disease is a life-threatening illness caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi . The disease can cause heart failure and can be difficult to treat with medication. The population of CD4+CD8+ T cells in people with chronic Chagas disease may play an important role in the body's response to the infection. However, it is not well understood how CD4+CD8+ T cells are affected by the disease or by treatment with benznidazole. This study aimed to learn more about the role of CD4+CD8+ T cells in chronic Chagas disease and how they respond to treatment with benznidazole. The study included 38 patients with chronic Chagas disease and 12 healthy controls. The researchers stimulated the cells with T. cruzi antigens to analyze the production of cytokines and cytotoxic molecules by CD4+CD8+ T cells. They also studied the expression and co-expression of inhibitory receptors in these patients after treatment. They found that the frequency of CD4+CD8+ T cells was higher in Chagas disease patients compared with healthy donors. Additionally, they found that the ratio of CD4+CD8low/CD4+CD8high subpopulations was higher in Chagas disease patients than in healthy donors. The researchers also found that CD4+CD8+ T cells from Chagas disease patients expressed and co-expressed higher levels of inhibitory receptors. After treatment with benznidazole, the frequency of CD4+CD8+ T cells was reduced and the ratio of CD4+CD8low/CD4+CD8high subpopulations was decreased. Additionally, the researchers found that the co-expression level of the inhibitory receptor was reduced after treatment simultaneously with an enhancement of the multifunctional capacity of CD4+CD8+ T cells. Finally, the researchers found an increase in the frequency of T. cruzi antigen-specific CD4+CD8+ T cells expressing IL-2 and TNF-α after treatment. Overall, the study suggests that CD4+CD8+ T cells could play an important role in the control of T. cruzi infection and that benznidazole treatment may reverse the exhaustion process in these cells.
The article describes the importance of phosphoinositides in plant growth and development, and the need to better understand the role of phosphoinositide-specific phospholipase C2 (AtPLC2) in these processes. The authors report that AtPLC2 is the primary phospholipase in phosphoinositide metabolism and is involved in seedling growth and the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress response in Arabidopsis thaliana. They used lipidomic profiling and heterologous expression to identify the function of AtPLC2 and found that it is involved in the production of phosphatidylinositol 4-phosphate and phosphatidylinositol 4 , 5-bisphosphate. These findings provide insight into the role of AtPLC2 in plant growth and development and the link between phosphoinositides and the ER stress response.
The reductionist approach in science assumes that the best way to understand a physical system is to look at it at its smallest scale. This is known as the micro level. However, this approach has been challenged by showing that cause-effect power can occur at the macro level, and that this power can be higher than the micro level. To do this, a measure of cause-effect power called integrated information (Φ) was developed, and it was shown that macro levels of organization have emergent properties that are not apparent at the micro level. This means that a macro level can "beat" the micro level in terms of cause-effect power. These results suggest that the reductionist approach may not always be the best way to understand a physical system.
Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are produced during energy production in mitochondria. These side products of electron transport can cause damage to cells in certain conditions. Scientists have been studying ROS production in the mitochondrial respiratory chain (RC), which is responsible for producing the majority of cellular energy. Electrons are transported through the RC in a process called electron transport, which is coupled to proton translocation and creates a transmembrane potential. However, the specific details of this process are not yet fully understood. Researchers have developed a mathematical model to study the complex interactions between different parts of the RC. They have been able to fit this model to data obtained from rat brain mitochondria, and to predict the conditions under which a state of high free radical content can occur. This new insight into the mechanisms of ROS production in the RC will be useful for understanding the causes of organ transplantation failure and certain systemic diseases.
Intracellular transport is an important function in cells, and is made possible by motor proteins that use energy to move cargo along microtubules. These proteins work in teams to transport cargo over long distances. Mutations in motor proteins can lead to neurodegenerative diseases such as Huntington's disease. In this article, researchers studied the effects of mutations on the transport properties of cargo carried by multiple wild-type and mutant motors. They found that mutants with altered stall forces might determine the average velocity and run-length, even when they are outnumbered by wild type motors in the ensemble. They also developed a semi-analytic method to analyze transport of cargo by multiple motors of multiple types, which can be used to model mutations in motor proteins and the effects of these mutations on the transport of a common cargo. This method can also be used to introduce alterations of various single motor parameters to model a mutation and to deduce effects of the mutation on the transport of a common cargo by multiple motors.
In the field of neuroscience, it is often believed that animals like humans learn by forming a connection between specific stimuli and their outcomes. This is known as stimulus-response learning. However, this may not be the case. Recent evidence suggests that animal learning may be a process of selecting and adapting behavioral policies. Calcium influx through high-voltage-gated calcium channels plays a crucial role in synaptic plasticity, and mutations in the CACNA1C gene have been associated with severe learning deficits and psychiatric disorders. To understand how learning is affected in these cases, researchers studied learning in terms of behavioral strategies using a selective functional ablation of the Cacna1c gene. They found that the majority of Cacna1c knockout mice still managed to increase reward feedback across trials but did so by adapting an outcome-based strategy. In contrast, the majority of matched controls adopted the experimentally intended cue-association rule. This highlights the importance of studying behavioral strategies in order to gain a better understanding of learning processes and the underlying mechanisms. The results may also have implications for treating psychiatric disorders.
Scientists are trying to control mosquito-borne diseases by using bacteria called Wolbachia to make Aedes aegypti mosquitoes less likely to carry and spread viruses. The scientists have found that the Wolbachia infection wMel, which was introduced into mosquitoes from Drosophila melanogaster, is the best option for invasion and persistence, but it may have some fitness costs. They have also found that the Wolbachia infection wMelPop-CLA, which was also introduced from Drosophila melanogaster, is good for population suppression but may have high fitness costs. Other Wolbachia infections have different effects and are better suited to different environments. The scientists have also found that temperature affects the reproductive effects of Wolbachia infections in Aedes aegypti mosquitoes, and that the optimal temperature for Wolbachia reproductive effects is not yet known.
The article describes a study done on adenoviruses, which are a group of viruses that cause infections in humans. The study found that chimpanzees, bonobos, gorillas, orangutans, and macaques shed large amounts of adenoviruses in their stool. This is different from what was seen in humans, where adenovirus shedding in stool was much less common. The researchers also found that the adenoviruses from apes were related to three different types of human adenoviruses. This suggests that these adenoviruses could be used as vectors for genetic vaccines or gene therapy in humans. However, the researchers caution that handling and housing of primates should be done carefully because of the high level of adenovirus shedding in their stool.
The nucleosome is the basic unit of chromatin in eukaryotic cells. It consists of a core of histone proteins and DNA. The DNA in a nucleosome is wound around the histone core like a rope around a pole. To function properly in the cell, this DNA needs to be unwrapped. Scientists used computer simulations to calculate the energy needed to unwrap the outer turn of the DNA in a nucleosome. They found that it takes about 11.5 kcal/mol to unwrap the outer turn. They also found that the unwrapping happens in an asymmetric way, meaning that one end of the DNA unwraps more than the other end. This unwrapping happens in a stepwise fashion, with about 5 base pairs unwrapping at a time. These findings provide insight into how nucleosomes function and how they are involved in processes such as gene expression and DNA repair.
The article describes the role of a protein called ApoD in protecting cells from oxidative stress. Oxidative stress can damage the membrane of lysosomes, which are important organelles in the cell that help break down waste and damaged cellular material. ApoD is a protein that binds to lipids and is found in the blood. It is also over-expressed in the aging brain and in neurodegenerative diseases. The authors found that ApoD is endocytosed and targeted to a subset of vulnerable lysosomes in a stress-dependent manner. Once inside the lysosome, ApoD is able to help maintain lysosomal pH gradients and prevent lysosomal membrane permeabilization. This helps to protect the cell from oxidative stress. Additionally, the authors found that ApoD is necessary for two lysosomal-dependent processes, such as myelin phagocytosis and optimization of autophagy. The authors conclude that ApoD is a previously unknown but important regulator of lysosomal membrane integrity, which has wide-ranging implications for many diseases.
In a recent study, researchers investigated the life cycle and susceptibility of Phlebotomus orientalis sand flies to Leishmania donovani, the parasite that causes visceral leishmaniasis (VL). They found that the two colonies of P. orientalis originated from different sites in Ethiopia had distinct life-cycle requirements and genetic makeup, but were able to produce viable hybrids. They also found that both colonies were highly susceptible to infection with L. donovani, and that the infective dose was as low as one or two promastigotes per blood-meal. The results of this study provide important information about the life cycle and susceptibility of P. orientalis sand flies to VL, which can help improve the management of the disease in the region.
The paper is about a study that aimed to estimate the disability weight (DW) of advanced schistosomiasis japonica, a serious health condition caused by infection with a type of tapeworm. The study used a patient-based evaluation and the EQ-5D plus questionnaire to assess the health status and DW of patients with advanced schistosomiasis japonica in China. The results showed that the overall DW for advanced schistosomiasis japonica was 0.447 and that age-specific DWs ranged from 0.378 among individuals aged 30-44 years to 0.510 among the elderly aged ≥60 years. The study also found that the DW of advanced schistosomiasis japonica was positively associated with certain factors, such as loss of work capacity, psychological abnormality, ascites, and active hepatitis B virus, while splenectomy and high albumin were protective factors for quality of life. These patient-preference disability estimates could provide updated data for a revision of the global burden of disease, as well as for evidence-based decision-making in China's national schistosomiasis control program.
Human African Trypanosomiasis (HAT) and Animal African Trypanosomiasis (AAT) are both highly prevalent in Africa. HAT is caused by a parasite called Trypanosoma brucei and is transmitted by tsetse fly bites. AAT is also caused by trypanosomes and is transmitted by tsetse fly bites. The parasites that cause AAT also cause disease in livestock, leading to decreased agricultural production, poverty, and nutritional deficiencies. The impact of both HAT and AAT on human health occurs through two exposure pathways: directly from the bite of a pathogenic tsetse fly resulting in HAT infection or indirectly, as the potential for AAT takes land out of agricultural production and diseased livestock leads to livestock morbidity and mortality, contributing to poverty and nutritional deficiencies. This study analyzed data from a national census in Kenya in 1999 to estimate population vulnerability and disability in Kenya's 7 tsetse belts where tsetse vectors for T . b . rhodesiense and other trypanosoma agents that cause AAT were present. It used a multilevel study design to estimate the likelihood of disability in individuals, nested within households, nested within tsetse fly habitats of varying levels of poverty. It found that residents and recent migrants of working age living in tsetse belts had a higher likelihood of disability than those living outside of tsetse belts, regardless of poverty levels. The study also found that residents had a higher likelihood of disability than migrants, likely due to increased duration of direct and indirect exposure to tsetse flies and poverty. Gender differences were also found, with women having a higher likelihood of disability than men. Housing type also appeared to vary vulnerability to disability in tsetse-endemic environments. This study suggests that national census data can be used as a tool to estimate population vulnerability and disability within and across tsetse belt regions as a potential indicator of HAT-acquired infection.
The article discusses the role of a drug called hexamethylene bisacetamide (HMBA) in inducing the production of HIV viral particles in chronically infected cells. The article suggests that HMBA activates a pathway called the PI3K/Akt pathway, which leads to the phosphorylation of a protein called HEXIM1 and the release of another protein called P-TEFb from a complex with HEXIM1 and 7SK snRNA. This results in the recruitment of P-TEFb to the HIV promoter, where it stimulates the elongation of viral transcription. Despite the continued presence of HMBA, the released P-TEFb quickly reassembles with 7SK snRNA and HEXIM1. The article also mentions that a mutant version of HEXIM1 that cannot be phosphorylated by Akt prevents the HMBA-mediated induction of viral production.
Leishmaniasis is a disease caused by parasites that spread through the bite of infected sand flies. The parasites can lead to different types of leishmaniasis, including mucosal and disseminated cutaneous leishmaniasis, which are more severe forms of the disease. In these forms, parasites spread to multiple parts of the body and cause severe inflammation and tissue damage. A recent study found that a virus found in some strains of Leishmania, a parasite responsible for leishmaniasis, is responsible for the more severe forms of the disease. The study used various techniques to detect the virus, including using an anti-dsRNA monoclonal antibody and nucleic acid purification. These techniques were tested on different parasite strains and found to be effective in detecting the virus. The study proposes that these techniques could be used as diagnostic tools in the field to predict the risk of developing more severe forms of leishmaniasis.
Enteropathogenic and enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli ( EPEC and EHEC ) are closely related pathogens that attach tightly to intestinal epithelial cells and trigger the formation of actin pedestals, which are structures that help bacteria to move across the surface of cells and invade the intestinal lining. In this study, researchers used a combination of genetic and cellular techniques to investigate the role of these pedestals in infection and colonization. They found that EPEC and EHEC both formed distinct communities of bacteria called macrocolonies, which encompassed multiple host cells. Tir and EspFU, two key proteins involved in pedestal formation, were required for the expansion of these macrocolonies over time. Unexpectedly, EspFU accelerated the formation of larger macrocolonies compared to EPEC Tir, as EspFU-mediated actin assembly drove faster bacterial motility to cell junctions. This study revealed that EspFU enhances epithelial colonization by increasing actin-based motility and promoting an efficient method of cell-to-cell transmission.
This article describes how to properly isolate extracellular vesicles (EVs) from the excretory-secretory products of Fasciola hepatica, a liver fluke that causes a major neglected zoonotic disease in humans and ruminant species worldwide. There is currently no gold standard for EV isolation, but the most widely used method for helminth pathogens is differential centrifugation (DC). However, size exclusion chromatography (SEC) has been used to purify EVs from other pathogens and there is no evidence that DC is the best method for purifying EVs from helminth pathogens. In this study, the authors compared DC and SEC EV purification methods for F. hepatica EVs. They found that SEC produced smaller, more homogeneous EVs that had a higher purity and lower contamination from free excretory-secretory products (ESP). They also found that SEC EVs had different protein and gene enrichment profiles compared to DC EVs. Overall, the authors recommend using SEC for EV isolation for helminth pathogens, as it produces high-quality EVs that can be used for further research and development.
In this study, we investigate the importance of post-transcriptional regulation in early development using the Drosophila melanogaster embryo as a model system. We analyze the dynamics of gap gene expression using reverse engineering to fit a model to quantitative data. We find that post-transcriptional regulation is not required for the correct timing and positioning of gap protein domain boundaries. However, it may play a role in controlling accurate protein levels, possibly through changes in translational efficiency and protein stability.
Rotavirus causes diarrhea in children and is shed by the body after recovery. Neonatal mice are highly susceptible to rotavirus infection and exhibit severe symptoms, whereas adult mice remain asymptomatic and shed low amounts of virus. To understand why adult mice are not susceptible to rotavirus infection, we investigated the role of the innate immune system in neonatal and adult mice. We found that Toll-like receptor (TLR) 3 expression is low in the intestinal epithelium of neonatal mice but strongly increases during the postnatal period, which correlates with increased susceptibility to rotavirus infection. In contrast, TLR3 expression is low in adult mice. We also found that adult mice deficient in TLR3 or TIR domain containing adaptor inducing interferon-β (Trif) had significantly higher viral shedding and decreased epithelial expression of proinflammatory and antiviral genes as compared to wild-type animals. In contrast, neonatal mice deficient in TLR3 or Trif did not display impaired cell stimulation or enhanced rotavirus susceptibility. Using chimeric mice, we found that the Trif-mediated antiviral host response was detected in the non-hematopoietic cell compartment in adult animals. Finally, we also found a significant increase in TLR3 expression during infancy in human small intestinal biopsies. These results suggest that the upregulation of TLR3 expression in the intestinal epithelium of infants might contribute to their susceptibility to rotavirus infection.
This paper reports the results of a study that used whole-exome sequencing to look for genetic variants associated with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). The study sequenced 1,039 people with ASD and 870 controls with similar ancestry. The study found that rare genetic variants were distributed similarly in both sets of samples, indicating that the data from the two different sequencing centers could be combined. The study then used different methods to analyze the combined data for associations with ASD. It found that combining the data before analyzing it (mega-analysis) was more powerful than combining the results of the different analysis methods (meta-analysis). The study also found that using principal components analysis to control for ancestry in the combined data was effective in reducing bias. Overall, the study did not find any clear-cut genetic associations with ASD.
Mycetoma is a disease that affects the skin and underlying tissue, and it causes nodules and sinuses that release pus. It can be caused by bacteria or fungi, and the fungus Madurella mycetomatis is the most common cause in Sudan. The study aimed to investigate if polymorphisms in two chitinase genes are associated with eumycetoma caused by M. mycetomatis. The study found that one polymorphism in the chitotriosidase gene, resulting in decreased chitotriosidase activity, was associated with an increased risk of eumycetoma. No associations were found between the polymorphisms in the AMCase gene and eumycetoma risk. Chitin is a major component of the cell walls of fungi, and chitinases are part of the immune system and play a role in fighting fungal infections. The study suggests that decreased chitinase activity may increase the risk of eumycetoma, but further research is needed to confirm this.
Herpes simplex virus ( HSV ) is a virus that has the ability to stay dormant or latent in the body for a long time. During this time, the virus is not actively spreading, but it is still alive and can potentially reactivate at any time. However, a new study challenges the idea that HSV latency is clearly defined. The study found that around half of the spread of the virus leading to latent infections happened after the initial infection, which means that the virus was still actively spreading even after it had entered the latent phase. In addition, the study also found that proteins from the lytic phase of the virus, when it is actively spreading, can be produced even during the latent phase. This means that the virus is not completely dormant during latency, but it is still able to produce proteins that could potentially harm the host. The study used a highly sensitive mouse model to make these findings, and the results challenge our understanding of how viruses behave during latency.
Prion diseases are a group of fatal brain diseases that affect both humans and animals. They are caused by the misfolding of a protein called PrP, which leads to the formation of abnormal, protease-resistant isoforms of PrP called PrPSc. PrPSc is responsible for the spread of the disease within the brain and other organs. In this study, the authors examined the cell specificity of PrPSc accumulation in mice infected with three different scrapie strains. They found that each strain had a different pattern of cell specificity, with one strain mainly associated with astroglia, another with neurons, and the third with both. Despite the differences in cell specificity, the authors found that all three strains had similar patterns of upregulated genes associated with neuroinflammation. Interestingly, the pattern of gene upregulation in scrapie differed markedly from the pattern seen in two acute viral CNS diseases. This study provides valuable insights into the mechanisms of prion diseases and may lead to new therapeutic approaches.
