The physical organization of chromosomes inside the cell nucleus plays an important role in regulating gene expression. Chromosomes are long and densely packed, which makes it difficult to study their folding and dynamics. We have proposed a generic strategy to develop efficient coarse-grained models for self-avoiding polymers, which allows us to investigate the structural and dynamical properties of chromosomes more efficiently. We have used our strategy to study the 3D organization of chromosome 3R in drosophila during one cell cycle, and our results show that a combination of our coarse-graining strategy with a one-parameter block copolymer model integrating epigenomic-driven interactions quantitatively reproduces experimental data at the chromosome-scale and predicts that chromatin motion is very dynamic during the cell cycle. Our work provides a systematic way to define reliable coarse-grained null models for chromosomes and paves the way for studying the folding and dynamics of long chromosomes during an extended time period with good statistics.
Gene expression is controlled by regulatory proteins, RNAs, and cis-regulatory elements with which they interact. These cis-regulatory elements can be located near the gene they regulate, or far away from it. Genetic variants within cis-regulatory elements can affect gene expression in a cell type specific manner. These variants are referred to as expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs). They are common and exist in both cis and trans (over long genetic distances). Many of the genetic associations found in genome-wide association studies (GWAS) are with non-coding single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), making their mechanistic interpretation more challenging. However, it is known that regulatory SNPs have causal roles in many complex human phenotypes. This is supported by the fact that GWAS associations are enriched within DNase I hypersensitive sites and eQTL SNPs. Although eQTLs are increasingly used to provide mechanistic interpretations for human disease associations, the cell type specificity of eQTLs presents a problem. To address this need, we performed an eQTL analysis in three parts. First, we identified eQTLs from eleven studies on seven cell types. Then, we integrated eQTL data with cis-regulatory element (CRE) data from the ENCODE project. Finally, we built a set of classifiers to predict the cell type specificity of eQTLs. We demonstrated the feasibility of predicting the cell type specificity of eQTLs using cell-specific CRE-SNP overlap as features. We also demonstrated that CREs from a trait-associated cell type can be used to annotate GWAS associations in the absence of eQTL data for that cell type. We anticipate that such integrative, predictive modeling of cell specificity will improve our ability to understand the mechanistic basis of human complex phenotypic variation.
The authors have developed a new cell line that can produce human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) vaccine immunogens that limit the incorporation of sialic acid into the vaccine proteins. Sialic acid is a type of carbohydrate that can interfere with the binding of certain monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) to the vaccine proteins. The new cell line was created using the CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing system and contains a mutation that inactivates the gene encoding Mannosyl (Alpha-1 , 3- ) -Glycoprotein Beta-1 , 2-N-Acetylglucosaminyltransferase (MGAT1), which is responsible for adding sialic acid to the vaccine proteins. The authors tested the vaccine proteins produced in the new cell line and found that they bound better to certain mAbs than the vaccine proteins produced in normal cells. The authors also found that the new cell line was able to grow at high densities and produce the vaccine proteins at large scales, making it useful for manufacturing HIV-1 vaccines. The authors concluded that the new cell line they created was a useful tool for producing HIV-1 vaccine immunogens that were better able to bind to certain mAbs.
Parasitic nematodes cause devastating diseases in many parts of the world. These diseases are caused by species of the genus Brugia and Wuchereria bancrofti. Trehalose-6-phosphate phosphatase (T6PP) is an enzyme required for the survival of these nematodes. In humans, the equivalent enzyme is not present, making T6PP a promising target for therapeutic inhibitors. The structure of T6PP from Brugia malayi has been determined, and it has been found to have a stabilizing N-terminal MIT-like domain and a catalytic C-terminal C2B-type HAD phosphatase fold. Structure-guided mutagenesis and kinetic analyses using a designed competitive inhibitor, trehalose 6-sulfate, have identified five residues important for binding and catalysis. This study provides the basis for the development of broad-range anthelmintic and antibacterial therapeutics.
The study presents a novel computational framework to simulate blood flow and interstitial fluid transport in tumours. The framework incorporates whole tumor microvascular networks extracted ex vivo to generate accurate predictions of tumor fluid dynamics. The study details the application of the framework to an orthotopic murine glioma and a human colorectal carcinoma xenograft. The framework enables highly-controlled experiments to be performed that provide insight into how tumor vascular heterogeneity contributes to tumor fluid transport. The study also performs sensitivity analysis to gain an understanding of the key biological mechanisms that determine tumor fluid transport. The framework incorporates spatially heterogeneous blood vessel lumen and interstitial permeabilities to generate accurate predictions of tumor fluid dynamics. The study mimics vascular normalization by modifying parameters such as vascular and interstitial permeabilities. The study hypothesizes that normalizing the interstitial microenvironment may provide a more effective means to increase interstitial perfusion within tumors.
HIV spreads efficiently from infected to non-infected cells through cell-cell contacts. However, it is unclear whether cell-cell transmission is equally important in human infection. Neutralizing antibodies can inhibit HIV infection by blocking attachment to receptors or preventing membrane fusion. It is also unclear how much the enclosed environment of the viral synapse protects the virus from neutralizing antibodies. The study used specially tailored experiments to distinguish between cell-cell and cell-free virus transmission modes. The results showed that CD4 binding site-directed neutralizing antibodies, such as VRC01, lost potency during cell-cell transmission. This suggests that these antibodies act preferentially by blocking free virus transmission. The study provides important insights for vaccine and entry inhibitor design.
The paper proposes a simple model that explains how attention can affect neural responses in the visual system. Attention can cause response rate changes (response gain, input gain, and biased competition) and receptive field changes (shifts and resizing), which occur at higher levels of the visual system. The model requires the existence of modulatory feedback connections between areas and short-range lateral inhibition within each area. Feedback connections redistribute the top-down modulation to lower areas, altering the inputs of other higher-area cells. Simultaneously, short-range lateral inhibition produces competitive effects automatically scaled to receptive field size. The model can explain all effects of visual attention, such as response rate changes and receptive field changes. The model also makes a novel prediction: attentional effects on response curves should shift from response gain to contrast gain as the focus of attention shifts away from the center of the studied cell’s receptive field.
Drosophila's immune system is controlled by a signaling center called the PSC, which regulates the production of immune cells. In this study, researchers identified a gene called CG14225/Latran that is involved in controlling the PSC. They found that CG14225/Latran forms heteromers with another gene called Dome and that these heteromers have the opposite function of Dome. When CG14225/Latran is not present, Dome is able to signal, which leads to the production of immune cells. However, when CG14225/Latran is present, it binds to Dome and prevents it from signaling. This is important because it shows that the immune response is regulated by a complex interplay of different genes, and it provides a new understanding of how the immune system works.
Begomoviruses are a type of virus that can change their genetic material through a process called recombination, which is the process by which two or more different types of genetic material combine to make a new type. This can happen when the same virus infects a plant at the same time, or when two different viruses infect the same plant. The study looks at how recombination happens within begomoviruses, and how it can disrupt interactions between different parts of the virus genome. By looking at patterns of recombination in different viruses, the researchers were able to understand more about how viruses change over time and how they can adapt to different environments.
The relationship between nucleosomes, DNA sequence, and evolution has been studied in humans and other eukaryotes, revealing biases in mutation and selection that may be correlated with nucleosome positioning. However, the assumption that experimentally determined nucleosome positions reflect ancestral positions and thus inform us about the chromatin context in which substitutions occurred may be incorrect. Here, we investigate if nucleosomes are repositioned following a change at the sequence level, and how this could affect the observed relationship between nucleosome positioning and sequence evolution. We compare substitution patterns around nucleosome footprints in humans to substitution dynamics in Haloferax volcanii, a haloarchaeon with nucleosome-like structures that differ from those in eukaryotes. We found that nucleosome-associated substitution patterns in both humans and Haloferax volcanii are remarkably similar, despite the differences in nucleosome structure and global nucleotide substitution profiles. We conclude that these dyad-oriented trends break down in the respective sister lineages, suggesting that the causal link between genetic and epigenetic change must be considered when assessing selection and mutation biases in the context of chromatin architecture.
The study explores the conformational diversity of proteins and its relationship to ligand-binding. The authors find that key positions involved in ligand-binding are evolutionarily conserved, mostly buried aliphatic residues located in regular structural regions of the protein like β-sheets and α-helix. The authors propose a novel procedure to identify these key positions based on the effect of mutations on subspaces defined by normal modes most involved in the conformational change. These normal modes are selected according to their corresponding overlap with structural distortions introduced by ligand binding. By analyzing the effect of simulated point mutations on preserving the conformational diversity of the protein, the authors identify critical sites for protein function. These sites are evolutionary conserved and play an important role in ligand-binding. The study suggests that normal modes subspaces associated to ligand-binding can provide valuable information for understanding the relationship between protein structure, function, and evolution.
Metabolic pathways used by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) to establish and maintain infections are important for our understanding of pathogenesis and the development of new chemotherapies. In this study, the authors investigated the role of fructose-1,6-bisphosphate aldolase (FBA), which is central to glycolysis and gluconeogenesis. They created a strain of Mtb in which FBA levels were regulated by anhydrotetracycline. Depletion of FBA resulted in clearance of Mtb in both the acute and chronic phases of infection in vivo, and loss of viability in vitro when cultured on single carbon sources. They found that Mtb's ability to adapt to multiple environments may in part be attributed to its metabolic flexibility and its capacity to efficiently catabolize multiple carbon sources simultaneously. The authors further found that FBA was an essential enzyme for both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis and that Mtb relied on FBA for both growth during acute and persistence during chronic mouse infections. The study highlights the importance of FBA as a potential drug target in both replicating and persistent Mtb.
The paper presents a study of the function of a type of protein called 2-cysteine peroxiredoxin (2-Cys PRX) in a parasitic protozoan called Leishmania infantum. These proteins are thought to have a function in reducing peroxides, which are harmful molecules produced in cells, but there is also some evidence that they can regulate signaling pathways in cells. The study used a strain of L. infantum that lacks the 2-Cys PRX gene, which was generated by a gene replacement strategy. It showed that these mutants were not able to survive in a mouse model of infection and that this was not due to their lack of 2-Cys PRX peroxidase activity. The study also showed that mTXNPx can have a function as a molecular chaperone. The study is important because it provides evidence that 2-Cys PRXs can have functions in parasites that are independent of their peroxidase activity.
Histoplasmosis is a fungal disease that affects many parts of Latin America, including Mexico. The standard way to diagnose the disease is to find the fungus in a sample such as bone marrow or blood. However, this method can take a long time and requires special safety equipment. In the US, doctors can use a test that detects antigens in the urine of patients. In 2007, a new version of this test called ALPHA-HUAg was approved for clinical use and allowed doctors to use it on-site, which is useful in regions outside the US. However, this version of the test is not as accurate as the original test. We did a study to see how well the ALPHA-HUAg test works to diagnose progressive disseminated histoplasmosis, a serious form of the disease that affects HIV-infected patients. We did this study at 10 hospitals in Mexico, including 2 that were considered tertiary care and 8 that were considered secondary care. We included 288 HIV-infected patients who had symptoms that could be due to progressive disseminated histoplasmosis. We compared the results of the ALPHA-HUAg test to the results of a more accurate reference standard, which was to find the fungus in a sample such as bone marrow or blood, or through a histopathology exam. We found that the ALPHA-HUAg test had a sensitivity of 67.1% and a specificity of 97.5%. This means that the test correctly identified 67.1% of the patients who had progressive disseminated histoplasmosis, but it incorrectly identified 2.5% of the patients who did not have the disease. The positive likelihood ratio was 27.2, which means that if a patient tested positive, they had a 27.2 times greater chance of having progressive disseminated histoplasmosis than they did of not having the disease. However, we found that 10.5% of the patients who had progressive disseminated histoplasmosis also had a co-existing opportunistic infection, mostly disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex infection. This means that a negative ALPHA-HUAg result does not rule out progressive disseminated histoplasmosis and a culture-based approach is necessary since co-infections are frequent and a negative IMMY-HUAg result does not rule out PDH.
The study used metagenomic sequencing to analyze the viral communities present in diarrhea specimens from 12 children. The method used minimal sample quantity, limited sequencing, and no purification of the samples. The study found evidence for the detection of known enteric viruses, viral co-infections, and novel viruses.
The Zika virus, which can cause birth defects, is a mosquito-borne disease that has been spreading rapidly in the Caribbean and South America. The Dominican Republic is no exception. In 2015, the country experienced a large dengue epidemic, and then in 2016, cases of Zika began to appear. Researchers wanted to learn more about the spread of both diseases in the Dominican Republic and to understand the risk factors for transmission. They analyzed data from the country's disease surveillance system to look at the age and sex distribution of both Zika and dengue cases, and to calculate the reproductive number (R0) of each outbreak.
Poly (ADP-ribose) polymerases (PARPs) are proteins that transfer poly (ADP-ribose) units onto target proteins. This process is important in a variety of cellular processes, including DNA repair. In humans, the PARP1 protein accounts for more than 90% of overall cellular PARP activity in response to DNA damage. In Arabidopsis, however, it appears that PARP2 makes the greatest contribution to PARP activity and organismal viability in response to genotoxic stresses. PARP2 also makes a stronger contribution to plant immune responses, including restriction of pathogenic Pseudomonas syringae pv. tomato growth and reduction of infection-associated DNA double-strand break abundance. Poly (ADP-ribose) glycohydrolase (PARG) enzymes are responsible for removing poly (ADP-ribose) from acceptor proteins. In humans, there is one PARG gene. However, in Arabidopsis, there are two PARG genes: PARG1 and PARG2. It appears that PARG1 rather than PARG2 is the primary enzyme that counteracts poly (ADP-ribosyl) ation in Arabidopsis. PARP1 associates with PARP2, and both proteins interact with both PARG1 and PARG2. These findings suggest that PARP and PARG proteins play important roles in plant DNA damage and immune responses.
The PHR proteins, called RPM-1 in C. elegans, are important signaling hubs that help regulate the formation of synapses and the termination of axons. In the nematode C. elegans, the PHR proteins, including RPM-1, have been found to help regulate habituation to repeated touch stimuli. By using suppressor genetics, the authors of this study have identified a new JNK pathway that is involved in regulating synapse formation in mechanosensory neurons of C. elegans. This pathway includes several kinases, including MIG-15, NSY-1, JKK-1, and JNK-1, and is distinct from the pathway that RPM-1 typically regulates. The authors found that loss of function mutations in these kinases specifically suppress defects in synapse formation in the mechanosensory neurons of rpm-1 mutants. Additionally, transgenic overexpression of kinases in this pathway in wild-type animals led to impaired synapse formation. The study provides new insights into the role of JNK signaling in synapse formation and habituation to touch stimuli in the nematode C. elegans.
The paper investigates a protein called TRA-1 in the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans, which controls whether the animal develops as a male or a hermaphrodite. TRA-1 is a "bipotential" protein, meaning that it can activate or repress the same gene depending on the context. The paper confirms that TRA-1 is bipotential by showing that it can both promote and repress the expression of a gene called fog-3 in germ cells, and also by testing for epistasis with another gene called TRR-1. The paper also shows that TRR-1 is a co-factor of TRA-1 that works to promote the expression of fog-3. The paper compares the role of TRA-1 in C. elegans with its role in a related species, C. briggsae, and finds that although TRA-1 has the same basic functions in both species, the two species use different mechanisms to regulate its activity. The paper suggests that this difference in regulation may have evolved to compensate for changes in the relationship between TRA-1 and other genes that control sex determination. The paper concludes by suggesting that the structure of a bipotential switch, like TRA-1, can change rapidly during evolution, and that these changes can affect the way that a binary switch controls an important biological process like sex determination.
The paper introduces two new measures of 'integrated information' that can be used to measure the complexity of a system's dynamics. The first measure is called 'integrated information' and is used for discrete Markov systems, while the second measure, called 'empirical integrated information', is used for continuous systems. The authors use simulations to demonstrate the practical applicability of these measures and explore their properties. They also propose a new measure of 'auto-regressive integrated information' that can be used for non-Gaussian systems. The authors argue that these new measures offer new opportunities for studying the dynamics of real and model systems, as well as for exploring the relationship between integrated information, consciousness, and other neurocognitive processes.
Sleeping sickness is a disease caused by parasites that are spread by tsetse flies. There are two types of sleeping sickness in Uganda: Rhodesian and Gambian. Rhodesian sleeping sickness has been spreading in Uganda over the past few decades. Recent research has tried to understand why this disease is spreading by looking at social, environmental, and climatic factors that may be causing the spread. The current study used statistical methods to analyze data from the past few years in Uganda. The results show that the movement of livestock may have contributed to the spread of Rhodesian sleeping sickness in certain areas. The study also confirmed the effects of other factors on the spread of the disease, such as the distance to a health center and the amount of green vegetation in a particular area. Overall, the study provides important insights into how Rhodesian sleeping sickness is spreading in Uganda, and how different factors may be affecting this spread.
The paper explores the relationship between complexity and stability in ecological systems. The "consensus that complexity begets stability" was challenged in the 1970s, and the authors of this paper provide new analytical results and simulations that show that equilibrium feasibility vanishes in species-rich systems. They also found that stability and feasibility are warranted irrespective of species richness with weak interactions. Furthermore, they found that the dynamical behaviour of ecologically-inspired architectures is very different and richer than that of unstructured systems. The authors conclude that a general understanding of ecosystem dynamics requires focusing on the interplay between interaction strength and network architecture.
The bacterium Coxiella burnetii causes a disease called Q fever, which affects both animals and humans. The bacteria can be found in many parts of the world, with a near-global distribution. There is a lack of understanding about the prevalence of C. burnetii in Africa, which is why this research was conducted in parts of Western and Nyanza Provinces, Western Kenya. A cross-sectional survey was conducted where blood samples were taken from 2049 humans and 955 cattle in 416 households. Questionnaires were also administered to collect information on demographic, socio-economic, and husbandry information. Environmental data, such as land cover, were also linked to the survey results. Correlation and spatial-cross correlation analyses were used to examine the potential link between cattle and human seroprevalence. Multilevel regression analysis was used to examine the relationships between a range of socio-economic, demographic, and environmental factors and sero-positivity in both humans and animals. The results showed that the overall sero-prevalence of C. burnetii was 2.5% in humans and 10.5% in cattle. However, there was no evidence of correlation between cattle and human seroprevalence, either within households or when incorporating spatial proximity to other households in the survey. The research also identified several factors that were important for exposure to C. burnetii, including purchasing cattle from market, lower precipitation levels, younger age group, variations between ethnic groups, and frequent livestock contact. The implication of livestock markets in cattle exposure risks suggests these may be a suitable target for interventions.
In this paper, researchers identified three genes that are similar to vasa, which is a marker of germ cells, in the genome of the schistosome worm (S. mansoni). These vasa-like genes are expressed in different stages of the schistosome life cycle, with the highest expression in the undeveloped egg. The researchers believe that this information could be used to monitor transgenesis in the schistosome germ line, which is an important step towards developing new treatments for schistosomiasis.
Heart valves are critical for the correct flow of blood in the heart. They develop from cells that go through a special process called endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition. This process involves a lot of cell proliferation and the formation of structures called cushions. The Hippo pathway is important for organ development and tissue homeostasis. VGLL4 is a protein that is important for this process. It is mainly expressed in cells that form cushions. Deleting VGLL4 in the cells that make cushions results in problems with the development of the valves. This happens because YAP, a protein that is important for cell proliferation, is not controlled properly. If you partially delete YAP in the heart, the problems with the valves can be fixed. These findings suggest that VGLL4 is important for the development and maintenance of heart valves and that controlling the activity of YAP could be a potential therapy for preventing problems with heart valves.
In this study, researchers examine the use of "soft selective sweeps" in explaining the patterns of genetic variation observed in natural populations. A soft sweep is a scenario where a beneficial mutation reaches high frequency in a population, but not to fixation. There are two main models of soft sweeps: selection on standing variation, where a beneficial mutation is already present in the population at appreciable frequency, and multiple de novo beneficial mutations, where multiple copies of the same beneficial mutation arise in the population. However, researchers argue that the evidence for the existence of soft sweeps is not strong. They note that many of the patterns of variation that are predicted by soft sweeps models are also predicted by other, simpler models of population genetics. They argue that most of the evidence for soft sweeps is likely due to false positives or a failure to account for other factors affecting genetic variation, such as demographic history. Overall, the study suggests that the concept of soft sweeps is overused and misinterpreted in the literature, and that a better understanding of the underlying population genetics is needed to accurately identify instances of positive selection.
This study aimed to identify the receptor responsible for a humoral factor that suppresses host-seeking behavior in female mosquitoes after they have fed on blood. The humoral factor is called Head Peptide-I and it has been shown to be involved in this inhibition. The study used a calcium imaging assay to screen for receptors that respond to Head Peptide-I. The study found that the receptor NPYLR1 was a candidate for the sNPF neuropeptides that are sensitive to Head Peptide-I. However, mutant mosquitoes with NPYLR1 removed did not show any changes in feeding or inhibition of host-seeking behavior, so it is likely that there are other signaling mechanisms involved in this important behavioral regulation.
Schistosomiasis is a parasitic disease that is spread by water and can cause serious health problems. This study aimed to identify areas with suitable conditions for schistosomiasis transmission using satellite imagery and spatial analysis for Akure North Local Government Area in Ondo State, Nigeria. The study used a multi-criteria evaluation method to determine the weight of each individual schistosomiasis risk factor, including temperature, drainage, elevation, rainfall, slope, and land use/land cover. The weighted overlay analysis was done after each factor was given its appropriate weight. The results showed that 82% of the area fell under the high and very high risk category, with one community having the lowest risk and four other communities having varying levels of risk. The study found that environmental factors can be used in identifying and predicting the transmission of schistosomiasis, as well as effective monitoring of disease risk in newly established rural and agricultural communities.
The article discusses the effects of bacterial meningitis on the brain, specifically the loss of synapses in the superficial layers of the frontal neocortex. This is particularly seen in patients with pneumococcal meningitis and mice with pneumococcal meningitis who express the pore-forming cholesterol-dependent cytolysin pneumolysin. The article also highlights the role of the NMDA glutamate receptor antagonists MK801 and D-AP5 in reducing this pathology. Additionally, the article shows that pneumolysin increases glutamate levels in the brain and that it induces excitotoxic damage by dysregulating the control of glutamate in the brain.
Human papillomavirus (HPV) infections are associated with many types of cancer, including cervical, head, and neck cancers. HPV has a complex life cycle that is closely linked to the differentiation of the host epithelial cells. In order to fully understand this life cycle, researchers have developed new methods to create infectious particles of HPV. Using these particles and infecting human keratinocytes, the researchers found that cell cycle progression through early stages of mitosis is critical for successful HPV infection. These findings reveal new insights into the mechanism by which HPV infects cells and provide one reason why HPV infects only undifferentiated, proliferating cells. These results also provide new leads for developing preventive and therapeutic strategies against HPV infection.
We looked for microRNAs (miRNAs) in the fungus Penicillium marneffei, which causes a respiratory disease called talaromycosis. MiRNAs are small molecules that control gene expression in animals and plants, but their existence in fungi was not well studied. We found that miRNAs exist in P. marneffei and are expressed differently in mycelial and yeast phases of the fungus. This is the first evidence that miRNAs are expressed differently in different growth phases of a fungus.
In 2013, the Zika virus (ZIKV) emerged in French Polynesia and spread across the Pacific region between 2013 and 2017. Several mosquito species may have been involved in the spread of ZIKV, including Aedes aegypti and Aedes polynesiensis. This study evaluated the ability of wild populations of Aedes aegypti and Aedes polynesiensis collected from different Pacific islands to transmit ZIKV. Infection and transmission rates were analyzed for the ZIKV strain that circulated in this region during the 2013-2017 outbreak. The results showed low vector competence for ZIKV of the different Aedes vector populations studied. These results suggest that other factors, such as vector density, mosquito lifespan, and the immunologically naive fraction of the population, may have contributed to the rapid spread of ZIKV in the Pacific region.
Xist is a long non-coding RNA that controls gene expression by inactivating one of the two female X chromosomes during mammalian development. To better understand the structure of Xist in cells, the researchers developed Targeted Structure-Seq, which combines chemical probing of RNA structure in cells with target-specific massively parallel sequencing. By enriching for signals from the RNA of interest, Targeted Structure-Seq achieves high coverage of the target RNA with relatively few sequencing reads, thus providing a targeted and scalable approach to analyze RNA conformation in cells. They used this approach to probe the full-length Xist lncRNA and develop new models for functional elements within Xist, including the repeat A element in the 5’-end of Xist. This analysis also identified new structural elements in Xist that are evolutionarily conserved, including a new element proximal to the C repeats that is important for Xist function.
The study proposes a novel statistical framework that allows us to evaluate and compare the performance of genetic risk prediction models for complex diseases. The study suggests that it is not enough to only use one measure, such as the area under the ROC curve (AUC) to evaluate the performance of genetic risk prediction models. Instead, a variety of prediction metrics should be used to make a more complete assessment of the model's performance. The study introduces a unifying statistical framework that allows us to estimate and compare a range of prediction metrics, such as the AUC, mean risk difference, net reclassification improvement, proportion of cases explained, variance of predicted risks, and risk at any percentile. The study also demonstrates how to construct graphs to visualize the performance of risk models, such as the ROC curve, density of risks, and predictiveness curve. The results of the study show that the proposed framework is able to accurately estimate the prediction metrics and that it is useful for evaluating the performance of genetic risk prediction models. The study also applies the framework to nine complex diseases and evaluates the predictive power of genetic tests based on known susceptibility variants for each trait.
Human African trypanosomiasis (HAT) is a parasitic disease that affects over 70 million people in sub-Saharan Africa. The most common form of the disease is caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambiense, which in 2015 accounted for over 97% of all reported HAT cases. The card agglutination test for trypanosomiasis (CATT) is a widely used screening test for HAT that detects antibodies using a suspension of purified and stained bloodstream-form trypanosomes expressing LiTat 1.3 variant surface glycoprotein, a predominant variant antigen of T. brucei gambiense. However, CATT has been reported to have low sensitivity and specificity, and operational challenges such as the need for an agitator, electricity, and refrigeration have limited its large-scale implementation for passive screening in health facilities in remote locations. To address these challenges, two rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) have recently been developed, the HAT Sero-K-SeT and the SD BIOLINE HAT, which detect host antibodies using the same two antigens, VSG LiTat 1.3 and VSG LiTat 1.5. A comparison of these two RDTs in an independent study using stored plasma samples concluded that there was no difference in diagnostic accuracy between the two tests. However, a comparison of both RDTs in a prospective study showed that their sensitivity was not different from the sensitivity of CATT, while their specificity was 1.3% lower. A new RDT, the SD BIOLINE HAT 2.0, has now been developed using recombinant antigens. The primary objective of this study was to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of SD BIOLINE HAT 2.0 in a multi-centric, prospective study in the Democratic Republic of the Congo and to demonstrate its non-inferiority to SD BIOLINE HAT. As a secondary objective, the accuracy of SD BIOLINE HAT 2.0 was compared to that of CATT. The study found that the highest sensitivity was achieved with SD BIOLINE HAT 2.0 (71.2%), followed by CATT (62.5%) and the SD BIOLINE HAT (59.0%). The most specific test was CATT (99.2%), while the specificity of the SD BIOLINE HAT and SD BIOLINE HAT 2.0 were 98.9% and 98.1% respectively. Sensitivity of the tests was lower than previously reported as they identified cases from partially overlapping sub-populations. The study also found that all three tests were significantly more sensitive in passive than in active screening. Combining two or three tests resulted in a markedly increased sensitivity: When the SD BIOLINE HAT was combined with the SD BIOLINE HAT 2.0, sensitivity reached 98.4% in passive and 83.0% in active screening. While the practicality and cost-effectiveness of algorithms including several screening tests would need to be investigated, using two or more tests appears to enhance sensitivity of diagnostic algorithms, although some decrease in specificity is observed as well.
The article "Effectiveness of multiple indoor residual insecticide spraying rounds in reducing vector infestation and human seroprevalence of Chagas disease in Comapa, Guatemala" describes the impact of multiple rounds of indoor residual insecticide spraying (IRS) on Chagas disease transmission in the municipality of Comapa, Guatemala. The study found that after multiple rounds of IRS, the infestation index decreased significantly from 39% to 27%. However, the seroprevalence in women of child-bearing age remains high, above 10%, indicating that there is still a risk for congenital transmission. The study suggests that systematic integrated vector control and improved Chagas disease screening and treatment programs for congenital and vector-borne disease are needed to reach the elimination goal in regions with persistent vector infestation.
The article is about the study of Citrobacter rodentium, a natural pathogen that causes disease in mice. The researchers found that the genome of C. rodentium is unstable due to large-scale genome recombination and the activity of mobile genetic elements. The researchers sequenced an additional C. rodentium strain to confirm that their previous findings were consistent. They found that the reference strain ICC168 is representative of the species and that most inactivating mutations were common to both isolates. The researchers draw parallels with other bacterial pathogens and conclude that C. rodentium is a recently evolved pathogen that may have emerged alongside the development of inbred mice as a model for human disease.
The paper presents a new method for inferring the biochemical mechanisms underlying the shape of protein distributions across cell populations. The method uses stochastic modeling of gene expression processes and analytical solutions to the first four moments of the protein distribution to fit the model parameters to experimental data. The method is assumption-free and can infer rates of chromatin modification, transcription, translation, and RNA and protein degradation. The method can identify specific molecular mechanisms that underlie protein distributions, such as transcriptional bursting or constitutive transcript production. The method is more efficient and provides more information than previous methods. The method is applicable to a wide range of genes and can be used to gain insight into the mechanisms of gene expression.
Monkeypox is a disease caused by the Monkeypox virus (MPXV) that is endemic in West Africa and sporadic in Central Africa. Smallpox vaccination provides good protection against MPX, but the vaccination campaign ended in Africa in 1980 and a large proportion of the population is currently unprotected. Disease control of MPXV hinges on deterring zoonotic exposure to the virus and, if that fails, interrupting person-to-person spread. The World Health Organization has reported an increasing number of human cases of MPX in recent years. The reason for this increase is unclear, but it may be due to several factors, such as increasing human-animal interactions through environmental degradation, the cessation of routine vaccination against smallpox, an increase in human susceptibility to the virus, an increase in animal-human and human-human transmissibility of the virus, and the adaptation of the virus to new host species. Because the smallpox vaccine is not effective against MPXV, new and efficacious vaccines to protect against human MPX are needed. A new approach to vaccination is being explored based on three recombinant bovine herpesvirus 4 (BoHV-4) vectors, each expressing different MPXV glycoproteins (A29L, M1R and B6R). The three recombinant BoHV-4 vectors were shown to be safe and effective at protecting 100% of STAT1(-/-) mice from mortality and 80% of STAT1(-/-) mice from morbidity against a lethal MPXV challenge. This study demonstrated the efficacy of BoHV-4-based vectors and the potential of BoHV-4 as a vaccine-vector platform for developing new vaccines to protect against human MPX.
This article describes the role of ALPH1, a protein found in trypanosomes, in the process of mRNA decay. Trypanosomes are single-celled parasites that cause sleeping sickness in humans and other animals. The deadenylation process, in which the poly(A) tail of mRNA is shortened, is an important step in the decay of mRNA in trypanosomes, as it is in other eukaryotes. However, trypanosomes do not have the same protein complex as other eukaryotes that is involved in the next step of mRNA decay, which is the removal of the cap from the mRNA. The authors of this article have found that ALPH1, a protein previously identified as a stress granule protein in trypanosomes, is the enzyme that removes the cap from mRNA in these parasites. They have also found that ALPH1 is essential for the survival of the parasites and that it is involved in the global increase in mRNA levels that occurs when deadenylation is complete but mRNA decay has not yet begun.
Recently, it was shown that newborn baby pancreatic cells can turn into adult insulin-producing cells by just expressing one gene. Now, researchers have found that adult pancreatic cells can also turn into new insulin-producing cells by inhibiting the expression of another gene. The researchers used a mouse model to show that when they turned off the gene Arx in adult alpha cells (which produce glucagon), those alpha cells turned into new beta cells that produce insulin. The new beta cells were able to reverse diabetes in the mice. This could lead to new treatments for diabetes in people.
Scientists have discovered that replication of certain parts of the genome in a yeast cell can be restarted after they have already been replicated once. They have also found that certain genetic elements can be used to trigger this restart process in specific parts of the genome. This discovery challenges the idea that all parts of the genome replicate equally and suggests that the replication process may be more complex than previously thought.
Entamoeba histolytica, a parasite that causes invasive amebiasis, is increasing among men who have sex with men and is becoming a problem in developed East Asian countries where it is also co-infected with HIV-1. Treatment with metronidazole or tinidazole was successful in most cases, but recurrence of amebiasis was common in high risk populations. Recurrence was more frequent in those who had hepatitis C antibodies or who acquired syphilis during the follow-up period. Different genotypes of E. histolytica were identified in some cases, but there was no correlation between genotype and clinical features.
Gambian sleeping sickness (HAT) is a deadly disease caused by parasites transmitted by riverine tsetse flies. The WHO aims to eliminate HAT as a public health problem by 2020 and stop transmission by 2030. In the south of Chad, a persistent focus of HAT remained, with over 100 cases diagnosed and treated annually until 2013. In 2014, tsetse control was added to medical interventions to further reduce transmission and consequently, reduce annual incidence of HAT. The control involved the deployment of ‘tiny targets’ that attract and kill tsetse, and a census of the human population and their settlements was conducted before control began. The tsetse population declined after target deployment, and mathematical modeling showed that 70% of the reduction in reported cases between 2013 and 2015 could be attributed to vector control. The tiny targets were also estimated to have reduced new infections by 63% due to tsetse control, with 8% due to enhanced passive detection. The modeling predicted that elimination as a public health problem could be achieved by 2018 in this focus if vector control and screening continue at the present level. The tsetse control combined with medical interventions has played a major role in reducing HAT incidence in 2014 and 2015.
Strongyloidiasis is a parasitic infection caused by a roundworm called Strongyloides stercoralis. It can cause symptoms such as diarrhea, skin rash, and difficulty breathing. This parasite can be transmitted through contaminated soil or water, and can persist in the body for years without reinfection. Immunosuppressant conditions, such as corticosteroid therapy or HIV infection, can cause the parasite to multiply, leading to severe symptoms like hyperinfection syndrome. Imported cases of strongyloidiasis are being diagnosed more often in non-endemic areas, such as Spain, due to increased migration and travel. This study analyzed data from a Spanish collaborative network to describe the characteristics of imported strongyloidiasis cases, as well as factors that affect the burden of the parasite and the success of treatment.
Vaccines are important for protecting against infectious diseases. When creating vaccines, it is important to consider the amount of antigen or attenuated pathogen that is used as the inoculum dose. Higher doses usually lead to better stimulation of the immune response but can also cause more severe side effects and allow for less population coverage in the presence of vaccine shortages. Determining the optimal amount of inoculum dose is an important part of rational vaccine design. By combining mathematical models with experimental data, we can determine the impact of the inoculum dose on important outcomes such as immune protection and morbidity. This can help in determining the best balance between low dose to reduce costs and side effects and high dose to trigger a robust immune response. We illustrate this concept using data from two infection experiments: influenza A virus (IAV) infection of mice and human parainfluenza virus (HPIV) infection of cotton rats at different inoculum doses. Our findings show that the impact of inoculum dose on immune protection and morbidity can depend on the specific pathogen and that both protection and morbidity do not necessarily increase monotonically with increasing inoculum dose. This framework can help in the rational design of vaccines and determination of the optimal amount of inoculum dose.
Filaments of a specific type of cyanobacterium, Anabaena, develop a pattern of specialized cells called heterocysts that fix nitrogen under nitrogen-poor conditions. Before this developmental process begins, many aspects of gene expression are unknown. In addition, it is unclear how gene expression fluctuations are coupled between cells along a multicellular filament. In this study, the authors studied the statistics of gene expression fluctuations for a protein essential for heterocyst differentiation, HetR, both under steady-state growth in nitrogen-rich conditions and at different times after nitrogen deprivation. They found that expression fluctuations of HetR in nearby cells are coupled, with a characteristic spatial range of circa two to three cells. This sets the scale for cellular interactions along a filament. Correlations between cells mainly arise from intercellular molecular transfer and less from cell division. Fluctuations after nitrogen step-down build up on those under nitrogen-replete conditions. The authors also found that several factors known to play a role in differentiation after nitrogen deprivation also play a role before differentiation is triggered. These factors set an underlying pattern of spatial correlations of gene expression along filaments on which the developmental pattern may later be built. The authors provide evidence of the participation of an intercellular communication protein in setting these spatial correlations at specific times during differentiation. These findings provide insights into how developmental patterns can arise in multicellular organisms and how noise in gene expression can be controlled during development.
Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) is a type of virus that causes encephalitis (inflammation of the brain) in humans and reproductive disorders in pigs in the Asian Pacific region. The virus has three main types: genotype I (GI), genotype II (GII), and genotype III (GIII). A recent study found that the dominant type of JEV in China has shifted from GIII to GI. To understand why this has happened, researchers conducted a survey of JEV infection in pigs and compared the replication of different strains of JEV in various cells in a laboratory. They found that GI viruses replicated more efficiently than GIII viruses in certain types of cells, which could lead to more JEV being spread in the environment. This could in turn lead to more JEV being transmitted from animals to mosquitoes, and eventually from mosquitoes back to animals, creating a more efficient cycle of transmission.
Biofilm formation in the fungus Candida albicans is controlled by six transcription factors. To understand how these transcription factors work together to regulate biofilm formation, researchers used a genetic interaction approach. They generated all possible double heterozygous mutants of these transcription factors and analyzed the genetic interactions between them. The results showed that the six network heterozygous mutants all had altered biofilm formation. In addition, many double heterozygous mutants were as severely affected as homozygous deletions. As a result, the network was found to be highly interdependent and efficient but not robust. The researchers also found that some transcription factors have sensitive expression and that some transcription factors cooperatively interact with others. Finally, they found that the heterozygous NDT80 deletion mutant was hyperfilamentous under both biofilm and hyphae-inducing conditions in a TEC1-dependent manner. Overall, the results provide new insights into the functions of individual transcription factors and the role of the overall network topology in its function.
Leishmaniasis is a serious disease caused by parasites that can lead to death if not treated. Asparagine (Asn) is a nonessential amino acid that is made by a protein called asparagine synthetase (AS). There are two types of AS: type A and type B. Type B uses glutamine or ammonia to make Asn, while type A only uses ammonia. Surprisingly, parasites called trypanosomatids, including the ones that cause leishmaniasis, have a type A AS. Previous research showed that this type of AS is essential for the survival of Leishmania donovani parasites. However, the current study has found that type A AS is not essential for the survival or growth of Leishmania infantum parasites. Therefore, this type of AS is not a suitable drug target for treating Leishmania infantum parasites.
Toxocariasis is a common infection caused by parasites that can cause inflammation and damage to various parts of the body. This infection is often associated with other illnesses, including epilepsy, a condition that causes seizures. However, there is a lack of conclusive evidence to establish a causal link between these two conditions. Therefore, a systematic review of all available studies was conducted to determine the relationship between toxocariasis and epilepsy. After analyzing 204 publications, 11 case-control studies were included that involved 4,740 participants. The results showed a positive association between toxocariasis and epilepsy, suggesting that the infection may play a role in the incidence of this condition. However, this relationship is still debated and further research is needed to fully understand the association between toxocariasis and epilepsy.
A recent study discovered a new way that the protein called ATM controls the body's response to DNA damage caused by radiation. This response involves microRNAs (miRNAs), which are small molecules that can control the production of other proteins. The study found that a specific miRNA, miR-335, is controlled by a protein called CREB, and that miR-335 can control another protein called CtIP, which is important for repairing DNA damage. This repair process involves a method called homologous recombination, which is used to fix certain types of DNA damage. The study found that patient-derived cells with too much miR-335 were defective in their ability to repair DNA damage, which made them more sensitive to radiation than normal cells. The study also found that reducing the level of miR-335 in these patient-derived cells restored their ability to repair DNA damage and made them less sensitive to radiation.
When it comes to understanding and interpreting others' behavior, humans have a tendency to assign mental states to them, such as beliefs, emotions, and intentions. This process of "mentalizing" is quite sophisticated and can lead to adaptive social skills like convincing, teaching, or deceiving. In this study, researchers tested whether sophisticated recursive beliefs were important for learning in social interactions. They asked participants to play repeated games against artificial, Bayesian mentalizing agents that had different levels of sophistication. The participants were told either they were playing against each other or were gambling. Although the information provided was identical in both conditions, participants performed better when they believed they were playing against each other. The researchers suggest that mentalizing was important for learning in the social interaction and that it might not be possible to decipher intentional behavior without attributing mental states to others.
The current study presents a new algorithm for analyzing biological networks using a statistical model called Gaussian graphical model (GGM). GGM helps to understand the complex relationships among molecules like DNA, RNA, and proteins, and plays an important role in various biological processes and diseases. However, existing methods for analyzing biological networks in a high-dimensional setting are inefficient and not statistically rigorous. The new algorithm proposed in this study is efficient and statistically rigorous, and is able to make inference of GGM in real biological applications with tens of thousands of variables. The algorithm has been implemented in an R package named "FastGGM" and has been demonstrated to be several orders of magnitudes faster than the current implemented algorithm while maintaining the same accuracy. This makes it feasible to analyze whole-genome biological networks using GGM.
The striatum is a part of the brain that receives information from the cerebral cortex and sends output to other parts of the brain. It is made up of many small nerve cells called medium spiny neurons (MSNs) that fire at different times depending on the task being performed. This behavior is thought to be caused by the connections between the MSNs, which are too weak to completely inhibit other cells from firing.
Researchers have discovered a new regulatory mechanism in budding yeast that directly links cycles of exocytosis and endocytosis. This mechanism involves the Rab GTPase Sec4p, which is involved in polarized exocytosis and moves along actomyosin cables during this process. Sec4p also interacts with Las17p, a yeast Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome protein (WASp) homologue, to promote actin polymerization and trigger compensatory endocytosis. This discovery could help explain how polarized growth is maintained in specific secretory cell types.
Researchers have found that when mice take acetaminophen, a commonly used pain reliever, it can cause liver damage. To better understand how this happens, researchers have been studying how the drug is metabolized inside the liver. One theory is that the drug is converted into a toxic form (NAPQI) that is produced in different parts of the liver. When this toxic form reaches a certain level, it can damage cells and cause liver failure. However, researchers have had a hard time testing this theory because it is difficult to control the different parts of the liver and measure what is happening inside it. To solve this problem, researchers used software to create a virtual model of a mouse's liver. They used this model to test different ideas about how the drug is metabolized and what happens when it reaches toxic levels. The results of these virtual experiments showed that the theory was not completely correct and that other factors were needed to explain the liver damage. The researchers think that this new information will help them better understand how acetaminophen causes liver damage and how to prevent it.
The paper describes a study done to measure the parasite burden in infants born to mothers infected with a parasite called Trypanosoma cruzi. The study used three different tests to diagnose T. cruzi infection in infants at different time points: the INP micromethod test at one month after delivery, a second parasitological diagnosis at six months of age, and a serology test at 10–12 months of age. The parasite burden was measured by using a method called quantitative PCR. The study also looked at the relationship between parasite burden and serology test results. Additionally, the study genotyped T. cruzi parasites isolated from 19 infected children.
The study proposes a model of Escherichia coli that predicts growth rate and cellular composition from a coarse-grained representation of its genome. The model assumes that E. coli is in a state of balanced exponential steady-state growth, growing in a constant environment that is rich in resources. The model is able to reproduce data from a series of past experiments where the growth rate and rRNA-to-protein ratio have been measured for seven E. coli strains with rRNA operon copy numbers ranging from 1 to 7 (the wild-type copy number). The model suggests that increasing the rRNA operon copy number beyond seven will lead to a cytoplasm that is densely packed with ribosomes and proteins, which will result in a decrease in growth rate. The study also discusses possible design principles suggested by the model and proposes further experiments to test its validity.
Plants respond to many types of environmental stresses, including drought, salinity, and cold. The hormone abscisic acid (ABA) is important for plant responses to stresses. PYR/PYL/RCARs are receptors that sense ABA levels in plant cells. They bind to a family of clade-A PP2Cs, including ABI1, ABI2, HAB1, and PP2CA/AHG3, which negatively regulate ABA responses by dephosphorylating and inhibiting positive regulators of ABA signaling, such as SnRK2s. ABI5 is a downstream target of the SnRK2 kinases and is involved in seed germination and seedling development. In this work, the authors showed that RSM1, a MYB-related transcription factor, is down-regulated by salt and up-regulated by ABA. They found that RSM1 interacts with the bZIP transcription factors HY5 and HYH, which are important regulators of light signaling. The authors also found that RSM1 regulates ABI5 expression by directly binding to its promoter. In addition, they showed that RSM1 regulates the expression of other ABA-responsive genes. Together, these results suggest that RSM1 interacts with HY5 and HYH to regulate ABA and abiotic stress responses.
The study reports that complex I, a large and complicated protein complex involved in energy metabolism, links the transfer of electrons from NADH to ubiquinone to the pumping of four protons from the matrix into the intermembrane space. In humans, defects in complex I are linked to a wide range of degenerative disorders. Recent structural analysis of complex I revealed that redox reactions are confined to the hydrophilic peripheral arm of the L-shaped molecule and take place at a remarkable distance from the membrane domain. This suggests that the proton pumping within the membrane arm of complex I is driven indirectly via long-range conformational coupling. The study provides evidence that the membrane arm of complex I contains two functionally distinct pump modules connected in series by the long helical transmission element.
Fever is a natural response to infection that increases body temperature to fight off infections. We wanted to know if fever also helps improve antibody binding to antigens, which is important for fighting off infections. To test this, we used selected antigens from two different types of infections - dengue and malaria - and measured how the binding affinity of antibodies for these antigens changed at different temperatures. We found that binding affinity increased at a temperature of 40°C compared to 37°C and 42°C. This suggests that fever may help improve antibody binding to antigens, which could make it easier for the body to fight off infections.
Actomyosin networks are important for many cellular processes including cell division, motility, and tissue morphogenesis. These networks are made up of actin filaments and myosin motors that produce contractile stress and generate cortical flow. But how these networks are able to produce and dissipate stress, and how this affects flow, is not well understood. A computational model has been developed that examines how stress production and dissipation depend on motor activity and network remodeling. The model reveals that filament turnover is required to maintain steady state flow against external resistance. The model also shows how active stress and effective viscosity depend on filament turnover, and how these dependencies combine to determine overall rates of cortical flow. These results provide a framework for understanding how animal cells tune cortical flow through local control of network remodeling.
In this study, researchers identified a gene called ANAC060 that controls seedling growth in response to high levels of glucose or fructose in Arabidopsis thaliana. They used a combination of methods, including mapping, transgenic complementation, and mRNA analysis, to determine that ANAC060 is responsible for sugar sensitivity in a process that involves ABA signaling. The researchers also found that the Col ANAC060 allele is responsible for sugar insensitivity, and that this allele causes a truncated version of the protein that lacks a transmembrane anchor domain. This truncated version of ANAC060 is constitutively located in the nucleus. Interestingly, the Col ANAC060 allele attenuates sugar-induced ABA accumulation, which explains its sugar-insensitive phenotype. This study provides important insights into the regulation of sugar-ABA signaling and sugar sensitivity in plants.
This study investigates how bacteria use c-di-GMP, a nucleotide second messenger, to communicate within cells and produce specific outputs, such as biofilm formation and motility. The study shows that c-di-GMP signaling gains output specificity in Pseudomonas aeruginosa by being relayed to specific pathways. The authors identified a new c-di-GMP synthase gene, hsbD, which regulates twitching, swimming, swarming, and chemotaxis in P. aeruginosa by interacting with the HptB pathway. The study provides clues about how bacteria evolved to develop this new network, and how c-di-GMP signaling can be orchestrated to produce specific outcomes.
Humans can learn to associate different visuomotor mappings with different contextual cues, which can be used to switch between different mappings. This study tested whether participants could learn the association between a contextual cue (target shape) and the required visuomotor mapping, and how generalization would occur when learning a linear relationship between the two. Participants performed a rapid target-pointing task while the visual feedback was manipulated to have horizontal offsets depending on the target shape. The target shapes were taken from a continuous set of shapes, ranging from spiky to circular. After training on a subset of shape/mapping pairs, participants were tested on other shapes that were not learned before. Experimental results showed that participants applied the mapping corresponding to the trained shape that was most similar to the current one, rather than explicitly extracting the linear relationship between the target shape and visuomotor mapping and applying it generalize. The Bayesian learning model developed in this study predicted this pattern of generalization and the observed learning rate pattern, suggesting that this model provides a possible mechanism for simultaneously learning multiple visuomotor mappings.
The inferior olivary nucleus (IO) is a vital part of the brain that sends signals to the cerebellum to help with motor skills. These signals come in the form of "climbing fibers" and they are important for the cerebellum to function properly. It was thought that the timing of these signals was related to motor commands and/or motor learning, but this has not been confirmed yet. Climbing fiber signals cause a sudden increase in electrical activity in cerebellar Purkinje cells, which can be measured as large all-or-none action potentials. However, researchers have found that the climbing fiber can transmit a short burst of spikes as a result of an olivary cell somatic spike. The size of the burst may be related to the phase of the olivary cell's sub-threshold membrane potential oscillation, but it is not yet clear what factors primarily determine this size.
Iron is vital for life but too much can be toxic due to its redox properties. The liver plays a key role in regulating iron levels in the body, but the metabolism of iron in the liver and the mechanisms controlling this regulation are not fully understood. In this study, a quantitative computational model of human liver iron metabolism was constructed, which includes key regulatory components and their kinetic properties. The model was validated by comparing its results with previously published physiological data and was able to reproduce multiple experimental findings. A time course simulation following an oral dose of iron was compared to a clinical time course study and the simulation was found to recreate the dynamics and time scale of the systems response to iron challenge. A disease state simulation of haemochromatosis was created by altering a single reaction parameter, and the simulation provided a quantitative understanding of the liver iron overload that arises in this disease. The model supports and supplements understanding of the role of the liver as an iron sensor and provides a framework for further modelling, including simulations to identify valuable drug targets and design of experiments to improve our knowledge of this system.
The nuclear pore complex (NPC) is a protein structure that regulates the movement of molecules into and out of the nucleus of a eukaryotic cell. Nucleocytoplasmic transport (NCT) is the process by which molecules move through the NPC. This process is critical for many cellular functions, such as transcription and protein synthesis. However, the mechanism of NCT is not fully understood. To help understand this process, researchers have developed a computational model that mimics the function of the NPC. The model takes into account the hydrophobic interactions between a molecule called a karyopherin (KAP) and a repeat domain called the phenylalanine-glycine (FG) repeat. These interactions are believed to play a key role in the transport of molecules through the NPC. The model also takes into account the polymeric nature of the NPC and the hydrophobic affinity of the KAP for the FG repeats. By simulating the transport of molecules through the NPC, researchers can gain new insights into the mechanisms underlying this important process.
The nonhuman primate (NHP) model is often the best experimental model for testing interventions designed to block infection by human pathogens, such as HIV, tuberculosis, and malaria. However, using too high or too low a challenge dose may lead to false negative results and an excessive use of animals. Here, I define an optimized protocol for defining the dose of pathogen that infects 50% of the time (AID50). This protocol minimizes the number of animals, while providing an estimate of the AID50 within 1.5-fold of the true value. This can be easily applied to other challenge doses, such as AID80. The protocol is generalizable to any pathogen and animal model.
In this paper, the authors studied a first-order auditory interneuron called AN2 in crickets. They found that adaptation, which is the change in a neuron's response curve, shifts the stimulus-response curves toward higher stimulus intensities, with a time constant of 1.5 seconds for adaptation and recovery. They then compared two competing hypotheses, infomax and selective coding, to see which one could better explain the response curves of AN2 neurons. They found that adaptation reduces the amount of encoded information when considering the whole range of input signals. The response curve changes were also not consistent with the selective coding hypothesis because the amount of information conveyed about the loudest part of the signal did not increase as predicted but remained nearly constant. Less information is transmitted about signals with lower intensity.
Prions are a group of infectious particles that cause fatal diseases in humans and animals. These particles contain a modified version of a normal protein called PrPC, called PrPSc. The PrPSc protein is required to cause prion diseases. Scientists have been studying how PrPSc is formed and how it spreads. They have found that PrPSc binds to PrPC, causing it to change into another form of PrPSc. This binding happens through a part of PrPC called polybasic domains. They also found that PrPSc molecules with these domains are less infectious than those without them. Scientists also investigated how PrPSc molecules with these domains are able to cause PrPSc to form in others. They found that these PrPSc molecules are able to bind PrPC in a new way, allowing it to change into PrPSc more efficiently. These findings show that PrPC polybasic domains are not required for PrPSc to form and spread, but they are important for PrPSc molecules to be infectious. This study gives scientists more information about how prion diseases are caused and how they can be treated.
Scientists have developed a new way to understand how animals make decisions by analyzing their behavior. They used a type of artificial intelligence called inverse reinforcement learning to study how C. elegans worms make decisions about temperature based on food availability. The scientists found that the worms use different strategies depending on whether they are fed or starved. They also found that certain neurons in the worm's brain are important for these strategies. The new method could be used to better understand other animal behaviors.
Haptophytes are important algae that play a major role in aquatic ecosystems. They are essential for carbon sequestration and food for many eco-cohorts. Their importance has led to the sequencing of the nuclear genome of Emiliania huxleyi, but Chrysochromulina tobin is the first haptophyte to be sequenced. The genome of Chrysochromulina tobin is small and compact, encoding around 16,777 genes. Genes important to fatty acid synthesis, modification, and catabolism show distinct patterns of expression when monitored over a 24-hour light/dark cycle. The genome also harbors a new type of xanthorhodopsin, as well as two unique RuBisCO activases. This study provides important information on the evolution, ecology, and economic importance of haptophytes.
Breast cancer is a complex and heterogeneous disease with different types of tumors and molecular signatures. The so-called "triple-negative" breast cancer (TNBC) is a type of breast cancer that lacks the expression of three clinical markers (ESR1, PGR, and HER2) and often has a poor prognosis with low long-term patient outcomes. Despite having different clinical behaviors, morphologies, and molecular biologies, TNBCs and Basal-like tumors are often used interchangeably. However, they are not completely synonymous. TNBCs can also be classified as Claudin-low tumors, which are characterized by the activation of molecular pathways associated with epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT), cancer stem cells, and the immune response. Different types of breast cancer also have different genetic and molecular characteristics. Inherited forms of breast cancer are often associated with mutations in genes that safeguard genomic integrity, such as BRCA1, BRCA2, p53, and Rb. These genes play important roles in DNA repair, cell cycle regulation, and transcription. In addition to these well-known tumor suppressors, other genes, such as those involved in the DNA damage response, may also be important in breast cancer pathogenesis. Understanding the complexity and heterogeneity of breast cancer is critical for developing new and effective treatments.
Dengue fever is caused by a virus that is primarily spread by the mosquito Aedes aegypti. This mosquito typically lays eggs in artificial water-holding containers, which are common in human settlements. A study in rural Thailand found that the number and density of containers used for breeding were the primary determinants of the distribution and abundance of Ae. aegypti pupae. The productivity of most container types increased significantly as habitat density increased. This suggests that a targeted approach to controlling the number of breeding sites and their density could be effective in reducing the abundance of these mosquitoes and, consequently, the transmission of dengue fever.
The intestine of the nematode C. elegans communicates with the nervous system to control development and behavior based on internal state and external cues. The study identified a protein called Rictor as part of the TORC2 complex that helps control development and behavior in C. elegans. In the intestine, TORC2 regulates expression of neuroendocrine genes, such as daf-7 and daf-28, which help determine whether the animal will undergo reproductive growth or enter the dauer larval stage in response to food and temperature. These neuroendocrine genes also influence food-dependent adult behavior. The study found that TORC2 signaling is required for food-dependent modulation of dauer entry and exploratory behavior in C. elegans.
In this study, researchers compared the gene expression patterns of embryonic stem (ES) cells and primordial germ cells (PGCs). They identified genes that are highly expressed in both ES and PGCs, and used a new computer program called CompMoby to search for DNA motifs that regulate gene expression. The researchers found that certain DNA sequences were preferentially active in ES and PGCs, and that these sequences could regulate gene expression in the context of an endogenous promoter. They also discovered that a transcription factor called NF-Y binds to one of these sequences, and that NF-Y is required for ES cell proliferation. Overall, the study provides new insights into the transcriptional regulatory networks of pluripotent stem cells, and highlights the potential for using systematic approaches to understanding transcriptional regulation in mammalian species.
Vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV) is a type of virus that causes flu-like symptoms in humans. It is a negative-strand RNA virus, which means that its genome is made up of RNA, not DNA. In order to replicate its genome and make new copies of itself, the virus needs a special protein called nucleoprotein (N) to help it make a complex called nucleocapsid. This nucleocapsid encases the RNA and helps the polymerase (another protein) make copies of the RNA. However, the nucleoprotein (N) by itself cannot form this complex. It needs the help of another protein called phosphoprotein (P). The P protein helps the nucleoprotein (N) form the nucleocapsid complex, but it also has two other jobs: it prevents the nucleoprotein (N) from binding to RNA and it prevents the nucleoprotein (N) from binding to itself. The P protein is a long protein with two folded domains and a flexible linker between them. It has a region that helps it bind to the nucleoprotein (N) and a region that helps it bind to RNA. The study shows that the P protein helps the nucleoprotein (N) form the nucleocapsid complex by folding the region that binds to the nucleoprotein (N) and by blocking the region that binds to RNA. It also shows that the P protein can bind to the nucleoprotein (N) without RNA being present and that it can disrupt the nucleocapsid complex once it has bound to it. This provides insight into how negative-strand RNA viruses like VSV replicate their genomes.
In the fly visual system, electrical synapses formed via gap junctions are ubiquitous, but their functional role is unclear. We used a model of the fly visual system to investigate the impact of these gap junctions on the encoding of visual motion information. We found that axonal gap junctions allowed for more efficient encoding of motion information in the vertical system, a critical network for visual processing in the fly. This efficient encoding was necessary for the fly's visually guided behavior, such as evasive maneuvers. Our findings suggest that gap junctions may play a crucial role in efficient sensory information processing, and highlight the importance of studying the computational implications of specific connectivity patterns in neural networks.
In this study, researchers investigated how a virus called EV71 infects and replicates in human cells. The researchers found that a molecule called PSGL-1, which is found on human leukocytes, is a key receptor for EV71 to enter and infect cells. They also found that the PSGL-1 molecule is modified by the addition of sulfate groups to certain amino acids. These modifications were important for the virus to bind to PSGL-1 and infect cells. The researchers concluded that sulfate groups play a crucial role in the entry and replication of EV71 in human cells.
Leishmaniasis is a serious global health problem that affects many people worldwide. The parasite is carried by the female phlebotomine sand fly and can infect a variety of mammalian species, including humans. Once in the infected host, Leishmania persists and multiplies within phagocytic cells such as macrophages. The disease can manifest in different forms, including cutaneous, mucocutaneous, and visceral leishmaniasis. Leishmaniasis can be treated with several agents, but drug toxicity and the emergence of resistant strains make these treatments ineffective in the long run. Inhibitors of the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) have been shown to have anti-pathogen properties. In this study, the authors tested the therapeutic efficacy of several mTOR inhibitors in controlling infection with Leishmania major in BALB/c mice. Rapamycin, GSK-2126458, and KU-0063794 were administered to the mice, which had received an intrafootpad injection of the parasite. Footpad swelling and parasite burden were assessed, and cytokine production by mouse splenocytes and phenotypic changes in draining lymph node cells were evaluated.
