The authors found that treatment with rapamycin or GSK-2126458, but not KU-0063794, dramatically lowered both the footpad swelling and the parasite load in the draining lymph node. The employed dose of rapamycin did not kill the promastigotes in vitro as judged by 3- ( 4 , 5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl ) -2 , 5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide ( MTT ) assays and electron microscopy. Moreover, the IL-4 production capacity of splenocytes harvested from infected mice that were treated with rapamycin was significantly reduced. Consequently, the IFN-γ:IL-4 production ratio was elevated, suggesting a T helper-type 1 ( Th1 ) -skewed cytokine profile. Finally, the expression level of CD69, an early activation marker, on splenic and lymph node CD4+ and CD8+ T cells was enhanced in rapamycin-treated mice. Taken together, the authors suggest that select mTOR inhibitors may be used in therapeutic settings for the management of leishmaniasis, and that the beneficial effects of such inhibitors stem from their immunomodulatory properties. They also propose that the adjuvanticity of mTOR inhibitors may be considered in vaccination strategies against Leishmania species.
Natural transformation is a common ability found in many bacteria that helps them adapt to their environment by taking up foreign DNA. In Neisseria meningitidis, natural transformation is important for the meningococcus to become virulent by acquiring new genes from other meningococci or bacteria sharing the same niche. This process involves specific DNA sequences called DUS and the DUS receptor ComP. In this study, researchers found that ComP is necessary for the transformation of N. meningitidis both with and without DUS. The bases of the DUS are important for its interaction with ComP and for the transformation process. Additionally, researchers found that a ComP homolog in N. subflava, a human commensal Neisseria species, can also bind its cognate DUS and mediate DUS-enhanced transformation in N. meningitidis. This finding suggests that co-evolution of DUS variants and cognate ComP receptors may be a mechanism for modulating horizontal gene transfer between competent species living in the same environment. Overall, this study provides important insights into the molecular events involved in the earliest step in natural transformation and reveals an elegant mechanism for modulating horizontal gene transfer.
In fungal cells, the process of cytokinesis (when a mother cell divides into two daughter cells) requires the formation of a cell wall structure called the septum, which is made of linear and branched sugar polymers. A protein called Pxl1 is important for anchoring the contractile ring (CAR) to the plasma membrane before septation (the process of forming the septum) onset. In addition, another protein, Bgs1, is responsible for forming the linear sugar polymer that is necessary for septation. In the absence of both Pxl1 and Bgs1, the CAR fails to contract and the septum is not formed. The amount of Pxl1 in the CAR increases during cytokinesis and this increase depends on the SH3 domain of the F-BAR protein Cdc15. In cells with a defective Cdc15 allele, the CAR fails to contract and septation is blocked. On the other hand, the absence of Pxl1 is lethal in cells with a defective Cdc15 allele. These findings suggest that Pxl1 and Cdc15 are important for the maintenance of the CAR and septum formation.
Glanders is a deadly disease caused by a bacterium and is known to be fatal to both animals and humans. The disease is spread by horses, which can be asymptomatic but highly infectious. In recent years, there have been several outbreaks of glanders in various regions, including Asia, the Middle East, Africa, and South America. In 2010, Bahrain was declared free of glanders, but in 2010 and 2011, there was an outbreak in the northern region of the country. The outbreak was caused by two different strains of B . mallei, and more than 6,700 horses were infected. The study provides evidence that the outbreak was caused by two different B . mallei strains, and the results demonstrate that MLVA can be used to rapidly estimate epidemiological links among B . mallei strains. The close relationship of the Dubai/UAE B . mallei population to the BH1 and BH2 populations may be indicative of a similar geographic source that has yet to be identified. The failure of initial eradication efforts in 2010 is evidence for the need for continued surveillance and abatement measures even after all animal cases appear to be cleared. All animals imported from known or potentially endemic regions should be routinely tested for glanders before importation, and repeated testing during quarantine is recommended as infected animals may be asymptomatic and serologically negative.
American cutaneous leishmaniasis (ACL) is a complex disease that causes about 67,000 new cases each year. The disease can be caused by different types of parasites, but it is difficult to identify which one is responsible. The World Health Organization recommends treating ACL caused by Leishmania braziliensis with pentavalent antimonial derivatives such as Glucantime or Sodium Stibogluconate. However, these treatments are not always effective, and it is unclear why they fail. A study was done on a group of 43 Colombian patients who had ACL that did not respond to Glucantime treatment. The study looked at the patients' clinical and parasitological characteristics, as well as their epidemiological and geographic information. Parasite species, in vitro antimony susceptibility, and in vitro infectivity were also analyzed. The majority of the parasites found in the patients were Leishmania braziliensis, and about 35% of the parasites had decreased in vitro susceptibility to Glucantime after previous administration of the drug. There was a negative correlation between lesion size and in vitro infectivity of the parasite, as well as a negative correlation between lesion size and parasite resistance. Leishmania braziliensis was the most common parasite species found in patients who had treatment failure or relapse. This study suggests that patients with ACL caused by Leishmania braziliensis who do not respond to Glucantime treatment may have a decreased in vitro susceptibility to the drug.
Escherichia coli is a normal resident of the gut of humans and animals, but can also be a pathogen associated with diarrheal disease and extra-intestinal infections. In some strains of E. coli, a group of virulence factors is clustered on a pathogenicity island. These virulence factors are responsible for extra-intestinal infections and include the biosynthesis of four types of siderophores, which are involved in iron uptake, and a genotoxin called colibactin. The biosynthesis of the first three types of siderophores requires a 4′-phosphopantetheinyl transferase (PPTase) that activates polyketide synthases (PKSs) and nonribosomal peptide synthetases (NRPSs). While the E. coli EntD PPTase is responsible for the biosynthesis of enterobactin and salmochelins, which are glycosylated forms of enterobactin, and the YbtD PPTase is responsible for the biosynthesis of yersiniabactin in Yersinia, a PPTase responsible for the biosynthesis of yersiniabactin in E. coli has not yet been identified. In this study, the researchers used genetic analysis and mouse models to investigate a potential connection between the biosynthetic pathways leading to the production of siderophores and the genotoxin colibactin. They found that ClbA, a PPTase encoded on the pks island that is responsible for the biosynthesis of colibactin, can also contribute to the synthesis of siderophores. In addition, they demonstrated that the presence of either functional EntD or ClbA is required for the survival of ExPEC in vivo. Their findings highlight the interconnection between different virulence factors with distinct functions, and suggest that the association of the pks island with a high pathogenicity island in some strains of E. coli may have been selected because ClbA can contribute to the synthesis of both the genotoxin and siderophores.
The article describes a new model for evolutionary analysis that takes into account insertions and deletions along with substitutions. This model was built based on the rate matrix augmented by the gap character, and the non-reversible generative evolutionary model was constructed by extending the continuous Markov process. The proposed model was applied to phylogenetic tree inference by extending the program dnaml in phylip, and it was shown that the extended program outperformed the usual approach of ignoring gaps. The authors have successfully integrated their model into a widely used phylogenetic inference tool.
The study aimed to understand how immunity to Herpes Simplex Virus ( HSV ) is initiated in humans. The first dendritic cells ( DCs ) to encounter HSV are Langerhans cells ( LCs ) in the epidermis. However, it is CD103+ dermal DCs that take the virus from LCs to lymph nodes for antigen presentation. In this study, the authors compared HSV-1 infected human foreskin explants with biopsies of initial human genital herpes lesions to show that LCs initially infected then emigrate into the dermis, where they form large clusters with BDCA3+ dermal DCs and DC-SIGN+ DCs/macrophages. HSV-expressing LC fragments were observed inside the dermal DCs and BDCA3+ dermal DCs had up-regulated a damaged cell uptake receptor CLEC9A. The authors conclude that a viral antigen relay takes place where HSV infected LCs undergo apoptosis and are taken up by dermal DCs for subsequent antigen presentation. This provides a rationale for targeting these cells with mucosal or perhaps intradermal HSV immunization.
This study compares the biogenesis of parasitophorous vacuoles (PVs) formed in mouse bone marrow-derived macrophages infected with either Leishmania major or L. amazonensis. The authors used multidimensional imaging to analyze the properties of these PVs, including their size, shape, acidity, and ability to take up lysosomotropic probes. They found that the amastigotes of L. major form small PVs that fuse with each other during replication and are acidic due to the presence of lysosomes. In contrast, the amastigotes of L. amazonensis form large PVs that enlarge over time and are neutral due to the absence of lysosomes. The authors also found that PVs of L. amazonensis can fuse with each other to form even larger structures. Their findings suggest that the biogenesis of PVs varies depending on the species of Leishmania and the host cell environment.
Our study focused on the chicken B cell line DT40 and its ability to repair DNA damage through a process called homologous recombination. In this process, a DNA repair team uses a template from a related sequence to make the necessary changes. We wanted to see how the structure of the template affects the outcome of the repair. We found that the templates in DT40 have marks on their histones that indicate they are open and accessible, which may make them more attractive as templates for repair. We also found that when we prevented the templates from being open and accessible, the repair team was less likely to use them as templates. This suggests that the structure of the template is important for homologous recombination. This could be relevant to understanding how genes are changed in cancer cells or how DNA repair goes wrong in general.
The cerebellum helps us adjust our actions quickly to fit the situation we are in. It does this by comparing our current behavior with what we want to do, and then making changes to our behavior to make it better. To do this, the cerebellum uses information from the climbing fiber system, which tells it when we make a mistake in our behavior. This mistake is called an "error". The climbing fiber system tells the cerebellum about this error immediately after it happens, so that it can change our behavior to prevent the same mistake from happening again. However, we now have evidence that the climbing fiber system also helps the cerebellum remember this error, so that it can use it to help improve our behavior in the future. This is important because it means that we can learn from our mistakes and become better at doing things.
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a neurodegenerative disease that causes the death of motor neurons in the brain and spinal cord, leading to muscle weakness, paralysis, and ultimately death. TDP-43 is a protein found in the nucleus under normal conditions but mislocalizes to the cytoplasm in ALS. TDP-43 forms aggregates, and mutations in the TDP-43 gene cause familial ALS. In a yeast model of ALS, the researchers found that TDP-43 aggregates reduce the degradation of cytosolic misfolded proteins by the ubiquitin proteasome system. However, overexpression of an Hsp40 chaperone called Sis1 rescues cells from TDP-43 toxicity, reduces the formation of TDP-43 aggregates, and restores the degradation of cytosolic misfolded proteins. Overexpression of the mammalian Sis1 homologue, DNAJB1, also reduces TDP-43-mediated toxicity in primary rodent cortical neurons. These findings suggest that Sis1 and its homologues may have neuroprotective effects in ALS and provide insights into the mechanism of toxicity associated with TDP-43 aggregation.
Chagas disease is a major public health issue in Latin America, and finding a connection between the Trypanosoma cruzi parasite genotypes and their clinical manifestations is still a major challenge. In this study, researchers used a multilocus conventional PCR and quantitative real time PCR (qPCR) approach to perform molecular typing and parasite load quantification directly from blood specimens of 65 chronic Chagas disease patients. They found that 35 (53.8%) of the patients presented positive amplification by qPCR, with 20 (30.7%) having the clinical indeterminate form and 15 (23.1%) having the cardiac form of the disease. The parasite load median for all positive patients was 2.54 [1.43–11.14] parasite equivalents/mL (par. Eq./mL), with the load ranging from 0.12 to 153.66 par. Eq./mL. Notably, the parasite load was significantly higher in patients over 70 years old. Using blood samples spiked with reference T. cruzi strains belonging to the six DTUs, the researchers were able to genotype the parasite up to 0.5 par. Eq./mL with high specificity. Of the patients with positive qPCR, 28 (80%) could be identified with the T. cruzi DTU. For the remaining patients (20%), at least a partial result was obtained. The researchers observed prevalences of TcVI, TcII, and mixed infection TcVI+TcII of 40%, 17.1%, and 14.3%, respectively. Additionally, they found two patients infected by TcV and one patient coinfected by TcIII+TcVI. These last three patients were in stage A of chronic chagasic cardiomyopathy and were born at the Bahia State, in the northeast region of Brazil. When the T. cruzi genotypes were compared with the parasite load, more elevated parasite loads were observed in patients infected by TcII in general (median of 7.56 par. Eq./mL) in comparison to patients infected by TcVI (median of 2.35 par. Eq./mL). However, while the frequency of chagasic cardiomyopathy was 50% in patients infected by TcVI and TcV, only 16.7% of patients infected by TcII evolved to chagasic cardiomyopathy. Taking all the results together, the researchers concluded that their findings contribute to updating the epidemiological knowledge of T. cruzi DTUs in Brazil and highlight the importance of the age of the patient and infection by TcII as factors leading to the observation of higher parasitemia levels.
Rabies in bats is present in Guatemala, but we know very little about it. To find out more, we took samples from bats and tested for rabies. We found that rabies was present in two types of bats (Desmodus rotundus) and that the virus was found in their brains, mouth swabs, lungs, and kidneys. The virus was also found in the blood of one bat. We also found a non-synonymous substitution in the genetic material of the virus. We know that rabies in bats can be transmitted to humans and dogs, but we did not find any evidence of this in Guatemala. However, we think that rabies in bats could pose a risk to humans and animals in the future, so it is important to continue to study it.
Herpes simplex virus (HSV) DNA replicates and expresses its genes inside a cell's nucleus. During the first hours of HSV infection, viral DNA forms a separate compartment inside the nucleus that is separated from the rest of the DNA in the cell. This compartment is called a "replication compartment," and it is where HSV DNA is actively replicated and expressed. A protein called lamin A/C is thought to help form this compartment and to help keep the viral DNA separate from the rest of the cell's DNA. However, the role of lamin A/C in HSV infection is not well understood. In this study, researchers used mice that were missing the gene for lamin A/C to investigate how this protein affects HSV infection. They found that in these mice, the replication compartment formed by HSV DNA was smaller than normal and did not form at the correct location inside the nucleus. The researchers also found that there was more "heterochromatin" (a type of DNA packaging that helps keep genes turned off) associated with the viral DNA in the mice that were missing lamin A/C. This suggests that lamin A/C may be involved in helping to turn off certain genes that are associated with HSV infection. Overall, this study provides new insights into how lamin A/C may play a role in HSV infection.
Mitochondria are organelles found in almost all eukaryotic cells that produce energy for the cell. They were originally bacteria that got taken into a cell and reprogrammed to work for the cell instead of itself. The protein import machinery that helps proteins get into the mitochondria has been studied for a while, but there is still much to learn about it. One type of mitochondrion that is especially interesting is called a hydrogenosome. These are found in certain organisms that don't use oxygen to make energy. The proteins that make up the protein import machinery in these organisms are very different from the ones in regular mitochondria. In this study, researchers looked at the protein import machinery in hydrogenosomes from a type of parasite called Trichomonas vaginalis. They found that the machinery is composed of three different types of proteins that are all very different from the ones found in regular mitochondria. These proteins are able to help proteins get into the hydrogenosomes, just like the protein import machinery in regular mitochondria does. The researchers also looked at the way that these proteins are put together and found that they form a skull-like shape. Overall, this study is important because it helps us understand how protein import machinery works in different types of organelles.
Researchers have found that certain genetic variations may be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as type 1 diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, and multiple sclerosis. To better understand how these genetic variations affect the immune system, researchers isolated T cells (a type of immune cell) from the blood of 313 healthy individuals. They then analyzed the genetic variations that were associated with changes in gene expression in these cells. The researchers found that some genetic variations only affected gene expression in certain types of T cells, such as CD4+ and CD8+ T cells. They also found that some genetic variations were associated with changes in protein production or isoform levels (different versions of the same gene) in T cells. The researchers believe that this study will help them to better understand how genetic variations affect the immune system and how they contribute to autoimmune diseases.
In this study, the authors explored the barriers that prevent people from participating in screening and treatment for Human African Trypanosomiasis (HAT) in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). The authors conducted interviews with current and former HAT patients, as well as healthcare providers and program managers of the national HAT control program, to understand the community's perspective. They discovered that people believed that observing six-month prohibitions after HAT treatment, such as no work, no sexual intercourse, no hot food, and no walking in the sun, caused serious complications. These prohibitions were well-known in the community and led some people to avoid HAT screening campaigns. However, the authors found that these prohibitions were not evidence-based and became obsolete with the new safer drugs. The authors emphasized the importance of correct health information for healthcare providers to address the community's perspective and keep abreast of unintended transformations of meaning in the context of HAT treatment.
Médecins Sans Frontières has worked to diagnose and treat patients with visceral leishmaniasis in Tabarak Allah Hospital in Sudan since December 2009. To estimate the incidence of visceral leishmaniasis in villages around the hospital, a survey was conducted from May to June 2011. The survey included 45 villages in Al-Gureisha locality, and a total of 17,702 households were interviewed. The crude mortality rate over the mean recall period of 409 days was 0.13/10,000 people per day. Visceral leishmaniasis was a possible or probable cause of death for 19% of all deaths. The survey estimated the incidence of visceral leishmaniasis over the past year at 7.0/1000 persons per year, or 7.9/1000 when deaths possibly or probably due to visceral leishmaniasis were included. The proportion of the population treated for visceral leishmaniasis in the past was 12.5%. The proportion of PKDL among patients previously treated for visceral leishmaniasis was 11.9%. The study concluded that visceral leishmaniasis is a significant health burden in eastern Gedaref State. Active visceral leishmaniasis case detection had a very low yield in this specific setting with adequate access to care and may not be the priority intervention to enhance control in similar contexts. The study emphasized the need for a combination of early detection, treatment, and indoor residual spraying for effective control of visceral leishmaniasis.
Supercoiling in bacterial DNA is produced by gyrase, which is composed of two types of proteins called GyrA and GyrB. These proteins form an A2B2 tetramer. The supercoiling of DNA has a major impact on the efficiency and phenotype of many proteins involved in DNA replication, chromosome segregation, RNA transcription, and recombination. It is known that supercoiling increases the efficiency of resolution of a site-specific recombination system called γδ in bacteria. This system uses supercoil diffusion to drive the assembly of a precise synapse of repeating sequences. However, supercoiling at multiple locations in the chromosome is difficult to analyze using classical techniques. To measure supercoiling at multiple locations, a 9 kb module called a "supercoil sensor" was developed. It contains an entire Lac operon plus a selectable gentamycin resistance gene flanked by repeating sequences. The sensor can measure resolution efficiency at multiple locations in the chromosome. The authors found that highly expressed genes, like the rrnG operon, act as barriers to supercoil diffusion in the chromosome. When the supercoiling of the rrnG operon was measured in strains with mutations in topoisomerase I and gyrase, it was found that the supercoiling differential increased in regions flanking the rrnG operon. The authors propose a model that RNA polymerase generates two supercoiling domains during transcription. This model suggests that highly expressed genes will have increased (−) supercoiling upstream and decreased (−) supercoiling downstream. The authors tested this model by placing a supercoil sensor upstream and downstream of the rrnG promoter and terminator. They found that the upstream sensor had a higher resolution efficiency than the downstream sensor, confirming the twin domain model. The authors suggest that local supercoiling levels can change dramatically at opposite ends of a highly transcribed operon in cells growing at permissive temperatures. They also found that temperature sensitive mutations in gyrase and topoisomerase I and IV caused significant changes in genome-wide negative supercoil levels, even when cells were grown at a permissive temperature. They suggest that transcription plays a causal role in the supercoil losses because supercoiling rebounded after addition of rifampicin, which blocked transcription initiation. The authors propose a model that suggests that transcription kinetics determine the optimal catalytic speed for gyrase, and the average chromosome supercoil density is an integral function of topoisomerases and RNA polymerase working together.
The human genetic disorder Chediak-Higashi syndrome (CHS) is caused by mutations in the LYST (lysosomal trafficking regulator) gene, which encodes a large cytosolic protein involved in regulating the size of lysosomes and related organelles. LYST/Beige expression is upregulated in CHS patient cells and in beige mouse cells, which lack functional LYST/Beige. LYST/Beige overexpression reduces lysosome size. LYS/Beige may also be involved in regulating the size of other organelles such as late endosomes. LYS/Beige regulates the size of organelles by influencing the activities of kinases and other molecules involved in membrane fusion and fission. LYS/Beige appears to be important for controlling the intracellular growth of Leishmania amazonensis, a parasite causing cutaneous leishmaniasis in the new world. L. amazonensis replicates within very large PVs (parasitophorous vacuoles) in CHS patient cells and in beige mouse cells, when compared to the small PVs found in LYS/Beige-expressing cells. The upregulation of LYS/Beige expression during L. amazonensis infection suggests that LYS/Beige may be involved in controlling the growth of L. amazonensis by inhibiting PV expansion.
The Allan-Herndon-Dudley syndrome (AHDS) is a rare genetic condition that results in severe mental retardation, muscle weakness, spasticity, and speech impairment. It is caused by mutations in the MCT8 gene, which encodes a protein that transports thyroid hormones into cells. To understand the underlying mechanism of AHDS, researchers have used gene-editing techniques to create MCT8-deficient zebrafish. These fish show behavioral deficiencies, including reduced locomotor activity, altered sleep patterns, and impaired responses to light and dark transitions. They also exhibit changes in the expression of genes related to myelination, the process of forming the protective insulating layer around nerve fibers. Furthermore, researchers have found that certain thyroid hormone analogs can partially reverse the behavioral and myelin-related deficiencies in MCT8-deficient zebrafish. These findings suggest that these hormone analogs may be useful for treating AHDS patients.
This paper describes experiments that show that the HCMV gB and gH/gL proteins interact with each other even when gB cannot fuse membranes together. The authors conducted experiments using cell-cell fusion assays and found that gBA154W and gBW240A, two mutant versions of HCMV gB, did not promote cell-cell fusion. However, these mutants still formed complexes with gH/gL. The authors also found that a third mutant version of HCMV gB, gBΔCT, which lacks the entire cytoplasmic domain of gB, also interacted with gH/gL. These results indicate that gB-gH/gL complexes form even when gB is not capable of fusion, and they support the hypothesis that stable gB-gH/gL complexes are present in the virion envelope and may initiate membrane fusion.
The study investigates how certain genes regulate the segregation of different mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) mutations in different tissues. Previous research has shown that certain mtDNA mutations, such as the A3243G mutation, can have different effects on tissues depending on the mutation and tissue. To understand the mechanisms behind this tissue-specific segregation, researchers used a heteroplasmic mouse model with two neutral mtDNA haplotypes derived from two inbred mouse strains. These haplotypes have different preferences for certain tissues. For example, in hematopoietic tissues, the BALB haplotype is preferred over the NZB haplotype, while in the kidney and liver, the NZB haplotype is preferred. The researchers showed that nuclear-encoded genes regulate this segregation process and mapped the quantitative trait loci involved. They also found that certain nuclear backgrounds can completely eliminate the selection for the BALB haplotype in hematopoietic tissues. In this study, the researchers investigated the role of Gimap3, an outer mitochondrial membrane GTPase, in regulating mtDNA segregation in hematopoietic tissues. They showed that Gimap3 is a critical regulator of this process. The study provides important insights into the mechanisms behind tissue-specific segregation of mtDNA mutations.
Buruli ulcer (BU) is a disease caused by bacteria that can cause skin and soft tissue infections. The bacteria are found in the environment, and it is not known exactly how people get infected. However, it is known that the primary risk factor for getting BU is living or traveling in an area where BU is endemic. In the state of Victoria, Australia, most people who get BU are visitors to these areas. A study was done to estimate the incubation period (the time between exposure to an area where BU is endemic and when the first symptoms appear) for BU. Previous estimates of the incubation period have varied widely, from a few weeks to over 5 months. The study looked at 443 cases of BU notified in Victoria between 2013 and 2016. Interviews were conducted with people who had a single visit to an area where BU is endemic or multiple visits within a one-month period. The mean incubation period for these people was 143 days, or about 4.8 months. This is very similar to the previous estimate of 135 days (4.5 months). Despite the predominant exposure location shifting from the Bellarina peninsula to the Mornington peninsula, the study found no association between incubation period and other factors such as age, sex, location of exposure, duration of exposure to an endemic area, or location of the BU lesion. This suggests that the mode of transmission of BU is similar in different geographic regions in Victoria. The knowledge of the mean incubation period of BU in Victoria is important for clinicians and public health officials to understand the disease better.
Toxoplasma, a parasite that lives inside of other cells, has a protein called TgNCR1 that is closely related to a human protein called NPC1. TgNCR1 is involved in the movement of cholesterol and other lipids within the parasite, and mutant parasites that lack this protein have abnormal amounts of certain lipids and can replicate more quickly. This suggests that TgNCR1 plays a key role in regulating lipids in the parasite, and that the parasite needs TgNCR1 to grow and survive.
The paper is about a disorder called Ophthalmo-acromelic syndrome (OAS), which is characterized by the combination of eye malformations, most commonly bilateral anophthalmia (the absence of the eyes), with post-axial oligosyndactyly (having fewer than five fingers on the hands or toes on the feet). The authors report on the identification of a locus on 14q24.2 for OAS with subsequent identification of homozygous, predicted loss-of-function mutations in the SMOC1 gene in eight out of fourteen unrelated families with OAS. Whole-mount in situ hybridization (WISH) combined with optical projection tomography (OPT) shows site- and stage-specific developmental expression of the orthologous mouse gene, Smoc1, in embryonic limb bud and craniofacial structures. The authors also discuss the potential role of SMOC-1 in modulating BMP signaling during eye and limb development.
In this study, the authors investigated how Type 1 interferons, which are part of the immune system and produced by many cell types, block HIV (human immunodeficiency virus) replication. They discovered that a protein called TRIM22 plays a key role in this process. They used transcriptional profiling to find out which cellular genes were induced by interferon treatment and found TRIM22 to be one of the most strongly up-regulated genes. They then confirmed that over-expression of TRIM22 inhibited HIV replication. To study the role of TRIM22 expressed under natural inducing conditions, they compared the effects of interferon in cells depleted for TRIM22 using RNAi (RNA interference) and found that HIV particle release was significantly increased in the knockdown, indicating that TRIM22 acts as a natural antiviral effector. They then studied how TRIM22 inhibited HIV replication and found that it blocked the release of HIV Gag particles. They also found that the RING domain of TRIM22 was required for its antiviral activity. The authors' findings provide new insights into how Type 1 interferons block HIV replication.
The fig-pollinator mutualism is a fascinating example of how cooperation can be sustained in the face of competition. By pollinating fig trees, wasps help disperse their pollen and promote seed production, while the trees provide resources for the wasps. However, the wasps are not passive pollinators, as they also parasitize the figs by laying eggs inside the ovules, which then develop into galls. A recent study has shown that parasitism pressure is not only a factor that affects the fitness of foundresses, but it also plays a role in the stability of the mutualism. The study found that parasitic wasps are more likely to attack inner ovules, which have a higher profitability to foundresses because they are less vulnerable to parasitism. This is due to the spatial segregation of parasites, pollinators, and seeds within the figs, which favors the development of galls in the inner ovules. The study also found that parasitic wasps contribute to the overall mechanisms that enable the mutualism to remain stable across Ficus species. This highlights the importance of considering multiple factors in understanding the stability of ecological interactions, especially those involving parasitism.
Plants grow differently depending on their genes and the environment they are in. Water, space, and time all affect how tall they will be. Researchers studied a type of grass plant called Setaria to learn more about how these factors affect plant height. They found that height is a complex trait that is influenced by multiple genes and can change depending on the environment. The researchers discovered that the genes that affect height in Setaria are different from the ones that affect height in other grasses. They also found that the effects of the genes that affect height are different at different times of plant development. These results show that researchers can better understand how to control plant height by studying how genes and the environment interact to affect plant growth.
The study aimed to confirm the circulation of Ilheus virus (ILHV) in the Pantanal wetlands of Brazil. ILHV is a virus that can cause encephalitis in humans, but is usually spread through zoonotic cycles between birds and mosquitoes. A total of 3234 mosquitoes were collected from the Nhecolândia sub-region of the Pantanal in 2009 and 2010. The mosquitoes were tested for ILHV RNA and virus isolation. ILHV RNA was detected in one pool of 50 non-engorged female mosquitoes of Aedes scapularis, indicating a minimum infection rate of 2.5 per 1000 mosquitoes. Full-length genomic sequence of the virus was obtained and found to have 95% identity to the only full genome sequence available for ILHV. This study confirms the circulation of ILHV in the Brazilian Pantanal.
Scabies is a common dermatological condition that is largely ignored as a public health issue. However, it can cause notable morbidity, especially in vulnerable populations, such as young children, Aboriginals in Northern Australia, and Fiji islands. Additionally, scabies outbreaks are common in institutions, underprivileged populations, and immunocompromised individuals. There are currently limited treatments for scabies, and the few available drugs, such as permethrin, benzyl benzoate, crotamiton, and malathion, are mostly topical agents. Ivermectin (IVM) is the only oral drug available for scabies. However, it has a short half-life and requires multiple treatments. In addition, there have been reports of resistance to IVM and permethrin, making it even more difficult to treat scabies. Moxidectin (MOX) is another macrocyclic lactone that has better pharmaco- and toxicokinetic profiles compared to IVM. A preclinical study was conducted to establish the efficacy, toxicity, and pharmacokinetics of MOX compared to IVM. The study used a porcine scabies model developed by Mounsey et al. In this study, 12 pigs were randomly assigned to receive either MOX (0.3 mg/kg once) or IVM (0.2 mg/kg twice) or no treatment. Efficacy was determined by assessing mite count, clinical lesions, pruritus, and ELISA-determined anti-S. scabiei IgG antibodies. The study found that MOX was more effective than IVM, with 100% efficacy compared to 62% for IVM. In addition, MOX persisted in the plasma and skin for a longer time, enabling long-lasting efficacy. The study suggests that MOX may be a potential therapeutic approach for scabies.
The paper "Identification of the Minimal Protein Composition of the Bacterial Peptidoglycan Synthesis Machine" by Rodriguez-Rubio et al. is about the study of how a particular kind of bacteria called Staphylococcus aureus makes a substance called peptidoglycan (PG), which is important for the structure of the bacteria's cell wall. The researchers wanted to understand more about how PG is made, so they tried to figure out what proteins are needed for this process to happen. They deleted genes from the S. aureus genome that encode proteins involved in PG synthesis, and then tested how the bacteria grew and functioned. They found that the bacteria could still make PG with just two proteins, PBP1 and bi-functional PBP2, which are involved in the last stages of PG synthesis. However, these bacteria were less able to fight off antibiotics and other threats, and were also less able to infect flies. This study shows that even though some proteins may not be essential for the basic function of the PG synthesis machine, they are still important for the bacteria to survive and cause infections in natural environments like a host.
Burkholderia pseudomallei is a bacterium that can cause a disease called melioidosis in humans. It can also survive in soil and water. To grow, B . pseudomallei needs iron, which is available in very low amounts in soil, water, and even in the blood of animals and people. To get enough iron, B . pseudomallei uses different ways to get it from its environment. These ways include using a type of iron-binding molecule called a siderophore and taking in heme from blood. Researchers have found that a bacterial gene called mba is responsible for making a type of siderophore called malleobactin, which helps B . pseudomallei get the iron it needs to survive. They have also found that another type of siderophore called pyochelin is made by a different gene called pch. The researchers made mutant versions of the bacteria that could not make these siderophores. They found that these mutant versions were still able to survive and cause disease in animals. This means that the bacteria do not need the siderophores to cause disease, and that there may be other ways for them to get the iron they need. The researchers also found that the bacteria need another gene called hmu to be able to take in iron from hemoglobin, which is a protein found in blood that carries oxygen. They also found that the bacteria need another gene called hem to be able to take in iron from heme, which is a protein found in blood that carries oxygen. The researchers made mutant versions of the bacteria that could not use these genes. They found that these mutant versions were able to survive and cause disease in animals, which means that the bacteria do not need these genes to cause disease, and that there may be other ways for them to get the iron they need. The researchers also found that the bacteria can also use a type of iron that is found in ferritin, another protein found in blood that carries oxygen. This means that the bacteria may have a new way to get the iron they need to survive and cause disease.
Metabolic models are important in understanding how organisms function. However, they often contain inconsistencies and errors. COMMGEN is a tool that can automatically identify these inconsistencies and generate consensus metabolic models. These consensus models are more consistent and accurate than individual models, and they can be used in a variety of metabolic simulations. The authors tested COMMGEN on four different organisms and showed that the generated consensus models were more consistent and accurate than individual models. They also showed that the consensus models retained their predictive capabilities. Overall, COMMGEN is a valuable tool for generating more comprehensive and accurate metabolic models.
In this study, we found that certain proteins called proteoglycans (PGs) in cartilage help regulate the timing of bone growth. To do this, we used zebrafish mutants to study how PGs affect interactions between chondrocytes (cells that make up cartilage) and other cells around them. We found that when we mutate genes that make these PGs, chondrocytes start to make bone instead of cartilage. This happens because the chondrocytes start to mature too early, which leads to bone growth happening too soon. We then used various techniques to show that these mutant chondrocytes are behaving in a way that makes them look like they're starting to make bone, even though they're still supposed to be making cartilage. This means that the mutant chondrocytes are maturing too early, which is why bone growth happens too soon. We also studied how these mutations affect other cells around the chondrocytes, like the perichondrium, which is a thin layer of cells that surrounds the developing cartilage. We found that these mutations also affect how these perichondrial cells behave, which helps explain how the mutant chondrocytes start to make bone too soon. Overall, our study suggests that certain proteins called proteoglycans are important for regulating the timing of bone growth, and that mutations in genes that make these proteins can cause bone growth to happen too soon.
This study looked at how a specific type of DNA, called heterochromatin, is separated during meiosis in fruit flies. The researchers used RNA interference (RNAi) to knock down the levels of a protein called Topoisomerase II, which helps separate DNA. They found that when Topoisomerase II levels are knocked down, heterochromatic regions do not separate as well during meiosis and the fruit flies have trouble completing their meiosis. This study shows that Topoisomerase II plays an important role in separating heterochromatin during meiosis in fruit flies.
Visceral leishmaniasis (VL) is a serious and deadly disease spread by sand flies that affects humans and dogs. The current control measures are ineffective and expensive, which is why researchers are testing an alternative approach. They tested a collar that is impregnated with a chemical repellent and placed it on dogs to protect them from being bitten by sand flies. The collar was found to be effective in reducing the risk of getting VL in dogs.
The study investigates the hypothesis that the X chromosome's unusual gene content is shaped by limits imposed on gene expression due to the X chromosome's haploid expression. The study uses data from the Functional Annotation of the Mammalian Genome (FANTOM5) project and The Encyclopedia of DNA Elements (ENCODE) to test this hypothesis. The study finds that the maximal expression of human X-linked genes is much lower than that of genes on autosomes. The study also finds that autosome-to-X retroposition events are associated with lower maximal expression of retrogenes on the X than seen for X-to-autosome retrogenes on autosomes. The study concludes that the traffic jam model provides a simple and robustly supported rationale for many peculiar features of X's gene content, gene expression, and evolution.
Helicobacter pylori is a bacterium that infects the stomach lining of humans. It was first discovered in the 1980s in patients with gastric ulcers. Since then, it has become clear that almost everyone in the world is infected with this bacteria, and that the infection is often asymptomatic. The bacterium has been found in three different African populations and one European population. These populations are called hpAfrica2, hpNEAfrica, hpAfrica1, and hpEurasia. The study discussed in this article focused on the H. pylori populations found in two populations of Baka Pygmies in Cameroon. The authors found that the prevalence of H. pylori in the Baka was much lower than in their neighboring non-Baka agriculturalist populations, and that the H. pylori population in the Baka did not define a new lineage. This suggests that the Baka acquired their H. pylori from their agriculturalist neighbors. The authors also used genetic analysis to determine the age of the H. pylori lineage in the Baka. They found that the lineage was relatively recent and had been acquired by the Baka after their contact with the agriculturalist populations. This study provides important information about the spread of H. pylori in different human populations, and highlights the role of demographic factors such as population size and life expectancy in the eradication of the bacteria from certain populations.
Dengue virus NS5 is a key protein for virus replication. It has been shown to localize to the nucleus or cytoplasm depending on the serotype. In this study, researchers used a combination of functional and structural analyses to determine the region responsible for this localization difference. They found that the C-terminal 18 residues (Cter18) alone were sufficient to direct the protein to the nucleus or cytoplasm. The researchers then used X-ray crystallography and mutational analysis to identify residues important for NS5 subcellular localization. They found that the Cter18 region plays a crucial role in RNA interactions, which are critical for replication. They also found that mutating a proline residue in DENV1 NS5 to a threonine led to mislocalization of NS5 to the cytoplasm, while a mutation to alanine in a conserved residue led to a completely non-viable virus. These findings suggest that the NS5 Cter18 region has an evolutionarily conserved function that is important for replication and pathogenesis.
The paper describes a new methodology to map neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) in a way that saves resources by identifying populations that need treatment. The methodology, called Integrated Threshold Mapping (ITM) Methodology, is designed to be efficient and to determine whether a disease has reached a threshold for public health intervention. The ITM methodology relies on the World Health Organization's recommended indicators for each disease in specific age groups, and uses a district or sub-district as the sampling frame for each disease. The methodology was tested in one district each in Mali and Senegal and found to reach the same conclusions as the standard WHO methodologies regarding the initiation of public health interventions for trachoma, LF, and STH. However, the ITM methodology resulted in more targeted intervention recommendations for schistosomiasis. The methodology was found to be practical, feasible and demonstrated an overall cost saving compared with the standard, non-integrated, WHO methodologies. The paper concludes that the ITM methodology could facilitate the implementation of programs in endemic countries.
The paper describes the process of releasing a protein called Cdc14 from the nucleolus during anaphase of the cell cycle. This protein is essential for exiting mitosis. Two mechanisms, the FEAR (Cdc14 early anaphase release) network and the MEN (mitotic exit network), are known to promote Cdc14 release. The paper presents new evidence that the Bre1 ubiquitin ligase is required for Cdc14 release during early anaphase, when the MEN is inactive. This function is mediated by the activation of histone H3 methylation on lysines 4 and 79 (meH3K4 and meH3K79) by the Bre1 ubiquitin ligase. The paper also suggests that this function for H3 methylation is not dependent on the histone deacetylase Sir2, which is part of the RENT (regulator of nucleolar silencing and telophase exit) complex. Additionally, the paper shows that the process is not due to aberrant regulation of known FEAR network components and can be extended to other histone modifications.
We present a novel computational methodology, GeneProgram, designed to analyze large compendia of human gene expression data. The algorithm simultaneously compresses sets of genes into expression programs and sets of tissues into groups. GeneProgram addresses challenges arising from tissue inhomogeneity, patchy origin of samples, and uncertainty in the number of tissue groups and expression programs. The algorithm infers a set of biologically interpretable expression programs and automatically discovers coherent tissue groups. GeneProgram has revealed a large number of expression programs involved in key signaling pathways and bound by NF-κB transcription factor family members.
The study explores the mechanisms underlying IFN-gamma expression in memory-like features of NK cells. The authors show that only NKG2C-expressing NK cells undergo epigenetic remodeling of the IFNG locus, which leads to enhanced and stable IFN-gamma expression. The study provides a molecular basis for the regulation of adaptive features in innate cells, such as NK cells, and highlights the role of epigenetic mechanisms in controlling IFN-gamma expression.
Pathogen-associated secretion systems are used by bacteria to enter and manipulate host cells. Legionella LubX protein is an effector that works as an E3 ubiquitin ligase to regulate the function of another effector, SidH, within the host cell. The regulation of these effectors by LubX occurs through a process called spatiotemporal control, which involves the delivery of the LubX protein to the host cytoplasm at different stages of infection. The regulation of these effectors by LubX is an example of the complex ways that bacteria and host cells interact and coevolve during infection.
HIV-1 is a virus that changes quickly when it infects a new person. In this study, researchers analyzed how quickly HIV-1 changed in 81 people who were recently infected with the virus. By comparing the viruses in these people to the viruses that infected them, the researchers could see which parts of the virus changed most quickly. They found that certain parts of the virus changed more quickly than others. In some cases, the virus seemed to be changing in a way that made it harder for the body's immune system to recognize it. The researchers also looked at how the virus changed in terms of its size. They found that the virus seemed to be changing its size in a way that made it more difficult for the body's immune system to recognize it. Overall, the study provides important information about how HIV-1 changes when it infects a new person and how it evolves to escape the body's immune system.
Our study aims to understand the silencing mechanism of yeast's heterochromatin, which regulates gene expression. To do this, we developed a computer model that incorporates known molecular interactions in the system, focusing on the epigenetic marks H4K16 acetylation and H3K79 methylation. Our model reveals that having both marks is important for robustness of the silencing system. The model also shows that the presence of multiple marks can lead to bivalent states, where some chromatin regions have both active and silencing marks. This is important for understanding the controversial role of Dot1, which methylates H3K79. Finally, the model helps us understand why Sir protein recruitment, spreading and stability of silenced regions in mutants all play important roles in the yeast silencing system.
Malnutrition is a major issue in developing countries and affects many children. Malnutrition can be divided into two types: oedematous and non-oedematous. Oedematous malnutrition is characterized by swelling and can be life-threatening in its most severe form, kwashiorkor. The causes of oedematous malnutrition are not fully understood, but it has been linked to gut microbiota (GM) dysbiosis. In this study, the researchers compared the GM of Ugandan children with oedematous and non-oedematous malnutrition. The children were hospitalized with severe acute malnutrition aged 6-24 months. Fecal samples were collected at admission, and the researchers used various techniques to analyze the GM composition. They found that non-oedematous malnutrition children had lower GM diversity compared to oedematous malnutrition children, but there were no clear differences in GM composition between the two groups.
The length of telomeres in yeast varies among individuals and is controlled by multiple loci. In a study, researchers screened 112 wild-type Saccharomyces sensu stricto isolates and found extensive telomere length variation in S. paradoxus isolates. The length of telomeres varies depending on the geographic origin of the isolates, with European strains having extremely short telomeres and American isolates having telomeres approximately three times as long. The study also found variation in telomere position effect (TPE) which is weakly correlated with telomere length. Researchers also identified several quantitative trait loci (QTLs) associated with telomere length and silencing variation. They validated their findings by reciprocal hemizygosity and suggested that sequence divergence within the Ku heterodimer generates negative epistasis within one of the allelic combinations. Overall, this study provides insights into the complex genetic mechanisms underlying telomere length variation in yeast.
Many decisions are made based on multiple pieces of information that are gathered over time. This type of decision-making process is not directly observable, but can significantly affect behavior. To capture this process, researchers use a model called a sequential sampling model (SSM), which assumes that decisions are made after an evidence accumulation process that lasts until a certain threshold is reached. However, the standard SSM does not account for the possibility that people may choose not to decide and may delay their responses. In a recent study, researchers used EEG and fMRI to investigate value-based decision-making in the brain. Participants were asked to buy or reject stocks based on probabilistic information sampled sequentially, and were free to make their decision at any time. The researchers developed an SSM variant that accurately predicted which choice was made and how many ratings were sampled. However, the model did not specify the exact timing of the decision. To address this issue, the researchers proposed a new SSM that allows for the possibility of a decision not to decide, which can temporarily stop the accumulation process. They supported this model with evidence from time-frequency analysis of the EEG data, which showed that the decision not to decide was accompanied by an increase in beta-band oscillatory power, indicating active inhibition of motor responses. Finally, the researchers tested their model experimentally by adapting the task so that the decision to sample more information was explicit, and found that the new SSM accurately predicted the data.
Hereditary Nasal Parakeratosis (HNPK) is a genetic condition that affects the skin of Labrador Retrievers, causing crusts and fissures on the nasal planum. A genome-wide association study (GWAS) was performed using 13 cases and 23 controls. The analysis identified a single strong association signal on chromosome 2. By sequencing the genome of one case at 38× coverage, three non-synonymous variants in the critical interval were identified. Only one variant was perfectly associated with the HNPK phenotype in a larger cohort of dogs. This variant is a missense mutation in the SUV39H2 gene, which encodes a histone 3 lysine 9 (H3K9) methyltransferase that mediates chromatin silencing. The variant is predicted to change an evolutionary conserved asparagine into a lysine in the catalytically active domain of the enzyme. The authors studied the histopathological alterations in the epidermis in vivo and found that the HNPK phenotype is not caused by hyperproliferation but rather delayed terminal differentiation of keratinocytes. This study provides evidence that SUV39H2 is involved in the epigenetic regulation of keratinocyte differentiation, ensuring proper stratification and tight sealing of the mammalian epidermis.
Influenza A viruses (IAVs) are contagious viruses that infect many different animals, including humans. These viruses are divided into different subtypes based on their surface proteins. Researchers have found that swine have both avian and human-like receptors on their respiratory tissue cells, making them a possible "mixing vessel" for creating new subtypes of IAVs through genetic reassortments with avian and human IAVs. However, it is not clear how a transmissible reassortant virus emerges in swine. In this study, the authors analyzed 571 IAV samples taken from the nasal passages and respiratory tissues of a group of feral swine that were co-infected with avian and swine IAVs. They found 30 distinct genotypes of reassortant viruses and identified the ones that were transmissible between pigs. The authors also determined the locations where these reassortant viruses were most likely to be found and how they grew in different types of respiratory tissue cells. Their findings suggest that the tissue tropism, or preference for growing in certain types of cells, is an important factor in selecting for a transmissible reassortant virus.
The study investigates whether maternal schistosomiasis infection and its treatment during pregnancy can influence the immune response of children when they are exposed to the same parasite later in life. The study involved offspring of 1343 women who were infected with the schistosome worm (S. mansoni) during pregnancy. The study found that the offspring of women who received praziquantel treatment during pregnancy had a higher IL-10 response to SWA, indicating that maternal schistosomiasis and its treatment during pregnancy may affect the development of immunoregulatory responses in childhood schistosomiasis.
Macrophages play a key role in fighting infections, but they can become overwhelmed and not be able to destroy enough pathogens to stop an infection. In this study, the authors found that when macrophages are exposed to certain stimuli, they change the way they take in material from their surroundings. Instead of taking in material through a process called receptor-mediated phagocytosis, where the material is brought in using specific receptors, the macrophages take in large amounts of material through a process called macropinocytosis. The authors found that this change in behavior is caused by a protein called coronin 1 being phosphorylated by a protein kinase called protein kinase C. This phosphorylation causes coronin 1 to relocate within the macrophage cell and switch the internalization process from receptor-mediated phagocytosis to macropinocytosis. This change allows macrophages to take in and destroy large amounts of material more efficiently.
This study assessed community knowledge and perceptions of tsetse baits (traps, targets) in villages where they had or had not been used previously in Uganda. The study found that while villages in close proximity had different perceptions of tsetse baits, villagers who had never seen traps before expressed fear and anxiety when they first encountered them. This was related to traditional beliefs that associated tsetse flies with physical or mental illness, death, and misfortune. By contrast, villagers living in areas where traps had been used previously had positive attitudes towards them and were fully aware of their purpose and benefits. The success of community-based tsetse control interventions therefore depends on early engagements with communities and carefully designed sensitization campaigns that reach all communities.
Researchers have created the first detailed map of recombination events across the entire genome of Drosophila melanogaster, a fruit fly species. They used high-resolution genetic mapping techniques to detect over 106,000 recombination events, with a median distance of less than 2 kilobases between each event and the nearest informative single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP). This is a significant improvement over previous genetic maps, which had much lower resolution and were based on fewer recombination events. The researchers also distinguished between two types of recombination events: crossing over and gene conversion. Crossing over is a process in which a strand of DNA from one parent is swapped with a strand of DNA from the other parent, while gene conversion is a process in which a small section of DNA is swapped between parents. The researchers found that recombination events occur at different rates across the genome and within the population of Drosophila melanogaster. They also observed significant intra-specific variation in recombination rates and landscapes, which may have important implications for the evolution of this species.
In this article, the authors identify the component of the RNA-directed DNA methylation (RdDM) machinery in Arabidopsis thaliana. They use affinity purification to purify the component and then use it to identify other components of the RdDM machinery. They also determine the function of each component by introducing them into a mutant plant and observing the effect on the RdDM machinery. They show that the previously uncharacterized XH domain of IDN2 is required for the formation of the IDN2-IDP1/IDP2 complex, which is required for the RdDM machinery to function properly. They also show that IDP1 is required for de novo DNA methylation and transcriptional gene silencing, while IDP2 has partially overlapping roles with IDP1.
Neutrophils are the body's first line of defense against invading pathogens. When Leishmania parasites invade a body, neutrophils are quickly recruited to the site of infection. In this study, we investigated how neutrophils respond to Leishmania braziliensis infection. We found that exposure of neutrophils to Leishmania parasites led to their activation and release of inflammatory mediators such as TNF-α and neutrophil elastase. We also observed that neutrophils infected with Leishmania parasites displayed early markers of apoptosis. Overall, our study suggests that neutrophils play an important role in the early stages of Leishmania braziliensis infection.
This paper explores the potential of vaccination to help control bovine tuberculosis (bTB) in cattle using a mathematical model. Currently, vaccination against bTB is not used in any international control program, and it is illegal in the EU. However, researchers are developing new diagnostic tests that can differentiate between vaccinated and infected animals. These diagnostic tests, called DIVA tests, could be used in combination with vaccination. The paper uses a mathematical model to explore how different DIVA tests could impact the use of vaccination in bTB control. The authors find that the specificity of the DIVA test, rather than its sensitivity, is the most important factor in determining whether vaccination can provide a protective economic benefit at the herd level. They also find that DIVA test characteristics can be optimized to achieve this. The authors suggest that the EU could consider relaxing testing requirements to mitigate the negative economic impact of DIVA testing.
Trichuriasis is a parasitic infection caused by a whipworm called Trichuris trichiura that affects around 500 million people worldwide. The most common drugs used to treat trichuriasis are albendazole and mebendazole, but they are not effective against all types of Trichuris. Scientists have been looking for new drugs to treat trichuriasis. Using a lab model of Trichuris muris, a type of whipworm, scientists screened 480 drugs and found a new class of molecules that paralyze the adult parasite. These molecules, called dihydrobenzoxazepinones, also reduce the ability of the eggs to infect a host. These findings suggest that the dihydrobenzoxazepinones could be used as new drugs to treat trichuriasis.
This study challenges the idea that hubs in protein–protein interaction networks can be categorized into two distinct groups based on their co-expression patterns. The study found that the reported importance of date hubs to network connectivity can be attributed to a small subset of these hubs, and that these few extremely central hubs do not display particularly low expression correlation. The previous study by Han et al. proposed that date hubs are global connectors while party hubs are local coordinators. However, this distinction was based on an approximately bimodal distribution of hub co-expression which the study shows is not always robust to methodological changes. The study also suggests that thinking in terms of a date/party dichotomy for hubs in protein interaction networks is not meaningful, and it might be more useful to conceive of roles for protein-protein interactions rather than for individual proteins. The study also shows that there is little correlation between interaction centrality and the functional similarity of the interacting proteins. Instead, it suggests thinking about topological roles in networks by defining measures on links rather than on nodes. The study examines the properties of yeast and human interaction networks and finds that the observed differences in network vulnerability to attacks on the two hub types seem to arise from only a small number of particularly important hubs. The study also shows that a detailed analysis of network topology, employing the novel perspective of community structure and the roles of hubs within this context, suggests that the picture is more complicated than a simple dichotomy. Proteins in the interactome show a variety of topological characteristics that appear to lie along a continuum and there does not exist a clear correlation between their location on this continuum and the avPCC of expression of their interaction partners. On the other hand, investigating link (interaction) betweenness centralities reveals an interesting relation to the functional linkage of proteins, suggesting that a framework incorporating a more nuanced notion of roles for both nodes and links might provide a better framework for understanding the organization of the interactome.
This study introduces the concept of "transmission divergence," which is the number of mutations separating whole genome sequences sampled from transmission pairs. The authors simulate outbreak scenarios alongside sequence evolution using two models described in the literature to describe transmission divergence of ten major outbreak-causing pathogens. They find that while mean values vary significantly between the pathogens considered, their transmission divergence is generally very low, with many outbreaks characterized by large numbers of genetically identical transmission pairs. The authors describe the impact of transmission divergence on the ability to reconstruct outbreaks using two outbreak reconstruction tools, the R packages outbreaker and phybreak. They demonstrate that genetic sequence data of rapidly evolving pathogens such as RNA viruses can provide valuable information on individual transmission events, while sequence data of pathogens with lower mean transmission divergence, including Streptococcus pneumoniae, Shigella sonnei, and Clostridium difficile, provide little to no information about individual transmission events. The authors highlight the informational limitations of genetic sequence data in certain outbreak scenarios and demonstrate the need to expand the toolkit of outbreak reconstruction tools to integrate other types of epidemiological data.
In mammals, there are two X chromosomes in females and only one in males. To make sure that females have the same number of chromosomes as males, one of the X chromosomes is randomly turned off (inactivated) in females. However, not all genes on the X chromosome are turned off. In this study, the authors used RNA-seq to measure the levels of expression of genes on the X chromosome in different tissues in female mice. They also used RNA-seq to measure the levels of expression of the same genes in male mice. By comparing the levels of expression in males and females, the authors were able to determine which genes are turned off and which genes are still turned on (escaping inactivation). They also used a new method to analyze the data from RNA-seq and estimate the probability of a gene being turned on. The authors used this method to identify common genes that escape inactivation and tissue-specific genes that escape inactivation. They also used other techniques, such as RT-PCR, to confirm their results.
In this study, we found a new enzyme that is important for malaria parasite growth and survival. This enzyme is called "vivapain-4" (or VX-4) and is similar to other enzymes called "cysteine proteases" that have been found in other malaria parasites. These enzymes are used by the parasite to break down food and to break down structures in the cell. VX-4 is different from other cysteine proteases in that it has a unique ability to switch between two different ways of breaking down food depending on the pH (acidic or basic) of the environment. This may be important for the parasite to be able to survive and grow in different parts of the body, where the pH is different. VX-4 also has the ability to break down other enzymes, which could help the parasite to break down food more efficiently. This enzyme may be useful for treating malaria because it is important for the parasite to survive and grow.
Acetogens are bacteria that can use carbon dioxide (CO2), hydrogen (H2), or a mixture of hydrogen and carbon monoxide (CO) called syngas to produce multi-carbon chemicals. These microorganisms are promising for alternative biotechnological production of commodity chemicals. However, their physiology and ability to accurately predict phenotypes are incomplete, hindering advanced design strategies. Therefore, a genome-scale model of metabolism and macromolecular synthesis (ME-model) was reconstructed for the model acetogen Clostridium ljungdahlii. The ME-model represents the first of its kind for a Gram-positive bacterium and captures all major central metabolic, amino acid, nucleotide, lipid, major cofactors, and vitamin synthesis pathways as well as pathways to synthesis RNA and protein molecules necessary to catalyze these reactions, thus significantly broadening the scope and predictability. The model accurately predicted secretion of acetate, ethanol, and glycerol during changing carbon and metal availability and revealed how protein allocation and media composition influence metabolic pathways and energy conservation in this model acetogen. Furthermore, predicting overflow metabolism enables new design strategies such as glycerol formation as a novel product for C. ljungdahlii, thus broadening its metabolic capability. Predicting changing secretion rates based on different metal availability provides new knowledge about the proteome utilization and carbon flux in acetogens and opens the window into fermentation optimization.
The article discusses the use of large panels of human osteoblasts (bone-building cells) to study the relationship between genetic variation and the expression of different isoforms of the same gene. The authors used these cells to perform a transcriptomic survey, which is similar to a study done on lymphoblastoid cells (immortalized immune cells) in the past. They found that genetic variants can be associated with changes in the expression of different isoforms of the same gene, and that some of these isoform variations are tissue-specific. This finding is important for understanding the genetic basis of diseases such as osteoporosis, which affects bone health. The authors compared their results with a previous study that looked at the relationship between genetic variation and gene expression in lymphoblastoid cells. They also compared their results with a recent study that looked at the relationship between genetic variation and gene expression in brain and peripheral blood mononuclear cells. Finally, the authors selected one example of a gene with a novel isoform variation that may be important for bone biology to follow up with more detailed studies.
This study aimed to understand how maltotriose utilization evolved in a strain of Saccharomyces eubayanus that does not naturally utilize it. The study used a combination of mutagenesis and laboratory evolution to select for strains with improved maltotriose utilization. The researchers discovered a novel maltotriose transporter gene, SeMalT413, in one of the evolved strains, and they also found evidence for gene neofunctionalization through a mosaic structure of the gene, with parts of the gene coming from different sources. Overall, the study sheds light on the evolution of maltotriose utilization in Saccharomyces eubayanus and suggests that gene duplication and recombination events play a role in this process.
Influenza viruses cause significant morbidity and mortality every season. Different strains of influenza viruses have emerged throughout history with varying mortality impacts. There are different approaches to assessing the impact of influenza viruses on human death. However, it is difficult to predict the mortality burden of a new influenza virus at the early stage of infection. In this study, researchers found a positive correlation between the antigenic distance of influenza viruses and their mortality burden. The mortality burden can be estimated by predicting the antigenic distance between influenza A (H1N1) strains based on their HA sequences. This study provides a method to rapidly estimate the mortality burden of influenza A (H1N1) virus, which can help develop cost-effective control and intervention strategies.
The Asian soybean rust fungus, Phakopsora pachyrhizi, causes severe soybean disease epidemics. It is an obligate biotrophic pathogen that interacts with its host plant using many small, secreted cysteine-rich proteins (SSCRPs). However, the roles of these SSCRPs are unknown. In this study, we investigated the role of one of these proteins, PpEC23, in suppressing plant immunity. We show that PpEC23 interacts with soybean transcription factor GmSPL12l and that soybean plants in which GmSPL12l is silenced have constitutively active immunity. This suggests that PpEC23 is able to suppress soybean immune responses and physically interact with soybean transcription factor GmSPL12l, a negative immune regulator.
Chlamydia trachomatis, a type of bacteria that causes sexually transmitted infections and respiratory diseases, invades cells to replicate and cause infections. The bacteria interact with cell surface receptors to attach and enter the cells. One such receptor is EphrinA2, which activates the PI3 kinase signaling pathway, which is necessary for efficient replication of Chlamydia. The bacteria internalize EphrinA2 along with its activation signal and keep it near the site of replication. If EphrinA2 is blocked or removed from the cell surface, Chlamydia cannot efficiently replicate and the infected cells are more likely to undergo apoptosis. Therefore, Chlamydia subverts EphrinA2 to promote its own replication and survival.
Dendritic trees are the extensions of neurons that receive signals from other neurons. Many studies have tried to understand the function of these active dendritic conductances. The authors propose a simpler hypothesis that explains the main function of these conductances: they increase the dynamic range of the neuron. The authors used a model to study the dendritic tree as an excitable system. They found that the system has a very large dynamic range, up to 50 dB. This means that the neuron can handle five orders of magnitude of stimulus intensity. This is much better than what was previously observed in other network topologies. The authors claim that this high dynamic range is due to the branching structure of the tree. They also observed that the neuron's transfer function does not need to be simply a saturating curve, but can also have a double-sigmoid behavior. The authors claim that this is because of the non-linear interactions among dendritic spikes. They also observed that dendritic spikes could be responsible for the double-sigmoid behavior of the transfer function. The authors claim that the only reason why neurons have active dendrites is because they need to work with a large stimulus range. This is because they have a large number of afferent synapses and large variability of input rates.
The study looks at how to use gene expression data from transcriptomics experiments to infer regulatory interactions and build models of gene regulation. However, commonly-made assumptions in this process are often not valid, leading to biased results. The authors used a combination of models and experiments to investigate the importance of these assumptions. They used a genetic circuit known as the FliA-FlgM module of the E. coli motility network to measure protein concentrations and global physiological effects in real-time. The results show that correcting for the bias of these assumptions improves the quality of the models inferred from the data. The authors also show that these improvements are expected to be stronger for systems where protein concentrations have longer half-lives or where global physiological effects vary more strongly across conditions. This approach is broadly applicable when using time-series transcriptome data to learn about the structure and dynamics of regulatory networks. In the case of the FliA-FlgM module, the authors show that protein concentrations and global physiological effects are important for the dynamics of FliA-dependent promoters.
This paper focuses on the study of Oligoryzomys fulvescens, a rodent species that is an important reservoir host of the Choclo virus in Central America. The authors analyzed the spatial and temporal distribution of O. fulvescens using different statistical methods in a study conducted in the community of Agua Buena in Tonosí, Panama, between April 2006 and December 2009. They found that O. fulvescens had heterogeneous population densities and degrees of dispersion that varied across seasons and among years. Spatial autocorrelation analyses indicated that local populations of O. fulvescens encompassed approximately 300-600 meters.
