The authors concluded that the Choclo virus transmission risk in this area was associated with the spatial and temporal dynamics of O. fulvescens, which were affected by seasonality and anthropogenic pressures.
Influenza viruses are a major cause of death and disease worldwide. They are constantly evolving, leading to the emergence of new strains that can evade pre-existing host immunity. To make efficient vaccines against influenza viruses, it is important to understand their evolutionary path. A new method has been developed that can predict the antigenic impact of amino acid changes in the viral surface protein hemagglutinin. This method is based on inferring an "antigenic tree" for hemagglutinin, where the antigenic weight is assigned to each branch of the tree. This allows for a more fine-grained resolution of the antigenic impact of individual amino acid changes. The method was applied to hemagglutinin sequences and serological data from human influenza A (H3N2) viral isolates from 1968 to 2003. It identified the amino acid changes associated with antigenic type transitions and known and novel key HA sites. This new method could help in the development of more effective influenza vaccines.
A new study is introducing a new method to understand how HPV (human papillomavirus) infects cells. This method uses RNAi technology to identify genes that are important for HPV infection. The study found that the virus needs the nuclear envelope to break down during mitosis to get into the nucleus. This is important because it explains why HPV can only infect cells that are dividing. This new method of studying HPV infection is important for developing new treatments for HPV-related diseases.
Black Sigatoka is a serious disease that affects banana crops worldwide. It is caused by a fungus called Pseudocercospora fijiensis. The disease is difficult to manage and requires frequent fungicide treatments, which are costly and environmentally damaging. The genome of Pseudocercospora fijiensis has been sequenced, and it is found to be extremely large and expanded by LTR retrotransposons. This could be an advantage for the fungus to adapt and evolve to different environments. Melting-curve assays and analyses of molecular markers suggest that two other fungi in the Sigatoka disease complex also have expanded genomes. The genome sequence will be useful for developing better methods to manage the disease and improve banana breeding programs.
In this paper, the authors present a novel method to study the evolution of regulatory elements in the human genome, specifically the binding sites of transcription factors. Using a birth-death model, the authors analyzed the evolution of binding sites for six transcription factors (GATA1, SOX2, CTCF, MYC, MAX, and ETS1) along the lineage toward human after the human-mouse common ancestor. The authors found that a substantial fraction of binding sites in humans have origins since the divergence with mouse, and that over 15% of all binding sites are unique to hominids. These lineage-specific regulatory elements are often enriched near genes associated with specific pathways and harbor more common SNPs than older binding sites in the human genome. These results support the ability of the method to identify lineage-specific regulatory elements and help understand their roles in shaping variation in gene regulation across species.
The zebrafish is a unique animal model for studying how the circadian clock is entrained by light. Unlike mammals, most of its tissues respond directly to light, leading to local clock entrainment. Light induces the expression of a set of genes, including certain clock genes, in most zebrafish cell types in vivo and in vitro. The zebrafish period2 (per2) gene is one of the clock genes whose expression is induced by light. In this study, researchers used transgenic fish and stably transfected cell line-based assays to define a Light Responsive Module (LRM) within the per2 promoter, which is both necessary and sufficient for light-driven gene expression and also for a light-dependent circadian clock regulation. The LRM lies proximal to the transcription start site and contains E- and D-box elements that are critical for its function. The human LRM can substitute for the zebrafish LRM to confer light-regulated transcription in zebrafish cells. Furthermore, the researchers discovered that the zebrafish homolog of the thyrotroph embryonic factor (TEF) binds efficiently to the LRM D-box and transactivates expression. TEF mRNA levels are light inducible, and knock-down of TEF expression attenuates light-driven transcription from the per2 promoter in vivo. Together, the findings suggest that a light-dependent crosstalk between E- and D-box binding factors is a central determinant of per2 expression. The study extends the general understanding of the mechanism whereby the clock is entrained by light and how the regulation of clock gene expression by light has evolved in vertebrates.
This study is about the movement of Plasmodium sporozoites, the motile form of a rodent malaria-causing parasite. The authors investigated how the parasite moves and how its movement is controlled. They found that a protein called coronin is important for the parasite to move properly. Coronin is thought to help the parasite move by organizing actin filaments. The authors also found that calcium and cAMP are important for the parasite to switch from moving to invading a host cell. This study will help us better understand how malaria parasites move and how we can stop them from causing disease.
In this study, the authors characterize four new amphotericin B (AmB)-resistant Leishmania mexicana lines. They found that all four lines had altered sterol biosynthesis, and hypersensitivity to pentamidine. Whole genome sequencing revealed that one line had a resistance-associated mutation of the sterol C5-desaturase gene, while three other lines had loss of expression of the sterol C24-methyltransferase (SMT) gene responsible for drug resistance and altered sterol biosynthesis. The authors also found that additional loss of the miltefosine transporter was associated with one of those lines. They also found that reduced overall expression was associated with loss of the 3’ untranslated region of the dominant gene copy, resulting from structural variations at this locus. The authors suggest that such repeat sequence-mediated instability is a significant concern, especially since it has been associated with resistance to a major antileishmanial drug, with no evidence of associated fitness costs. They suggest that understanding the routes by which resistance may emerge is an important priority, and that their findings can help guide strategies for controlling and treating leishmaniasis.
The human brain is thought to use two processes, "prediction" and "attention," to interpret and prioritize incoming sensory information. It is not clear, however, how these two processes interact. A recent extension of the "predictive coding" theory suggests that attention increases the selectivity of prediction errors, which code for the difference between predicted and observed stimulus features. This model would suggest that attention increases the selectivity for mismatch information in the neural response to surprising stimuli. Alternative predictive coding models propose that attention increases the activity of prediction neurons, suggesting that attention and prediction synergistically modulate selectivity for feature information in the brain. In the current study, researchers used forward encoding models to test the effect of attention on mismatch and feature information in the neural response to surprising stimuli. They found that surprising stimuli evoked neural responses that contained information related to the difference between predicted and observed stimulus features. Attention also increased the selectivity for mismatch information in the neural response to surprising stimuli. These findings support the hypothesis that attention increases the gain of prediction errors.
Trypanosoma brucei is an important parasite in sub-Saharan Africa. There are three sub-species of T. brucei: T. b. brucei, T. b. gambiense, and T. b. rhodesiense. T. b. brucei is unable to infect humans because it is sensitive to human serum that contains proteins that can kill the parasite. T. b. gambiense and T. b. rhodesiense are resistant to human serum and can infect humans. These two sub-species differ in their ability to resist human serum. Group 1 T. b. gambiense have an invariant phenotype, meaning they are always resistant to human serum, while group 2 T. b. gambiense show variable resistance. Researchers have found that group 1 T. b. gambiense are resistant to trypanosome lytic factor 1 (TLF-1) due to reduced uptake of TLF-1. This reduced uptake is due to reduced expression of the TLF-1 receptor (HpHbR) gene. In this study, researchers compared the ability of group 1 and group 2 T. b. gambiense to internalize TLF-1 and APOL1. They found that both group 1 and group 2 T. b. gambiense internalized fluorescently labeled TLF-1 and APOL1, but only group 2 T. b. gambiense were lysed by APOL1. The researchers conclude that group 2 T. b. gambiense is innately resistant to APOL1, which could be based on the same mechanism as group 1 T. b. gambiense. However, group 2 T. b. gambiense variably displays this phenotype and expression does not appear to correlate with a change in expression site or expression of HpHbR. Thus, there are differences in the mechanism of human serum resistance between T. b. gambiense groups 1 and 2.
HIV-1 is a virus that causes AIDS. To evade the body's immune system and antiviral drugs, HIV-1 uses a mechanism called DNA methylation to turn off its own transcription and form a latent reservoir in the body. This study is the first to show that DNA methylation is an important mechanism that controls the stability of the HIV-1 latency. The study used an in vitro model of HIV-1 latency and patient data to show that HIV-1 LTR methylation is a mechanism that turns off the virus's transcription and prevents it from being reactivated. This study is important because it helps us understand how HIV-1 forms a latent reservoir and how it can be eradicated from the body.
The paper presents a comprehensive list of genetic variants in Drosophila melanogaster Genetic Reference Panel (DGRP), which is a population resource consisting of 192 sequenced wild-derived inbred lines. The authors used an integrative approach to identify over 3.6 million distinct variants, including insertions, deletions, complex substitutions, and structural variants. The study also provides insights into the relationship between genetic and phenotypic variation by mapping cis-expression quantitative trait loci (cis-eQTLs) for more than 2,000 genes. The authors found that indels comprise around 10% of all cis-eQTLs and show larger effects than SNP cis-eQTLs. The study revealed a partial decoupling of the genomic architecture between the sexes and the importance of genetic factors in mediating sex-biased gene expression. The majority of strong cis-eQTLs can be validated in heterozygous individuals using RNA-seq-based allelic expression imbalance analyses in the offspring of crosses between sequenced lines. Overall, the study provides a valuable resource for further investigating the molecular basis of morphological evolution, gene expression variation, and other phenotypic traits in Drosophila.
The rectified EMG signal is used to estimate the neural drive to muscles and therefore infer sources of synaptic input to motor neurons. However, the overlap of motor unit action potentials, known as amplitude cancellation, distorts the spectrum of the rectified EMG and can lead to inaccurate estimation of the neural drive. In this study, we investigated the impact of amplitude cancellation on this correlation using analytical derivations and a computational model of motor neuron activity, force, and the EMG signal. We found that amplitude cancellation distorts the spectrum of the rectified EMG signal, and that valid use of the rectified EMG as an estimator of the neural drive requires low contraction levels and/or strong common synaptic input to the motor neurons.
Auxin is important for controlling root growth, but how it is regulated in response to aluminum (Al) stress is unknown. This study has found that a group of proteins called YUCCAs control the synthesis of auxin in the root-apex transition zone (TZ) in response to Al stress. Aluminum causes the upregulation of five YUCCA genes in the root-apex TZ, which in turn leads to the accumulation of auxin in the TZ and the inhibition of root growth. This process is regulated by ethylene signaling, as enhancing or reducing ethylene signaling causes either enhanced or reduced upregulation of YUCCA genes in response to Al stress, respectively. Ethylene-insensitive3 (EIN3) and Phytochrome Interacting Factor4 (PIF4) play key roles in this process by regulating the transcription of YUCCA genes in response to Al stress. This study has shed new light on how Al stress affects root growth and may lead to new ways to protect plants from Al toxicity.
In this study, we investigated the impact of viral peptides on the activity of natural killer (NK) cells. We found that certain viral peptides can suppress the activity of NK cells and may help viruses avoid being killed by NK cells. This study provides new insights into how viruses can evade the immune system and highlights the importance of understanding the interactions between viruses and NK cells.
Bacteria that need to survive in changing environments may change over time through microevolution, which can help them adapt and survive. We have shown that a type of bacteria that causes otitis media (OM) called Nontypeable Haemophilus influenzae (NTHI) can change over time in response to a lack of nutrients. We have also shown that NTHI can form communities within the cells of the middle ear, called intracellular bacterial communities (IBCs). These IBCs may help NTHI survive and persist in the middle ear, even after antibiotics are used to treat OM. This may explain why children can have repeated episodes of OM caused by the same strain of NTHI.
Melioidosis is a rare but severe bacterial infection caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei. It is known that high levels of iron in the body can increase susceptibility to this infection. In this study, researchers wanted to investigate how B. pseudomallei modulates iron balance and how changes in host iron content affect its growth within the body. They found that B. pseudomallei downregulates the expression of ferroportin, which is a protein that exports iron from cells. This results in higher iron availability within macrophages, the cells that B. pseudomallei infects first. When the researchers added more iron to the macrophages, it stimulated the growth of B. pseudomallei. On the other hand, when they used a drug to reduce iron availability, it decreased the growth of B. pseudomallei. They also found that B. pseudomallei can acquire iron from heme, which is a component of hemoglobin found in red blood cells. The researchers also found that B. pseudomallei can take up iron from host proteins like transferrin and lactoferrin. These results suggest that B. pseudomallei has developed strategies to acquire iron from the host to support its growth. The researchers concluded that B. pseudomallei modulates cellular iron balance to improve its iron acquisition and to restrict antibacterial immune effector mechanisms. They also found that changes in host iron homeostasis can influence susceptibility to melioidosis, a serious bacterial infection. The researchers suggest that drugs that chelate iron may be an additional therapeutic option for treating melioidosis.
We propose a new method, called functional mode analysis, which aims to detect the specific collective motion in a protein that is related to a particular function. By analyzing a set of protein structures and a functional quantity that describes the desired function, this method can identify the collective motion that is most correlated to the functional quantity. The new method is illustrated using several examples, including a polyalanine helix, T4 lysozyme, Trp-cage, and leucine-binding protein. The method can help in understanding how a protein's function is related to its motion.
Nuclear genes of euglenids and marine diplonemids contain unusual introns that are not found in the genomes of other eukaryotes. These nonconventional introns do not have the same structure as other types of introns. In the pre-mRNA transcripts of euglenids, nonconventional and conventional introns occur in different genes. It is unknown how these different types of introns are removed from the transcripts. In this study, the authors analyzed the order of intron removal for two genes that contain both nonconventional and conventional introns. They found that nonconventional introns are removed earlier than conventional introns, and that there is a time gap between the removal of the two types of introns. This is the first time that the order of removal of these two types of introns has been studied, and it provides important information about the splicing process in these organisms.
A study looked at the effects of a virus called Coxsackievirus B3 (CVB3) on the heart. CVB3 is a common cause of mild infections in people, such as fever, rash, and respiratory problems. In rare cases, it can cause heart problems such as myocarditis, a disease that can lead to heart failure. However, it is not well understood how CVB3 can cause long-term damage to the heart. The study found that CVB3 efficiently infects c-kit+ cells, which are a type of heart stem cell, and that the number of these cells in the heart is reduced in adult mice that were infected with CVB3 as juveniles. This reduction in c-kit+ cells may impair the heart's ability to increase its blood vessels to adapt to increased load, leading to a higher risk of heart failure. The study suggests that a mild CVB3 infection can cause long-term damage to the heart, but more research is needed to understand the exact mechanisms.
Burkholderia pseudomallei is a bacterium that can cause a disease called melioidosis, which is common in Southeast Asia and northern Australia. When a person is infected with B. pseudomallei, it can cause various diseases including pneumonia, organ abscesses, and septicemia. The bacterium can invade phagocytic and non-phagocytic cells and replicate in the host cell cytosol by using a T3SS3. Macrophages are important for controlling the early replication of the bacterium. In a previous study, we showed that rapid pyroptotic cell death is involved in defence against B. pseudomallei by removing the bacterium's replication niche. However, caspase-1, a protease that contributes to the control of intracellular bacterial replication in macrophages, is also activated by B. pseudomallei. In this study, we investigated the general features of cell death in wild-type macrophages and in caspase-1/11 knockout macrophages unable to induce pyroptosis. We identified downstream signaling pathways of B. pseudomallei-induced caspase-1 activation. We also characterized the role of B. pseudomallei flagellin FliC, the T3SS3 effector protein BopE, and the inner rod protein BsaK in caspase-1 activation, pyroptosis induction, and IL-1β secretion. Our findings help to better understand the mechanism of action of B. pseudomallei and its ability to cause disease.
Pollen grains need to germinate on the stigma of the female plant in order to fertilize the egg. This process is controlled by a plant-specific protein called KINβγ. KINβγ is a cytoplasm- and nucleus-localized protein that is critical for pollen germination. The pollen of a kinβγ mutant cannot germinate on the stigma, although it can germinate normally in vitro. Further analysis revealed that the compromised hydration of the kinβγ mutant pollen on the stigma led to its defective germination. In addition, the kinβγ mutant pollen exhibited reduced levels of reactive oxygen species ( ROS ) in pollen, and its mitochondria and peroxisomes were damaged. Overexpression of Arabidopsis CATALASE 3, which increases ROS levels in pollen, partially compensated for the reduced hydration of the mutant pollen on the stigma. These results suggest that Arabidopsis KINβγ is critical for the regulation of ROS levels by mediating the biogenesis of mitochondria and peroxisomes in pollen, which is required for pollen–stigma interactions during pollination.
In bacteria, ribonuclease III (RNase III) is a key enzyme that helps process double-stranded RNA. It is important for many biological systems, including ribosomal RNA maturation and mRNA turnover. In the bacteria Bacillus subtilis, RNase III plays an essential role in protecting the cell from toxin genes carried by two prophages. These genes are controlled by antisense RNA, and without RNase III, the toxin genes cannot be degraded properly. The study shows how RNase III is involved in the degradation of the antisense RNA that controls these toxin genes. This helps to ensure that the genes do not cause harm to the cell and that it continues to function properly.
Lymphatic filariasis (LF) is a parasitic disease caused by the filarial nematode Brugia malayi. The parasite releases extracellular vesicles (EVs) that contain bioactive proteins and small RNA species that allow secretion of parasite effector molecules and their potential trafficking to host tissues. These vesicles are released across all intra-mammalian life cycle stages of B . malayi, including the infective L3 stage, microfilariae, L4, adult male, and female worms. The EVs released by all stages of B . malayi are internalized by murine macrophages and contain putative host immunomodulatory molecules. The protein components of the vesicles vary in a stage- and sex-specific manner, suggesting that the parasite's ability to modulate the host immune response may have a sexual dimorphic element. Finally, the process of EV release is inhibited by ivermectin, suggesting a potential mechanism of action for this drug and highlighting EV release as a possible assay platform in future drug discovery efforts.
The article is about two common skin conditions, scabies and impetigo, which are treatable but often occur together in rural areas with warm and humid climates. The article discusses how there is a lack of good quality epidemiological data from the Solomon Islands, but a study was done in ten rural villages in the Western Province. The total prevalence of scabies in the study was 19.2%, with the highest prevalence found in children aged 1-4 years. The prevalence of impetigo was 26.7%, with the highest prevalence found in children aged 1-4 years as well. The study found that scabies infestation is strongly associated with impetigo infection. It also suggests that community control strategies for scabies may reduce the burden of both conditions and their downstream complications.
Adult neurogenesis occurs in the hippocampus of mice and its function is not clear. In this study, the authors used heterogeneous stock (HS) mice to map quantitative trait loci (QTLs) that influence adult neurogenesis. They found that QTLs affecting neurogenesis are also linked to other traits, such as disease models, haematological, immunological, and anatomical assays. These traits include anxiety, contextual fear conditioning, and novelty suppressed feeding, which are previously suggested to be related to neurogenesis. The authors suggest that their findings may indicate that adult neurogenesis has broader roles than previously thought, beyond learning, memory, and emotional regulation.
Chagas disease is a serious health problem in Latin America and is now becoming a problem in the US due to an increase in immigration. Previous research has screened a database of Trypanosoma cruzi genes to find potential vaccine candidates. In this study, a DNA-prime/protein-boost vaccine was tested in mice. This vaccine included several antigen candidates that had been previously identified as potentially protective against Chagas disease. The vaccine was shown to induce a strong antibody response and a moderate level of T cell proliferation, leading to protection from acute parasite infection. The vaccine also led to a type 1 cytokine response, which has been shown to be protective against Chagas disease. In chronic infection, the vaccine led to a decrease in inflammation and tissue parasitism.
In this study, we propose using sophisticated machine learning algorithms with a large ensemble of markers to improve the performance of disease risk assessment for complex diseases, such as type 1 diabetes. We applied a support vector machine algorithm on a genotyping dataset generated on the Affymetrix platform for type 1 diabetes, and optimized a risk assessment model with hundreds of markers. We then tested this model on an independent Illumina-genotyped dataset, as well as a separate Affymetrix-genotyped dataset, resulting in an area under ROC curve of approximately 0.84 in both datasets. In contrast, poor performance was achieved when we limited the model to dozens of known susceptibility loci in the SVM model or logistic regression model. Our study suggests that improved disease risk assessment can be achieved by using algorithms that take into account interactions between a large ensemble of markers. We are optimistic that genotype-based disease risk assessment may be feasible for diseases where a notable proportion of the risk has already been captured by SNP arrays.
This research looked at how memory CD8+ T cells, a type of immune cell, respond to infection in the skin. These cells can remember past infections and quickly respond to new ones. The researchers found that memory CD8+ T cells can enter the skin quickly and provide protection against viral infections in the skin. They also found that memory CD8+ T cells can become tissue-resident memory cells (TRM), which are CD69+/CD103- and are important for providing protection against skin infections in the long term. The researchers also discovered that memory CD8+ T cells can use cytolysis, or cell death, to provide protection against viral infections in the skin. This research provides important information about how memory CD8+ T cells can protect the skin from viral infections.
Proteins in neurons are found in different areas of the cell depending on their function. Axonal proteins are mainly found in the axon, while dendritic proteins are mainly found in the dendrites. Researchers found that Myosin VI, a type of motor, plays a role in making sure proteins are found in the right place. They also discovered that the proteins are sometimes moved from the axon to the dendrites and back. To do this, Myosin VI helps move the proteins to the right place. Additionally, Myosin VI is important for making sure that the proteins are found on the surface of the cell. This is important for the function of the neurons.
This study is about two genes that control sexual characteristics in the water flea Daphnia magna. These genes are important because they are involved in determining whether an animal reproduces sexually or asexually, depending on the environment. The authors identified two similar genes in D. magna, named DapmaDsx1 and DapmaDsx2. They then used genetic and molecular techniques to determine the function of these genes. They found that DapmaDsx1 is responsible for controlling male characteristics in a specific period of the animal's life, and that it is expressed differently between males and females. The authors also found that DapmaDsx1 is similar to genes that control sexual characteristics in insects, which are thought to be closely related to branchiopods like D. magna. However, the way that DapmaDsx1 is regulated is different from what is seen in insects. The authors concluded that the functions of Dsx genes are conserved across different animal lineages, but the way that they are regulated has evolved independently. This study adds to our understanding of how animals determine whether to reproduce sexually or asexually, depending on the environment. It also shows that genes that control sexual characteristics have similar functions across different species, but may be regulated differently.
Genital herpes is a common sexually transmitted infection, but there is no cure. The current study examines a potential vaccine for genital herpes. The vaccine contains three proteins that are designed to block the virus from entering the body and to prevent the virus from evading the body's immune response. The study found that the vaccine was effective in preventing genital lesions and reducing the amount of virus that was shed from the genitals after infection. Overall, the vaccine showed promising results and may help prevent the spread of genital herpes.
ChIP-seq is a technique that maps proteins bound to DNA in cells, which helps identify important regulatory regions of the genome. However, some regions of the genome contain repeated sequences, and when reads from these regions are mapped to the reference genome, they can match multiple locations. This creates ambiguity about the true origin of these reads. Standard analysis methods for ChIP-seq ignore these multi-mapping reads or use only a small fraction of them. However, the true origin of these reads is important for understanding the regulatory activity in these regions, such as segmental duplications or LINE elements that contain near-identical DNA sequences. Therefore, we developed a new method called Perm-seq, which uses additional data from DNase-seq to accurately allocate multi-mapping reads. We evaluated our method and found that it significantly improves multi-read allocation accuracy compared to methods that do not use additional data. We also applied Perm-seq to 64 ENCODE ChIP-seq datasets from GM12878 and K562 cells, and identified many novel protein-DNA interactions in segmental duplication regions. Our analysis revealed that although the protein-DNA interaction sites in these regions are evolutionarily less conserved, they share the overall sequence characteristics of the protein-DNA interaction regions identified by uniquely mapping reads. This is an important finding because it means that the regulatory activity in these important regions of the genome can be studied using standard methods, despite the challenges posed by their repetitive nature.
This study investigated whether a parasitic infection called schistosomiasis increases the odds of getting HIV and the viral load at the time of HIV-1 infection in adults living in Tanzania. The study found that women with schistosome infections were more likely to become HIV-infected and had higher HIV-1 viral loads at the time of HIV-1 seroconversion compared to those without schistosome infections. However, men with schistosome infections did not have an increased risk of HIV-1 acquisition or viral loads. This study shows that schistosome infections may increase the risk of HIV-1 infection and viral load in women. Further research is needed to confirm these findings.
A study by Chen et al. has explored how rDNA copy number is regulated in mammalian genomes. Ribosomal DNA (rDNA) is an essential part of the genome that encodes the functional RNAs of the ribosome, which is responsible for protein synthesis. The number of rDNA copies varies in human genomes, with an estimated range of 14–410 copies. The study used computational and droplet digital PCR approaches to measure rDNA copy number in normal and cancer states in human and mouse genomes. The results showed that copy number and sequence can change in cancer genomes. Human cancer genomes showed a loss of copies, accompanied by global copy number co-variation and more variable sequence. Loss of copies occurs early and is associated with hypersensitivity to DNA damage. Surprisingly, hematopoietic cancer stem cells from a Pten-/- mouse model for leukemia had lower rDNA copy number than normal tissue despite increased proliferation, rRNA production, and protein synthesis. This study provides evidence that rDNA copy number can act as a simple and useful indicator of whether a cancer will be sensitive to DNA damaging treatments.
In this study, we describe a new approach to understand the growth and spread of bacteria inside a host, specifically in the context of a Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium infection of mice. We used a combination of eight isogenic tagged strains and quantitative PCR to track the growth of each strain in multiple organs over the course of the infection. By analyzing the dynamics of each strain separately, we were able to gain insights into the spread and growth of bacteria within the host. We found that during the initial stages of the infection, there was rapid bacterial replication and death, leading to the establishment of independent bacterial subpopulations in different organs. Later in the infection, there was a decrease in microbial death, leading to an exponential increase in the number of bacteria that spread locally and mix between organs via bacteraemia. This approach provides a new outlook on the dynamics of Salmonella enterica infections and highlights the complex and stochastic nature of within-host bacterial dynamics. Our work also illustrates the importance of considering multiple subpopulations within the same host when studying infectious diseases.
3D motion is the perception of moving objects in three dimensions. To solve the inverse optics problem, which is the determination of the direction and speed of motion in a 3D environment from 2D input, several models have been proposed in the past. These models are based on interocular velocity difference, changing disparity over time, and joint encoding of motion and disparity. These models have limitations and do not provide a general solution to the inverse optics problem. The authors suggest that local velocity constraints combined with binocular disparity and other depth cues can provide a more flexible framework for solving the inverse optics problem. The authors also distinguish between two default strategies of 3D motion processing: the vector normal prefers slow motion in 3D while the cyclopean average is based on slow motion in 2D. Experimental results suggest that velocity constraints and disparity from feature tracking are needed to solve the inverse problem of 3D motion perception. The authors propose that motion and disparity input is processed in parallel and integrated late in the visual processing hierarchy.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a type of bacteria that can cause lung infections in people with cystic fibrosis. The bacteria make a sticky substance called alginate to protect themselves from antibiotics and other treatments. Alginate is made from long chains of a sugar called mannuronic acid. The chains of mannuronic acid are acetylated (attached to acetate molecules) to make the alginate even stickier. Four proteins are thought to be involved in adding acetate to alginate in P. aeruginosa: AlgI, AlgJ, AlgX, and AlgF. AlgJ and AlgX are proteins that can attach acetate molecules to the mannuronic acid chains, while AlgI and AlgF are not believed to have any role in acetylation. In this study, the authors determined the structure of AlgJ and tested its function in acetylation. They found that AlgJ is not able to bind to mannuronic acid chains or attach acetate molecules to them. They also found that AlgX is able to attach acetate molecules to mannuronic acid chains. The authors suggest that AlgJ and AlgX have different roles in acetylation, and that the four-protein system used by P. aeruginosa is more complex than the three-protein system used by other bacteria.
Candida albicans is a type of fungus that commonly causes human infections and can be fatal. To protect against C. albicans, the human body has a defense system that recognizes the fungal cell wall, which contains a type of sugar called β-1,3-glucan. However, C. albicans can hide this sugar from the defense system by covering it with other substances. Recent studies have found that a specific type of enzyme called phosphatidylserine synthase is involved in hiding β-1,3-glucan. To better understand how this enzyme works, researchers studied the genetic mutant of this enzyme and found that it causes more β-1,3-glucan to be exposed. This leads to a stronger immune response, which may be more effective at fighting C. albicans infections.
This paper is about discovering new genes and their function in Alzheimer's disease. Alzheimer's disease is a common brain disorder that affects memory and thinking. In this study, the authors analyzed brain samples from 4,914 people and looked for genetic changes associated with the disease. They also looked at the different types of brain changes that occur in Alzheimer's disease, such as plaques and tangles. They found that there were genetic changes associated with different types of brain changes. They also found that some genetic changes that were thought to be associated with Alzheimer's disease were actually associated with other brain changes. This study helps us better understand the genetic causes of Alzheimer's disease and how it affects the brain.
Protein unfolding is the process by which a protein changes from a folded, functional structure to an unfolded, non-functional structure. Urea is a chemical commonly used to study the unfolding of proteins. However, despite decades of research, it is not entirely clear how urea affects the unfolding process. In this study, researchers used computer simulations to investigate the role of urea in unfolding and found that it actively induces unfolding by stabilizing partially unfolded microstates. The researchers used a variety of proteins and force-fields in their simulations to ensure the results were universal. Overall, the study provides a comprehensive picture of how urea affects the unfolding of proteins.
A research review was done to understand the spread of dengue disease in Colombia. Researchers found that the number of dengue cases in Colombia is stable each year, but there were big outbreaks in 2001, 2002, and 2010. Most of the cases were among people under the age of 15. The researchers found that there are gaps in the knowledge of dengue disease in Colombia, such as information about asymptomatic dengue virus infections, different types of infections (primary or secondary), and under-reporting of the disease. The researchers hope that this review will help fill these gaps and provide a basis for future research and policies related to dengue disease prevention.
This paper reviews the prevalence of coinfections with Leishmania, a parasite that causes tegumentary leishmaniasis (TL) in humans. The paper also discusses the interactions between Leishmania and other pathogens in animal models and human subjects, as well as the implications of these coinfections on clinical practice. The paper concludes that TL coinfections are common, may cause diagnostic errors and delays, and can affect the effectiveness and safety of treatment. More research is needed to understand how coinfections affect the pathogenesis of TL.
We studied how natural genetic variation affects the expression of MHC class I and II proteins and the ratio of CD4 to CD8 T cells in rats. We used two genetic models, the Heterogeneous Stock rats and MHC-recombinant congenic strains. In Heterogeneous Stock rats, we mapped QTLs associated with variation in MHC class I and II protein expression and the CD4:CD8 T cell ratio. We found that QTLs for the individual traits overlapped within a region spanning the MHC. To identify the genes underlying these overlapping QTLs, we generated a large panel of MHC-recombinant congenic strains, and refined the QTLs to two adjacent intervals of ∼0 . 25 Mb in the MHC-I and II regions, respectively. An interaction between these intervals affected MHC class I expression as well as negative selection and lineage commitment of CD8 single-positive ( SP ) thymocytes. We mapped this effect to the transporter associated with antigen processing 2 ( Tap2 ) in the MHC-II region and the classical MHC class I gene ( s ) ( RT1-A ) in the MHC-I region. We also identified a novel type of class-I modification that we termed inverse cim , which reduced the expression of TAP-B linked RT1-A molecules if associated with TAP-A . Finally, we showed that polymorphisms in Tap2 significantly contribute to CD8 lineage commitment, likely by altering the class-I peptide repertoire on antigen presenting cells in the thymus.
Chagas disease is a serious illness caused by a parasite named Trypanosoma cruzi, which can lead to heart, digestive, or neurological problems in later years. Chagas disease is mainly transmitted through the bite of a bug called Chagas disease vector, which is a triatomine bug found in 21 Latin American countries. However, the disease can also spread through blood transfusions or organ transplants. Chagas disease is endemic in many Latin American countries and has emerged in non-endemic countries, such as North America, Australia, and Europe, where it is mainly caused by population mobility, particularly migration from Latin American countries. Spain has the highest number of immigrants from Latin American countries in Europe, and the European Center for Disease Prevention and Control estimates that between 40,000 and 65,000 infected people currently reside in Spain. The paper describes Chagas disease hospitalizations in Spain from 1997 to 2011 in terms of time, geographical distribution, and individual characteristics.
The authors present BlocBuster, a novel systems-level approach to efficiently construct genome-wide, allele-specific networks that accurately segregate homogenous combinations of genetic factors, test the associations of these combinations with the given phenotype, and rigorously validate the results using a series of unbiased validation methods. The authors applied BlocBuster to analyze psoriasis, discovering a combinatorial pattern with an odds ratio of 3.64 and a Bonferroni-corrected p-value of 5.01×10−16. This pattern was replicated in independent data, reflecting robustness of the method. These results demonstrate BlocBuster's potential for discovering combinatorial genetic associations within heterogeneous genome-wide data, thereby transcending the limiting "small effects" produced by individual markers examined in isolation.
A group of researchers investigated the causes of a few brain disorders, including agenesis of the corpus callosum (ACC), cerebellar hypoplasia (CBLH), and polymicrogyria (PMG), that affect the brain development in utero. They analyzed a large number of patients with these disorders and a group of healthy controls to look for genetic differences. The study found a higher prevalence of large gene-rich CNVs in ACC than in CBLH and PMG. The researchers also found a number of large gene-rich de novo CNVs, which were inherited from the father, that are likely to be causing these disorders in single patients. This study shows that ACC patients with gene-rich de novo CNVs are more likely to have an autism spectrum disorder, which may explain some of the social and executive function deficits seen in ACC patients.
The freshwater planarian, Schmidtea mediterranea, is a unique animal that can regenerate many of its body parts, including parts of its brain, gut, and muscle tissue. The Hippo signaling cascade is a key regulator of growth in most organisms, and the YAP/TAZ transcriptional co-activator is the main effector of this pathway in vertebrates. We investigated the role of Yki, the planarian homologue of YAP/TAZ, in the regeneration process. We found that RNA interference knockdown of Yki leads to increased proliferation and the activation of an early injury response program, which is normally turned off after 48 hours. This indicates that Yki plays a crucial role in integrating the proliferative and injury response processes during regeneration. We also found that in Yki-knockdown animals, the brain, gut, and midline did not grow or scale properly, and that the eyes failed to regenerate. Our results suggest that Yki is a critical regulator of multiple early wound response processes during regeneration.
Exosomes are small packages released from cells that contain proteins, lipids, and RNA molecules. These packages can be taken up by other cells and can participate in various biological processes. Some viruses, such as HCV, HTLV-1, and HIV, use exosomes to transfer their genetic materials to new host cells. EV71 is a virus that causes hand-foot-and-mouth disease, and it has been shown that it can transfer its genetic materials to new host cells through exosomes. These exosomes also contain a specific cellular miRNA called miR-146a that can suppress the immune response of the new host cells and facilitate the replication of the virus. The findings of this study suggest that exosomes play a crucial role in the EV71 life cycle and could potentially be used as a target for developing new treatments for HFMD.
Researchers have identified a new player in a process that helps keep the cells healthy. This process is called mitophagy, which is the removal of damaged mitochondria in cells. The new player is called phosphoglycerate mutase 5 (PGAM5). Previous studies have suggested that PGAM5 is not important for this process, but new research has shown that it is actually involved in the process of mitophagy. The researchers used Drosophila models to show that PGAM5 is required for maintaining the integrity of mitochondria. They also showed that loss of PGAM5 activity improves the mitochondrial defects caused by PINK1 inactivation in Drosophila. This is an exciting new discovery that will help us understand how to keep cells healthy and prevent disease.
Buruli ulcer is a disease caused by the bacteria Mycobacterium ulcerans and affects the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It is mainly found in rural areas of West Africa, but has also been reported in America, Australia, and Asia. The bacteria produce a toxin called mycolactone, which is responsible for the disease's cytotoxic effects. Mycolactone is essential for the bacteria's virulence and has been shown to downregulate the immune response of mammalian cells. However, individuals living in BU-endemic areas often develop antibodies against the bacteria, indicating that the immune system is capable of clearing the infection. Interferon-γ (IFNγ) is a cytokine that is critical for host defense against intracellular pathogens and may play a role in containing M . ulcerans infections. In a mouse model of the disease, IFNγ knockout mice had a faster progression of the infection compared to wild-type mice, with more tissue necrosis and oedema formation, as well as a significantly higher bacterial burden after five weeks of infection. This indicates that IFNγ is important for clearing the bacteria during the early intra-macrophage growth phase. These findings support the idea that concepts for vaccine development against tuberculosis may also be valid for BU.
The Q-cycle of complex III in mitochondrial electron transport can operate in two different steady states at the same set of parameters, one with high rate of reactive oxygen species (ROS) production and the other with low ROS production. The system can be switched from one steady state to another one by the initial state, the level of succinate, and the availability of oxygen. The experimental data of isolated brain mitochondria are consistent with the predictions of the model. The proposed mechanism explains the paradoxical increase of ROS production induced by anoxia and reoxygenation.
The gap gene network is a key model system for understanding how genes control patterns of gene expression in living organisms. In this study, we used an integrative, systems-level approach to investigate the regulatory effect of the terminal gap gene huckebein (hkb) on gap gene expression. We presented quantitative expression data for the Hkb protein, which allowed us to include hkb in gap gene circuits. Gap gene circuits are mathematical models of gene networks that have been used to extract regulatory information from spatial gene expression data. By fitting the model to gap gene expression patterns, we obtained estimates for regulatory parameters that predict a specific network topology. We showed that considering variability in the data combined with analysis of parameter determinability significantly improved the biological relevance and consistency of the approach. Our models are in agreement with earlier results and extend them in two important respects: First, we showed that Hkb is involved in the regulation of the posterior hunchback (hb) domain but does not have any other essential function. Specifically, Hkb is required for the anterior shift in the posterior border of this domain, which is now reproduced correctly in our models. Second, our gap gene circuits presented here are able to reproduce mutants of terminal gap genes, while previously published models were unable to reproduce any null mutants correctly. As a consequence, our models now capture the expression dynamics of all posterior gap genes and some variational properties of the system correctly. This is an important step towards a better, quantitative understanding of the developmental and evolutionary dynamics of the gap gene network.
Brucellosis is a bacterial disease that affects humans and various animals worldwide, including cattle. Currently, there is no effective therapy or biomarker to monitor the efficacy of therapy for Brucellosis. Treatment is ineffective and animals remain carriers for life. Phage lysates of two live attenuated vaccine strains of Brucella abortus, RB51 and S19, have been found to be effective in treating bovine Brucellosis. RB51 phage lysates induce cell-mediated immunity and are resistant to Rifampicin, while S19 phage lysates induce antibodies. A single subcutaneous dose of a cocktail of phage lysates eliminated live virulent Brucella from Brucellosis-affected cattle within 3 months of immunization. Brucella-specific RNA in plasma was used as a biomarker to monitor the efficacy of therapy in a non-destructive and minimally invasive manner. This is the first report on the use of phage lysates for the successful immunotherapy of Brucellosis in cattle and minimally invasive monitoring of therapy efficacy using Brucella-specific RNA in plasma.
In this paper, the authors used a chemical genetics approach to study the role of a specific CDK2 in protecting genomic integrity. They replaced wild-type Cdk2 with a mutant version sensitized to inhibition by bulky adenine analogs in human cells. They found that transient and selective inhibition of analog-sensitive (AS) Cdk2 after exposure to ionizing radiation (IR) enhances cell-killing. In extracts supplemented with an ATP analog used preferentially by AS kinases, Cdk2as phosphorylated the Nijmegen Breakage Syndrome gene product Nbs1, a component of the Mre11-Rad50-Nbs1 complex required for normal DNA damage repair and checkpoint signaling. In vivo, selective inhibition of Cdk2 delayed and diminished Nbs1-Ser432 phosphorylation during S phase, and mutation of Ser432 to Ala or Asp increased IR sensitivity. Therefore, by chemical genetics, they uncovered both a non-redundant requirement for Cdk2 activity in response to DNA damage and a specific target of Cdk2 within the DNA repair machinery.
Researchers have found ways to identify the functional variants responsible for certain traits and diseases using genome-wide association (GWA) studies. These variants can be common or low-frequency, and they are often found in intronic and intergenic regions. Many of these initial association signals are likely to be regulatory variants, meaning they control gene expression. To find these functional variants, researchers can use techniques such as fine-mapping and functional annotation using biochemical assays. These studies have shown that some trait-associated alleles are related to cellular functions and pathways. For example, genetic loci associated with platelet counts have been linked to coronary artery disease and myocardial infarction. To explore this further, researchers used a technique called formaldehyde-assisted isolation of regulatory elements (FAIRE) to map open chromatin regions in a megakaryocytic and an erythroblastoid cell line. These open chromatin regions are likely to contain regulatory variants. The researchers then compared the chromatin architecture of the two cell types and looked at the phenotypic causality of variants that fell into NDRs specific to either cell type. They found a site of open chromatin in megakaryocytes but not erythroblasts, and they elucidated the molecular mechanism that contributes to the platelet phenotype. In summary, this study shows how GWA studies can be used to identify functional variants and how these variants can contribute to certain traits and diseases.
The study investigates how pharmacological blockade of voltage-gated ion channels affects neuronal and circuit activity. The study uses computer simulations to show that different mechanisms of action can have different effects on neuronal and circuit activity. Specifically, the study looks at the persistent sodium current (INaP) in respiratory pre-Bötzinger complex (pre-BötC) neurons and simulates blockade of INaP using two different drugs: tetrodotoxin (TTX) and riluzole (RZ). TTX blocks INaP by directly obstructing the sodium pore, while RZ shifts INaP inactivation in the hyperpolarizing direction. The study shows that TTX block of INaP effectively stops respiratory rhythms in the intact respiratory network, while RZ block does not. This is because after RZ application, INaP can be reactivated by transient hyperpolarizing perturbations. The study suggests that the failure of RZ to stop respiratory rhythms in intact experimental preparations does not rule out a central role for INaP in rhythm generation, as the study supports. The study highlights the importance of considering the mechanism of action when interpreting and simulating experimental data from pharmacological blocking studies.
In this study, we examined the role of the microRNA (miRNA) miR-218 in the metastasis of gastric cancer. We found that miR-218 is decreased in highly invasive GC cells, and its downregulation is correlated with advanced clinical stage, lymph node metastasis, and poor prognosis in patients. We also discovered that Robo1, a receptor for the Slit protein family, is a functional target of miR-218. We found an intriguing negative feedback loop between Slit proteins and miR-218 that plays a crucial role in GC cell motility. Our findings not only provide new insights into the metastatic mechanisms in GC, but they also reveal a novel regulatory mechanism of receptor signaling.
The paper is about studying the effects of cholesterol lowering on atherosclerosis, which is a progressive disease that can cause heart attack and stroke. They used a special mouse model that has a similar plasma lipoprotein profile to that of human familial hypercholesterolemia and a genetic switch to lower plasma lipoproteins. They then measured changes in gene expression related to the disease at different stages of atherosclerosis development and identified a group of 37 cholesterol-responsive atherosclerosis genes that are responsible for preventing the formation of advanced plaques. This study provides important information for developing new therapies for atherosclerosis.
Scientists have created a new test to find genes that help bacteria build their protective outer shell. They used this test on E. coli and found 102 genes that might play a role in building the outer shell. They also studied one of these genes, ycbC, in more detail and found that it helps the bacteria grow by making a chemical that is important for building the outer shell. This new test might help scientists find new ways to treat bacterial infections.
Researchers are studying biological systems using more and more techniques, but it is difficult to combine all the data into a complete picture. This paper presents a way to do that using a special kind of learning method and data from images of a protein called Dorsal in the early Drosophila embryo. The Dorsal protein is important for creating the Dorsal-Ventral (DV) stripes in the embryo, which help control cell fates and tissue deformations. Researchers have studied how different things like gene expression and protein phosphorylation work together to create the DV stripes, but they have only looked at a few of those things at the same time. This paper suggests a way to combine that information into a full picture of how all those things work together. They do this by treating the data as a big puzzle and trying to figure out what the missing pieces are based on the information they already have. They show that their method works well on both synthetic and real data.
Snake venom metalloproteinases (SVMPs) from different classes are compared in terms of their ability to hydrolyze basement membrane components, their tissue localization, and the effect of these toxins on the microvasculature. The analysis was conducted using immunohistochemistry, proteomics, and immunochemistry techniques. The results showed that PII and PIII SVMPs co-localize with type IV collagen in capillaries, arterioles, and post-capillary venules to a higher extent than PI SVMP. The patterns of hydrolysis by these enzymes of type IV collagen, nidogen, laminin, and other extracellular matrix components differ, and proteomic analysis of exudate collected from the tissue injected with these SVMPs revealed differences in the pathological effects induced by these toxins.
The study focuses on the regulation of the homeotic gene abd-A by the non-coding RNA (ncRNA) iab-8. The authors find that the iab-8 ncRNA is expressed in the epidermis and central nervous system of embryos, and that it represses abd-A expression in the posterior central nervous system. They also show that the repression is dependent on the miR-iab-8 microRNA, and that it is likely caused by transcriptional interference. Finally, they suggest that this regulation may be important for the posterior dominance of homeotic genes in Drosophila.
This study is about understanding why certain brain seizures start differently from others. There are two main types of seizure onsets: one where the seizure starts with a series of high frequency oscillations called low amplitude fast oscillations (LAF), and another where the seizure starts with a single high amplitude wave called high amplitude slow oscillations (HAS). Researchers have studied these two types of onsets extensively, but they still don’t know why they happen differently. To figure this out, the researchers used a computer model of the brain that has been shown to work well in simulating seizures. They then tested the model by comparing it to real brain recordings from people with seizures. The researchers found that LAF seizures start with many small patches of seizure activity that slowly grow together over time. In contrast, HAS seizures start with a single large event that spreads throughout the entire brain. The researchers believe that the difference in how these two types of seizures start is related to the way the surrounding healthy brain tissue responds to the seizure. They think that the healthy tissue might be more excitable in the case of LAF seizures, which would make it more likely to join in and become part of the seizure. On the other hand, in the case of HAS seizures, the healthy tissue might not be as excitable, which would make it less likely to join in. The researchers believe that this difference in the surrounding tissue could be the reason why some people with seizures respond well to treatment and others don’t. They also think that this difference in the surrounding tissue might explain why some people with seizures have a better outcome when the part of their brain that is causing the seizure is removed, while others don’t. Finally, the researchers suggest that it might be possible to test their theory by stimulating the brain in a specific way, and seeing if that changes how the surrounding healthy tissue responds to the seizure.
This paper describes the role of four proteins in the process of fertilization in plants. These proteins are specifically found in the embryo sac, which is a part of the female reproductive structure. These proteins are thought to be involved in a signaling process that causes the pollen tube to burst, releasing the sperm cells. The paper suggests that this process is important for successful fertilization and may be a way for different plant species to prevent hybridization.
This study looks at how well a type of virus called herpes simplex virus ( HSV ) kills off cancer cells. The cancer cells that the virus targets are those that express a specific protein called HER-2. This protein is overexpressed in ovarian and breast cancer cells, so it was thought that the virus could be retargeted to target and kill off these cancer cells. The researchers first created a virus that was retargeted to specifically kill off cancer cells that express high levels of HER-2. They then tested this virus in mice with cancer cells that had spread to the peritoneal cavity, a common location for cancer cells to spread to in the human body. The virus was shown to effectively target and kill off cancer cells that expressed high levels of HER-2, and to inhibit the spread of cancer cells in the peritoneal cavity.
In this study, the authors investigate the role of the protein Sfi1 in regulating the duplication of the Spindle Pole Body (SPB) in yeast. The SPB is a structure that serves as the center of the mitotic spindle, and its duplication is essential for proper chromosome segregation. The authors found that Cdk1, a protein that controls the cell cycle, phosphorylates Sfi1 at multiple sites. They also found that dephosphorylation of these sites by the protein Cdc14 promotes the duplication of the SPB. The authors propose that Sfi1 acts as a licensing factor for SPB duplication, and its phosphorylation by Cdk1 blocks duplication. The authors also show that reduplication of the SPB occurs when Cdk1 activity is reduced or when Cdc14 is activated. Overall, the study provides important insights into the mechanisms that regulate SPB duplication in yeast.
The article is about a protein called Vpr, which is produced by the HIV virus. Vpr has the ability to cause G2 cell cycle arrest and apoptosis in HIV-infected cells in a lab setting. Vpr is also highly conserved in transmitted/founder HIV viruses and is found in all primate lentiviruses. This suggests that Vpr plays an important role in HIV-1 pathogenesis, but its direct evidence in vivo has not been shown. To solve this, researchers used a human hematopoietic stem cell-transplanted humanized mouse model to investigate the role of Vpr in HIV-1 infection in vivo. They found that Vpr causes G2 cell cycle arrest and apoptosis in proliferating CCR5+ CD4+ T cells, which mainly consist of regulatory CD4+ T cells (Tregs), resulting in Treg depletion and enhanced virus production during acute infection. The Vpr-dependent enhancement of virus replication and Treg depletion is observed in CCR5-tropic but not CXCR4-tropic HIV-1-infected mice. This suggests that these effects are dependent on the coreceptor usage by HIV-1. Immune activation was observed in CCR5-tropic wild-type but not in vpr-deficient HIV-1-infected humanized mice. When humanized mice were treated with denileukin diftitox (DD), to deplete Tregs, DD-treated humanized mice showed massive activation/proliferation of memory T cells compared to the untreated group. This activation/proliferation enhanced CCR5 expression in memory CD4+ T cells and rendered them more susceptible to CCR5-tropic wild-type HIV-1 infection than to vpr-deficient virus. Taken together, these results suggest that Vpr takes advantage of proliferating CCR5+ CD4+ T cells for enhancing viremia of CCR5-tropic HIV-1. Because Tregs exist in a higher cycling state than other T cell subsets, Tregs appear to be more vulnerable to exploitation by Vpr during acute HIV-1 infection.
Vivax malaria is a type of malaria parasite that is found in many parts of the world. The parasite was successfully eliminated in South Korea in the late 1970s, but it was found to have re-emerged from 1993. To understand the transmission of the parasite, researchers analyzed genetic markers from 163 South Korean isolates collected from 1994 to 2008. The results showed that a drastic genetic change occurred in the South Korean population during 2002 and 2003, suggesting that the parasite was continually introduced from other population sources. One possible source was North Korea. These findings suggest that the transmission of vivax malaria in South Korea is not continuous and that control measures may need to be adjusted accordingly.
Introns, which are non-coding segments found in the middle of genes, have been known to enhance the transcription of genes in eukaryotes for over 25 years. While the exact function of introns is still not completely understood, it is believed that they play a role in regulating transcription directionality. This is because most RNA polymerase (RNPII) transcription in eukaryotes starts in both the sense and upstream antisense directions. The transcription in the sense direction produces mRNA, while the transcription in the upstream antisense direction creates a type of transcript called uaRNA. In yeast, uaRNA synthesis is terminated by a poly ( A ) -independent mechanism, while in mammalians it is terminated by the same cleavage and polyadenylation machinery that stops mRNA synthesis. Gene looping, which is the physical interaction of the promoter and terminator regions of a gene in a transcription-dependent manner, has been shown to confer directionality to the promoter-initiated transcription. Now, a recent study has shown that the intron-facilitated gene looping recruits termination factors near the promoter region to selectively terminate uaRNA synthesis, thereby conferring directionality to the promoter-initiated transcription.
Scientists have found a gene called ZBED6 that affects muscle growth and fat deposition in animals. This gene was found after studying a mutation in pigs that was discovered to increase IGF2 production in their muscles. The mutation disrupted the interaction of IGF2 with a repressor, resulting in a 3-fold up-regulation of IGF2 in skeletal muscle. Scientists then identified the repressor and found that it is a previously unknown protein called ZBED6, which is specific for placental mammals and derived from an exapted DNA transposon. Silencing of Zbed6 in mouse C2C12 myoblasts affected Igf2 expression, cell proliferation, wound healing, and myotube formation. Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) sequencing using C2C12 cells identified about 2,500 ZBED6 binding sites in the genome, and the deduced consensus motif gave a perfect match with the established binding site in Igf2. Genes associated with ZBED6 binding sites showed a highly significant enrichment for certain Gene Ontology classifications, including development and transcriptional regulation. The phenotypic effects in mutant pigs and ZBED6-silenced C2C12 myoblasts, the extreme sequence conservation, its nucleolar localization, the broad tissue distribution, and the many target genes with essential biological functions suggest that ZBED6 is an important transcription factor in placental mammals, affecting development, cell proliferation, and growth.
We have discovered the editome of rhesus macaques, a close relative of humans, using a combination of genome and transcriptome sequencing of multiple tissues from the same animal. This study provides the first comprehensive quantitative profile of RNA editing for a non-human primate. We found 31,250 editing sites, of which 99.8% are A-to-G transitions. These findings highlight RNA editing as a widespread functional regulation in primate evolution.
Perception is a complex process that involves interpreting sensory signals and deciding what we see. Researchers have been studying how the brain does this, specifically in the primary visual cortex (V1). One approach is to decode sensory information from the neural responses in V1 into a reliable decision variable. This involves computing the likelihood that specific stimuli gave rise to the observed neural responses, which can be done using a log likelihood function. However, researchers have found that the brain does not always read out the likelihood function precisely at the relevant locations and instead reads it out broadly. This suboptimal decoding could account for previous findings of an unselective pooling of sensory responses. In the study, researchers measured how the brain perceived the spatial frequency of a grating in the presence of filtered visual noise. They found that filtered noise backgrounds dramatically altered the perception of grating spatial frequency. The researchers propose a population code model to simultaneously model grating detectability and discriminability, and estimate the amount of sensory information encoded in the V1 population response. They found that only when read-out functions as broad as 4 octaves are assumed does the model account for all behavioral measurements, indicating that the brain fails to sample the likelihood function at the appropriate locations with arbitrary high precision.
Scientists have found that Piwi-interacting RNAs (piRNAs) play a vital role in defending the genome against foreign genetic elements. In many organisms, piRNAs appear to be derived from processing of a long, polycistronic RNA precursor. However, researchers at the University of California, Santa Cruz (UCSC) have discovered that each Caenorhabditis elegans piRNA represents a tiny, autonomous transcriptional unit. This study reveals that each piRNA requires only a 21 nucleotide (nt) piRNA sequence and an approximately 50 nt upstream motif with limited genomic context for expression. The minimal C. elegans piRNA cassette can be expressed independently of other piRNA cassettes in the genome and can be selectively expressed in male or female germline. Over 70% of C. elegans piRNAs are selectively expressed in male or female germline, and the genes they target suggest that these two populations have evolved independently. The number of transcriptional units encoding piRNAs rivals the number of mRNA coding genes in the C. elegans genome. The findings of this study provide important insights into the mechanisms of piRNA biogenesis and the regulation of piRNA expression in C. elegans.
Brucella, a zoonotic pathogen, infects both animals and humans. Infection causes severe problems for both animals and humans. The bacterium is able to replicate in host cells, but the process is not well understood. The current study investigated how Brucella replicates within host cells and how it is able to use the host's resources to its advantage. The study identified a host protein called Yip1A as a key factor for Brucella replication. Yip1A is involved in the unfolded protein response, which is a cellular response to stress. The study found that Yip1A is critical for Brucella to establish a safe replication niche within host cells. The study provides important insights into the mechanisms of Brucella replication in host cells.
In this work, we show that the Tombusviruses use a cellular protein called Vps34 to build a compartment for their replication. The function of Vps34 is important for the replication of the virus. We found that the kinase function of Vps34 is important for the building of the compartment, and that Vps34 recruits a lipid called PI3P, which helps to build the compartment. We also found that Vps34 interacts directly with a replication protein called p33, which is important for the replication of the virus. Overall, our results suggest that Vps34 and PI3P are important for the replication of Tombusviruses.
The study aimed to compare methods for feeding mosquitoes with blood from humans with dengue fever for use in a larger study. The study was conducted in Iquitos, Peru, between 2011 and 2015. The researchers collected blood from 58 participants with viremias ranging from 1.3×102 to 2.9×106 focus-forming units per mL of serum and used it to feed mosquitoes directly or indirectly, with or without an additive. The study showed that infection and dissemination rates were not significantly different between direct and indirect feeding methods and infection rates varied more after indirect feeding with no additive than indirect feeding with EDTA. The study also showed that there were no differences in infection or dissemination rates in mosquitoes fed directly on participants with different dengue illness severity. The study demonstrated the feasibility of using direct and indirect feeding methods for field-based studies on vector competence. Direct mosquito feeding is preferable due to its logistical ease, biosecurity, and reliability.
A group of drugs called topoisomerase II poisons are used to treat cancer, but they are differentially effective from one patient to the next. A study used the roundworm Caenorhabditis elegans to investigate the genetic basis of this variation. The researchers found that wild strains of C. elegans vary in their sensitivity to these drugs, and they used an unbiased genetic approach to determine that natural variation in a methionine-to-glutamine substitution in the topoisomerase II enzyme is the cause of this variation. The presence of a non-polar methionine at this residue increases hydrophobic interactions between topoisomerase II and etoposide, resulting in increased genomic instability in strains that contain a methionine residue. This residue is conserved in humans, and it has a different amino acid in the two topoisomerase II isoforms. The researchers went on to show that this amino acid difference influences cytotoxicity of topoisomerase II poisons in human cell lines. These results demonstrate the utility of C. elegans in understanding the genetics of drug responses, which can lead to more effective and personalized treatments for cancer patients.
Scientists found that some African mole-rat species have much longer lifespans than similar species, and wanted to learn more about the genes that might be involved in this extended lifespan. They collected genetic and gene expression data from 17 rodent species and looked for genes that had been positively selected along 11 different evolutionary branches that were related to enhanced longevity. They found that many of the identified positively selected genes were related to aging and longevity, and had functions that could help explain why the African mole-rats had longer lifespans. They also found that many of these genes were upregulated or downregulated differently in old and young animals, which could help explain how aging works. Overall, their results suggest that these mole-rat genes could be important for understanding how to extend human lifespans.
This paper presents a new strategy to control the spread of mosquito-borne diseases by introducing a new Wolbachia strain into a mosquito line. The new line, ARwP-M, was created by inserting the wMel Wolbachia strain into an existing line, ARwP, which has wAlbA and wAlbB Wolbachia strains. The study found that ARwP-M females have 15 times higher levels of Wolbachia than ARwP females and that this high level is associated with a lower rate of transmission of chikungunya and dengue viruses. The study also found that ARwP-M males are more sterile than ARwP males, which may be useful for controlling mosquito populations. Overall, this new line of mosquitoes could be a promising tool for controlling mosquito-borne diseases.
The article "Domain-peptide interactions: Structural and evolutionary aspects" presents a new method to identify domain-peptide interactions (DPI) based on the structural analysis of known high-resolution 3D structures. These interactions play a critical role in signaling networks, where they transmit information and regulate biological processes. The new method involves the use of Support Vector Machines (SVMs) and other structure-encoded information about binding interfaces to search for unnoticed DPIs among known protein interactions. The study reveals that DPIs often have a characteristic stretched and elongated structure, different from other peptides of the same length. The authors also identify novel peptide-binding domains, along with their respective high-resolution 3D structures and consensus motifs, that have not been described before. These new insights provide molecular details for many protein interactions discovered in high-throughput initiatives and suggest relevant mutagenesis experiments to tinker with them.
Environmental enteropathy (EE) is a common health problem that causes stunting in children and growth failure in adults. It is caused by poor sanitation and leads to impaired absorption of nutrients, micronutrient malabsorption, and immune responses to vaccines. We used confocal laser endomicroscopy and other techniques to study EE in 49 adults from Lusaka, Zambia. We found that nearly all of the participants had damage to the intestinal lining. We also found that this damage was associated with increased leakage of material from the gut into the bloodstream, lower nutrient absorption, and higher levels of inflammation in the body. Transcriptomic analysis identified several genes that may be important in protecting the gut from damage. We also found that higher levels of a hormone called GLP-2 were associated with better gut function. We conclude that EE is a complex condition that affects the gut, immune system, and overall health, and that further research is needed to better understand how to prevent and treat it.
The paper introduces the phenomenon of superinfection exclusion (SIE), where a virus stops another virus from infecting the same cell, even if the second virus is very similar to the first. The paper then explains that the SIE phenomenon has been observed in many different types of viruses, including human and animal pathogenic viruses like HIV and HCV, as well as plant viruses like TMV. The paper then explains that SIE is determined by one or a few virus-encoded proteins and relatively little involvement of host cell components, highlighting SIE as a primarily virus-driven phenomenon. The paper then describes the authors' research on the turnip crinkle virus (TCV), which encodes a protein called p28. The authors found that p28 is the only protein responsible for SIE in TCV infections. They also discovered that p28 forms large, mobile punctate inclusions in infected cells that trans-aggregate a non-coalescing, SIE-defective p28 mutant. The authors propose a model whereby p28 forms multimeric complexes that intercept fresh p28 monomers translated from superinfectors, abolishing superinfector replication. The authors also found that this model could be applicable to many other RNA viruses, and predicts a novel target for antiviral therapy.
Scientists have been working on vaccines for Trypanosoma cruzi, a parasite that causes Chagas disease in humans.
