They have been testing vaccines that use DNA or protein from the parasite to stimulate the immune system to make antibodies against the parasite. In this study, scientists tested if adding a protein called IL-15 to the DNA or protein vaccines would improve the immune response and protection against the parasite. They found that adding IL-15 to the DNA or protein vaccines improved the immune response and protection against the parasite for at least 6 months after vaccination.
Scientists discovered a way to control the amount of a protein called PLK in a parasite called Trypanosoma brucei. They found that this protein plays a crucial role in the formation of a new structure called flagellum attachment zone, which helps the parasite to grow. The scientists found that a protein called WDR1 binds to PLK and helps to control its level. When the level of WDR1 is reduced, the level of PLK increases, leading to abnormal development. The scientists believe that this discovery can help to develop new treatments for diseases caused by this parasite.
This paper explores the role of a specific type of protein called DEAD box RNA helicases in the innate immune system. These proteins play an important role in detecting and fighting off infections. In particular, a type of DEAD box RNA helicase called DDX3X was found to be crucial for a response to infection. Mice that lack DDX3X have altered leukocyte compositions, which affects their ability to fight off infections. This is due to decreased effector cell availability and function as well as impaired cytokine synthesis. The study provides evidence for the importance of a non-RLR DEAD box RNA helicase in innate immunity and suggests that this protein may contribute to sex-related differences in resistance to microbes and resilience to inflammatory disease.
A new biophysical model of how male moths detect pheromone molecules has been developed. This model takes into account all the steps of the transduction process, from the arrival of pheromone molecules in the antenna to the generation of the receptor potential in the ORNs. It also focuses on the main post-effector processes, such as the production and degradation of second messengers, the opening and closing of various ionic channels, and the modulation of the effector and channels by various modulators. The model was used to simulate the evolution of chemical species and currents in response to various pheromone doses, and was found to capture the main features of the dose-response curves. The model also made several predictions that can be tested in future studies.
The study of how a tumor suppressor protein called p53 regulates gene expression is important for understanding its function. Researchers have used genome-wide mapping of DNA binding sites for p53 and chromatin structure in human lymphoblastoid cells. They found that p53 binding was correlated with chromatin accessibility and p53RE sequence content. The study also revealed that p53 binding was inversely correlated with evolutionary conservation of p53REs. These findings suggest that p53 binding is influenced by both chromatin structure and evolutionary factors.
The paper by Lukyanov and colleagues from St. Petersburg State University in Russia aimed to understand the signal-response relationship of a specific type of two-component signaling system in bacteria and yeast. In this system, a single histidine kinase (HK) can transfer its phosphoryl group to two separate response regulators (RRs). The authors showed that this one HK-two RR system is able to implement a sigmoidal signal-response relationship, which allows the system to act like a switch that has a threshold level of signal input and sensitivity. They confirmed their findings experimentally by in vitro reconstitution of the chemotaxis pathway of S. meliloti and measuring the resulting signal-response curve. They also found that the level of sigmoidality in this system can be experimentally controlled by the presence of the sink RR and an auxiliary protein that binds to the HK, yielding Hill coefficients of above 7.
When exposed to stress, not all cells within the same population respond in the same way. Some cells survive, while others do not. This is known as cell-to-cell variation in stress tolerance. The causes of this variation are not clear. In this study, researchers used single-cell RNA sequencing to quantify transcript variation in single yeast cells treated with and without salt stress. They found significant regulatory variation in individual yeast cells, both before and after stress. They also discovered that a subset of cells appears to decouple expression of ribosomal protein genes from the environmental stress response in a manner partly correlated with the cell cycle but unrelated to the yeast ultradian metabolic cycle. The researchers used live-cell imaging of cells expressing pairs of fluorescent regulators, including the transcription factor Msn2 with Dot6, Sfp1, or MAP kinase Hog1. They found that cells maintain a cellular filter against decoupled bursts of transcription factor activation but mount a stress response upon coordinated regulation. The study suggests that cells maintain a cellular filter against decoupled bursts of transcription factor activation but mount a stress response upon coordinated regulation, even in a subset of unstressed cells. Understanding what gives rise to cell-to-cell variation in stress survival has broad applications, including treating pathogenic microbial infections and blocking drug-resistant human metastases.
The parasite Trypanosoma brucei, which is transmitted by tsetse flies, causes African trypanosomiasis. A study has shown that parasites can accumulate in large numbers in the mouse testis, epididymis, and epididymal adipose tissue. This accumulation is associated with severe inflammation and tissue damage. Infected mice have reduced fertility. The study suggests that T. brucei may be transmitted sexually in addition to the previously known mode of transmission through the bite of a tsetse fly.
Drosophila melanogaster, also known as the fruit fly, has a well-characterized chemosensory system, which allows it to detect odors and tastes. This study used customized microarrays to investigate how the expression of chemosensory genes changes under different conditions. The study found that genes within a cluster are independently regulated in males and females, during different developmental stages, and under different physiological and social conditions. Whereas many chemosensory genes showed plasticity in expression, a smaller number of exceptionally plastic genes was evident. Analysis of covariance of transcript levels across all environmental conditions showed that the chemosensory subgenome is structured as a mosaic of 20 small modules of highly correlated transcripts. This finely pixilated modular organization of the chemosensory transcriptome allows finely tuned phenotypic plasticity of expression of the chemoreceptor repertoire under different environmental conditions.
This paper is about how certain kinds of chromosomal errors happen during egg formation in humans. These errors can lead to genetic conditions, such as having an extra chromosome. The authors explain that a special kind of protein called MLH1 helps mark where recombination happens during egg formation. They used this protein to look at how often recombination happens in human eggs and where the recombination happens. They found that recombination happens less often than expected, and that it often happens in places that are more likely to cause chromosome errors. They also found that different chromosomes have different patterns of recombination.
Blood-feeding arthropods like mosquitoes, sand flies, and ticks transmit many diseases that cause serious health and economic problems to people worldwide. When these insects bite mammals, they inject saliva that contains immunogenic compounds that help them feed. Some of these compounds can also alter the immune response of the mammal, which can affect the severity of the disease if the mammal is later infected. In this study, the authors created a mathematical model to explore how the immune response to insect bites could affect the spread of vector-borne diseases. They found that increasing the mortality of the insects could either increase or decrease the number of infected hosts, depending on the effect of pre-sensitisation on the duration of infection. The authors conclude that further research is needed to understand the complex ways that insect saliva and host immunity interact and affect the spread of vector-borne diseases.
In this study, the researchers compared the proteomes of amastigotes (the infective form of Leishmania parasites) isolated from two different mice strains (BALB/c and BALB/c nude). They found that there were 44 differentially expressed proteins in the two strains. These proteins were related to oxidative/nitrosative stress and proteases. The researchers also found that some of the proteins were known virulence factors, and that the posttranslational modifications of these virulence factors were influenced by the host immune response. The researchers believe that this study could help identify potential virulence factors and ways of regulating their expression.
This study shows that the protein Activation Induced Deaminase (AID) is controlled by the cell cycle. AID is responsible for changing cytosines to uracils in DNA in activated B cells, which leads to changes in the immune response. The study found that AID is more stable in the nucleus during the G1 phase of the cell cycle than during the S or G2/M phase. Mutations that affect the activity or stability of AID can also affect its abundance in the nucleus. The study used a technique called nuclear localization tags to force AID to be located in the nucleus outside of the G1 phase. The study found that forcing AID to be in the nucleus during the G1 phase increased the rate of changes in the immune response, but did not harm the cells. The study also found that forcing AID to be in the nucleus during the S or G2/M phase was harmful to the cells. The study generated AID derivatives that increased the rate of changes in the immune response with less harm to the cells. The study suggests that the cell cycle can be used to control the amount of AID in the nucleus, which can be useful for engineering genes and proteins.
This research paper presents a new method for analyzing the ability of bacteria to break down different types of plant material. The researchers used a special type of plate called an agar plate to grow different types of bacteria on different types of plant material. They then used a technique called strand-specific RNA sequencing to learn more about the genes that the bacteria use to break down the plant material. They also used a technique called CAZyme assays to learn more about the enzymes that the bacteria use to break down the plant material. The researchers found that different types of bacteria break down different types of plant material in different ways. They also found that some enzymes work better together to break down plant material than they do alone. This information can be used to learn more about how different types of bacteria break down different types of plant material and to develop new ways to use plant material for food and energy.
The paper is about a study on the impact of three rounds of MDA (mass drug administration) on the prevalence and density of lymphatic filariasis (LF) in 12 rural health districts of Sierra Leone. The study found that after three rounds of MDA, the prevalence of LF decreased to less than 1% in all but one district, and the overall arithmetic mean mf density decreased by 65.4% among mf-positive individuals and 96.2% for the entire population examined. The study concluded that the prevalence of LF decreased significantly after three rounds of MDA.
The paper discusses the use of high-throughput sequencing techniques, such as 16S rRNA gene profiling, to study the complex microbial communities in the world's oceans and the human gut. The authors describe a common method of analyzing such data by identifying correlations between taxa using correlation analysis. However, they explain that this method may produce unreliable results due to compositional effects. They demonstrate that such effects can be widespread and severe, and suggest that community diversity is a key factor that modulates the severity of such effects. The authors introduce a new approach called SparCC, which is capable of estimating correlation values from compositional data. They use SparCC to infer a rich ecological network connecting hundreds of interacting species across 18 sites on the human body and estimate that the standard approach yields 3 spurious species-species interactions for each true interaction and misses 60% of the true interactions in the human microbiome data. The authors conclude that SparCC is a reliable and valid method for identifying correlations between taxa in high-throughput sequencing-based microbial communities.
The paper is about how lysozyme, an antimicrobial protein found in high amounts in mucosal surfaces like the upper respiratory tract, kills bacteria. The authors show that two enzymes, PgdA and Adr, are involved in S. pneumoniae's resistance to lysozyme. They show that a mutation in either of these genes increases S. pneumoniae's sensitivity to lysozyme in vitro. The authors then demonstrate the importance of lysozyme and PgdA and Adr in determining the composition of the microflora of the mucosal surface of the upper airway.
The study aimed to investigate the usefulness of using NS1 capture tests to detect the presence of dengue virus (DENV) in human tissue specimens from previously confirmed dengue fatal cases. This study was conducted in Brazil, where approximately 80% of dengue cases occur in the Americas. The goal of the study was to determine the sensitivity of three NS1 capture tests, the first generation Dengue Early ELISA (PanBio Diagnostics), Platelia NS1 (BioRad Laboratories), and the rapid test NS1 Ag Strip (BioRad Laboratories). The researchers analyzed 74 tissue specimens from 23 dengue fatal cases, including liver, lung, kidney, brain, heart, skin, spleen, thymus, and lymph nodes. The overall diagnosis of dengue based on the tissues analyzed by Dengue Early ELISA, Platelia NS1, and the NS1 Ag Strip was 34.7%, 60.8%, and 91.3%, respectively. The NS1 Ag Strip was the most sensitive, with a sensitivity of 78.3%. The study concluded that the NS1 capture assay is a valuable tool for postmortem dengue confirmation and is useful for cases confirmation in an increasing number of dengue hemorrhagic fever and fatal cases.
Multiple Myeloma (MM) is a cancer of plasma cells that affects the bone marrow. It is more common in African Americans (AA) compared to Caucasians (CA) and leads to higher incidence and mortality rates among AA patients. A study used somatic whole exome, RNA-sequencing, and clinical data from 718 MM patients from the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation CoMMpass study Interim Analysis 9 to analyze the differences in molecular alterations in MM as a function of self-reported race and genetic ancestry. The study found significant differences in mutation frequency between AA and CA cases. The mutations in BCL7A, BRWD3, and AUTS2 were found to be higher in frequency among AA cases while TP53 and IRF4 mutations were more frequent among CA cases. The study suggests that interrogating diverse tumor cohorts is important to understand tumor genomics across populations.
The study aimed to understand the growth of cancer cells and how mutations occur during this process. It focused on neutral mutations (passengers) that do not affect the growth of the cell, but can still provide important information about the timing of cancer evolution. The study used a mathematical model to simulate the growth of a population of cancer cells, taking into account the birth and death of cells and the occurrence of mutations. The model allowed the authors to predict the likelihood of specific evolutionary trees and the number of cancer cells present at a particular point in time. They also derived an equation to estimate the number of subclonal mutations present in a cancer. Fitting this equation to cancer sequencing data led to an estimate of the ratio of birth and death rates of cancer cells during the early stages of clonal expansion. Overall, the study shows that passenger mutations can be used to infer important information about the timing of cancer evolution.
Huntington's disease (HD) is a neurodegenerative disorder caused by a mutation in the Huntingtin gene. The first exon (XN1) of this gene contains a polyglutamine (polyQ) region that is believed to play a key role in the development of HD. In this study, the authors used molecular dynamics simulations to study the misfolding of XN1 and its role in the development of HD. They created different constructs of XN1 and polyQ homopolymers (Qn) to study the effect of the length of the polyQ region on its misfolding. They found that the probability of XN1 and Qn to form β-rich misfolded states increased as the length of the polyQ region increased. The authors also found that the flanking regions surrounding the polyQ region affect its probability to form a β-rich state compared to the isolated polyQ peptide. They suggest that their findings provide a structural insight of XN1 misfolding and may help to develop strategies to inhibit XN1 aggregation.
The article describes a study of CRISPR (Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats), a protective system that some bacteria and archaea use to fight against foreign nucleic acids. The study used metagenomic datasets from the Human Microbiome Project to analyze the distribution and diversity of known and new CRISPRs in the human microbiome. The researchers developed a new method for reconstructing CRISPR arrays, which allowed them to identify 64 known and 86 novel CRISPRs in the human microbiome. They found that the distributions of CRISPRs are largely body-site specific, and they provided several examples of how CRISPRs can be used to trace rare species and study virus exposure in individuals. The study highlights the importance of identifying and characterizing CRISPR loci in order to better understand the ecology of the human microbiome.
Scientists have found that C. elegans, a type of roundworm that lives in the soil, has a circadian clock. This clock is not as stable or well-known as the clock in other animals, but scientists have found evidence that it exists. They did this by studying the genes that are expressed when C. elegans is exposed to light or temperature changes. These genes are expressed in a rhythmic way that lasts for about 24 hours, which is the length of a day. They also found that this rhythmic expression is stable and can still happen when C. elegans is not exposed to any changes in light or temperature. The scientists also found that the light and temperature changes can cause different groups of genes to be expressed in a rhythmic way, but these groups do not necessarily overlap. They also found that the genes that are thought to be part of the clock are not expressed in a rhythmic way. They also found that a specific type of channel that helps animals sense temperature and light is important for the circadian rhythm in C. elegans. Overall, these findings show that C. elegans has a circadian clock that can be affected by light and temperature changes.
The S. cerevisiae RAD3 gene is a DNA helicase that is part of the TFIIH complex. It plays a role in both nucleotide excision repair (NER) and transcription. Some mutant alleles of RAD3 have partial defects in DNA repair and a strong hyper-Rec phenotype. Previous studies showed that the hyper-Rec phenotype associated with rad3-101 and rad3-102 can be explained as a consequence of persistent single-stranded DNA gaps that are converted to recombinogenic double-strand breaks (DSBs) by replication. This study further characterizes these events using a system that recovers the reciprocal products of mitotic recombination. Both rad3-101 and rad3-102 elevate the frequency of reciprocal crossovers about 100-fold. Mapping of these events shows that three-quarters of these crossovers reflect DSBs formed at the same positions in both sister chromatids (double sister-chromatid breaks, DSCBs). The remainder reflects DSBs formed in single chromatids (single chromatid breaks, SCBs). The ratio of DSCBs to SCBs is similar to that observed for spontaneous recombination events in wild-type cells. A comparison of these data with previous analysis of spontaneous mitotic recombination events suggests that a sub-set of spontaneous events in wild-type cells may be initiated by incomplete NER reactions, and that DSCBs, which cannot be repaired by sister-chromatid recombination, are a major source of mitotic recombination between homologous chromosomes. The study also found a significant association between the location of these recombination events and regions with elevated gamma-H2AX, and a hotspot for deletions and duplications at the IMA2 and HXT11 genes near the left end of chromosome XV.
Scientists have found a way to explain how a small genetic change in the bacterium Helicobacter pylori affects the way it binds to human stomach tissue. When H. pylori infects the stomach, it needs to adapt to the changing environment inside the stomach to survive. To do this, the bacterium has a genetic change that allows it to switch on or off the expression of a protein called SabA, which helps the bacterium bind to human stomach tissue. The genetic change is caused by a slip in the DNA strands, which creates different versions of the genetic code for SabA. Scientists have found that the length of the genetic code for SabA controls how much SabA is made and how well the bacterium binds to human stomach tissue. They have also found that this genetic change is common in H. pylori strains from different people.
The JAK-STAT family of proteins are important regulators of the innate immune system. HPVs (human papillomaviruses) are the cause of cervical and other genital cancers, and they must evade the innate immune system to establish infections. HPV proteins downregulate the expression of STAT-1 to allow for stable maintenance of viral episomes. However, this study finds that HPV E7 activates STAT-5 phosphorylation without altering total protein levels. Inhibition of STAT-5 phosphorylation with the drug pimozide abolishes viral genome amplification and late gene expression in differentiating keratinocytes. Knockdown studies show that the STAT-5β isoform is mainly responsible for this activity and that this is mediated through the ATM DNA damage response. A downstream target of STAT-5, the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ (PPARγ), contributes to the effects on members of the ATM pathway. Overall, these findings identify an important new regulatory mechanism by which the innate immune regulator STAT-5 promotes HPV viral replication through activation of the ATM DNA damage response.
Typhoid fever is caused by the bacteria Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi (S. Typhi) and Paratyphi A (S. Paratyphi A). It affects over 21 million people each year and can result in death in 200,000 cases. The majority of patients recover from the acute stage of illness and clear infection. However, a small percentage of infected individuals develop a chronic but asymptomatic infection in the biliary tract that can persist for decades. Chronic carriers may act as reservoirs of infection within a community, contributing to the transmission cycle through intermittent shedding of bacteria in feces and introducing S. Typhi and S. Paratyphi A into previously uninfected communities. There is currently no reliable diagnostic assay to identify asymptomatic carriers. A study by Klemm et al. aimed to identify potential biomarkers unique to S. Typhi carriers through an immunoscreening technique called in vivo-induced antigen technology (IVIAT). IVIAT identifies immunogenic bacterial antigens expressed in vivo, not in bacteria grown in standard laboratory conditions. The study identified 13 antigens that were immunoreactive in carriers, but not in healthy individuals from a typhoid endemic area, including putative membrane proteins, lipoproteins, and hemolysin-related proteins. Further evaluation of these antigens could lead to the development of improved diagnostic assays for asymptomatic carriers of S. Typhi and S. Paratyphi A.
Scientists have recently discovered that a wide range of RNA molecules are expressed in eukaryotic genomes. These RNA molecules are called non-coding RNAs (ncRNAs) and are involved in regulating gene expression. It has also been observed that these RNA molecules are part of epigenetic regulatory networks, which are heritable and have shown surprising evolutionary conservation. In this study, the authors examined the role of cellular RNA pools produced by homologous genomic loci in changing the transcriptional state of a silenced gene. They discovered that non-functional alleles of a white gene, unable to produce a coding transcript, could reactivate in trans the expression of a wild type copy of the same gene silenced by heterochromatin. This new epigenetic phenomenon of transcriptional trans-reactivation is heritable, relies on the presence of homologous RNA's, and is affected by mutations in genes involved in post-transcriptional gene silencing. Overall, the authors found that trans-reactivation is a new epigenetic phenomenon that positively controls gene expression in the context of heterochromatin through homologous RNA molecules.
Ticks and mosquitoes are known for feeding on blood, and they do this by expressing protease inhibitors to prevent the blood from clotting. These inhibitors are found in different parts of their bodies, such as salivary glands and midguts. Boophilin is a protease inhibitor that was identified in the midgut of ticks. It can inhibit the activity of several different enzymes involved in blood clotting, including thrombin, elastase, and kallikrein. It can also block the activity of platelets, which are blood cells involved in clotting. The authors of this study have expressed Boophilin in cells and purified it to study its properties in more detail. They have shown that Boophilin behaves as a non-competitive inhibitor of thrombin, meaning that it binds to the enzyme and prevents it from binding to its substrate. They have also shown that Boophilin can inhibit thrombosis in vivo, meaning that it can prevent blood clots from forming in living animals.
A new model called Spatially Explicit General-purpose Model of Enteric Tissue (SEGMEnT) has been created to understand how the architecture of the intestinal mucosa is influenced by inflammation. The model can be used to understand the role of inflammation as a controller of enteric mucosal tissue patterning and to identify the underlying cellular and molecular dynamics that determine the epithelial crypt-villus architecture across a range of conditions from health to disease. The model has been able to reproduce healthy ileal mucosal dynamics and a series of morphogen knock-out/inhibition experiments. The SEGMEnT model has also been used to investigate two types of potentially pathogenic conditions: acute insults/perturbations and chronic conditions. The model has been able to generate colonic metaplasia of the ileum as seen after surgery for ulcerative colitis by proposing a new link between inflammation and the induction of apoptosis through the Phosphotase and tensin homolog/phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PTEN/PI3K) pathway. The SEGMEnT model is a dynamic knowledge representation of a minimally sufficient set of components, mechanisms, and interactions for the maintenance of enteric mucosal architecture (morphogenesis) and the effect of inflammation. The model can be used as a community resource by allowing researchers to instantiate and investigate their own knowledge and try out novel and innovative hypotheses for a range of intestinal diseases.
This study describes the release and evaluation of a Wolbachia strain, wMelRio, in the Brazilian community of Tubiacanga, Rio de Janeiro. The goal of this study was to establish Wolbachia in the local mosquito population to control the spread of arboviruses such as dengue, Zika, and yellow fever. However, the previous release of a different Wolbachia strain, wMelBr, was unable to establish in the local population. The study investigated the factors that contributed to the failure of wMelBr, including insecticide resistance. The study also developed a new Wolbachia strain, wMelRio, by backcrossing the wMelBr strain with local mosquitoes to make it more fit and better suited to the local population. The wMelRio strain was then released and successfully established in the local population. The study highlights the importance of matching the genetic background of Wolbachia strains to the local population to ensure successful establishment.
Poxviruses, like other viruses, have sophisticated pathways that control their growth and allow them to infect and multiply in cells. These pathways are controlled by proteins that communicate with each other and regulate cellular defenses. Scientists have recently discovered that a protein called B1 plays a vital role in the vaccinia virus. In this study, researchers have used experimental evolution to search for genes that could take over the function of B1. They found that the B12 gene was able to suppress the B1 deletion phenotype and enhance the fitness of the virus.
The study investigates the folding and aggregation behavior of two synthetic peptides, LKKLLKLLKKLLKL (LK) and EAALAEALAEALAE (EALA), with built-in amphiphilic properties upon forming an alpha-helix. The peptides were found to neither form random coils in bulk water nor fully formed alpha-helices, but adopt multiple conformations and secondary structure elements with short lifetimes. Differences in their response to macroscopic and molecular interfaces can be linked to their inherent alpha-helical tendencies in bulk water. The presence of interfaces or an aggregation partner was shown to strongly affect their aggregation behavior and to affect their folding and aggregation equilibria.
Researchers have discovered that human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) can integrate its DNA into the telomeres of human chromosomes. Telomeres are protective caps at the end of chromosomes that help keep genes intact. HHV-6 has two copies of telomeric repeats (TMR) that are similar to human telomeres at the beginning and end of its genome. The researchers used viruses with missing or altered TMR to see if they could still infect and integrate into human cells. They found that the TMR are important for integration to occur. They also discovered that one copy of TMR is more important than the other for integration to happen. This finding could help us understand how HHV-6 infects and integrates into human cells.
The article provides a detailed structural and functional characterization of the Vaccinia Capsid Protein 13 (D13). It highlights the importance of D13 in the assembly of immature virions of vaccinia virus and its ability to remodel lipid membranes. The article also discusses the molecular mechanisms underlying the assembly of immature virions.
Auxin is a hormone important for plant growth and development, including root growth and branching. In Arabidopsis thaliana, auxin biosynthesis is essential for root growth, and this biosynthesis requires two genes: TRYPTOPHAN AMINOTRANSFERASE OF ARABIDOPSIS 1 (TAA1) and TAA1-RELATED (TAR). However, in a monocotyledon plant called Brachypodium distachyon, ethylene inhibits the rate-limiting step of auxin biosynthesis in an indole-3-pyruvic acid (IPA)-dependent manner. This results in sub-optimal auxin levels that are necessary for root cell elongation. In Brachypodium, the ethylene precursor 1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylic-acid (ACC) suppresses the root phenotypes, and this is accompanied by down-regulation of the rate-limiting step of auxin biosynthesis. Furthermore, ethylene inhibits the rate-limiting step of auxin biosynthesis by inhibiting BdTAR2L, which encodes a B. distachyon gene that is homologous to the TAR2 gene in Arabidopsis. This suggests that the wiring of auxin-ethylene crosstalk is different in Arabidopsis and Brachypodium.
This article discusses how genes evolve at different rates in different species, and how the organization of their promoter nucleosomes affects this. To study this, the authors artificially selected for high expression of GFP-fused yeast proteins. They found that both OPN and DPN genes could successfully increase expression by a similar amount, but did so by different mechanisms: OPN genes mostly underwent trans mutations, while DPN genes underwent large-scale duplications. When selection was removed, DPN genes quickly reverted back to their original expression levels, while OPN genes did not. This suggests that promoter organization affects the early evolutionary dynamics and biases the path of long-term evolution.
HTLV-1 is a virus that causes a type of cancer called adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma. The virus's main protein, Tax, activates the NF-κB pathway. This pathway is important for the virus to survive and spread. However, Tax also causes cellular senescence, which is a program that stops the cell from dividing. This program is caused by the proteins p21CIP1/WAF1 and p27KIP1, which are controlled by NF-κB. The senescence program acts as a checkpoint that stops the NF-κB pathway from becoming overactive. The virus's anti-sense protein, HBZ, can mitigate the senescence program by reducing the activity of NF-κB. This allows the virus-infected cells to continue to divide and persist.
The human brain's frontal lobes are responsible for decision-making and controlling actions. However, existing models of frontal executive function cannot explain how the brain handles changing and uncertain situations, which require exploring and adapting to different strategies. We propose a new model, named PROBE, which can explain these strategies. The PROBE model uses behavioral experiments to test its predictions. We compare the PROBE model to other models, and we find that it can best fit the human data. Moreover, our model suggests that the frontal lobe can monitor up to three or four strategies at the same time, and that new strategies are created if none of the existing strategies is reliable enough. This finding suggests that the frontal lobe has a limited monitoring capacity, but this limitation is compensated by its ability to explore and create new strategies.
In this paper, we present a new modeling approach, called Analysis of Dynamic Adaptations in Parameter Trajectories (ADAPT), to analyze the long-term effects of a pharmacological treatment. This approach is particularly useful to study biological systems where the network topology is relatively well known, such as metabolic pathways. The concept of time-dependent evolution of model parameters is introduced to study the dynamics of molecular adaptations. The trajectories of model parameters are predicted by identifying necessary dynamic changes in these parameters to describe the transition between experimental data obtained during different stages of the treatment. These trajectories provide insight into the affected underlying biological systems and the molecular events that should be studied in more detail to unravel the mechanistic basis of treatment outcome. We demonstrate how ADAPT can be used to design new target interventions to prevent unwanted side effects.
The authors present a new hypothesis for how the spinocerebellar systems and the cerebellar cortex can interact to support coordination of our multi-segmented limbs and bodies. The hypothesis proposes that the spinal circuitry provides useful recombinations of sensory and motor signals, which can be described as linear projections through aspects of the multi-dimensional sensorimotor input space. The cerebellar granule cells potentially with the aid of differentiated thresholding from Golgi cells, enhance the utility of these projections by allowing the Purkinje cell to establish piecewise-linear approximations of non-linear functions. The authors find that random recombination of sensory and motor signals is not a good strategy since the number of granule cells severely limits the number of recombinations that can be represented within the cerebellum. The authors provide a novel view on the function of the spinal circuitry and cerebellar granule layer, illustrating how the coordinating functions of the cerebellum can be crucially supported by the recombinations performed by the neurons of the spinocerebellar systems.
The study aimed to investigate the role of miRNAs in the Aedes albopictus mosquito host during Chikungunya virus (CHIKV) infection. The study used deep sequencing of small RNA populations in Ae. albopictus Singh's cell line both before and after CHIKV infection. The study identified 88 and 79 known miRNAs in uninfected and CHIKV-infected Ae. albopictus cells, respectively. Additionally, nine novel miRNAs were identified in Ae. albopictus cells. Comparison of the two libraries revealed differential expression of 77 common miRNAs between them. CHIKV infection specifically altered the miRNA profile of eight miRNAs. These miRNAs were predicted to target specific pathways and cellular processes, and the study's findings suggest that the miRNA profile of Ae. albopictus cells can be modified during CHIKV infection. The study's findings also provide insights for identifying potential candidates for vector-based antiviral strategies.
Cystic Echinococcosis (CE) is a parasitic infection that affects humans and livestock and causes a great deal of medical and economic problems in many countries, including Iran. The aim of the study is to estimate the monetary burden of CE in Iran by using epidemiological and economic data. The study found that the annual cost of CE in Iran was about US$232.3 million, including both direct and indirect costs. The cost associated with human CE was estimated at US$93.39 million, while the annual cost associated with CE in livestock was estimated at US$132 million. The cost per surgical human case was estimated at US$1,539. It is important to note that this disease has a considerable economic impact on Iran, with the cost of the disease estimated to be 0.03% of the country's gross domestic product. The study recommends the establishment of a surveillance system and a control program for CE to reduce its economic burden on Iran.
The aim of this study is to understand how a virus called mouse polyomavirus (MPyV) affects its host cells. The researchers infected mouse cells with MPyV and used a deep sequencing method to follow the infection over time. They found that MPyV genes are expressed in a specific way and that certain host genes are also affected. The researchers analyzed the changes in the levels of both viral and host transcripts, splicing, and editing that occurs during MPyV infection. At 36 hours after infection, 359 host genes were upregulated and 857 host genes were downregulated. Gene ontology analysis showed that the upregulated genes were mainly involved in metabolism, DNA replication, RNA processing, and translation, while the downregulated genes were mainly involved in transcription regulation, cell adhesion, extracellular matrix, and signal transduction. The researchers also looked at the binding of specific transcription factors to the genes that were upregulated and downregulated. This study provides important information about how MPyV affects its host cells and could help in understanding how to treat or prevent MPyV infection.
This article presents a mathematical model of the energy requirements and fuel use of marathon runners. The model takes into account the runner's aerobic capacity, the energy cost of running at different speeds, and the size of their glycogen stores before and after loading. The model is used to estimate the distance at which a runner will exhaust their glycogen stores and the fastest pace they can maintain over that distance. The model can also be used to determine the optimal pacing strategy for a given runner and to estimate their expected finishing time based on their individual physiological characteristics.
Toxoplasma is a type of parasite that causes toxoplasmosis in humans. There are three main clonal lineages of Toxoplasma in Europe and North America, but in South America many other strains exist. These strains differ in several ways, including their virulence, persistence, oral infectivity, migratory capacity, induction of cytokine expression, and modulation of host gene expression. In this study, researchers infected 29 different Toxoplasma strains, representing global diversity, with murine macrophages and used RNA-sequencing to determine the host and parasite transcriptomes. They found that some strains had large structural variations that had an impact on gene expression levels, and that a few atypical strains induced macrophage type I interferon production, which was associated with parasite killing. This study provides insight into the host response to a large variety of Toxoplasma strains and can form the basis for the discovery of novel Toxoplasma effectors.
The current study presents a new method to better understand how recombination works in viruses. In particular, the authors studied recombination in enteroviruses, a group of viruses that includes polioviruses. Recombination is a way that viruses can change and evolve, and it is an important process for their survival. However, it is not well understood how it works. The authors used a new method to study recombination in enteroviruses, which involves using reverse genetics to create chimeric viruses with duplicated sections. They then used serial passage to study the stability of these viruses and how they evolved. The study found that recombination is a two-step process. First, a chimeric virus is created with a duplicated section. Then, this virus undergoes deletion of the duplicated section, resulting in a viral genome of the expected size. This study provides important insights into how recombination works in positive-strand RNA viruses, and how viruses can evolve over time. The new method used in this study can be used to further study this important process.
The study presents a new approach to fighting obesity by targeting white adipose tissue (WAT) through the use of norepinephrine (NE) to activate the browning of WAT. The researchers discovered that the uptake rate of NE by Oct3 in white adipocytes is the greatest among the known routes of NE clearance. They further demonstrated that adipocytes can clear NE by expressing NE degradation enzymes and reuptake transporter Oct3. When Oct3 is knocked out in adipocytes, the mice show higher body temperatures, thermogenesis, and lipolysis compared to control mice. In addition, the researchers found that humans with fewer functional alleles in the OCT3 gene have increased basal metabolic rate. The study suggests that Oct3 can be used as a therapeutic target to combat obesity by promoting the browning of WAT through NE clearance.
The HP1 proteins play a crucial role in regulating the structure and activity of genes in our bodies. These proteins can bind to DNA and regulate the activity of genes. To better understand how HP1 proteins work, researchers are trying to find out more about how they bind to DNA. They have found that HP1 proteins bind to a particular area of the DNA called the nucleosome. However, this binding is not very strong. The researchers also found that the hSWI/SNF complex, which helps to unpack DNA and make it more accessible, can interfere with the binding of HP1 proteins to DNA. This suggests that hSWI/SNF helps to control how HP1 proteins work on DNA.
RNA molecules usually fold into a certain shape to function properly. This folding happens because different parts of the RNA tend to stick together, like pieces of a puzzle. RNAs like miRNAs have the tendency to keep their shape, even when they are cut out of a larger RNA molecule and put into a new location. This property is important for miRNAs because they are made by cutting a piece of RNA out of a larger molecule. The researchers found that miRNAs tend to have this property, while other RNAs don't. They also found that miRNAs from the same family and that are located in different parts of the genome tend to have this property. This property is important because it allows miRNAs to function properly in different locations.
We discovered four new plant transcription factors that control resistance to necrotrophic fungi. These transcription factors are part of a complex signaling system that helps plants defend themselves against pathogens. We found that when any of these four factors are mutated, plants become more susceptible to two different types of necrotrophic fungi, Botrytis cinerea and Plectosphaerella cucumerina. We also identified 77 genes that were commonly up-regulated in the mutants. These genes encode peptides that are secreted outside the plant cell and help the fungi grow inside the plant. We called these peptides "provirus factors." We found that many of the provirus factors are important for disease susceptibility to necrotrophic fungi. Finally, we discovered that these provirus factors are localized to the pericellular space, outside of the plant cell.
The endometrium needs to be in a specific state, called the "window of receptivity", to allow for a fertilized embryo to implant and for a pregnancy to be successful. The FOXO1 transcription factor is important for the endometrium to be receptive during this window. FOXO1 is found in the nucleus of the uterine epithelium during the window of receptivity. If FOXO1 is not present, the embryo cannot implant, leading to infertility. The loss of FOXO1 in the uterine epithelium is due to the retention of progesterone receptor (PGR) in the epithelium, which in turn prevents FOXO1 from being present. The loss of FOXO1 in the uterine epithelium causes problems with the apical surface of the luminal epithelium, leading to a failure to allow the embryo to implant. The retention of PGR in the uterine epithelium is due to the loss of FOXO1, leading to a feedback loop. The retention of PGR in the uterine epithelium causes the endometrium to be receptive to the embryo, leading to successful implantation. The loss of FOXO1 in the uterine epithelium causes the endometrium to not be receptive to the embryo, leading to a failure of implantation. FOXO1 is found in the nucleus of the uterine epithelium during the window of receptivity, and the loss of FOXO1 in the uterine epithelium causes the failure of implantation. The loss of FOXO1 in the uterine epithelium leads to the retention of PGR in the epithelium, which in turn leads to the failure of implantation. The retention of PGR in the uterine epithelium causes the endometrium to be receptive to the embryo, leading to successful implantation.
Dengue is a tropical disease caused by the dengue virus and transmitted by the Aedes mosquito. It is endemic in Bangladesh, where it was first reported in 2000. Since then, cases have been reported every year, mostly among adults and older children living in metropolitan cities. Despite no effective control program being introduced and no changes in surveillance until 2010 when serological confirmation was mandated for case reporting, nationally reported cases have declined since 2002. However, there is considerable under-reporting inherent in the passive hospital-based surveillance system. To map the spatial variation in dengue incidence in Bangladesh, we used a negative binomial generalized linear mixed effect model accounting for zero-inflation, spatial, and temporal random effects. We found that mean monthly temperature and its interaction with mean monthly diurnal temperature range, as well as mean monthly rainfall at two months lag, were significantly associated with dengue incidence. Densely populated districts and districts bordering India or Myanmar had higher incidence than others. The model estimated that 92% of the annual dengue cases occurred between August and September. We identified districts with 94% of reported cases, but only 409 were reported to authorities. To adjust for under-reporting, we used Bayesian inference to produce maps of monthly spatial variation in dengue incidence at the district-level. These maps can help distribute vector control interventions to areas of highest need at the appropriate time. The method is useful for identifying locations where dengue transmission occurs but incidence data are lacking.
Mice explore their environment and create a map of their surroundings. Sometimes they establish a "home base," a place they visit most often and spend the most time in. Scientists discovered that mice also like to create other special places in their environment. These places are not as well-defined as home bases, but they are still important to the mice. These places are called "knots" because the mice trace twisting and turning paths while exploring them. Knots are usually located near where the mouse first entered the environment and are not like home bases in any other way, except that the mice move faster when they are inbound to the knot and slower when they are outbound. The scientists think that knots help the mice understand their environment and figure out where they are. The scientists discovered that knots are more likely to form when the mice are stressed or aroused, like when they are injected with saline or placed in an exposed area of the environment.
The authors report the discovery of a new antifungal compound, NGx04, which has a dual function. It inhibits the growth of fungi that cause life-threatening infections, such as Candida albicans, Cryptococcus neoformans, and Aspergillus fumigatus. Furthermore, it inhibits the secretion of virulence determinants essential for these fungi to cause infections. The authors used genetics to identify the target of NGx04 and found that it is a lipid transfer protein called Sec14p. The authors showed that NGx04 inhibits the growth of Cryptococcus neoformans and found that related compounds have even higher potency against this fungus. Additionally, NGx04 showed fungicidal activity against a fluconazole-resistant strain of Cryptococcus neoformans. The authors demonstrated that NGx04 inhibits the function of Sec14p in fungi by genetic and biochemical methods. The discovery of NGx04 and its mode of action against Sec14p in fungi is an important step towards the development of new antifungal drugs to treat life-threatening infections caused by fungi.
A recent study tested the antischistosomal properties of mefloquine, a drug used to treat malaria, in mice infected with adult and juvenile worms of two different species of Schistosoma ( S . mansoni and S . japonicum ). Mefloquine was found to have high and comparable reductions in worm burden when given as a single dose to mice with either a sub-patent or patent S . mansoni infection, and even better results were achieved when the drug was given to mice infected with juvenile worms. Both enantiomers of mefloquine were effective in reducing worm burden, suggesting that the drug's activity is not due to its erythro-enantiomer. The study shows promise for the development of a new antischistosomal drug based on an aminoalcohol functionality and further in vitro and in vivo studies have been launched to elucidate the possible mechanism of action and to study the effect of mefloquine on S . haematobium and other trematodes.
Podoconiosis is a disease that causes swelling of the legs due to long-term contact with irritant red clay soil. It is not caused by an infection, but by a combination of environmental, genetic and socio-economic factors. The disease is not well understood, and its geographical distribution is incomplete. In this study, we mapped the distribution of podoconiosis in Cameroon to generate data that can help in the global atlas of podoconiosis. We used a multi-stage sampling design and surveyed 76 villages from 40 health districts. We found that the overall prevalence of podoconiosis in Cameroon is 0.5% (95% confidence interval: 0.4-0.7). At least one case of podoconiosis was found in every region of Cameroon, except two surveyed villages in Adamawa. We identified 52 people with podoconiosis using the clinical algorithm. The study has demonstrated the low prevalence but almost nationwide distribution of podoconiosis in Cameroon. This finding is important because it will help to design a podoconiosis control program and develop an efficient and cost-effective podoconiosis control and elimination program. The results of the study will help to identify endemic districts and affected communities and will contribute to the global effort to map the global distribution and burden of podoconiosis.
The paper is about how stem cells that make eggs in fruit flies called GSCs get attached to their niche as they age. The niche is a special type of cell that helps GSCs stay stem cells and make eggs. As the fruit flies age, the GSCs start to move away from the niche and eventually disappear. The paper looks at how Notch signaling, a pathway that helps stem cells stay stem cells, changes as GSCs get older and how it affects their attachment to the niche. The paper also shows that Notch signaling in the niche cells, which help keep the GSCs attached, also decreases as the fruit flies age.
The article discusses the conserved herpesvirus-encoded protein kinases (CHPKs), which are proteins that have a similar structure and function across different herpesvirus families. These proteins have been identified as having Cdk-like activity in cells, and the authors describe an experiment where they tested the ability of these proteins to phosphorylate Rb and lamin A/C in human cells. The results showed that all CHPKs from the beta- and gamma-herpesvirus families had this activity, but none of the alpha-herpesvirus CHPKs did. The authors also tested the ability of these proteins to disrupt the nuclear lamina and found that all CHPKs from the beta- and gamma-herpesvirus families had this activity, but none of the alpha-herpesvirus CHPKs did. The authors conclude that the CHPKs from beta- and gamma-herpesvirus families are v-Cdks, while the CHPKs from alpha-herpesvirus families do not have the same functions.
Melioidosis is a rare but serious disease caused by a bacteria called Burkholderia pseudomallei. This bacteria is found in the environment in many tropical countries, but we don't have a good idea of where it is. In order to help prevent melioidosis, we need to know where this bacteria is found. The authors are part of a group of experts who have come together to develop guidelines for how to sample the environment for B. pseudomallei in a standardized way. This will help us create a better map of where this bacteria is found, and what areas we need to be aware of.
The dengue virus has a protein called "E" on its surface that helps it enter cells. The "E" protein is made up of two copies that are attached to each other ("dimer") and have a long, "stem" region that connects two sections of the protein ("domain I" and "domain II"). When the "E" protein is exposed to acidic conditions, it changes shape to form three copies of the "E" protein ("trimer") that are arranged in a special way. Researchers have found that peptides (short chains of amino acids) that are derived from the stem region of the "E" protein can bind to the trimer form of the protein. These peptides also can inhibit the ability of the dengue virus to enter cells by binding to the virus before it reaches the acidic environment of the endosome, which is where the virus usually enters cells. This is important because it shows that targeting a specific step in the fusion process can be an effective way to stop infection.
Cholera is a major global health concern, with 4 million cases and 95,000 deaths annually worldwide. Recent outbreaks in countries such as Haiti and Yemen highlight the ongoing threat of cholera. Stool specimens preserved on filter paper allow for molecular analysis of Vibrio cholerae, the bacteria that causes cholera, even in remote areas or areas of civil unrest. Whole genome sequencing (WGS) on these specimens provides valuable data on circulating cholera strains, which may inform public policy response on cholera control and elimination. In a proof-of-principle study, the authors demonstrated that DNA extracted from APW-enriched and culture isolate spotted filter paper can generate high-quality accurate sequence data that has the potential to inform public health decisions by providing essential information on cholera genotype and co-infection burden.
The study was focused on identifying the protein network responsible for controlling epithelial polarity. The team found that the Dynein motor is an essential regulator of apico–basal polarity. They showed that Dynein acts through the cytoplasmic scaffolding protein Stardust (Sdt) to localize the transmembrane protein Crumbs, in part through the apical targeting of specific sdt mRNA isoforms. They also identified an alternatively spliced coding exon in the sdt mRNA that is responsible for its apical localization, and showed that this switches during development. This study suggests that mRNA localization may have a functional role in the regulation of apico–basal organization.
The paper describes a study on the reproductive cycle of Leishmania, a parasite that causes several dangerous diseases in humans and animals. For many years, scientists believed that Leishmania reproduced mostly clonally, meaning that new generations of parasites were produced from a single parent without any genetic exchange. However, recent evidence suggests that Leishmania may also reproduce sexually, meaning that new generations are produced from the fusion of two different parent parasites. The paper describes a study where researchers created transgenic parasites of Leishmania infantum with two different drug resistance markers linked to green and red fluorescent reporters. They then fed these transgenic parasites to sand flies, the natural vector of Leishmania, along with parental parasites. The researchers found that the sand flies were able to recognize and mate between parasites from the same strain, resulting in yellow fluorescent hybrid progeny. This provides evidence that Leishmania is able to perform genetic exchange between the same genotype during mating. The paper concludes that this study suggests that Leishmania may be able to recognize and mate between parasites with the same genotype, which could have important implications for the spread and evolution of the parasite.
Visceral leishmaniasis (VL) is a disease caused by Leishmania donovani, a parasite that is spread by different vectors in different regions of Ethiopia. Recently, 63 L. donovani strains were studied using PCR and high-resolution melt (HRM) analysis to see if the parasites could be distinguished based on their geographic location. The study found that the k26 region of L. donovani has polymorphisms that can be used to distinguish between different regions, such as northwestern and southwestern Ethiopia. The study also found that the number and order of the repeats in L. donovani varies between geographic regions, which should be taken into account when designing diagnostic assays and vaccines based on this antigen.
HIV-1 is a rapidly evolving virus that can switch between different RNA templates during reverse transcription. Recombination between different subtypes or CRFs (circulating recombinant forms) can create new and potentially more successful viral variants. In this study, the authors create a model to predict the breakpoints of recombination based on local sequence identity. They then compare their model's predictions to the observed breakpoints in the HIV/AIDS pandemic. The authors find that most breakpoints are predicted accurately by their model, suggesting that sequence identity plays a crucial role in determining the recombination breakpoints. However, they also find that some regions have a higher frequency of breakpoints than expected, which may indicate that natural selection is favoring these specific recombinants. The authors suggest that the recombinants generated in these regions may be more successful in evading the immune response or have other beneficial properties.
Computational modeling is an important tool used in neuroscience research to analyze experimental data. However, a key issue in this research is the challenge of estimating individual variation in parameters across a population of subjects while simultaneously comparing models to determine which one provides the best explanation for the data. The authors propose a hierarchical Bayesian inference (HBI) framework that addresses both of these problems simultaneously. This framework allows researchers to make inference at the population level, estimate individual variation in model expression, and compare different models. The authors show that the parameters estimated using HBI are more accurate than previous methods, and model comparison using HBI is robust against outliers and not biased towards oversimplistic models. Additionally, the authors show that the HBI framework allows for group-level inference using a t-test, which is not possible using previous methods.
The study by Carlezon and colleagues provides new insights into the role of rhombomeres and their associated Hox genes in the development of auditory circuits in the mammalian brainstem. Rhombomeres are subdivisions of the hindbrain along the antero-posterior axis, where distinct sensory and motor nuclei are generated. The authors used a novel Cre-recombinase driver to create a highly restricted r4-specific fate map, which showed that r4-derived cells contribute significantly to the ventral nucleus of lateral lemniscus (VLL) and the posteroventral cochlear nucleus (PVCN). Moreover, the authors demonstrated that r4-derived cells contribute to the medial nucleus of the trapezoid body (MNTB) in Hoxa2 mutants, though with different severities. The study also revealed the influence of Hoxb1 and Hoxb2 on the VLL, PVCN, and medial nucleus of the trapezoid body (MNTB), showing a direct correlation between rhombomere-specific Hox genes and the development of auditory-related neural circuits. The study's findings have important implications for our understanding of the role of Hox genes in the formation of auditory circuits and suggest that rhombomere-specific Hox genes play a crucial role in the development of auditory-related neural circuits in the mammalian brainstem.
The genus Saccharophagus consists of four species that can degrade various complex carbohydrates, including cellulose, xylan, and pectin, and can break down lignin to its constituent monomers. These species are found in marine and estuarine environments and can degrade plant and algal biomass, making them important contributors to the carbon cycle. They also have the ability to fix atmospheric carbon dioxide, making them important players in the fight against climate change. However, little is known about the mechanisms underlying their ability to degrade complex carbohydrates.
Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) is a mosquito-borne virus that causes viral encephalitis mainly in children. There are five genotypes of JEV, and the most dominant genotype has shifted from genotype III (GIII) to genotype I (GI) over the last 20 years. Scientists used Chinese Culex pipiens mosquitoes as a model to explore if mosquitoes played a role in JEV genotype shift. The results showed that Cx. pipiens mosquitoes were competent vectors for both GI and GIII JEV infection, with similar infection rates, growth kinetics, dissemination rates, and transmission rates. Therefore, JEV genotype shift was not likely to be due to differences in vector competence between GI and GIII viruses.
Dengue fever is a viral infection spread by mosquitoes and mainly affects people in tropical and subtropical areas. In recent years, Malaysia has had several large dengue outbreaks. In this study, we looked at the characteristics of people who died from dengue fever in Malaysia between 2013 and 2014. We found that adults (15-59 years old) and the elderly (60 years old or more) were more likely to have co-morbidities like diabetes and hypertension. Abdominal pain was more commonly observed in adults while lethargy (feeling tired) was more common in children. However, about a quarter of the cases did not show any warning signs. The majority of the deaths were caused by severe plasma leakage, followed by multi-organ involvement and severe bleeding. Overall, we found that dengue fever deaths occurred primarily in adult patients, with severe plasma leakage being the leading cause of death.
Researchers have shown that Drosophila melanogaster fruit flies choose their mates based on traits that reflect their reproductive potential. These traits are thought to be used as cues for mate selection and are assumed to reflect an underlying quality. However, the specific traits that are used for this purpose and how they reflect quality are not entirely clear. The researchers have found that global manipulation of the insulin signaling pathway affects the composition and attractiveness of the female pheromone profile. They have also found that insulin signaling influences the attractiveness of male dung beetles. The researchers believe that flies and beetles have evolved to “read” insulin pathway activity in different forms as an honest and accurate metric of reproductive potential. They are currently dissecting the mechanistic links between insulin signaling, reproduction, and attractiveness by investigating tissue specificity of insulin signaling effects. They have found that global insulin signaling effects on attractiveness come from insulin signaling in the fat body and ovarian follicle cells, whose signals are integrated by pheromone-producing cells called oenocytes. They have also found that manipulations of insulin signaling in the fat body produce opposite effects on attractiveness, suggesting a competitive relationship with the ovary. All investigated tissue-specific insulin signaling manipulations that changed attractiveness also changed fecundity in the corresponding direction, pointing to insulin pathway activity as a reliable link between fecundity and attractiveness cues. The cues themselves, cuticular hydrocarbons, responded differently to fat body and follicle cell manipulations, indicating independent readouts of the pathway activity from these two tissues. Thus, the researchers believe that the attractiveness of female D. melanogaster fruit flies results from an apparent connection between attractiveness cues and an organismal state of high fecundity, both of which are created by lowered insulin signaling in the fat body and increased insulin signaling in late follicle cells.
The Ebola virus disease (EVD) epidemic in West Africa in 2013–2015 was the largest EVD epidemic ever observed. Our study aimed to investigate the heterogeneous transmission of EVD across the three hardest-hit countries (Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone) and estimate the basic reproduction number (R0) for each affected district and each country. We applied a statistical modeling approach to estimate the R0 based on weekly incident case numbers, growth rates during the early exponential phase of the outbreak, and the reported serial interval distribution. The district-level R0 ranged from 0.36 to 1.72 in Guinea, from 0.53 to 3.37 in Liberia, and from 1.14 to 2.73 in Sierra Leone. At the national level, we estimated an R0 of 0.97 for Guinea, 1.26 for Liberia, and 1.66 for Sierra Leone. Our study found that district-level socio-demographic variables related to urbanization, such as high population density and high wealth index, were positively associated with R0, suggesting that the consequences of fast urban growth in West Africa may have contributed to the increased spread of EVD. Our study provides valuable insights into the subnational spread of EVD during the 2013–2015 epidemic and highlights potential drivers of EVD transmission.
Protein evolutionary rates vary widely within an organism, and researchers have been trying to understand the factors that determine these rates. In this study, researchers used a large set of one-to-one orthologs between human and mouse proteins to analyze the relationship between protein structure and evolutionary rate, as well as the role of protein age. They found that previously observed structural correlations also hold within each age group, including relationships between solvent accessibility and designability and evolutionary rates. However, age modulates the relationship between solvent accessibility and rate. Younger proteins, despite being less designable, tend to evolve faster than older proteins. The researchers also introduce a knowledge-based potential function to study the stability of proteins through large-scale computation. They find that older proteins are more stable and robust to mutations than younger ones. Their results suggest that several factors, both intrinsic and historical, can interact to determine rates of protein evolution.
This paper is about Polycomb repressive complex 2 (PRC2), which plays a role in controlling gene expression during development and differentiation. PRC2 adds a chemical group to a type of protein called histone H3, which is a building block of DNA. This chemical group helps to keep certain genes turned off. The paper describes a new protein called Pcl3, which is part of PRC2, and how it helps to control gene expression in embryonic stem cells (ESCs). The paper shows that Pcl3 interacts with the core components of PRC2 and is necessary for PRC2 to function properly. It also shows that Pcl3 helps to recruit PRC2 to certain parts of the genome. The paper concludes that Pcl3 is an important regulator of PRC2 at a subset of target genes.
The article you're referring to presents a study on the regulation of chemoreceptor gene expression in Caenorhabditis elegans (a type of roundworm) as a function of feeding state. The researchers found that basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH) transcription factors work together with MEF-2, a transcription factor known to be regulated by feeding state, to control srh-234 gene expression in ADL sensory neurons. They identified a cis-regulatory MEF2 binding site that is required for the starvation-induced down regulation of srh-234 expression. They also found that HLH-2 (E/Daughterless), HLH-3 and HLH-4 (Achaete-Scute homologs) and HLH-30 (TFEB ortholog) regulate srh-234 expression in ADL neurons. They discovered that MXL-3 (Max-like 3 homolog) acts in the intestine to remotely regulate srh-234 expression in ADL neurons, and that this regulation depends on insulin signaling functioning specifically in ADL neurons. The study suggests that chemoreceptor gene expression is regulated by both cell-autonomous and non-cell-autonomous transcriptional mechanisms mediated by MEF-2 and bHLH factors. These findings may help to explain how animals adapt their chemosensory responses to different feeding states.
Buruli ulcer is a skin condition caused by infection with a type of bacteria. The bacteria, Mycobacterium ulcerans, is found in the environment and can be transmitted to humans through biting insects. In this study, researchers tested mosquitoes for the presence of the bacteria and compared it to the incidence of Buruli ulcer in humans in different areas. They found a strong correlation between the presence of the bacteria in mosquitoes and the risk of humans getting Buruli ulcer. This study suggests that mosquitoes may be involved in the transmission of Mycobacterium ulcerans and could help inform strategies to prevent and control the spread of the disease.
The demyelination mutation (dmy) in rats causes severe and progressive myelin damage in the central nervous system (CNS) after myelination is complete. Researchers have now identified the gene responsible for this mutation, Mrs2, and have shown that it encodes a protein that is an essential component of the major Mg2+ influx system in mitochondria. This protein is also found in yeast, bacteria, and other organisms. The research suggests that the dmy mutation is a mitochondrial disease, and that the maintenance of myelin in the CNS is dependent on Mg2+ homeostasis in mitochondria.
The article describes how microarray gene expression signatures can be used to diagnose diseases. However, there is a problem with the current documentation standards for these signatures that makes it difficult to apply them to external patients. This hinders their use in clinical practice. The authors analyzed eight publicly available clinical microarray studies and compared the study-internal diagnoses with study-external diagnoses, which were based on documented information only. They found that discrepancies between the two diagnoses can be as frequent as 30% and 18%. They suggest a new documentation strategy that would reduce this discrepancy to 1%. By implementing this approach, the evaluation and use of microarray gene expression signatures in clinical practice can be improved and made more reliable.
A recent study has revealed that extracellular amyloid fibers called curli, produced by Escherichia coli, resemble human pathological amyloids. Curli proteins are made through dedicated cellular processes and play important roles in the biofilm formation of bacteria. In this study, the authors have determined the crystal structure of amyloid-forming segments from the major curli subunit, CsgA, revealing steric zipper fibrils of tightly mated β-sheets. The study also shows that D-enantiomeric peptides, which were originally developed to interfere with Alzheimer's disease-associated amyloid-β, inhibit CsgA fibrillation and reduce biofilm formation in Salmonella typhimurium. Moreover, the study reveals that as previously shown, CsgA fibrils cross-seed fibrillation of amyloid-β, providing support for the proposed structural resemblance and potential for cross-species amyloid interactions. These findings provide structural insights into amyloidogenic regions important for curli formation, suggest a novel strategy for disrupting amyloid-structured biofilms, and hypothesize on the formation of self-propagating prion-like species originating from a microbial source that could influence neurodegenerative diseases.
The Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) is a common cause of encephalitis in Asia. It can result in high rates of death and long-term neurological problems. The epidemiology of JE in the Philippines is not well understood. To help the Philippines decide whether to introduce JE vaccine into their routine immunization program, a systematic literature review was conducted. This review included 29 published reports and presentations from 2011 to 2014. These reports found that JEV was the cause of 7-18% of cases of clinical encephalitis, and that JE predominantly affected children under 15 years of age. Surveillance data from 2011 to 2014 identified 73 cases of laboratory-confirmed JE out of 497 cases tested. This comprehensive review demonstrates the endemicity of JE in the Philippines and supports the use of JE vaccine. Continued and improved surveillance is needed to measure the impact of preventive measures and guide their use.
A new large-scale computational study has been conducted to chart the level of robustness of metabolic networks of hundreds of bacterial species across many simulated growth environments. The study provides evidence that variations among species in their level of robustness reflect ecological adaptations. The results indicate that genetic robustness can be decoupled into two components: an environmental-dependent component and an environmental-independent component. The study identifies reactions that are uniquely susceptible to perturbations in human pathogens, potentially serving as novel drug-targets. The authors conclude that the evolution of genetic robustness is a complex phenomenon that involves various factors, including genetic mutations, environmental variations, and ecological adaptations.
Schistosoma infection has been linked to a reduced immune response to vaccines in children. In this study, researchers wanted to investigate the impact of schistosoma mansoni infection on measles catch-up immunisation and praziquantel treatment on this outcome in a randomised trial. The study was based in Entebbe, Uganda, and included 193 children infected with S. mansoni and 61 uninfected children aged 3-5 years. The researchers found that infected children had lower anti-measles IgG levels and a lower percentage with protective antibody levels compared to uninfected children one week after measles immunisation. However, at 24 weeks after immunisation, there was no difference in IgG levels between the trial groups. Praziquantel treatment was shown to improve the measles vaccine response in S. mansoni-infected children. The researchers concluded that S. mansoni infection may contribute to impaired vaccine responses in endemic populations and that praziquantel treatment may improve the response. This study highlights the importance of considering the impact of helminth infections on vaccine responses and the potential for praziquantel treatment to improve the immune response to vaccines.
The paper presents a new set of tools for studying the evolution of bacterial populations. The authors point out that traditional methods for studying evolution, such as phylogenetic analysis, can have difficulties when there is a lot of recombination in the population. The authors introduce a new algorithm for detecting and representing recombination between populations, as well as a model for describing the shape of a population in sequence space. The authors then use real data from the genus Neisseria to show how their tools can be used to study the evolution of a bacterial population. They also use simulations to demonstrate how their Bayesian approach can handle large databases and complex genetic population structures. The authors emphasize that biological insights are best gained by combining several complementary methods of analysis.
Cortical rhythms, such as those found in the beta frequency band, are thought to play a significant role in our cognitive abilities. Recent studies have shown that top-down beta rhythms, which originate in higher cognitive areas and are delivered to lower areas, can support attentional gain modulation. To understand how beta rhythms achieve this, we built a computational model of sensory cortical areas. Our simulations show that top-down beta rhythms activate ascending synaptic projections from L5 to L4 and L2/3, which are responsible for biased competition in superficial layers. Slow-inhibitory interneurons, which have slow postsynaptic kinetics relative to fast spiking interneurons, are shown to resonate to the 20 Hz input and modulate the activity in superficial layers in an attention-related manner. The predicted critical roles of these cells in attentional gain provide a potential mechanism by which cholinergic drive can support selective attention.
