Scientists have developed a new method to estimate the fundamental parameters of an epidemic and make predictions about its trajectory during the initial phase of disease emergence, when the dynamics are stochastic and the data is incomplete. They compared this new method with three state-of-the-art benchmark methods and found that their method outperforms them in most scenarios tested. This new method could be used by public health decision-makers to make better decisions in response to emerging diseases.
Our work investigates how previous stimuli and decisions impact our perception of the present moment. Using multilevel modeling and cross-validation techniques, we found that past decisions have a stronger impact on our perceptions than past stimuli. Specifically, we found that there are two types of serial dependence that are driven by opposite forces: low-level adaptation, which repels our perception away from past stimuli, and past decisions, which attract our perception toward them. These findings suggest that the visual system is anchored and calibrated to the recent history of sensory and decisional events. This provides a new perspective on how previous experiences impact our perception of the present moment.
The Clock-Cycle (CLK-CYC) is a key circadian transcription complex in fruit flies. This complex works by binding to DNA and regulating the expression of target genes. Previous research showed that most of the transcriptional activity of CLK-CYC derives from the glutamine-rich region of its partner CLK. To better understand the role of transcription in circadian timekeeping, scientists have used a fusion protein of the Cyclic protein with the VP16 protein from Herpes virus. This fusion protein has a stronger transcriptional activity than CLK-CYC, and when expressed in fruit flies, it leads to an increase in CLK-CYC direct target gene mRNAs and a shortened period. These results suggest that the timing of transcriptional activation and not the activation itself is the key event responsible for the behavioral effects observed in CYC-VP16-expressing flies. This implies that circadian transcription is important for core circadian function in fruit flies.
In this study, researchers have investigated how a horizontally acquired gene works in different species. The pmrD gene, which helps protect bacteria from the antibiotic polymyxin B, is horizontally acquired in Salmonella enterica. However, this gene does not function in the closely related bacteria Escherichia coli. The researchers found that this is because the PmrB protein, which regulates PmrA/PmrB pathway, has higher phosphatase activity in E. coli than in Salmonella. This difference in the ancestral protein's biochemical activity allows E. coli to survive in low magnesium environments, which is one of the triggers for activating the PmrA/PmrB system.
The differentiation of embryonic stem cells is the process by which they become more specialized cells. To identify the genes that regulate this process, scientists have traditionally compared the gene expression of two cell types (e.g. embryonic stem cells and fully differentiated cells) and identified the genes that are differentially expressed between these two cell types. However, this method can produce a list of genes that are not important to the regulation of the differentiation process. This study shows that instead of comparing two cell types, it is possible to detect genes that regulate the differentiation process by measuring the average gene expression of a mixture of cell types. This is done by using a new statistical test based on variance ratio. The study shows that this method is effective by using biological replicates and validating the results through two experiments.
The functional analysis of gene variants is becoming standard in next-generation sequencing studies, but there are some problems with it. Firstly, many genes have unknown functions and are not well-classified into pathways. Therefore, functional associations between genes are often inferred from large-scale omics data, such as protein-protein interactions and gene co-expression networks. However, these data types can sometimes be affected by confounding factors, which can lead to false positive findings. In this study, we explored the potential confounding factors affecting the implicated genes and found that the genes mutated in the same disease are biased in their coding-sequence length and tend to cluster together, leading to exaggerated p-values in functional studies. We developed a novel method that addresses these bias and found that genes implicated through de novo gene variants tend to cluster more significantly in an integrated phenotypic-linkage network than in other gene networks. We have also presented a tool of superior power to identify functional associations among genes mutated in the same disease even after accounting for significant sequencing study bias and demonstrated the suitability of this method to functionally subcluster the gene variants underlying a polygenic disorder. Overall, this study has important implications for future research in the field of next-generation sequencing studies.
The Mexican government implemented taxes on nonessential energy-dense food and sugar-sweetened beverages in 2014. The study examined the changes in the volume of taxed and untaxed packaged food purchases in response to these taxes in the entire sample and stratified by socioeconomic status. The study used data from household packaged food purchases representative of the Mexican urban population from The Nielsen Company’s Mexico Consumer Panel Services. The findings showed that household purchases of nonessential energy-dense foods declined by 25 g (95% confidence interval = -46 , -11) per capita per month, or a 5.1% change beyond what would have been expected based on pre-tax trends. Low SES households purchased 10.2% less taxed foods than expected, while medium SES households purchased 5.8% less taxed foods than expected. High SES households’ purchases did not change. The main limitations of the study were the lack of a control group, the fact that the study was conducted in urban areas only, the use of only two years of data prior to the tax, and the possibility of underreporting by the household. Overall, the study suggests that the Mexican food and beverage taxes were successful in reducing the volume of taxed food purchases, especially among low SES households.
Power laws are used to describe brain functions at different levels. It is possible that these functions are generated by similar mechanisms. A model was developed that uses a power law to scale inhibitory input to a collision-sensitive neuron, and this model was able to successfully predict response characteristics of the Lobula Giant Movement Detector Neuron. Noise in the inhibitory pathway was critical, but the results were fairly robust against noise in the excitatory pathway. The results suggest that threshold smoothing may also occur at the single neuron level, such as when noisy and thresholded (pre-synaptic) inputs are integrated by the dendritic tree of a neuron.
Buruli ulcer is a skin disease caused by a bacterium that is found in certain parts of Africa, Asia, and South America. The disease causes open sores on the skin and can lead to permanent disfigurement, physical limitations, and social stigma if left untreated. The disease affects people of all ages and both sexes, but mostly children under 15 years old. It is important to diagnose and treat the disease as early as possible to prevent it from worsening and causing serious problems. Buruli ulcer can be diagnosed by trained health workers using simple tools, and it can be treated with antibiotics and surgery. The World Health Organization recommends a specific treatment regimen for Buruli ulcer, which involves using antibiotics to kill the bacteria and controlling the spread of the infection.
In this study, researchers wanted to learn more about how confident people feel when making choices in a learning environment. They found that when people learned to seek rewards, they felt more confident in their choices than when they learned to avoid losses, even though the two tasks were the same difficulty and performance. The researchers think that this might be because of a "context-value" that is learned from the environment. This value is a dynamic estimate of how much people should expect to get from the different choices. They think this could be important in volatile environments, where people need to be flexible with their learning strategies. The researchers also suggest that the bias in confidence that they found might have important consequences for learning and decision-making.
Alphaviruses are a family of viruses that are responsible for a variety of diseases in humans and animals, including Venezuelan equine encephalitis and Sindbis virus infections. The virus is composed of a complex of four nonstructural proteins, one of which is nsP3. The role of nsP3 in the replication of the virus is not well understood, but a recent study suggests that nsP3 interacts with amphiphysin proteins through a specific sequence motif. This interaction is important for the replication of the virus, as mutations in nsP3 disrupting this binding site or the expression of a protein that binds to the same site as amphiphysin both impair viral replication in cells and lead to attenuated virus in mice. These findings provide important insight into the role of nsP3 in the replication of alphaviruses.
Chromoblastomycosis is a skin infection caused by melanized fungi. It is common in humid areas and has been found in several countries worldwide. In Brazil, it is prevalent in rural areas and affects agricultural workers. The most prevalent agents of the disease are Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Fonsecaea monophora, Fonsecaea nubica and Fonsecaea pugnacius. The disease can take several years to develop and can cause disfigurement in severe cases. However, with appropriate treatment, the disease can be effectively controlled.
In this study, we found that Listeria monocytogenes infection of human cells causes DNA breaks. However, the response of the cells to these breaks is only partially activated. We discovered that the toxin Listeriolysin O (LLO) is responsible for this dampening of the response, by degrading one of the key sensors of DNA damage, Mre11. This is an important mechanism for Listeria to replicate successfully in the cells. Our findings reveal a new way in which Listeria monocytogenes subverts the DNA-damage response pathway in host cells.
Herpes simplex viruses (HSV-1 and HSV-2) are common pathogens that cause diseases such as cold sores, blisters, and sexually transmitted infections. During infection, the viruses enter mucosal epithelial cells and nerve termini of sensory neurons. In the cell body, the virus establishes latency, which serves as a reservoir of virus for recurrent infection and transmission to other individuals. Chemicals that inhibit histone deacetylase activity have been reported to enhance viral replication. Inhibition of the histone demethylase LSD1 blocks virus lytic replication and reactivation from latency. Whether other factors of epigenetic regulation have a role in HSV infection is not well studied. In this study, the authors screened a chemical library of epigenetic regulation to identify factors affecting HSV infection. They discovered several BRD4 inhibitors that promoted HSV-1 and HSV-2 infection. BRD4 is an epigenetic reader that recruits transcriptional regulatory complexes to acetylated chromatin and therefore participates in host gene regulation. The authors performed detailed studies and discovered that bromodomain inhibition enhances HSV infection by promoting transcription factor association with HSV gene promoters.
Noma (also known as cancrum oris) is a devastating ancient disease that causes severe facial disfigurement in 140,000 malnourished children every year. The cause of noma is unknown, but it is thought to be a result of a chaotic mix of microbial infection, oral hygiene, and weakened immune system that leads to the development of oral lesions. These lesions are a plausible entry point for unidentified microorganisms that trigger gangrenous facial infections. To understand the microbial ecology of noma, a cross-sectional sequencing study of 16S rRNA gene amplicons was performed on sixty samples of gingival fluid from twelve healthy children, twelve children suffering from noma (lesion and healthy sites), and twelve children suffering from Acute Necrotizing Gingivitis (ANG) (lesion and healthy sites). The study revealed that samples taken from lesions in diseased mouths were enriched with Spirochaetes and depleted for Proteobacteria, whereas samples taken from healthy sites of diseased mouths had proportions of Spirochaetes and Proteobacteria that were similar to healthy control individuals. The study did not identify Fusobacterium as a causative agent of noma, but it did find that microbial communities sampled from noma and ANG lesions were dominated by the same Prevotella intermedia OTU. The study also identified several OTUs in the Orders Erysipelotrichales, Clostridiales, Bacteroidales, and Spirochaetales as indicators of noma, suggesting that one or more microbes within these Orders is associated with the development of noma lesions.
The bacterial protein NprR plays a crucial role in the insect-infecting process of Bacillus thuringiensis. It acts as a transcriptional regulator, controlling the expression of genes involved in the bacterium's necrotrophic lifestyle, such as toxin production. In the presence of its cognate signaling peptide, NprX, NprR regulates the expression of at least 41 genes involved in the bacterium's survival in the insect cadaver. Recent research has suggested that NprR may also play a role in the sporulation process. However, the findings are conflicting, with some studies proposing that NprR is a positive activator of sporulation and others indicating that it is a negative inhibitor. In this study, we investigate the role of NprR in the sporulation process and demonstrate that it acts as a Rap-like indirect regulator of sporulation. In the absence of bound peptide, NprR negatively affects the commitment to sporulation by dephosphorylating Spo0F, preventing the initiation of the sporulation process. Furthermore, we show that the dimeric apo form of NprR is highly flexible, similar to the Rap proteins. Our findings suggest that NprX regulates the switch from an indirect sporulation inhibitor function to a transcriptional activator function. This allows for an accurate synchronization of important functions of the cell, such as adaptation properties and cell fate. Overall, our study highlights the importance of NprR in the insect-infecting process of Bacillus thuringiensis, as well as its role in sporulation.
HIV resistance to treatment is a major problem in the fight against AIDS. Computational models can be used to predict the effectiveness of different drugs against HIV mutations. These models can be used to identify new mutations that confer resistance to current drugs and to design more effective treatments for HIV.
The article explains a new way in which eukaryotic cells move towards a source of attractants, such as food or water. The movement is called chemotaxis, and it is an important process for many types of cells, including bacteria, fungi, and animals. The new model describes how cells move using a cycle of pseudopod generation and retraction. These pseudopods are small, branching structures that extend from the cell and help the cell to move. The model suggests that chemoattractants do not directly cause actin polymerization, which leads to pseudopod formation. Instead, they modify the cycle of pseudopod generation and retraction. The article presents data that supports this new model, and it suggests that this model could be used to understand the movement of many different types of cells.
Fleas can transmit plague through two mechanisms: EPT and BDT. The transmission efficiency of fleas varies depending on the species of flea and the host blood source. In a study by Li et al. (2021), fleas were infected with plague bacteria using different sources of rodent blood (mouse, rat, guinea pig, and gerbil) and their ability to transmit the bacteria was assessed. It was found that 10-28% of fleas that consumed rat or guinea pig blood refluxed a portion of the infectious blood meal back into the esophagus within 24 hours of feeding, a phenomenon known as PIER (post-infection esophageal reflux). This reflux was rarely observed in fleas that consumed mouse or gerbil blood. The study also found that fleas that consumed rat blood were more likely to become partially or fully blocked, and to transmit the bacteria through BDT. The findings of this study suggest that the host blood source can influence the transmission efficiency of plague bacteria by fleas.
In this paper, the authors show that positive correlations in the activity of neurons can actually enhance coding performance, in contrast to previous studies suggesting that they are detrimental. The authors show that the probability of discrimination error can be suppressed by many orders of magnitude and the number of stimuli encoded can be enhanced by more than tenfold. These effects are achieved by tuning a few effective parameters and require only a few tens of neurons. The authors also suggest that heterogeneity commonly seen in population activity is beneficial for these effects. They provide experimental tests to identify the pattern of positive correlation that leads to a lock-in limit of perfect coding.
The article describes the development of a cholera vaccine that uses a type of squaric acid chemistry to combine the O-specific polysaccharide (OSP) of Vibrio cholerae serogroup O1 Inaba strain PIC018 with a heavy chain fragment of tetanus toxin (OSP:rTTHc). This vaccine was tested in mice to determine how the vaccine's OSP content, molar ratio of OSP to rTTHc, effect of an adjuvant, and route of immunization affected the immune response. Immunized mice developed a strong immune response that included serum IgG and intestinal IgA responses, as well as vibriocidal antibody and memory B cell responses. The study found that the vaccine was effective in a mouse survival cholera challenge model, resulting in 55% protective efficacy. The development of an effective cholera vaccine could be beneficial, especially for children who have difficulty responding to polysaccharide antigens.
Lymphatic filariasis (LF) is a disease caused by parasites called filarial worms that are spread through mosquitoes. The World Health Organization (WHO) has set a goal to eliminate this disease by 2020. However, this goal is hard to achieve because it is difficult to accurately identify areas where the disease is present. One way to identify areas where LF is present is by using a test called the Immunochromatographic Card Test (ICT). In this study, researchers used the ICT to map the distribution of LF in areas with different levels of loiasis and mansonellosis in Cameroon. They found that the ICT was more likely to give a positive result in areas with high levels of loiasis than in areas with low levels of loiasis. They also found that the ICT was not likely to give a positive result in areas with high levels of mansonellosis. The researchers concluded that the ICT is useful for identifying areas where LF is present, but it is important to consider the levels of other parasites that may cause cross-reactivity when interpreting the results.
The article describes the use of electron tomography to study the ultrastructure of double-membrane vesicles (DMVs) in cells infected with severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). DMVs are structures that have been implicated in viral RNA synthesis. The study shows that DMVs are not isolated vesicles, but are integrated into a network of modified endoplasmic reticulum membranes. This network includes structures with convoluted membranes that are not thought to be involved in viral RNA synthesis, raising questions about the actual site of SARS-CoV-2 RNA synthesis.
This article describes a new genetic study that found a link between the chemical barrier suberin in plant roots and water and mineral uptake in shoots. The study used the newly identified esb1 mutant in Arabidopsis thaliana, which has increased suberin content in roots. The results showed that esb1 mutants had reduced water loss through transpiration, increased water-use efficiency, and altered accumulation of various minerals in the shoot. The authors presented direct evidence that suberin in roots plays a critical role in controlling both water and mineral uptake and transport to the leaves. The study also highlighted the importance of suberin in regulating the apoplastic transport of water and minerals in the root.
The study investigates the sources of variability in the single photon response (SPR) in vertebrate phototransduction. The authors used a Continuous Time Markov Chain (CTMC) based on the biochemistry of rhodopsin activation and deactivation, interfaced with a spatio-temporal model of phototransduction. They found that the randomness of the sojourn times of R* in each phosphorylation state is responsible for the variability of the photoresponse, while the randomness of the number of R* turnoff steps has a negligible effect. The study suggests that R* shutoff is responsible for the variability of the photoresponse, while the diffusion of the second messengers acts as a variability suppressor. The authors also report that mutant mice with variable numbers of phosphorylation sites reproduce the WT response, with the same set of parameters.
The dynamics of cellular processes are often affected by factors outside the process itself. In this work, the authors develop a general framework to account for such extrinsic factors by incorporating only their effects on the process into a new model. They derive corresponding process and master equations, allowing for stochastic simulations, and demonstrate the significance of their approach through several case studies. The resulting model accounts for intrinsic noise and extrinsic noise, and is self-exciting. The authors previously developed a similar approach for the case of constant but random environmental conditions. In this work, they extend their approach to include dynamically changing environments.
Researchers have developed a novel closed-loop BMI training architecture that allows for processing, control, and adaptation using spike events, enabling robust control and extending to various tasks. The architecture incorporates an infinite-horizon optimal feedback-control ( OFC ) model of the brain’s behavior in closed-loop BMI control, and a point process model of spikes. The OFC model infers the user’s motor intention during CLDA—a process termed intention estimation. OFC is also used to design an autonomous and dynamic assisted training technique. The point process model allows for neural processing, control, and decoder adaptation with every spike event and at a faster time-scale than current decoders; it also enables dynamic spike-event-based parameter adaptation unlike current CLDA methods that use batch-based adaptation on much slower adaptation time-scales. The researchers conducted closed-loop experiments in a non-human primate over tens of days to dissociate the effects of these novel CLDA components. The results show that the OFC intention estimation improved BMI performance compared with current intention estimation techniques, OFC assisted training allowed the subject to consistently achieve proficient control, and spike-event-based adaptation resulted in faster and more consistent performance convergence compared with batch-based methods. The architecture also extended control to tasks beyond those used for CLDA training. These findings have significant implications towards the development of clinically-viable neuroprosthetics.
The retina, like other parts of the brain, uses a clever way to process information that comes in from the eye. This involves using some of the signals that come in from different parts of the retina to create a representation of what's being seen. However, the way that these signals are processed and combined can change depending on what is being seen. In this study, researchers wanted to understand how changes in what's being seen would change the way that the retina processes this information. To do this, they presented different kinds of images to the retina and looked at how the signals coming out of the retina changed. They found that when the retina saw images that were more structured and had more patterns in them, it changed the way that it processed the information that it was getting from different parts of the retina. This meant that the retina was able to keep the same amount of information about what was being seen, even when the image changed. This could be important for helping the brain to understand what's being seen, even when the input changes.
A recent study focused on predicting genetic interactions in yeast, which are important for understanding how genes work together to cause diseases. The authors developed a new approach that predicts these interactions by using a wide range of different features and machine learning techniques. The results of this study showed that their approach was more effective than existing methods, and that it could be applied to other organisms as well.
The BRCA Challenge project is a collaboration between the Global Alliance for Genomics and Health (GA4GH) and a group of research institutions to create a comprehensive data exchange platform for BRCA1 and BRCA2 variants. The platform, called the BRCA Exchange, aims to provide a single source of truth for variant annotations in these genes, which can be used to improve clinical care and research. The BRCA Exchange is designed to be a global resource, and it is currently available to the public.
Malaria, a disease caused by a parasite, is a threat to human health and causes about one million deaths each year. The parasite needs to defend itself against a high level of reactive oxygen species (ROS), which are produced during its developmental cycle in humans and mosquitoes. Plasmodium, the apicomplexan parasite that causes malaria, is able to maintain a balanced redox state by using various redox-related proteins. In this study, we investigated the subcellular localization of the major redox-related proteins in Plasmodium falciparum, which causes the most dangerous form of malaria. We found that a number of these proteins are targeted to the apicoplast, a non-photosynthetic plastid in the parasite. Additionally, we discovered that some of these proteins are targeted to different subcellular compartments by using an alternative-translation-initiation (ATI) mechanism. This suggests that dual targeting of proteins is a common phenomenon in apicomplexan parasites, and may be a potential target for new antimalarial drugs.
Intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) are involved in a wide range of critical physiological processes. The discovery of IDPs has led to the need for new approaches to understanding protein-protein interactions. Many of these interactions are coupled with protein folding. Coarse-grained simulations have been used to investigate these processes. Here, we used a coarse-grained simulation model, with an explicit Debye—Hückel charge model, to study the importance of electrostatic interactions in the binding of PUMA and Mcl-1. We found that intramolecular electrostatic interactions affect the unbound states of PUMA only marginally. We also found that intermolecular electrostatic interactions play a role in the formation of the initial encounter complex. Our findings suggest that non-native electrostatic interactions are important for understanding the binding of IDPs.
Polycomb group (PcG) proteins maintain gene silencing in embryos. These proteins are found in distinct nuclear structures called PC bodies that contain PcG-silenced genes. PC bodies are formed at early embryogenesis and move around the nucleus, with both fast and slow motions. This motion likely reflects interactions between PcG proteins and other nuclear components that are important for maintaining stable gene silencing.
This study aimed to determine the most accurate method for measuring somatic mutations in mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) in mice. The study found that mice with a mutated mtDNA polymerase had 10 times more mtDNA point mutations and an increased amount of linear mtDNA deletions compared to their wild-type siblings. However, the study found no increase in mtDNA mutations with age in normal mice, suggesting that most somatic mtDNA mutations occur during development and not in adult life. The study also refuted the popular notion that increased levels of oxidative stress lead to more mtDNA mutations, as the mtDNA mutator mice had no or minor increase in oxidative damage despite a severe decline in mitochondrial function. The study used ultra-deep sequencing to accurately measure mtDNA mutations in mice, providing valuable information on the role of mtDNA mutations in aging and mitochondrial function.
Fusobacterium nucleatum is an anaerobic bacteria that makes energy by using glutamate to generate a sodium-motive force (SMF) across the cell membrane. This SMF is used to make ATP (adenosine triphosphate) in a process called ATP synthesis. In this study, we wanted to understand how the bacteria uses the SMF to make ATP. We found that the bacteria has a unique way of recognizing sodium ions (Na+) and that it uses many sodium ions to make one ATP molecule. We also found that this bacteria is different from other bacteria because it has two carboxyl groups that recognize sodium ions, instead of just one. This means that the bacteria has a unique way of using the SMF to make ATP. Our findings will help us understand how this bacteria makes energy and how it can be targeted for treatment.
T cell immunity is essential for fighting off pathogens and tumors. In order for T cells to recognize and respond to a foreign substance (such as a virus or cancer cell), T cells need to bind to that substance through a specific molecule called a major histocompatibility complex (pMHC). The strength of the T cell's binding to the pMHC is influenced by several factors, including the strength and length of the TCR/pMHC interaction. However, it is unclear how these factors affect T cell responses in vivo. To study this, researchers used mice and a special type of T cell called 5C . C7 T cells to examine the relationship between TCR/pMHC interaction parameters and in vivo T cell responses. The researchers found that optimal T cell responses occur to ligands with intermediate binding characteristics. This means that a T cell response is strongest when the T cell and the pMHC interact for a moderate amount of time. This information can be useful for designing vaccines that trigger strong, long-lasting T cell responses.
Fusarium solani is a type of fungus that is part of a group called the Fusarium solani species complex. Members of this complex have different characteristics, including the ability to infect over 100 different types of plants and people. Scientists have studied a specific type of Fusarium solani called Nectria haematococca, which is found in many different environments such as forests, deserts, and even caves. This fungus has extra chromosomes that contain genes that help it live in different environments. The DNA of this fungus has been sequenced, and scientists have found that it has a large genome, meaning it has a lot of genes. Some of these genes might have been acquired from other organisms through a process called horizontal gene transfer. The DNA sequence of this fungus can help scientists understand how it is able to survive in many different environments and how its genes have evolved.
We developed a new method to watch how the herpesvirus PRV (pseudorabies virus) leaves infected cells. We used live-cell fluorescence microscopy to track individual viral particles, and found that they move in small acidified vesicles towards the plasma membrane. We also found that certain Rab proteins are involved in the transport of these viral particles, and that they exit the cell by exocytosis near patches of LL5β, a protein complex that connects microtubules to the plasma membrane. This study helps us better understand the final steps of alpha herpesvirus egress.
Scientists have been studying the association between pinworms and allergies and autoimmune diseases, but the results have been contradictory. A new study was done to understand how exposure to pinworms and the drug mebendazole affect the gut microbiota and immune responses. The study recruited 109 primary school children in Taichung, Taiwan. In this study, the children were divided into two groups: one group was pinworm-negative, and the other group was pinworm-positive. In the pinworm-positive group, fecal samples were collected again two weeks after they took mebendazole to deworm the pinworms. The study found that exposure to pinworms and mebendazole increased the diversity of gut bacteria, and it also increased the abundance of the probiotic bacteria Bifidobacterium. The study also found that exposure to pinworms and mebendazole decreased the proportion of the bacteria Fusobacteria. The study also found that the gut level of a protein called secretory IgA (SIgA) was lower in the pinworm-positive group and was increased in half of the individuals after they took mebendazole. The study suggests that childhood exposure to pinworms and mebendazole can change the composition of gut bacteria and may have a protective effect on the development of allergies and autoimmune diseases.
A recent study examined the genetics of Arabidopsis thaliana root length and found that the genomic narrow-sense heritability for this trait in the examined population was statistically zero. This means that most genetic variance is not additive, and therefore, could not be captured by a standard additive model-based genome-wide association analysis. To map loci contributing to the epistatic genetic variance, the researchers performed an epistatic GWA analysis. They identified four interacting pairs of loci, involving seven chromosomal loci that passed a standard multiple-testing corrected significance threshold. The genotype-phenotype maps for these pairs revealed epistasis that cancelled out the additive genetic variance, explaining why these loci were not detected in the additive GWA analysis. The researchers estimated that half of the associated pairs were true positive associations. They used a combination of careful statistical epistatic analyses and functional genetic experiments to support their estimate. The study provides new insights into the value of epistatic GWA analyses for dissecting the genetic architecture of complex traits in small, inbred populations.
Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) mutations are a common cause of human diseases. These mutations occur multiple times around the world and are strongly associated with specific mtDNA haplogroups. A study analyzed the characteristics of 30,506 mtDNA sequences from different parts of the world. The study found that the pathogenicity of mtDNA mutations is different in different mtDNA macro-haplogroups. Some mutations were found on specific clades, while others were found on different clades. The study also found that mutations that recurred only within the same phylogenetic cluster were more common than expected by chance. The study provides an explanation for the low frequency of mtDNA diseases reported in specific ethnic groups. The findings of the study highlight the importance of mtDNA background in recurrent mutation events that have been purified through natural selection in older populations.
In cancer, embryonic development, and wound healing, cells can move together in a coordinated way, known as collective migration. To study how these cells interact with each other, researchers use a technique called contact inhibition of locomotion (CIL), where the velocity of pairs of cells is measured before and after collision. Recently, 1D collision assays have been developed to study cell-cell collision outcomes, where cell motion is restricted to a micropatterned stripe. The goal of this study is to use a computational model of collective cell migration, incorporating the mechanics of cell shape and a minimal chemical model for CIL, to reproduce the different outcomes seen in 2-cell collisions. The model identifies the parameters that control these transitions, including cell-cell adhesion, propulsion strength, and the rates of CIL. These parameters suggest hypotheses for why different cell types have different collision behavior and the effect of interventions that modulate collision outcomes. The authors identify the key properties of cell-cell interactions that are responsible for the different outcomes seen in experiments.
A study published in the journal "Biochemistry" explains the mechanism of thioredoxin-disulfide exchange reactions. The authors used molecular dynamics simulations, pKa calculations, and reactivity analysis to study the reaction between thioredoxin (Trx) and its endogenous substrate, arsenate reductase (ArsC). Specifically, they focused on the mechanism of Trx mixed disulfide complex dissociation, which involves the activation of the nucleophilic cysteine of Trx and the regioselectivity of the nucleophilic attack on the intermediate disulfide complex. The authors observed that the conformational changes around the intermediate disulfide bring Cys32Trx into contact with Cys29Trx, and that Cys32Trx is activated for its nucleophilic attack by hydrogen bonds. They also found that Cys32Trx directs its nucleophilic attack on Cys29Trx, not on Cys89ArsC. This multidisciplinary approach provides new insights into a key thiol/disulfide exchange reaction mechanism.
This study shows that people can change their preferences based on what they see others preferring. This change in preferences is thought to be caused by uncertainty about what people prefer, rather than by a desire to conform to others or by other social factors. To study this effect, the study looked at how people choose between rewards that are available now or later. The study found that people change their preferences for these rewards based on what others prefer, and that this change is better explained by uncertainty about what people prefer than by other social factors. The study also found that people become more certain about what they prefer after seeing what others prefer. This study has important implications for understanding how people make decisions and how their preferences can change based on the preferences of others.
Filamentous growth is a complex differentiation response in yeast that occurs under specific conditions and is regulated by multiple pathways. In this study, we developed a new approach to identify regulators of the pathway that controls filamentous growth. We found that many of the major regulatory pathways (such as RAS, RIM101, OPI1, and RTG) were required for the activation of the MAPK pathway, which controls filamentous growth. This indicates that the pathways that control filamentous growth are connected in co-regulatory circuits, which is a systems-level coordination of this differentiation response. This finding is significant as it provides insight into how different pathways are integrated during complex behaviors.
The article explains how gene expression changes can be important in the evolution of different body shapes in fungi. The study was done by examining gene expression levels in different stages of development in five fungi species in the Sordariomycetes. This helped identify genes that play an important role in the development of fruiting bodies. The knockout of these genes in two different species was then performed to see if it had any impact on fruiting body development. The findings of the study suggest that the evolved increase in gene expression across different developmental stages is a key factor in the evolution of different body shapes in fungi. The study also shows how genetic networks can be used to understand the development of fruiting bodies. The study's findings can help us understand how gene expression patterns and regulatory mechanisms evolve to create new body forms.
The egg of a parasite is a good place to put new genetic material into. This is because there are a lot of germ cells (which can make babies) in eggs, and you can also infect snails with miracidia that hatch from eggs. It's also good because eggs are easily available from infected rodents, and they have a high ratio of germ cells to other types of cells. We wanted to see if we could put new genetic material into the eggs of the schistosome worm (S. mansoni) using a method called square wave electroporation. We wanted to use this method because it has been successful in other organisms. We first put new genetic material into the eggs and then exposed them to electric pulses. We looked at the eggs under a microscope to see if the new genetic material had been put in. We also exposed the eggs to virions (which are like little bags of genetic material) and looked to see if those had been taken up by the eggs. We found that the eggs had taken up the new genetic material better when they were exposed to electric pulses, and we were able to detect the genetic material that had been put in. This means that square wave electroporation could be a good way to put new genetic material into the eggs of the schistosome worm.
The paper describes a new approach called the Perturbation-based Markovian Transmission (PMT) model to study the dynamic response of the chaperone complex in Escherichia coli. The model is used to analyze details of the time trajectories of residues upon perturbation. The authors describe how the model works, and the predictions that can be made using the model. They then use the model to study the GroEL-GroES protein chaperone system, and the predicted residues are compared with experimental studies to validate the model's predictions. The authors conclude that the PMT model is useful for studying the dynamic properties of large macromolecular assemblies.
Fungal galectins are proteins that have a role in defense against predators by binding to specific carbohydrate signatures displayed on the cell surfaces of these organisms. In this study, we found that a mushroom galectin, Coprinopsis cinerea CGL2, was toxic to Caenorhabditis elegans nematodes. This toxicity was dependent on the interaction between CGL2 and a specific carbohydrate on the nematode's N-glycans. We identified a novel putative glycosyltransferase required for the biosynthesis of this glycoepitope. We also found that the nematode's resistance to CGL2 was dependent on its ability to produce GDP-fucose, a carbohydrate building block. These findings suggest that fungal galectins may play a role in the defense of fungi against predators by binding to specific carbohydrate signatures displayed on the cell surfaces of these organisms.
HIV reservoirs of latently infected CD4+ T cells have been extensively studied in terms of treatment and eradication. However, the impact of these reservoirs on the evolutionary dynamics of the virus during untreated infection has received little attention. Here, we present a within-host quasispecies model that incorporates a long-lived reservoir. We find that the presence of a latent reservoir can severely delay evolutionary dynamics within a single host, with longer delays associated with larger relative reservoir sizes and/or homeostatic proliferation of cells within the reservoir. These delays can fundamentally change the dynamics of the virus at the epidemiological scale. In particular, the delay in within-host evolutionary dynamics can be sufficient for the virus to evolve intermediate viral loads consistent with maximising transmission, as is observed, and not the very high viral loads that previous models have predicted, an effect that can be further enhanced if viruses similar to those that initiate infection are preferentially transmitted. These results depend strongly on within-host characteristics such as the relative reservoir size, with the evolution of intermediate viral loads observed only when the within-host dynamics are sufficiently delayed. In conclusion, we argue that the latent reservoir has important, and hitherto under-appreciated, roles in both within- and between-host viral evolution.
This article describes how some viruses, including coxsackievirus B3 (CVB3), can evade immune responses from the body. The authors found that while most viruses induce strong immune responses, CVB3 evades CD8+ T cell immunity by almost completely inhibiting the MHC class I antigen presentation pathway. In contrast, MHC class II presentation is relatively unencumbered and CVB3 induces primary and memory CD4+ T cell responses. The authors also describe the quantity and quality of these memory CD4+ T cells, which are induced by CVB3 infection. These findings have implications for the efficiency of cross-priming during CVB3 infection.
This paper is about a medical study that looks at treating a condition called leprosy type 1 reactions, which can cause nerve damage and disability. The study wanted to see if a higher dose of a medicine called methylprednisolone could be more effective in treating leprosy type 1 reactions. They did this by comparing a group of people who received three infusions of high-dose methylprednisolone at the start of their treatment with a group of people who only received a standard dose of prednisolone. The study found that the group who received high-dose methylprednisolone was less likely to experience deterioration in nerve function over the course of the study. However, there were no significant differences in the rate of adverse events or clinical improvement at the end of the study. The study also found that about half of the people who received the treatment needed more prednisolone to treat their leprosy type 1 reactions, despite receiving a standard 16-week course of corticosteroids. The study provides further support for the use of more prolonged courses of corticosteroid to treat leprosy type 1 reactions and the investigation of risk factors for the recurrence of type 1 reaction and nerve function impairment during and after corticosteroid treatment.
CD8 T cells are important for controlling viral infections. HIV-specific CD8 T cells are involved in the response to HIV infection but have failed to clear the virus in most infected people. Chronic viral infection and ongoing antigenic stimulation can lead to exhaustion of virus-specific T cells by engaging down-regulatory mechanisms, such as the programmed cell death-1 (PD-1) pathway. HIV-specific CD8 T cells have a decreased proliferative capacity, incomplete differentiation, and reduced cytotoxic ability as compared to CD8 T cells specific for non-progressive persistent infections, such as EBV or cytomegalovirus. Several studies have suggested a particular role for the PD-1/PD-L1 pathway in the exhaustion of HIV-specific CD8 T cells. In this paper, the researchers investigated the inhibitory effects of Treg on CD8 responses in chronic HIV infection. They found that Treg from HIV-infected patients (Treg/HIV+) did not significantly inhibit polyclonal autologous CD8+ T cell function, suggesting either a defect in the suppressive capacity of Treg/HIV+ or a lack of sensitivity of effector T cells in HIV infection. Results showed that Treg/HIV+ inhibited significantly the IFN-γ expression of autologous CD8+ T cells stimulated with recall CMV/EBV/Flu (CEF) antigens, but did not inhibit HIV-Gag–specific CD8+ T cells. In cross-over cultures, the researchers showed that Treg/HIV- inhibited significantly the differentiation of either CEF- or Gag-specific CD8+ T cells from HIV-infected patients. The expression of PD-1 and PD-L1 was higher on Gag-specific CD8+ T cells as compared to CEF-specific CD8+ T cells, and the expression of these markers did not change significantly after Treg depletion or co-culture with Treg/HIV-. In summary, the researchers showed a defect of Treg/HIV+ in modulating both the differentiation and the expression of PD-1/PD-L1 molecules on HIV-specific CD8 T cells. Their results suggest that this particular defect of Treg might contribute to the exhaustion of HIV-specific T cell responses.
Lymphatic filariasis is a serious and disabling disease caused by parasites that live in the lymphatic system of humans for years. The parasites produce molecules that neutralize the effects of the host's immune response. These molecules are called glutathione-S-transferases (GSTs). GSTs from other parasites, such as schistosomes and fascioliasis, have been used in vaccines to protect against infection. In this study, the authors have cloned the GST gene from the larval stage of the parasite Wuchereria bancrofti, expressed it in the lab, and tested it as a potential vaccine candidate. They found that the antibodies produced by vaccinated animals could inhibit the enzymatic activity of the GST, and that these animals were partially protected against infection with a related parasite. The authors suggest that further studies should be done to improve the vaccine's effectiveness and explore its potential for use in humans.
CRISPR-Cas9 is a new technology that allows scientists to edit the DNA of experimental organisms. It also has huge potential for therapeutic purposes. However, there is concern about the possibility of "off-target effects" caused by poor editing fidelity. To address this concern, scientists have used whole genome sequencing to look for new mutations that may have been caused by the editing process. However, these studies used strain-matched but not pedigree-matched controls, meaning that they couldn't tell the difference between true mutations and those caused by other factors. In this study, the researchers used a "trio design" and whole genome sequencing to look for mutations caused by CRISPR editing in embryos. They also looked at the number of these mutations and found that it was not statistically different from the number of mutations that occur naturally in embryos. This means that if CRISPR editing is causing off-target effects, it's likely not happening very often.
Photosynthesis and water use are influenced by the size of stomata, which are tiny holes on the surface of plant leaves that help plants take in carbon dioxide and release oxygen. The size of stomata can be controlled by exposure to light, with blue light causing stomata to open and red light causing them to close. Two proteins, HRB1 and PP7, play important roles in this process and help to control the opening and closing of stomata in response to changes in light intensity. Mutations in either HRB1 or PP7 can affect the normal functioning of stomata, leading to changes in water use and photosynthesis. Researchers have studied the interactions between these two proteins and how they work together to regulate stomatal opening.
The article is about a protein called Mediator, which helps with gene expression in eukaryotes. Mediator works together with many other proteins to help RNA polymerase produce a copy of the gene. In a previous study, the authors found that a specific Mediator protein, called MDT-15, helped control certain metabolic genes in a specific way. Now, they are studying the function of MDT-15 in more detail to understand how it works and what other genes it affects. The authors did a new study to find new genes that MDT-15 affects. They discovered that MDT-15 affects many genes that are not related to metabolism, but are important for response to stress. The authors suggest that MDT-15 may be a key link between gene regulation and metabolism.
The hippocampus, a brain structure that's essential for spatial memory, encodes spatial information by creating "mental maps" of environments. These maps are thought to be encoded in the patterns of spiking across many neurons, and the resulting information needs to be decoded accurately to form a spatial map of the environment. It is believed that the temporal pattern of neuronal firing, specifically co-firing, is key to decoding this information. The authors propose that co-firing implies spatial overlap of place fields, meaning that the map encoded by co-firing will be based on connectivity and adjacency, or topological, rather than geometric, information. Using computational tools from algebraic topology, the authors demonstrate that it is possible to effectively and reliably derive a topological connectivity map from neuronal spiking patterns. They show that there are certain requirements for the firing activity to produce a stable topological map, and they propose that the experimentally observed characteristics of firing activity likely satisfy these requirements. The authors conclude that a topological connectivity map is a plausible mechanism for decoding place cell firing patterns and forming a spatial map of the environment.
A research paper has been published about the production, assembly, and secretion of hepatitis C virus (HCV) in cells. The researchers identified many new host factors required for HCV egress and used live cell imaging of HCV core trafficking to study the dynamics of HCV core trafficking in association with its cellular cofactors. The study used infectious HCV with a tetracysteine (TC) tag insertion in core (TC-core) to monitor the dynamics of HCV core trafficking in association with its cellular cofactors. The researchers found that HCV is infectious upon envelopment at the ER and exits the cell via the secretory pathway. They also found that dynamic HCV core trafficking in association with apolipoprotein E (ApoE) and vesicles is important for HCV egress. The study provides new insights into the mechanisms of HCV egress and suggests potential targets for antiviral therapies.
In this article, the authors investigate the role of the imprinted gene Grb10 in neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), a genetic disorder characterized by an increased risk of developing benign and malignant tumors. The authors used mutagenized mice heterozygous for NF1 to model radiation-associated second malignant neoplasms. They found that Grb10 is commonly lost in diverse Nf1 mutant tumors, and that this loss independently promotes Ras pathway hyperactivation, which promotes hyperproliferation. The authors also found that restoring Grb10 in Nf1 mutant tumors decreases proliferation and downregulates Ras signaling, and that Grb10 silencing in untransformed mouse embryo fibroblasts significantly increased cell proliferation and Ras-GTP levels. These findings suggest a novel role for an imprinted gene in tumorigenesis, and highlight the need for further research on the role of imprinted genes in cancer.
Pavlovian threat conditioning is a way that animals learn to associate neutral stimuli with dangerous outcomes. This process is similar to learning a new language or a new skill. A new skill takes time and effort to master, and it is not easy to learn. The brain has a mechanism that helps it to learn from experiences, just as it helps to learn a new skill. This mechanism is called learning. In the case of Pavlovian threat conditioning, the brain uses learning to associate a neutral stimulus with a dangerous outcome. This can help the animal to react to danger quickly and effectively. It is not clear how the brain uses learning to associate a neutral stimulus with a dangerous outcome. There are many different theories, and scientists have studied this for a long time. In this study, scientists wanted to learn more about how the brain uses learning to associate a neutral stimulus with a dangerous outcome. They did this by looking at how the autonomic nervous system (ANS) responds to different stimuli. The ANS is responsible for the body's automatic responses, such as heart rate, breathing, and sweating. Scientists used a method called PsPM (psychophysiological modelling) to measure the ANS responses of study participants. PsPM uses all of the data from the ANS response, not just a few specific data points. This method allows scientists to get a more accurate picture of the ANS response. Scientists also looked at different models of how the brain uses learning to associate a neutral stimulus with a dangerous outcome. They compared these models to the ANS responses of study participants. They found that a probabilistic learning model best explained the ANS responses of study participants. This means that the brain uses probabilistic learning to associate a neutral stimulus with a dangerous outcome. The study also found that different ANS responses reflect different aspects of the same learning model. This means that different parts of the ANS respond differently to the same learning process. Overall, the study provides new insights into how the brain uses learning to associate a neutral stimulus with a dangerous outcome.
The SepH-SIN protein kinase cascade plays an essential role in septation (separation of hyphal cells) and conidiation (asexual reproduction) in the filamentous fungus A. nidulans. However, whether negative regulators of conidiation exist is unknown. In addition, the SepH-SIN kinase cascade and the HOG-MAPK pathway, which are involved in regulating reversible protein phosphorylation and are required for cell growth and reproduction, may communicate with each other. Using mutation comparison analysis of next-generation sequencing, we identified a suppressor of SepH, PomA, which is involved in septation and conidiation. Furthermore, deletion of pomA causes activation of the HOG-MAPK pathway. These findings demonstrate that the SepH-SIN cascade and the HOG-MAPK pathway interact with each other and play important roles in cell growth and reproduction.
Leishmaniasis is a skin disease caused by a parasite and is endemic in many parts of the world, including Brazil. There are different types of leishmaniasis, and some people can develop more severe forms of the disease. The reasons why some people develop more severe forms of the disease are not fully understood. A study was done to investigate the relationship between the different species of Leishmania that cause leishmaniasis and a virus that can affect the parasites. The study included 156 patients with leishmaniasis who attended a hospital in Brazil. The researchers found that the virus was present in the parasites causing leishmaniasis, but it did not seem to be the only factor that determined whether someone would develop a severe form of the disease.
This study showed that type I interferon (IFN-I), which is known to help fight viral infections, also plays an important role in preventing pneumococcal bacteria from invading the bloodstream after infecting the lungs. This is done by reducing the ability of the bacteria to travel through the lung and blood vessel walls, as well as by reducing the number of bacteria that can invade the bloodstream. The study found that IFN-I accomplishes this by increasing the strength of the tight junctions that hold the cells of the lung and blood vessel walls together, and by decreasing the ability of the bacteria to use a protein called PAF receptor to invade those cells. The study also showed that giving mice a type I interferon before infecting them with pneumococcal bacteria could help protect them from developing a serious infection.
We have developed a new computer model of how the brain works that can solve complex problems, like deciding which food to eat in a maze. This model has two layers of "neurons," which are like tiny computers that communicate with each other. The first layer of neurons is able to learn how to recognize patterns in the food, while the second layer is able to use this information to decide which food to go for. This model shows that the brain's way of learning and thinking is more complex than we thought, and that it's able to solve really difficult problems.
Breast cancer is a disease that is caused by the growth of abnormal cells. There are different types of breast cancer, and each type is caused by different factors. One of the factors that can cause breast cancer is a protein called ELF5. ELF5 is involved in the growth of cells that produce milk. In breast cancer, ELF5 can cause the growth of cancer cells and can also make the cancer cells more likely to spread to other parts of the body. In this study, researchers investigated how ELF5 is involved in the spread of breast cancer. They found that ELF5 can cause cancer cells to spread to other parts of the body. They also found that ELF5 can cause the body's immune system to help the cancer cells spread. The researchers hope that this information will help them find ways to treat breast cancer.
In recent years, evidence has shown that the interaction between chromatin loops, which can be characterized by three factors - connection pattern, distance between regulatory elements, and communication form - play an important role in determining the level of cell-to-cell variability in gene expression. However, there is a need for a modeling effect that addresses the question of how changes in these factors affect variability at the expression level in a systematic rather than case-by-case fashion. In this study, we present such a modeling effort, based on a mechanic model that maps three fundamental patterns for two interacting DNA loops into a 4–state model of stochastic transcription. We first show that in contrast to side-by-side loops, nested loops enhance mRNA expression and reduce expression noise whereas alternating loops have just opposite effects. Then, we compare effects of facilitated tracking and direct looping on gene expression. We find that the former performs better than the latter in controlling mean expression and in tuning expression noise, but this control or tuning is distance–dependent, remarkable for moderate loop lengths, and there is a limit loop length such that the difference in effect between two communication forms almost disappears. Our analysis and results justify the facilitated chromatin–looping hypothesis.
This research focuses on developing a new type of RNA called translation inhibiting RNA (tiRNA) that can repress gene expression by blocking translation initiation. To create a predictive framework for tiRNA design, various features related to RNA structure and thermodynamics were analyzed in a design of experiments. First, an in silico analysis was performed to identify features with the highest information content. Next, the performance of these features was evaluated in vivo using a library of tiRNAs. A partial least squares model was constructed to link the features of tiRNA to gene repression, and this model was compared to an ordinary least squares model.
The relationship between neurons is thought to be important for memory and behavior. However, there is little known about how these relationships occur or how to identify them. In this study, the authors recorded the electrical signals from multiple sites in the brain of awake monkeys and organotypic cultures of brain tissue. They discovered that when a group of neurons' activity patterns exceed a certain threshold, the patterns are replicated at other brain sites. This replication occurs quickly, within hundreds of milliseconds, and is similar to the way action potentials (single-cell signals) are replicated at the level of single cells. These patterns, which the authors called "coherence potentials", are unique to each group of neurons and can be used to identify specific associations. The nonlinear behavior of these coherence potentials is similar to the spread of ideas and behaviors in social networks.
In this study, we identified 25 essential genes in fission yeast that affect nuclear size control. We found that RNA processing and LINC complexes play important roles in nuclear size control. Our study also revealed lower and more extreme higher nuclear size phenotypes, and we identified global cellular processes and specific nuclear components that are important for nuclear size control. These findings are important for understanding how nuclear size is controlled in cells.
Deep brain stimulation (DBS) is a commonly used treatment for neurological disorders such as Parkinson's disease (PD) and essential tremor (ET). It works by delivering a train of pulses with constant frequency via electrodes implanted into the brain. New "closed-loop" approaches aim to provide improvements in terms of efficiency, efficacy and reduction of side effects. The success of closed-loop DBS depends on being able to devise a stimulation strategy that minimizes oscillations in neural activity associated with symptoms of motor disorders. A useful stepping stone towards this is to construct a mathematical model, which can describe how the brain oscillations should change when stimulation is applied at a particular state of the system. Our work focuses on the use of coupled oscillators to represent neurons in areas generating pathological oscillations. Using a reduced form of the Kuramoto model, we analyze how a patient should respond to stimulation when neural oscillations have a given phase and amplitude. Our predictions suggest that the best stimulation strategy should be phase specific but also that stimulation should have a greater effect if applied when the amplitude of brain oscillations is lower. We compare this surprising prediction with data obtained from ET patients. In light of our predictions, we also propose a new hybrid strategy which effectively combines two of the closed-loop strategies found in the literature.
This study was about developing a new method to detect the parasite Schistosoma mansoni in the fresh water pulmonate snails of the genus Biomphalaria that act as intermediate hosts for the parasite. The method, named Biompha-LAMP, used a set of six primers targeting a sequence of the parasite's ribosomal intergenic spacer 28S-18S rRNA, and was able to detect as little as 0.1 fg of S. mansoni DNA at 63°C for 50 minutes. The assay was evaluated by examining S. mansoni DNA in B. glabrata snails experimentally exposed to miracidia at different times post-exposure. DNA for LAMP assays was obtained by using a commercial DNA extraction kit or a simple heat NaOH extraction method. The Biompha-LAMP assay was able to detect S. mansoni DNA in all groups of snails and is specific, sensitive, rapid, and could be potentially adapted as a cost-effective method for screening of intermediate hosts infected with S. mansoni in both individual snails and pooled samples. This method could be suitable for large-scale field surveys for schistosomes control campaigns in endemic areas.
Dengue is a major public health problem in Sri Lanka, with all four serotypes of the dengue virus in circulation for more than 30 years. Dengue has become a high priority disease for public health authorities in Sri Lanka, with large numbers of public health staff involved in year-round dengue control activities and free medical care provided to dengue patients at public hospitals. The aim of this study was to estimate the public sector costs of dengue control activities and the direct costs of hospitalizations in Colombo district during the epidemic year of 2012. The costing was conducted from the Ministry of Health’s perspective and focused on operational and administration costs. The findings are expected to inform public health planning and decision-making in Sri Lanka and contribute to the growing body of literature on the costs of dengue prevention and treatment.
Scientists have been trying to figure out where most European Y chromosomes come from. They studied a specific genetic lineage, haplogroup R1b1b2, and found that it originates from the Near East via Anatolia during the Neolithic. This means that most European Y chromosomes likely came from the Neolithic expansion, which was a major cultural transition that happened around 10,000 years ago in the Near East.
This study aims to understand the relationship between motor variability and learning. It uses computer simulations and experiments to show that variability can have both positive and negative effects on learning, and that these effects can vary depending on the specific factors involved. The study also highlights the importance of sensory uncertainty in the relationship between variability and learning rate, and suggests that this relationship may depend on the specific task. Additionally, the study found that there is no clear statistical relationship between variability and learning rate across a wide range of previously published data.
This paper describes the structure of a protein complex between RelA, a component of the NF-κB family of transcription factors, and CBP/p300, a general transcriptional co-activator. The authors used NMR spectroscopy to solve the structure of the RelA:CBP/p300 complex. They found that RelA's transcriptional activation domain binds to a region of CBP/p300 called TAZ1, through hydrophobic interactions. The authors also designed mutants of RelA that selectively abrogated the RelA:CBP/p300 interaction, and used these mutants to gain insight into the role of this interaction in transcription. They found that genes that were previously thought to be independent of the RelA:CBP/p300 interaction were actually dependent on it, and that the interaction is important for recruitment of RelA to its target promoter sites. This information can help us understand the role of the NF-κB pathway in immune response and inflammation.
Gene set analysis methods have been successfully used for analyzing gene expression data in cross-sectional studies. However, they need to be extended to longitudinal data because many experiments measure gene expression over time. The method presented here, called time-course gene set analysis (TcGSA), is an extension of gene set analysis to longitudinal data. TcGSA uses linear mixed effects models to analyze repeated measures in longitudinal data, and can accommodate missing data. It also allows for heterogeneity within gene sets. TcGSA has been applied to two real-life datasets: an HIV vaccine trial and a study on influenza and pneumococcal vaccines. It revealed significant changes in gene sets in both studies. The method is also supported by a simulation study and an R package.
The current understanding of where P. vivax, a common human malaria, is spread globally is not well-developed. This study aims to map the global endemicity of this disease using a statistical approach to combine existing data from various sources. Using this method, the authors find that P. vivax is most endemic in Asia, with the highest levels of endemicity in Indonesia and Papua New Guinea. Africa has lower levels of endemicity due to a high frequency of a genetic trait that protects against the disease. The Americas also have lower levels of endemicity, but these areas are densely populated, contributing to a higher number of people at risk globally. These maps and endemicity estimates can help guide efforts to control and eliminate P. vivax malaria in different regions of the world.
This study investigates the role of a protein called clumping factor B (ClfB) in skin and soft tissue infection (SSTI) caused by the bacterium Staphylococcus aureus. ClfB is a protein that helps S . aureus adhere and invade host cells and tissues, and evade the immune system. Previous studies have shown that ClfB helps S . aureus colonize the nose, but its role in SSTIs has not been investigated. The authors found that ClfB is important for the formation of abscesses and determines the bacterial burden during early infection. This was dependent on a specific interaction with the ligand loricrin, which is expressed within the abscess tissue. The authors also found that a vaccine that targets ClfB protects against S . aureus skin infection. Therefore, ClfB is an important antigen for future SSTI vaccines.
HIV-1 continues to be a major public health problem, and preventing its transmission is very important. The 90-90-90 goal set by UNAIDS aims to end AIDS by 2030 by reducing the number of new HIV infections. One way to achieve this goal is through pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP), which uses a medication to protect people who are at high risk of being exposed to HIV. There are currently two medications approved for PrEP: tenofovir and emtricitabine (Truvada). However, Truvada has limitations, including that it is expensive, requires daily dosing, and does not provide 100% protection from infection. To overcome these limitations, researchers are developing next-generation PrEP regimens, including more cost-effective drugs and drug formulations that require infrequent dosing. To help design these regimens, researchers need tools that integrate the various factors that affect PrEP efficacy, such as pharmacokinetics (how the body processes the medication), pharmacodynamics (how the medication affects the body), and viral characteristics. In this study, researchers developed a novel method that integrates these factors to predict the efficacy of different PrEP and PEP schedules. They used this method to analyze the second-generation integrase inhibitor dolutegravir, which has shown promise as a PrEP and PEP agent. The researchers found that oral 50mg dolutegravir provided non-inferior protection to Truvada and that nano-formulations of dolutegravir could potentially improve its prophylactic efficacy.
In this study, we discovered how Hepatitis C virus (HCV) regulates autophagy, a process in which cells break down damaged parts of their cells to recycle. We found that HCV causes two different proteins called Rubicon and UVRAG to be made. These proteins control the maturation of autophagosomes, which are the containers that carry the damaged parts of cells to be broken down. HCV makes more Rubicon than UVRAG at first, which leads to a temporary build-up of autophagosomes. But after a while, the balance of proteins changes, and more UVRAG is made, which helps to break down the autophagosomes. We also found that the HCV protein NS4B helps to make more Rubicon and autophagosomes. Overall, our study showed that HCV uses autophagy to its advantage by controlling when and how autophagosomes are broken down. This helps HCV to replicate itself more efficiently.
Researchers have discovered a protein called CCNYL1 that is very similar to another protein called CCNY in its genetic makeup. While the function of CCNYL1 is not well understood, the researchers found that it is highly expressed in the testis of mice and is important for male fertility. Mice without CCNYL1 were infertile, while those without CCNY had normal fertility. The researchers also found that CCNYL1 binds to a protein called CDK16 and that this binding leads to an increase in CDK16 kinase activity. This finding provides important new information about the role of CCNYL1 in spermatogenesis and male fertility.
Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC) bacteria can cause serious illnesses such as diarrhea and hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), a condition where the kidneys shut down. These diseases are caused by toxins produced by EHEC, including a toxin called EHEC-Hly. This toxin can be found in two forms: free or attached to tiny sacs called outer membrane vesicles (OMVs). Researchers found that OMV-associated EHEC-Hly can enter and damage human brain microvascular endothelial cells and intestinal epithelial cells, which are important sites of injury in HUS. The toxin is internalized by these cells via OMVs, but then separates from them and targets mitochondria, leading to cell death. These findings suggest a new mechanism for how EHEC-Hly can contribute to the development of HUS.
The article describes how the co-transcriptional modification of histones H2B and H3 is regulated by a conserved pathway in yeast and human cells. This pathway involves a cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK9) that phosphorylates the subunit Spt5 of the elongation factor DSIF (DRB-sensitivity inducing factor) to promote the elongation of the mRNA. The article describes how the loss of the H2Bub1 modification, which is catalyzed by the ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme Rad6 and the E3 ubiquitin ligase Bre1, leads to the loss of Spt5 phosphorylation and results in the loss of the elongation factor DSIF from chromatin. This, in turn, leads to defects in mRNA elongation and, ultimately, cell death. The article suggests that CDK9 and H2Bub1 oppose each other to regulate mRNA elongation, but that proper balance between the two is ensured via a positive feedback loop. The article highlights the importance of the H2Bub1 modification in maintaining the balance between CDK9 and DSIF and in regulating mRNA elongation. It also suggests that defects in H2Bub1 may contribute to the development of diseases such as cancer.
We examined YFV isolates from around the world and created a new timeline of the virus's evolution. The virus has been transmitted among humans via Aedes aegypti mosquitoes for centuries. We found that YFV originated in Africa and was introduced to the Americas by slave ships. This discovery has important implications for controlling future outbreaks of the disease.
In this study, the authors examined the pathogenesis of the pneumococcus, a bacterial pathogen that causes a range of diseases including otitis media, pneumonia, and sepsis, in an infant mouse model. They identified key points in the pathogenesis process where the pneumococcus must pass through a population bottleneck, which is a sharp reduction in the size of the population due to environmental constraints. This study provides insights into potential weak points in the pathogenesis process of the pneumococcus that could be targeted for intervention strategies. By using an animal model, the authors were able to recapitulate many of the key features of pneumococcal pathogenesis, including increased susceptibility in infants, localized disease, invasive infection, and transmission.
A new study has been conducted to test whether humans have been exposed to bites from the sand fly Phlebotomus orientalis, a vector for visceral leishmaniasis. The study uses recombinant proteins derived from P. orientalis' salivary glands to test human sera from Sudan and Ethiopia. The study found that two recombinant proteins, mAG5 and mYEL1, are the best markers for exposure to P. orientalis bites. These proteins were also found to increase the sensitivity of the test when used in combination. This study is the first to use recombinant proteins to screen for exposure to P. orientalis bites in humans. It could help in the development of new ways to prevent visceral leishmaniasis.
Conjugative plasmids are small, self-replicating pieces of DNA that can be transferred from one bacterial cell to another, and are found in many different types of bacteria. They often carry genes that confer advantages such as antibiotic resistance to the bacteria that host them. One type of conjugative plasmid, called IncC, has been found in many different types of bacteria, including those that cause foodborne illness. These plasmids can replicate themselves and transfer to other bacteria.
