The app was designed to help doctors estimate a child's weight, determine the appropriate amount of fluids and medications to use, and assess the child's dehydration. The app was tested in two hospitals in Bangladesh, which did not have scales. The study found that the app improved doctors' adherence to the guidelines in several ways. Doctors prescribed the recommended antibiotic more often, used the recommended fluid resuscitation amount more often, and used the recommended zinc supplement more often. However, there were limitations to the study, including the lack of a control group and the fact that doctors were not blinded to which patients used the app. Despite these limitations, the study suggests that smartphone apps can be a useful tool for improving clinical care for patients with diarrheal disease in resource-limited settings.
Infectious diseases are sensitive to environmental changes, especially temperature. However, it is difficult to predict how host-parasite systems will respond to climate change because host and parasite traits may have different temperature dependencies that need to be taken into account. Researchers used experimental data from a freshwater crustacean (Daphnia magna) and its parasite (Ordospora colligata) to fit a mathematical model of within-host parasite population dynamics. They used parameters from host aging and mortality, as well as parasite growth, virulence, and equilibrium abundance, that were specified by relationships arising from the metabolic theory of ecology. The model accurately predicted host survival, parasite growth, and the cost of infection across temperature. This study shows that linking simple metabolic models with a mechanistic host-parasite framework can be used to predict the temperature responses of parasite population dynamics at the within-host level. This approach has the potential to be applied to other host-parasite systems and may help us better understand the impacts of climate change on disease.
The article focuses on the role of GABAergic interneurons in shaping the activity of excitatory cells. The authors propose a functional role for a specific network motif consisting of parvalbumin- (PV), somatostatin- (SOM), and vasoactive intestinal peptide-expressing interneurons. They suggest that mutual inhibition between VIP and SOM cells amplifies weak inputs to VIP interneurons into large changes in somato-dendritic inhibition of pyramidal cells. The authors also show that the SOM-VIP motif allows transient inputs to switch between two processing modes, depending on the strength of the input. They provide a mathematical analysis and simulations of a microcircuit consisting of these three interneuron types and excitatory PCs to support their hypothesis.
The human body is home to many microorganisms, collectively known as the microbiome. These microorganisms can have a big impact on our bodies, affecting things like our mental health, weight, and overall health. Researchers have studied the microbiome to see how it is related to different diseases, like diabetes, arthritis, cancer, autism and inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). However, the results of these studies have been conflicting, and many associations have been found between microorganisms and diseases that are not actually linked. To address this problem, a team of scientists developed a new method to remove these spurious associations and focus on the ones that are truly linked to the disease. They applied this method to a large study of IBD and found that the majority of the previously reported associations could be explained by interactions between different microorganisms in the gut. This means that these associations were not actually linked to the disease itself, but were caused by other factors. The scientists also found that a small number of microorganisms were directly linked to the disease, including Roseburia, Faecalibacterium prausnitzii, Bifidobacterium adolescentis, Blautia producta, Turicibacter, Oscillospira, Eubacterium dolichum, Aggregatibacter segnis, and Sutterella. These microorganisms are known to be important for overall health and may play a role in the development of IBD. The scientists also found that these direct associations were much better at distinguishing between people with the disease and healthy people than associations that were not directly linked to the disease. This new method of analyzing microbiome data can help scientists to better understand how the microbiome is related to disease and to identify the microorganisms that are most important for our health.
Insects, such as mosquitoes, can carry pathogens that can cause diseases in humans and animals. Wolbachia is a type of bacteria that can infect mosquitoes and reduce the transmission of these pathogens. In this study, the researchers compared the effect of Wolbachia on two flaviviruses (dengue virus and West Nile virus) in two types of infected mosquitoes: stable and transient. The stable infected mosquitoes were infected with Wolbachia and the infection was maintained in their offspring. The transient infected mosquitoes were injected with Wolbachia and the bacteria remained in their body for only a few days. The researchers found that Wolbachia blocked the replication and transmission of both viruses in both types of infected mosquitoes. However, the blocking effect was significantly lower in the transient infected mosquitoes. This study provides further evidence for the potential use of Wolbachia as a natural control method for mosquito-borne pathogens.
Cilia are microtubule-based organelles that play a critical role in cell signaling. They are composed of a basal body, a transition zone, a doublet region, and a singlet region. The doublet region is a portion of the cilia shaft adjacent to the transition zone. The InvC, a distinct region of the cilia shaft, is composed of components such as NPHP-2, NPHP3, NEK8, and ANKS6. The InvC is important for signal transduction and amplification, cilia placement, and ciliogenesis. The current study used genetic and structural analyses to examine the biogenesis, structure, and composition of the C . elegans doublet region and InvC. The study found that the InvC is conserved in C . elegans, is established early in development, and is distinct from the doublet region. NPHP-2, ARL-13, and UNC-119 localize to the InvC and require their calcium binding EF hand domain for targeting. The study also found that nphp-2, arl-13, and unc-119 fall into two redundant genetic modules. The genetic modules modulate the sizes of the NPHP-2 InvC and ARL-13 doublet region, and glutamylation, a tubulin post-translational modification, is not required for ciliary targeting of InvC and doublet region components. The study concludes that the C . elegans InvC is distinct from the doublet region, and that components in these two regions interact to regulate ciliogenesis via cilia placement, ciliary microtubule ultrastructure, and protein localization.
Researchers have found that Scribble, a protein involved in cell polarity, is important for myelination and remyelination in the brain. Scribble is expressed in oligodendrocytes, the cells that make the myelin sheath in the brain, and is needed for the myelin sheath to form properly. When Scribble expression is removed, the myelin sheath does not form correctly. This finding suggests that Scribble may be a target for developing new treatments for diseases that cause myelin loss, such as multiple sclerosis.
This paper talks about a type of bacteria that can make a toxic and harmful substance called Streptolysin S (SLS). SLS can damage and kill cells, and it makes the bacteria more likely to spread. This substance is made by some bacteria in the same way that other bacteria make antibiotics. The paper explains that there are some other bacteria that can make a similar substance, and it talks about how this substance can help some bacteria to survive and spread. The paper also explains that the bacteria that make SLS are related to other bacteria that can make this substance, and it talks about how some of these bacteria can produce it too. The paper also explains that different strains of bacteria can produce different substances that are related to SLS.
Mycetoma is a painful, inflammatory disease that affects the skin and soft tissues, often resulting in disfigurement, disability, and reduced quality of life. This disease is caused by either fungal or bacterial organisms that form "grains," which are surrounded by an inflammatory response. However, the immune response that leads to the formation of these grains and the specific expression of cytokines and matrix metalloproteinases in mycetoma lesions are not well understood. Therefore, this study aimed to determine the expression of interleukin-17 (IL-17) and matrix metalloproteinase-9 (MMP-9) in mycetoma lesions and their correlation with clinical characteristics of the patients. The study included 100 patients with confirmed mycetoma, and their biopsies were analyzed using immunohistochemistry. The results showed that IL-17 was mainly expressed in zones 1 and 2, while MMP-9 was mainly expressed in zones 2 and 3. MMP-9 expression was higher in Actinomadura pelletieri and Streptomyces somaliensis biopsies compared to Madurella mycetomatis biopsies. Moreover, the expression of IL-17 and MMP-9 were directly proportional to each other. The only significant association between MMP9 and patients' characteristics was the duration of the disease. There was an insignificant correlation between the expression of IL-17 and patients' demographic characteristics. This study provides valuable insights into the immune response that leads to the formation of mycetoma granulomas and suggests that IL-17 and MMP-9 may be potential targets for therapeutic interventions in mycetoma.
The article is about a specific type of recognition that takes place between disordered proteins called intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) and target proteins. This recognition does not require the IDP to change its structure, but instead it recognizes the target in its disordered state. This phenomenon is referred to as fuzziness and is characterized by polyvalency, sequence insensitivity and a variety of disordered bound-state conformations. The article describes a specific IDP called the transcriptional activation domain of the Ewing's Sarcoma oncoprotein family (EAD), which exhibits many features of fuzziness. To understand this recognition process, the authors propose a model called the polycation-π model, which suggests that EAD recognizes the target by making polycation-π contacts with basic residues on the target. The authors tested this model by performing a range of experiments and molecular simulations. Their results show that the model is consistent with the experimental data and can be used to understand the molecular recognition process of EAD. This study highlights the importance of cation-π interactions in protein-protein recognition and suggests that this type of recognition is a general concept for promiscuous target recognition by polyvalent IDPs.
The article "Lon Proteins of Borrelia burgdorferi: A Comparative Study" by M. K. Johnson, S. M. O'Connor, E. J. Hodges, J. W. Collins, A. A. W. Rutherford, and A. J. Stark discusses the Lon proteins of Borrelia burgdorferi, the causative agent of Lyme disease. Specifically, they discuss Lon-1 and Lon-2, two proteins that have been identified in B. burgdorferi but not in other bacterial species. The authors describe the structure and function of these proteins, as well as their potential role in the adaptation of B. burgdorferi to its host. They also compare Lon-1 and Lon-2 to the Lon proteins of other bacteria, highlighting their unique features. Overall, the article provides a comprehensive overview of the Lon proteins of B. burgdorferi and their potential role in the survival and adaptation of this important human pathogen.
The paper investigates the role of antibody-dependent phagocytosis (ADP) in preventing HIV infection. ADP is a process where antibody-opsonized virions or cells with viral antigens are internalized into phagocytic cells. To determine if HIV-specific antibodies mediate this process, researchers used several phagocytic cells (THP-1, U937, and freshly isolated primary monocytes) and virions decorated with gp41 or gp41-derived peptides. They found that minimal or no ADP of virions occurred with any of the antibodies. However, when gp41-specific mAbs were used, efficient phagocytosis occurred. The researchers estimated that a minimum of a few hundred gp41 molecules were needed for successful phagocytosis, which is similar to the number of envelope spikes on viruses that are readily phagocytosed (e.g., influenza virus). The researchers also found that virion-decorated cells were targets for phagocytosis or trogocytosis in the presence of HIV-specific antibodies. In conclusion, the paper suggests that ADP of virions may not play a role in preventing HIV infection, likely due to the paucity of trimers and the consequent inability of virion-bound antibody to cross-link FcyRs on phagocytes. On the other hand, ADP or trogocytosis could play a role in clearing HIV-infected cells and cells on the verge of infection.
Hookworms are intestinal parasites that infect millions of people worldwide, and their economic and health impact is not well known. Hookworm infections can lead to anemia, malnutrition, lethargy, impaired physical and cognitive development, and adverse pregnancy outcomes. It is difficult for decision-makers to determine how much time, energy, and resources to invest in controlling hookworms because of the lack of information on their economic and health burden. Therefore, we created a computational simulation model to estimate the economic and health burden of hookworms globally and in different countries. Our model used disability weight estimates to calculate DALYs, which is a measure of the number of healthy years lost due to a disease. We found that hookworm infections resulted in millions of DALYs worldwide in 2016, with even more DALYs when cognitive impairment was included. Productivity losses from hookworm infections varied depending on the probability of anemia and calculation method used, ranging from $7.5 billion to $138.9 billion annually using gross national income per capita as a proxy for annual wages. Hookworms cause more subtle chronic health problems, making it difficult for decision-makers to determine the economic and health burden. Our computational simulation model can help decision-makers to allocate time, energy, and resources to effectively control hookworms.
The research group studied the effects of developmental hypoxia on axon guidance in zebrafish. The study used the zebrafish model to investigate hypoxia during different stages of brain development. The team generated transgenic zebrafish to test the genetic pathways involved in hypoxia-induced guidance errors. The research found that hypoxia-induced pathfinding errors are caused by the activation of the hypoxia-inducible transcription factor (hif1) pathway and are mimicked by chemical inducers of the hif1 pathway. Further, the team discovered that a protein called ephrinB2 is a target of the hif1 pathway and is responsible for the pathfinding errors. The study also showed that a protein called ephA4 is complementary to the misrouting axons. The team found that a constitutively active form of ephrinB2a could mediate the pathfinding errors via a reverse-signaling mechanism. Finally, the study found that magnesium sulfate, which is used to improve neurodevelopmental outcomes in preterm births, protects against the pathfinding errors by preventing the upregulation of ephrinB2a. Overall, the study demonstrated that evolutionarily conserved genetic pathways regulate connectivity changes in the developing brain in response to hypoxia, and it supports the potential neuroprotective role of magnesium sulfate in preterm births.
In this study, the authors compared the use of high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) to conventional histopathological methods in the study of lung damage in mice infected with Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, a fungus that causes a chronic progressive disease called human paracoccidioidomycosis. The authors found that HRCT is a useful tool for the evaluation and quantification of lung damage in the experimental model of PCM in mice, as it allows the monitoring of disease progression over time. HRCT images can provide information on the three-dimensional distribution of lesions throughout the lung volume, which is not possible with conventional histological analysis or pulmonary function tests in live animals. The study suggests that HRCT can be used as a non-invasive tool to monitor treatment efficacy in the experimental model of PCM in mice.
This study proposes a new way to test for latent Leishmania donovani infections. The test is based on a whole-blood assay that measures the cell-mediated immune response to specific leishmania antigens. The test was evaluated on blood samples from active and cured visceral leishmaniasis patients, healthy endemic controls, and healthy non-endemic controls. The test based on soluble leishmania antigen (SLA) had a sensitivity of 80% and a specificity of 100%. The test's findings suggest that it can be used to measure the cell-mediated immune response in L. donovani infections. However, the positive IFN-γ response to stimulation with leishmania antigen in patients with active visceral leishmaniasis was contradictory to the conventional finding of a non-proliferative antigen-specific response of peripheral blood mononuclear cells and needs further research.
A new study has found that a bacterial toxin called CNFY is responsible for causing inflammation that eventually leads to the clearance of enteropathogenic yersiniae from the body. Suppression of CNFY function, however, promotes the establishment of a commensal-type life-style for the bacteria, making them persist in the body and leading to autoimmune disorders. This study has provided important insights into the mechanisms underlying persistent infections and will contribute to the development of new therapies for these infections.
In order to be successful and reproduce in plant hosts, pathogens must overcome the plant's innate defense system. A new pathogenicity gene in Magnaporthe oryzae, called DES1, has been identified and it helps the fungus counteract host defense mechanisms. The DES1 gene codes for a serine-rich protein that has unknown biochemical properties and is only found in filamentous Ascomycetes. Targeted deletion of DES1 showed that it is not involved in fungal development, but it did result in the fungus being hypersensitive to oxidative stress. The fungus was also unable to penetrate the host plant and caused a decrease in pathogenicity. In addition, plant defense mechanisms were activated, including the accumulation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and the accumulation of brown granules in primary infected cells. The results suggest that DES1 is a pathogenicity factor that counters host defense mechanisms by restraining the oxidative component of PTI.
The study aims to determine the accuracy of using model-based geostatistics (MBG) to predict the prevalence of Schistosoma haematobium infection in Ghana. The study found that using the mean predicted values alone, 21 of the 25 empirically determined "high-risk" schools requiring yearly praziquantel would have been undertreated, and almost 20% of the remaining schools would have been treated despite empirically-determined absence of infection. This translates into 28% of the children in the 79 schools being undertreated and 12% receiving treatment in the absence of any demonstrated need. Therefore, the study suggests that the current predictive map for Ghana is not adequate for guiding the national program and that predictive risk mapping should be an iterative process that incorporates empiric testing and model refining to create updated versions that meet the needs of disease control operational managers.
Prostaglandins are important molecules that help sperm find oocytes and eventually fertilize them. In a recent study, researchers found that Caenorhabditis elegans (C. elegans) oocytes make a group of prostaglandins from certain fatty acids that are provided in the yolk lipoprotein complexes. The researchers used genetic and chemical analyses to study the pathway of prostaglandin synthesis in C. elegans. They found that multiple prostaglandins work together to guide sperm towards oocytes. They also found that a conserved enzyme called CYP-6A14 in humans and CeCYP-6A14 in C. elegans play a role in regulating prostaglandin synthesis. The results of this study support the idea that prostaglandins are important molecules for sperm guidance and fertilization in C. elegans.
This paper describes a new approach to designing biotherapeutic proteins that are both effective and have low immunogenicity. The approach involves using algorithms to optimize the design of proteins for both high-level function and reduced T cell epitope content. By doing this, the authors identified a set of Pareto-optimal variants that balance the two objectives. The authors then built and evaluated these variants experimentally, and found that they maintained their functionality while reducing immunogenicity. This approach may be useful in accelerating and de-risking experimental deimmunization efforts.
Sexual reproduction is a fundamental process for most eukaryotes that requires meiosis. In turn, meiosis requires a reciprocal exchange of DNA between each pair of homologous chromosomes, known as crossovers. The frequency and distribution of crossovers are regulated by internal and external environmental factors. Here, the authors show that elevated temperature induces meiotic hyper-recombination in Arabidopsis thaliana and demonstrate that the extra crossovers are derived from the major Type I interference sensitive pathway. They also show that heat-induced crossovers occur without an increase in meiotic double-strand breaks and that the hyper-recombination phenotype is likely specific to thermal stress rather than a more generalized stress response.
There are many different types of tools available to help scientists analyze large amounts of biological data. Some of these tools use computers to combine information from various sources and come up with new hypotheses. One of these tools is called Hanalyzer. Hanalyzer was used on a large dataset of gene expression results related to the development of the face. By using Hanalyzer, the scientists were able to generate new hypotheses about the role of four genes in face development. These hypotheses were then tested through further experiments. Overall, Hanalyzer is a useful tool for helping scientists make sense of large amounts of biological data.
The liver fluke, Fasciola hepatica, secretes tiny sacs called extracellular vesicles (EVs) that can be taken up by host immune cells to help the fluke avoid being detected by the host's immune system. These vesicles contain many different molecules that can help the fluke cause disease in its host. In this study, the authors used a biotin reagent to capture proteins on the surface of two types of EVs (called 15k and 120k EVs) released by the fluke. They then used mass spectrometry to identify the proteins on the surface of these EVs. The authors also used a lectin microarray to analyze the sugars displayed on the surface of these EVs as they would be seen by the host. They found that both types of EVs have high mannose sugars on their surface, but they are different in other ways. The authors found that EVs that are released from the fluke gut are more likely to be taken up by host immune cells than those that are released from the excretory system. They also found that antibodies raised against proteins found on the surface of the EVs can enhance their uptake by host immune cells. These results help us understand how the fluke's EVs interact with host immune cells.
MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are small molecules that regulate many biological processes in plants, and they are produced from long primary transcripts (pri-miRNAs) that are transcribed by RNA polymerase II. In this study, we identified a cycling DOF transcription factor named CDF2 that binds directly to the promoters of some miRNA genes and affects DCL1-mediated processing of these pri-miRNAs. CDF2 regulates a group of pri-miRNAs at both the transcriptional and posttranscriptional levels to maintain proper levels of their mature miRNAs, which helps control plant development.
Folliculogenesis is the development of a female's eggs. It involves communication between the oocyte (egg) and granulosa cells, which provides the oocyte with necessary nutrients for growth. The authors found that geranylgeranyl diphosphate (GGPP) is required for this communication and for the growth of the oocyte. GGPP is produced in the oocyte and it helps to regulate the activity of Rho GTPases, which are important for cell communication. Without GGPP, the physical connection between the oocyte and granulosa cells is disrupted, which leads to problems in the oocyte's growth and the transition from primary to secondary follicles. The authors also found that GGPP helps with the secretion of important proteins from the oocyte, such as Gdf9.
The RNA polymerase II (Pol II) is an important enzyme in the process of transcription, where it synthesizes messenger RNA (mRNA) using DNA as a template. It has been suggested that there are two possible routes for the entry of nucleotide triphosphate (NTP) into the active site of Pol II: the secondary channel and the main channel. However, there is currently no complete picture of how the NTP enters Pol II through the main channel, and it is unclear if this route is significant. In this study, a structural model was built of Pol II with a complete transcription bubble, which is the region of DNA that separates and bends at the downstream edge of the transcription bubble. The model was then used for molecular dynamics (MD) simulations to study the diffusion of NTP through the channels. The results of these simulations showed that both the secondary channel and the main channel are possible routes for NTP entry, but that the secondary channel is more significant.
Dengue is a common but under-reported disease that causes high morbidity and mortality, especially in children and young adults. The authors used information from a prospective cohort study to estimate the burden of dengue in Thailand and Cambodia. The study found that the true number of dengue cases is significantly higher than the number of reported cases, and the authors recommend using multiplication factors derived from prospective cohort studies to more accurately estimate disease burden.
In this study, the researchers investigated the role of natural killer ( NK ) cells in promoting antiviral immune responses. They used a mouse model of cytomegalovirus ( MCMV ) infection to determine the effects of efficient and inefficient NK cell activation on the development of adaptive immune responses. The researchers found that NK cells can accelerate CD8 T cell responses against a viral infection in vivo. They identified the underlying mechanism as the ability of NK cells to limit pDC IFN-α/β production, which can have immunosuppressive effects on the host. The researchers suggest that understanding the role of NK cells in antiviral immune responses may lead to the development of innovative treatments for viral infections.
In this study, we discovered four different types of rRNA genes in Arabidopsis thaliana, a plant commonly used for scientific research. Two of these rRNA genes are always active, while the other two are either repressed or have no activity. We found that one of the inactive rRNA genes becomes active in plants that lack a protein called nucleolin. This protein helps control which rRNA genes are active and which are not. We also found that the active rRNA genes have DNA that is highly methylated, while the inactive rRNA genes do not have as much methylation. This suggests that the amount of methylation on DNA might play a role in deciding which rRNA genes are active. We hope this information will help us understand how rRNA genes work and how they are controlled in plants.
The article focuses on the role of histone deacetylation in regulating human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) gene expression during the infection process. The authors used a method called rapid immunoisolation to identify candidate HDAC1-interacting proteins in the context of HCMV infection, which included several human cytomegalovirus-coded proteins such as pUL38 and pUL29/28. The authors confirmed the interaction of pUL38 and pUL29/28 with HDAC1 using reciprocal immunoprecipitations. They also showed that the NuRD complex, a protein complex involved in chromatin remodeling and deacetylation, was associated with both pUL38 and pUL29/28. The authors demonstrated that blocking the expression of NuRD components inhibited the replication of HCMV, suggesting that NuRD is important for efficient HCMV replication. They also showed that full activation of the HCMV major immediate-early promoter required pUL29/28 but not pUL38, suggesting that pUL29/28 may play a more important role in enhancing HCMV gene expression. The authors propose that HCMV may co-opt NuRD function in order to enhance expression of its immediate-early genes.
The purpose of this study is to understand the antibody repertoire following primary Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) infection and its evolution through adolescence and adulthood. Phage display libraries were used for unbiased epitope profiling of infant sera before and after RSV infection. The results showed that the antibody response to F protein epitopes increased steadily from young children to adults, while the antibody response to G protein epitopes declined significantly in adults. Several novel epitopes were identified in pre-fusion F and an immunodominant epitope in the F-p27. Furthermore, the study found an unlinked evolution of the antibody responses to F and G proteins, which provides important information for the development of effective countermeasures including vaccines.
Filariae are parasitic worms that are transmitted to humans by mosquitoes. Filariae cause diseases such as elephantiasis and river blindness. There are several species of filariae that cause disease, including Brugia malayi, which causes lymphatic filariasis. Current treatments only kill the larval form of the worm, not the adult form. This means that people need to be treated repeatedly over a long period of time to control the disease. However, a new drug called emodepside, which has been shown to be effective against adult filariae, has the potential to change this. Emodepside works by activating voltage-gated potassium channels. However, the specific isoform of this channel that emodepside targets is not known. In this study, researchers investigated how emodepside works in the adult form of Brugia malayi by using a patch-clamp technique to measure the activity of individual muscle cells. They also used a technique called RNAi knock down to determine which isoform of the channel is targeted by emodepside. Their findings suggest that the male worm is more sensitive to emodepside than the female worm. This study provides valuable information about how emodepside works in the adult form of Brugia malayi and could help in the development of more effective treatments for filarial diseases.
The article is about developing better diagnostic tests for two different diseases: lymphatic filariasis (LF) and loiasis. LF is a disease caused by worms that are transmitted by mosquitoes and can lead to disfigurement and disability. Loiasis is a disease caused by a different type of worm that is also transmitted by mosquitoes and can cause symptoms such as itching and swelling. Currently, diagnostic tests for LF use antibodies that recognize a specific protein from the worm that causes LF. However, these tests can also give false positive results for loiasis. To better understand the nature of this cross-reactivity, researchers used antibodies that recognize proteins from the worm that causes LF to immunoaffinity purify proteins from the blood of people with loiasis. They found many different proteins that were reactive with the antibodies and suggested that they could be released by dying worms and used to develop better diagnostic tests for both diseases.
The cilium is a specialized organelle found on most eukaryotic cells. It has important functions in cell signaling and development. Defects in cilia lead to a range of diseases known as ciliopathies, which can affect multiple organs and physiological processes. To identify new cilium-associated genes, researchers used the nematode worm C. elegans to create a list of candidate genes from RNA-Seq libraries. They then confirmed that some of these genes are cilium-localized in worms. Among them is RAB-28, a protein that is associated with the BBSome, a complex involved in cilium formation and function. Overexpression of RAB-28 in worms leads to ciliary and cell non-autonomous sensory pore defects. This work provides a new approach to finding new ciliary proteins and uncovers a functional association between the BBSome, IFT, and RAB28.
The brain is responsible for representing the environment around us. But, how does it do this? One way that the brain might represent the environment is through the use of cells called place cells. Place cells are found in the hippocampus and fire in a specific location in space, called a place field. In this study, researchers investigated what can be learned about the environment using the spikes of place cells. They discovered that by analyzing which groups of place cells fire together, they could extract global topological features of the environment, and reconstruct an accurate geometric representation of space within which the animal's position could be tracked. They used standard tools from algebraic topology and graph theory to do this. Their findings suggest that the brain may use different methods to represent the environment around us, and that it may not need to rely on place fields or precise spike timing to do this.
In this study, researchers used a mouse model of viral FH to understand the immune mechanisms behind this disease. They found that the virus caused the liver to make too much of a protein that helps blood clot, and that this protein caused the liver to clot. They also found that the virus caused the liver to make too much of a protein that causes inflammation, and that this protein caused the liver to become inflamed. This study evaluated the hookworm infection prevalence and species-specific infection load in pre-school children in Malawi and their association with severe anemia and bone marrow iron deficiency using multiplex real-time PCR. The study found that the prevalence of Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus infections was 26.1% and 4.9%, respectively, with a higher prevalence of moderate and high load A. duodenale infections being associated with severe anemia and bone marrow iron deficiency. This study highlights the importance of species-specific hookworm screening for the diagnosis and treatment of severe anemia and iron deficiency in children living in resource-poor settings.
The article discusses the role of COM-1, a protein found in the Caenorhabditis elegans worm, in the repair of DNA double-strand breaks during meiosis. Meiosis is a specialized form of cell division that occurs in germ cells to produce gametes, the cells that make up sperm and eggs. During meiosis, DNA double-strand breaks are introduced into the DNA, which then need to be repaired in order for the cell to continue dividing. There are two main ways to repair DNA double-strand breaks: homologous recombination (HR) and non-homologous end joining (NHEJ). HR is considered to be more accurate than NHEJ, but it also requires an undamaged template, which is not always available. In C. elegans, COM-1 is required to block NHEJ activity and ensure that DNA double-strand breaks are repaired via HR. This ensures that the cell can divide correctly and produce healthy gametes.
Melioidosis is a serious and sometimes fatal disease caused by the bacteria Burkholderia pseudomallei and is particularly common in Southeast Asia and Northern Australia. A goat model for aerosol infection that mimics human melioidosis has been developed to study the humoral immune response. The immune response was monitored by ELISA and western blot, and the antigenic proteins were identified by mass spectrometry. It was found that IgG antibodies were the main humoral immune response and reactive to a range of antigens. The heat shock protein GroEL was found to be the most immunogenic protein. The study highlights the potential of using this goat model to study the immune response to melioidosis and to identify potential diagnostic biomarkers.
In this article, the authors describe how they developed a new approach to investigate the activation of mitotic cyclin B1–Cdk1 complexes in live human cells. By using a combination of immunofluorescence microscopy and flow cytometry, the authors were able to track the development of cyclin B1–Cdk1 activity in real-time. They found that cyclin B1–Cdk1 activity increased gradually during early mitosis, and that a critical threshold level of activity was required to drive mitotic entry. The authors also discovered that high levels of Cdk1 activity were needed for normal mitotic progression, and that a different threshold level of activity was required to initiate anaphase. These findings provide important insights into how the activity of mitotic cyclin B1–Cdk1 complexes is regulated in human cells.
HIV-1 vaccines have not been able to generate neutralizing antibodies (Nabs) that protect against various HIV-1 subtypes. We looked at the neutralizing antibody responses of 21 Kenyan women who were superinfected with HIV-1 subtypes A, C, and D, about 1.07 years after their initial infection. We collected their plasma samples at a median time of 2.72 years after superinfection. Previous studies have shown that the majority of broad and potent neutralizing activity in singly infected individuals can be mapped to four main epitopes on the HIV-1 Envelope, which include the CD4-binding site, a V1/V2 glycan, the N332 supersite in V3, and the membrane proximal external region of gp41. We focused on these targets and found that superinfection did not induce a dominant neutralizing antibody response to any one of these epitopes. Computational analyses also suggested that 20 of the 21 superinfected women's neutralizing antibody responses could not be ascribed a single specificity with high confidence. These data suggest that superinfection with diverse HIV-1 subtypes promotes the development of a broad polyclonal neutralizing antibody response. This study provides support for vaccine designs that use multivalent HIV immunogens to elicit a diverse repertoire of neutralizing antibodies.
Congenital human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) infection can cause serious brain development problems in babies. We have studied this infection in human neural progenitor cells (NPCs), which are important for brain development. We have found that HCMV infection reduces the levels of Hairy and Enhancer of Split 1 (Hes1) protein in infected NPCs. We also found that the immediate-early 1 protein (IE1) of HCMV is involved in this reduction. Our study suggests that HCMV infection downregulates Hes1 protein levels by causing IE1 to assemble a ubiquitination complex and promote Hes1 ubiquitination, leading to proteasomal degradation. This study provides new information about HCMV infection and its role in brain development disorders.
In this study, we compared how changes in gene expression occur in different species of flies from the same genus, which have evolved over millions of years. We looked at how closely gene expression patterns match the binding of transcription factors that play a role in early embryonic development. We found that although gene expression levels are quite similar across species, the binding of transcription factors is much more varied. Additionally, we noticed that highly bound sites, binding sites in regions where multiple factors bind, and binding sites near genes are more likely to be conserved across species. This suggests that some of the binding of transcription factors may not be important and may not be subject to evolutionary pressures. Overall, our study provides important information about how changes in gene expression occur in different species and how they are related to changes in transcription factor binding.
This study was conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of a program to eliminate lymphatic filariasis in India. The program involves mass drug administration to people who are at risk of being infected with the disease. The study found that there were still areas with high levels of infection, despite the mass drug administration program. These areas are known as "hotspots" and are important to monitor because they can lead to new cases of infection. The study also found that it is important to use good surveillance strategies to detect hotspots and to adopt evidence-based sampling strategies and evaluation unit size for Transmission Assessment Surveys (TAS). This information can help guide the development of more effective ways to eliminate lymphatic filariasis.
Dengue is a disease transmitted by mosquitoes, and controlling the mosquitoes is important in preventing the spread of the disease. A common method for controlling mosquitoes is using the insecticide temephos in water storage containers. This review aims to assess the effectiveness of temephos in controlling dengue when used as a single intervention or in combination with other interventions. The authors searched for relevant studies and found that temephos consistently reduced the number of mosquito larvae when used alone, but not when used in combination with other interventions. The effectiveness of temephos also varied depending on factors such as water quality and environmental conditions. While temephos may be effective in reducing the number of mosquitoes, there is no evidence to suggest that it reduces the spread of dengue.
The article discusses the role of two proteins, Ctf19 and Csm3, in cohesion at the pericentromere, a specific region on the chromosomes that is particularly enriched in cohesin proteins. Ctf19 and Csm3 are important for establishing cohesion at the pericentromere but work through different mechanisms. Ctf19 is involved in loading cohesin onto the pericentromere before DNA replication, while Csm3 is involved in the subsequent step of ensuring that cohesin is incorporated into functional linkages that hold sister chromatids together. The article suggests that these proteins work together to ensure that chromosomes are properly divided during cell division.
Researchers used mass spectrometry to analyze the metabolome and lipidome of serum from adult dengue fever (DF) patients at three different stages of infection: early febrile, defervescence, and convalescent. They found 60 differentially expressed metabolites, most of which were involved in acute inflammatory responses. They also found that sphingomyelins were associated with CD8+ lymphocyte activation during the early febrile period, and plasmalogen phosphatidylethanolamines and lysophosphatidylethanolamines were associated with platelet numbers during defervescence and convalescence. The researchers concluded that the self-limiting nature of DF may be due to early widespread host changes in the metabolome and lipidome.
This article describes a study that aimed to identify and map networks of researchers who are conducting research on Neglected Tropical Diseases (NTDs) in Germany and their partners abroad. The study used a variety of tools, such as OpenRefine, OpenStreetMaps, Table2Net, Gephi, and data from the SCOPUS database, to analyze co-authorship networks, identify highly productive and innovative researchers, and visualize and analyze network characteristics. The study found that a large proportion of NTD research within Germany was conducted by research institutions located in Germany, and that collaborations with partners on the African continent were relatively scattered. The study also identified researchers who were highly productive and innovative in their research on NTDs. The findings of the study can help inform evidence-driven policy making that addresses the needs of patients with NTDs.
Lymphatic filariasis (LF) and soil-transmitted helminths (STH) are diseases that affect millions of people worldwide, including in Haiti. In 2000, a strong mass drug administration (MDA) program was launched in Haiti to combat these diseases. The program was led by the Ministry of Public Health and Population and its collaborating international partners. The program reached full national scale by 2012, and by 2012, almost all districts in Haiti had met the epidemiological coverage targets of 65% for LF and 75% for STH. The program was a great success, and Haiti has made significant progress toward the elimination of LF. The program involved several key programmatic elements, including strong community awareness, community trust of drug distributors, direct observation of treatment, easy access to treatment, and quality data collection. The program has been successful in part due to sustained international financial and technical support, especially in the past eight years. The program has not only helped establish the global portfolio of "best practices" for NTD control but also has laid the foundation for ongoing STH control.
Sinorhizobium meliloti is a type of bacteria that can live in the soil by itself or as a partner with legumes to form a mutualistic symbiosis. The symbiosis involves several developmental stages, during which the bacteria must coordinate cell proliferation with the development of host plant cells. CtrA is a protein that helps control the timing of cell division and other processes during the cell cycle. Recent research has shown that CtrA is also important for the symbiotic differentiation of S. meliloti, which includes cell branching and genome amplification. The authors of this paper wanted to learn more about how CtrA regulates the cell cycle in S. meliloti during the symbiosis. They found that the cell cycle of S. meliloti is uncoupled from DNA replication in the symbiotic state, which is different from the cell cycle in the free-living state. They also found that CtrA regulates different processes in S. meliloti during the symbiosis, such as cell branching, and genome amplification, compared to C. crescentus CtrA. The authors believe their findings provide valuable insight into how genetic networks can evolve to fit the diverse lifestyles of different bacteria.
Francisella tularensis is a bacterium that causes the disease tularemia and is highly infectious. It has the ability to multiply and survive inside macrophages, which are types of white blood cells. In this study, the authors used a special method to identify genes that are important for Francisella to survive inside macrophages. They found a gene called FTL_0766 that was important for Francisella to survive inside macrophages. The FTL_0766 gene encodes a protein that helps Francisella to use glutathione (GSH) as a source of cysteine. Cysteine is an important amino acid that Francisella needs to grow and survive. The authors also found that a mutant strain that had a deleted FTL_0766 gene was strongly attenuated for virulence in mice. This means that the mutant strain was much less able to cause disease in mice. The authors concluded that the FTL_0766 gene is important for Francisella to survive inside macrophages and to cause disease in mice.
Leishmania parasites are two species that cause two different types of Leishmaniasis in humans and animals. These parasites can be found inside a sac-like structure within cells called parasitophorous vacuoles (PVs). These PVs can fuse with other PVs that contain different Leishmania species, but not with PVs of other organisms. The ability of parasites to fuse with each other is important for their survival and reproduction. Researchers have found that L. amazonensis amastigotes, which are found in large PVs, can fuse with L. major promastigotes, but not with L. major amastigotes. The PVs that contain L. major promastigotes can fuse with L. amazonensis PVs, but the promastigotes cannot differentiate into amastigotes. These findings suggest that PVs can be customized by different Leishmania species, and that the PV environment can influence the ability of parasites to fuse with each other.
In this study, the authors investigate the ability of native, membrane-expressed JR-FL Env trimers to elicit neutralizing antibodies ( nAbs ) against HIV-1. They find that unusual potent nAb titers developed in 2 out of 8 rabbits immunized with virus-like particles ( VLPs ) expressing trimers and in 1 out of 20 rabbits immunized with DNA expressing native Env trimer, followed by a protein boost. They also find that 2 out of 3 sera neutralize via quaternary epitopes and exploit natural gaps in the glycan defenses of the second conserved region of JR-FL gp120. These gaps were shared by 2 trimer VLP sera and one of the trimer DNA sera. The authors also find that removing the N197 glycan from the trimer DNA serum (which was proximal to the CD4 binding site) rendered 50% or 16.7% of clade B tier 2 isolates sensitive to the two trimer VLP sera, showing broad neutralization via the surface masked by the N197 glycan. They also find that the neutralizing DNA trimer serum took advantage of the absence of a glycan at residue 230, also proximal to the CD4 binding site. The authors conclude that their data show for the first time that strain-specific holes in the glycan fence can allow the development of tier 2 neutralizing antibodies to native spikes. They also suggest that cross-neutralization can occur in the absence of protecting glycan. The authors believe that their findings provide new insights that may inform the future development of a neutralizing antibody vaccine.
Buruli ulcer (BU) is a skin disease that can lead to severe scarring, caused by bacteria called Mycobacterium ulcerans. It affects mainly children and the elderly, and is most common in West Africa. The current treatment for BU involves taking antibiotics for eight weeks, but some patients' wounds take longer to heal. In this study, researchers looked at the proteins found in the skin of patients with BU during the healing process, using a technique called immunohistochemistry. They found that several proteins were useful for understanding how the skin heals after BU treatment, and that some patients' wounds take longer to heal due to issues with wound healing.
Axons can be very long, and mitochondria need to be transported to the right places to meet the metabolic demands of the axon. Scientists have studied how mitochondria move in vitro, but these studies have limitations because they do not have the same structure and physiology as living cells. To solve this problem, scientists used confocal imaging to observe mitochondrial movements in vivo along resting and electrically active mouse nerves. They stimulated myelinated and unmyelinated axons to see how this affected mitochondrial movement. They found that electrical stimulation increased anterograde and retrograde mitochondrial movement, and that the frequency of the electrical stimulation increased the speed and number of moving mitochondria. Additionally, the scientists found that stationary mitochondria became shorter and that these shorter mitochondria were used to replenish the population of moving mitochondria. The moving mitochondria did not congregate near the nodes of Ranvier, but continued to move along the axon. This suggests that the peripheral terminals of sensory axons are areas of high metabolic demand during electrical activity. The scientists also found that increased mitochondrial movement during electrical activity may be a way to ensure that there is a uniform increase in mitochondrial density along the length of the axon, supporting the increased metabolic demand of sustained conduction. This research provides important information about how mitochondria move in vivo and how electrical activity affects this movement.
The article is about a genetic condition called spondylocarpotarsal synostosis (SCT), which causes progressive vertebral fusions and short stature. The article discusses how the protein Filamin B (FLNB) is important for proper vertebral bone formation. The authors used mice to study the role of FLNB in SCT and found that FLNB helps to maintain the correct shape of the spinal discs. Without FLNB, the spinal discs undergo abnormal cell fate changes and become more similar to bone, leading to fusions and degeneration of the discs. The authors also found that FLNB helps to regulate TGFβ and BMP signaling, which are important for bone formation and growth. These findings provide new insights into the causes of SCT and degenerative disc disease.
The Thogoto virus (THOV) is an orthomyxovirus that infects chickens and causes respiratory disease. Researchers have found that THOV ML, a protein produced by the virus, interacts with a protein called TFIIB, which is involved in the initiation of gene expression. THOV ML causes TFIIB to be localized to the cytoplasm instead of the nucleus, which leads to changes in gene expression. However, not all genes are affected by THOV ML. Instead, the virus specifically targets the expression of type-I interferon genes, which are important for the immune response. The researchers believe that THOV ML impairs expression of these genes by interfering with IRF3, a transcription factor that is involved in the expression of type-I interferon genes. However, THOV ML does not directly interact with IRF3 and instead may be targeting a central transcription factor, such as TFIIB, to indirectly affect IRF3.
Parvovirus B19 (B19V) infects human red blood cell-producing cells, causing cell cycle arrest and DNA damage. This article describes the function of a protein called non-structural protein 1 (NS1) in this process. The authors used two versions of NS1 to study its role in cell cycle arrest. They found that the NS1 protein contains a transactivation domain that is responsible for arresting cells at G2 phase. The authors then analyzed the gene expression changes that occur in response to the NS1 protein to understand how it causes cell cycle arrest. They found that NS1 activates the ataxia-telangiectasia mutated and Rad3-related (ATR) pathway, which is involved in DNA damage repair. The ATR pathway, in turn, phosphorylates CDC25C at serine 216, which inactivates the cyclin B1/CDK1 complex. The authors conclude that the NS1 protein is responsible for arresting cells at G2 phase by activating the ATR pathway and inactivating the cyclin B1/CDK1 complex. This is important because it helps us understand how parvoviruses infect and damage cells, which may lead to new ways of treating these infections.
Dengue is a common mosquito-borne illness that causes a wide range of symptoms. In severe cases, it can lead to vascular leakage, or fluid accumulating in tissues. The virus responsible for dengue, called DENV, produces a protein called NS1 that causes the endothelium, or the layer of cells that line blood vessels, to become more permeable, allowing fluid to leak out. This can be prevented by using medications that target proteins involved in the breakdown of the glycocalyx, a layer of sugars and proteins that covers the surface of endothelial cells.
This research describes the relationship between the septin ring in budding yeast and the spindle position checkpoint (SPOC) during mitosis. The septin ring is a collar of proteins that forms at the bud neck and helps coordinate cytokinesis. The SPOC ensures that the anaphase spindle is aligned correctly before cytokinesis. The research shows that two redundant ubiquitin ligases, Dma1 and Dma2, are required for the correct assembly and dynamics of the septin ring and for the activation of the SPOC. This is because Dma1 and Dma2 help recruit a kinase called Elm1 to the bud neck, which is necessary for the SPOC to function properly. The research suggests that Dma1 and Dma2 help regulate the position of the spindle by controlling the dynamics of the septin ring, which in turn affects the position of the spindle.
In this study, the authors used genetic data from 61 worldwide populations to identify signals of selection in the human genome that are associated with climate variables. They found that genic and nonsynonymous SNPs were more strongly correlated with climate variables than non-genic SNPs, suggesting that adaptation to climate has shaped the distribution of genetic variation in humans. The authors also found that several of the strongest signals of selection overlapped with those from previous genome-wide association studies (GWAS), including SNPs associated with pigmentation and autoimmune diseases. Additionally, they found enrichments of strong signals in gene sets related to UV radiation, infection and immunity, and cancer. These results suggest that climate has played a central role in shaping human adaptations, and that many of the genetic signals of selection identified in previous GWAS may be related to adaptations to climate.
The short QT syndrome (SQTS) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by shortened QT intervals and an increased risk of sudden death due to arrhythmias. Researchers have identified the N588K mutation in the hERG potassium channel, which leads to changes in the IhERG current and IKr current. These changes are associated with shortened QT intervals and increased risk of re-entrant arrhythmias. Using mathematical models of ionic channels and cardiac tissue, researchers have been able to simulate the effects of the N588K mutation on ventricular action potentials and tissue excitability. The findings of this study provide a clear link between the molecular changes in the hERG channel and the functional changes in cardiac tissue that contribute to the arrhythmic risk in SQTS.
Collective behavior refers to the behavior of a group of individuals as a whole rather than as individuals. A number of models have been proposed to explain this behavior, but they can either be simple or accurate, but not both. New techniques allow us to individually track each animal in large collectives with high precision, but it is difficult to increase accuracy without increasing complexity. Here we propose a new type of deep neural network, called deep attention networks, that are organized into modules. This modular organization allows us to understand the underlying rules of collective behavior by analyzing the modules. We have tested this model with simulated and experimental trajectories of zebrafish, and we found that it can accurately predict the behavior of the zebrafish and extract important information about the underlying rules of collective behavior.
The emergence of drug-resistant HIV is a serious concern for the long-term efficacy of antiretroviral treatment. Around 10% of ART-naive patients in Europe are infected with drug-resistant HIV type 1. The fitness cost of major resistance mutations, defined as the ratio between transmission rates of hosts infected by drug-resistant strains and transmission rates of hosts infected by drug-sensitive strains, is an important measure for understanding drug resistance dynamics. In this study, we use phylogenetic analysis to reconstruct the transmission tree of HIV strains and model it using stochastic birth–death–sampling processes to quantify the fitness cost of major resistance mutations in the Swiss HIV cohort. We found that the 90M mutation in the protease gene is the only resistance mutation that has significantly higher fitness than the drug-sensitive strains. Among the remaining resistance mutations, only 67N, 70R, 184V, and 219Q had fitness costs that were significantly lower than the drug-sensitive strains. Our study provides a novel approach for estimating the fitness cost of drug resistance mutations using data from a Swiss HIV cohort.
In this study, the authors examined the role of the Elongator complex, a group of proteins that help with transcription, in fission yeast. They found that a protein called Sin3/Elp3, which is part of the Elongator complex, is important for stress survival in fission yeast. The authors determined that Sin3/Elp3 helps with the modification of certain tRNAs, which are responsible for coding amino acids and are important for protein synthesis. They found that a tRNA modification is required for normal survival after stress in cells lacking Sin3/Elp3, and that overexpressing a particular tRNA can complement the stress-related phenotypes of Sin3/Elp3 mutant cells. The authors also found that the lack of a functional Elongator complex results in stress phenotypes due to its contribution to tRNA modification and subsequent translation inefficiency of certain stress-induced, highly expressed mRNAs.
We found that Nef can increase the resistance of HIV-1 virions to neutralization by certain antibodies that target the membrane proximal external region (MPER) of the envelope glycoprotein (Env) by up to 50-fold. This increase in resistance is not due to changes in the quantity of Env on the virion, but rather to changes in the way that Env is incorporated into the virion. Nef increases resistance to MPER-targeting antibodies such as 2F5 and 4E10, but has no effect on resistance to antibodies that target other regions of Env or that are inhibited by the peptide T20. We found that this activity of Nef is conserved in a retrovirus that does not encode Nef. This new function of Nef has important implications for anti-HIV-1 immunity and AIDS pathogenesis.
We are studying the way the liver fluke, Opisthorchis viverrini, interacts with its snail intermediate host, Bithynia siamensis goniomphalos, using molecular techniques. We have created a transcriptome of the snail that will help us better understand the relationship between the snail and the parasite. This information may lead to new ways to treat or prevent this type of cancer.
Leprosy is a common and socially stigmatizing infectious disease. It is caused by bacteria called Mycobacterium leprae and M. lepromatosis, which primarily affect the skin and peripheral nervous system. The disease can range from paucibacillary tuberculoid to multibacillary lepromatous disease, depending on the quality of the immune response. Genetic variants of the host and environmental factors influence the immune response. Recent genetic association studies have identified specific polymorphisms associated with susceptibility to leprosy. In this work, we investigate complement receptor 1 (CR1) polymorphisms, mRNA expression levels, and soluble CR1 levels in Brazilian leprosy patients. Our results suggest that CR1 polymorphisms may play a regulatory role in mRNA and sCR1 levels, with haplotype-specific effects increasing susceptibility to leprosy.
Metabolomics is a powerful tool used to analyze physiological and disease-induced biological states. It takes into account both an organism's genetic factors and the effects of lifestyle, diet, and environment. Recently, common genetic variants have been found to have a large effect on individual metabolic capacities. These are called "genetically determined metabotypes." Genetic variants in metabolism-related genes lead to specific and differentiated metabolic phenotypes. Genetic studies can help to understand the direction of effects between metabolites and diseases. The combination of genetic and metabolic markers is an important emerging approach for biological research. It is important to minimize the occurring confounders on human serum metabolites in a population-based study.
We developed a new objective function, MiMBl, to improve the capacity of genome-scale metabolic models for predicting genetic interactions. MiMBl captures the biologically important concept of metabolic adjustment and was found to outperform the current objective functions used for predicting genetic interactions in yeast. Using MiMBl, we found a large set of negative genetic interactions involving functionally distant genes, as well as positive interactions between genes that are connected by a short metabolic pathway. These interactions are well-supported by experimental data and suggest that the metabolic network is strongly regulated to maintain metabolic homeostasis.
This study investigates how the topography of the landscape affects the spread of plague, a highly virulent and re-emerging disease, in Madagascar. The study was carried out in four areas that differ in topographic relief and cover about 150–200 km2 within the plague focus of Madagascar. The authors compared plague seroprevalence levels and genetic structure of black rats (Rattus rattus), the main reservoir of plague in Madagascar. They found that the seroprevalence levels mimicked those previously reported for humans, and that rat populations had a more marked genetic structure with increasing relief. However, the relationship between seroprevalence data and genetic structure differs between areas. This suggests that plague distribution is not related everywhere to the effective dispersal of rats. The authors conclude that the relationship between plague occurrence and landscape characteristics in Madagascar is complex and requires further research to fully understand.
In this study, the authors examine the immunoglobulin response to a family of proteins on the surface of the schistosome worm that causes the parasitic disease schistosomiasis in humans. The authors identify 11 proteins within this family and demonstrate that infected humans mount an immune response to two of these proteins, providing evidence that they are exposed to the surface of the schistosome. These findings may contribute to the development of a vaccine against this parasitic disease.
The study used a computer simulation to understand the shapes of cells in the Drosophila retina, which is made up of many repeating units called ommatidia. Each ommatidium contains many cells, including eight photoreceptor neurons and twelve accessory cells. In the retina, two types of cell-cell adhesion molecules are expressed: E-cadherin and N-cadherin. N-cadherin is only expressed by four cone cells, which are part of the core of the ommatidium. The study found that the shapes of the cells in the retina can be explained by a simple model that minimizes the interfacial energy between cells. The model was able to reproduce the shapes of wild-type and mutant cells, and it emphasized the importance of adhesion protein biogenesis and its timing with respect to cell remodeling. The study also found that N-cadherin protein is recycled from inactive interfaces to active interfaces, which helps to modulate the adhesion strengths between cells.
The protein MT1-MMP is important for the process of cancer cell invasion. It helps to degrade the surrounding matrix which allows the cancer cells to move and spread. It is located at structures called invadopodia, which are specialized membrane protrusions that help cancer cells move through the surrounding matrix. However, the turnover rate of MT1-MMP at invadopodia and its role in ECM degradation were not clear. The authors measured the turnover rate of MT1-MMP using Fluorescence Recovery after Photobleaching (FRAP) experiments, and found that it was very rapid, with time constants of 26 seconds and 259 seconds. They also built a computational model and found that the rapid turnover of MT1-MMP was crucial for ECM degradation. The authors suggest that their computational model can help design and evaluate intervention strategies for cancer cell invasion.
Scientists have studied how HIV-1 evolves within an individual and spreads spatially. They have found that the virus in the blood is not the same as the virus in other parts of the body. For example, they found that the virus in the vagina is different from the virus in the blood, which suggests that the genital tract forms a different viral population. It is unclear how well the blood plasma represents the broader HIV-1 population. This could lead to incorrectly applied therapies and the selection for further drug resistance. Additionally, previous studies have examined the relationship between viruses from different tissues, but the results are equivocal. The scientists compared viral DNA and RNA from four different compartments (the blood, lymph nodes, gut, and vagina) of four macaques infected with RT-SHIV, a simian immunodeficiency virus containing HIV-1 reverse transcriptase, and treated with monotherapy to induce the emergence of two of the most prevalent drug resistance mutations. They found that the blood and lymph nodes were rarely compartmentalized, while the blood and lymph node were more frequently different from mucosal tissues. This study suggests that even often-sampled blood does not fully capture the viral dynamics in other parts of the body, especially the gut.
Tissue growth can be influenced by chemical signals (called "diffusible factors") that can change the probability of stem cells to renew or differentiate. In some tissues, these chemical signals can also control the shape of the tissue and the way it grows. Recent research has shown that some tissues use this mechanism to grow in specific shapes, such as branches or tubes. This can happen in many different tissues, including the lungs, limbs, and intestines.
The article describes a genome-wide association study of myopia in Europeans. The study identified 22 novel genetic associations with myopia, including a strong association with a variant in the LAMB2 gene. The study also replicated a previous association with the GJD2 gene and a novel association with the RASGRF1 gene. The findings suggest several novel genetic pathways in the development of myopia and provide new insights into the complex etiology of myopia.
The current study investigates different forms of feedback from body curvature to a central pattern generator (CPG) circuit that controls the movement of a lamprey. Two types of feedback were considered: directional feedback and magnitude feedback. Directional feedback either excites or inhibits the oscillators on the same side of the body, depending on the direction of the curvature. Magnitude feedback excites or inhibits the oscillators on both sides of the body, depending on the magnitude of the curvature. The results show that directional feedback changes the duration of muscle activity, while magnitude feedback changes the frequency of the oscillations. The study highlights the importance of understanding the different forms of feedback that are present in the CPG circuit and how they affect the movement of the lamprey.
The global HIV pandemic is dominated by one group of viruses (group M), and this group has been diversifying since it jumped from chimpanzees to humans about 100 years ago. HIV has been spreading across the world and has been split into several different types or subtypes. Some countries have more than one subtype, which means that there are compartmentalized epidemics where different subtypes infect different risk or ethnic groups. HIV has been spreading slowly between these compartmentalized epidemics, and shifts between subtypes occur only very slowly. Scientists have developed a simple model of HIV epidemics to better understand how different virus strains compete with each other at the population level. They simulated epidemics where the second strain was introduced into a population where the first strain had already established a steady-state epidemic and assessed whether the second strain was able to spread in the population. They found that the second strain spread on a much slower time scale than the initial expansion of the first strain. In order to become dominant over a time scale of decades, the second strain needed a considerable advantage in transmission efficiency over the resident strain. If the second strain was introduced while the first strain was still in its growth phase, it was even harder for the second strain to invade. The scientists also tested how different mechanisms of interference, such as inhibition of superinfection, depletion of highly connected hubs in the network, and one-time acute peak of infectiousness, contribute to the inhibition effect. They found that all of these mechanisms play a role in the competition dynamics of HIV at the population level, which may explain the global phylogeography of the virus and may influence the future evolution of the pandemic.
The organization of muscles is a product of adaptation over different length scales, including the sarcomere and muscle bundles. To better understand how the cytoskeleton organizes with respect to these scales, we developed a computational model and tested it in vitro. We found that myofibrils organize into bundles that are tightly spaced, rather than being irregularly dispersed, and that the alignment of these bundles is dependent on geometric cues in the extracellular matrix. Additionally, we identified two organizational processes that contribute to the polarization of the contractile cytoskeleton: the interaction between actin fibers, premyofibrils, and focal adhesions, as well as cooperative alignment and parallel bundling of nascent myofibrils. Our results suggest that a hierarchy of mechanisms regulate the self-organization of the contractile cytoskeleton, and that a positive feedback loop is responsible for initiating the break in symmetry that is necessary for polarization.
The paper describes a study on the potential use of Wolbachia, a type of bacteria that infects mosquitoes, as a biocontrol tool to reduce dengue transmission. Wolbachia can invade and spread to infect all individuals within wild mosquito populations at a high rate of maternal transmission, strong cytoplasmic incompatibility, and low fitness costs in the host. However, the study found that extensive differences in climate, field-release protocols, urbanization level and human density among the sites where Wolbachia has been deployed have limited comparison and analysis of its invasive potential. To address this issue, the researchers examined the key phenotypic effects of the wMel Wolbachia strain in laboratory Aedes aegypti mosquitoes with a Brazilian genetic background to characterize its invasive potential. They also performed mark-release-recapture experiments using Wolbachia-uninfected Brazilian mosquitoes in two areas of Rio de Janeiro where Wolbachia will be deployed in the future. Through analysis of laboratory, field and mathematical data, the researchers show that the wMel strain of Wolbachia possesses the characteristics required to spread effectively in different urban socio-demographic environments in Rio de Janeiro. They also developed optimized release strategies for each field site that will greatly benefit the upcoming biocontrol trials and likely prove applicable to field sites in other cities and countries that share similar characteristics.
In this study, the researchers identified a new protein that can remove methyl groups from histones in rice, a type of plant. This protein, called JMJ703, specifically removes methyl groups from histone H3 lysine 4, which is involved in plant growth and stress adaptation. The researchers also analyzed the structure of JMJ703 and identified key residues that are necessary for the protein to function. They found that these key residues are also conserved in other proteins that remove methyl groups from histones. This suggests that JMJ703 and its homologues may be specifically adapted to remove methyl groups from histone H3 lysine 4. The researchers believe that this new understanding of JMJ703's structure and function can help us better understand how plants regulate their growth and stress response.
The article describes a study on the HIV-1 capsid, which plays a key role in all steps of infection. The study reveals that a previously unknown multi-subunit interface within CA hexamers mediates the binding of linear epitopes to cellular cofactors NUP153 and CPSF6, and is competed for by antiretroviral compounds PF74 and BI-2. This interface involves multiple ligands sharing an overlapping binding site in HIV-1 capsid that is lost upon viral disassembly. The study also shows that NUP153 and CPSF6 have overlapping binding sites, but each makes unique interactions with CA. These results provide a molecular basis for the interactions of NUP153, CPSF6, PF74 and BI-2 with HIV-1 capsid, and reveal how these ligands influence infection. The study has important implications for the development of new antiviral therapies that target this interface.
The mosquito Aedes aegypti transmits important human arboviruses such as dengue, yellow fever, and chikungunya viruses. To understand how these diseases are transmitted in mosquitoes, researchers need to know the organization of their genome. However, the genome of Ae. aegypti is very large and has many repetitive sequences, making it difficult to assemble. To overcome this problem, researchers have used genetic mapping and a new technology called RAD sequencing to improve the genome assembly of Ae. aegypti. This improved genome assembly allowed researchers to assign more scaffolds to chromosomes and order the scaffolds along the chromosomes. Additionally, researchers found large regions of suppressed recombination around the centromeres. Using the improved genome assembly, researchers were able to map a gene that makes Ae. aegypti resistant to the human parasite Brugia malayi. This study provides an important resource for researchers to better understand the genetic basis of vector competence in mosquitoes.
This study compares four types of traps that are commonly used to monitor the mosquito Aedes aegypti, which is a disease-carrying mosquito found in tropical areas. The study was conducted in five cities with different climates in Brazil and was designed to investigate how well each trap detects mosquito density variation and how consistently each trap measures mosquito infestation over time. The study found that all four traps performed better than the traditional household larval survey in measuring the seasonal variation in mosquito abundance. The study also found that the four traps were consistent in their ability to detect changes in mosquito infestation over time. The study concludes that all four traps are useful tools for mosquito surveillance and should be considered as complements or alternatives to the traditional household larval survey.
The human protein APOBEC3G (A3G) is a protein that stops the spread of HIV-1 virus. It does this by editing the viral DNA during replication, which causes mutations that make the virus less able to infect new cells. The protein also inhibits the infection process in a way that is not yet fully understood. A3G is incorporated into the HIV-1 virus when it is made, but the virus protein Vif removes it from the virus. By analyzing the crystal structure of a similar protein, researchers have found that certain parts of A3G are important for its ability to inhibit the virus.
