We have estimated the short-term mutation and recombination rates in Helicobacter pylori, a common cause of stomach infections, by sequencing fragments of DNA from 78 gene fragments from 97 isolates. These isolates came from 34 pairs of sequential samples taken at intervals of 0.25 to 10.2 years, and from 29 individuals whose average age was 45 years. We used Approximate Bayesian Computation to estimate the rates of mutation, recombination, mean length of recombination tracts, and average diversity in those tracts. Our results indicate that the short-term mutation rate is 1.4×10−6 to 4.5×10−6 per nucleotide per year, and that three times as many substitutions are introduced by recombination as by mutation. We also found that the long-term mutation rate over millennia is 5–17-fold lower, partly due to the removal of non-synonymous mutations due to purifying selection. Our estimates of short-term mutation rates vary dramatically in different bacterial species and can span a range of several orders of magnitude. We therefore recommend that age estimates for bacteria be based on species-specific clock rates. We also note that clock rates for genetic diversity between species should not be used for dating within a species.
In this study, the authors explore the contribution of melanopsin-based photoreception to conventional visual pathways in the mammalian retina. They use new reporter lines to show that melanopsin-expressing retinal ganglion cells (mRGCs) have much more extensive projections than previously thought and extend across the dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus (dLGN), which is the origin of thalamo-cortical projection neurons. They continue to show that this input supports extensive physiological light responses in the dLGN and visual cortex in mice lacking rods+cones. Moreover, using chromatic stimuli to isolate melanopsin-derived responses in mice with an intact visual system, they reveal strong melanopsin input to the ∼40% of neurons in the LGN that show sustained activation to a light step. They demonstrate that this melanopsin input supports irradiance-dependent increases in the firing rate of these neurons. The authors conclude that melanopsin-based photoreception is a significant source of sensory input to the thalamo-cortical visual system, providing unique irradiance information and allowing visual responses to be retained even in the absence of rods+cones. This finding identifies mRGCs as a potential origin for aspects of visual perception and indicates that they may support vision in people suffering from retinal degeneration.
HIV-1 infection affects the immune system, especially in the gut where a large amount of mucosal memory CD4+ T cells reside. These cells play an important role in humoral responses and preventing the spread of microbial antigens from the gut to the rest of the body. In this study, researchers found that HIV-1 infection resulted in a decrease in mucosal memory CD4+ T cells and affected the production of antibodies specific to gut bacteria. They discovered that HIV-1-infected individuals with low CD4+ T cell counts had reduced levels of IgG and IgA specific to gut bacteria and an increase in IgM levels. This may contribute to the chronic inflammation seen in HIV-1 infection. The study highlights the importance of CD4+ T cells in maintaining the immune response in the gut and emphasizes the need for further research to understand the mechanisms underlying immune activation in HIV-1 infection.
Ecosystems can only sustain a certain number of species based on the availability of resources. When a population grows, it must balance out by reducing other populations. In neutral models of biodiversity, all populations change slowly due to random births and deaths. We propose a new model that explains how a sudden and severe reduction in the population of a single species releases resources for the remaining ones, causing diversity waves. During these waves, the abundance of species peaks at the beginning and then decreases exponentially. The population distribution is split into two peaks: one composed of species that recently collapsed or newly introduced species, and another composed of species that have not collapsed yet. This peak structure has a long-term memory, and it results in a scale-free tail of the population distribution with a universal exponent of 1.7. We show that this model is robust, and it can handle variations in parameters such as the diffusion between environments, species-specific growth and extinction rates, and bet-hedging strategies.
In this study, the authors investigate how the number of CW-rotating motors affects the tumbling angle of E. coli, a chemotactic bacterium. They extended a previously developed hybrid model of E. coli to take into account the duration of CW-rotation of each motor. The authors find that the tumbling angle depends on the number of CW-rotating motors, which causes a difference in tumbling angles for cells swimming up or down a gradient. This difference in tumbling angles leads to a small but significant increase in the chemotactic efficiency of E. coli. The authors suggest that this additional mechanism of tumbling angle tuning helps E. coli navigate through gradients more efficiently.
The thymus is a vital organ that produces T cells, which play a crucial role in the immune system. Thymic epithelial cells (TECs) are a key part of the thymus and provide a unique environment that helps T cells develop. TECs produce substances that help T cells grow and mature, and they also help T cells move from one area of the thymus to another. There are two main types of TECs: cortical TECs (cTECs) and medullary TECs (mTECs). cTECs help T cells become mature, and mTECs help T cells develop into T regulatory cells (Tregs), which are important for regulating the immune system. Mice that lack a functional mTEC compartment develop autoimmune diseases.
We have developed and applied a new computational method to search for potential small noncoding RNA (sRNA) genes in the genome of C. difficile. We then validated these predictions through RNA-seq and 5′-end RNA-seq analysis. We found that 250 sRNA genes, including both IGR and cis-antisense RNAs, were expressed in the strain 630Δerm. Most of the detected sRNAs were novel, and their functions are still unknown. We also identified a large number of CRISPR RNAs and RNA-based regulatory mechanisms in C. difficile. Our study provides a foundation for further functional characterization of these sRNAs in C. difficile.
The liver-specific microRNA miR-122 plays a crucial role in the liver and hepatitis C virus (HCV) life cycle. However, little is known about how the expression of miR-122 is regulated by HCV infection. In this study, the authors found that the HCV core protein inhibits the terminal mononucleotidyl transferase activity of GLD-2, which results in the downregulation of miR-122 isomers bearing non-templated 3′-end single-nucleotide additions. This downregulation of miR-122 isomers leads to the dysregulation of miR-122 function, which in turn affects HCV replication and translation. Overall, the study demonstrates a novel role of the HCV core protein in regulating viral replication and translation through GLD-2-mediated miR-122 stability control.
Trypanosomes are harmful parasites that cause disease in humans and livestock in Africa. Although certain species seem to have developed resistance to these parasites, there has been no evidence of acquired immunity to natural infections. We found that lions, which are wild African animals, have a pattern of infection rates that could be explained by cross-immunity from other trypanosome species. These findings may help in developing vaccines against the disease, even though the surface proteins of trypanosomes are known to be very complex.
The article presents a study that aimed to investigate the role that mathematical modeling and systems biology could play in molecular medicine and clinical development. The researchers used mathematical modeling and sensitivity analysis to explore a working hypothesis that computationally derived points of fragility in a model of the coagulation cascade could be used as a basis for target selection in drug discovery. The coagulation cascade is a complex biochemical process that involves a variety of proteins and blood cells that work together to prevent excessive bleeding and promote blood clotting. The model, which was validated using 21 datasets, predicted that fluid and surface phase factor X/activated factor X (fX/FXa) activity and thrombin-mediated platelet activation were fragile, while fIX/FIXa and fVIII/FVIIIa activation and activity were robust. These predictions were supported by both in vitro and in vivo experimental evidence. The results suggest that computationally derived points of fragility of human-relevant cascades could be used as a rational basis for target selection in drug discovery, despite model uncertainty.
This article describes a study that investigates the kinetics of using bacteriophages (viruses that kill bacteria) as a type of therapy. Researchers examined the interaction between a food-borne pathogen, Campylobacter jejuni, and a suitable virulent phage in an in vitro system. Phage-insensitive populations of C. jejuni readily arise, and researchers tested models for phage-bacteria interactions incorporating phage-insensitive or resistant bacteria. The results showed that even an apparently simplistic model fit the data surprisingly well, and the researchers confirmed that the so-called inundation and proliferation thresholds are likely to be of considerable practical importance to phage therapy. They estimated the thresholds and rate constants directly using a comparison of the fit for each culture, revealing density-dependent features of phage infectivity that are worthy of further investigation. The researchers concluded that insight from empirical studies can be greatly enhanced by the use of kinetic models. They recommend that this study serves as an essential precursor to building a meaningful picture of the kinetic properties of in vivo phage therapy.
In this study, the authors provide the first functional characterization of a Toll-like receptor (TLR) in the snail Biomphalaria glabrata, which acts as an intermediate host for the parasite Schistosoma mansoni. The TLR is called BgTLR and was identified as part of a peptide screen of snail immune cell surface proteins. The authors found that BgTLR is involved in the cellular immune response of the snail following challenge with S. mansoni, and knockdown of BgTLR altered the resistant phenotype of the snail, leading to patent infections in 43% of the normally resistant snails, which shed S. mansoni cercariae one week before the susceptible controls. This study represents the first functional characterization of a gastropod TLR and demonstrates that BgTLR is an important snail immune receptor that is capable of influencing infection outcome following S. mansoni challenge.
The study aims to develop an immuno-epidemiological tool to assess human exposure to mosquito bites of Aedes mosquitoes, which transmit infectious diseases. This tool will be a test to detect the presence of IgG directed against proteins from the salivary gland extracts (SGE) of Aedes aegypti and Aedes polynesiensis in human populations. The test was conducted on Tahiti and Moorea islands where these mosquitoes are present, and a cohort of people from metropolitan France, not exposed to these Aedes mosquitoes, was used as a control. The results showed that 98% and 68% of individuals have developed IgG directed against Ae . aegypti and Ae . polynesiensis SGE , respectively. This new immuno-epidemiological tool will help to evaluate the risk of disease transmission and to assess the efficacy of novel vector control strategies in French Polynesia and other tropical settings.
Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacteria that causes tuberculosis (TB), is able to infect humans and survive inside our cells thanks to its ability to adapt to the intracellular environment of human macrophages. In this paper, the authors explore how this process happens by studying the metabolic reactions of both the host and the pathogen. They found that Mtb pathogenicity is linked to its ability to regulate the host cell's metabolism, and that this regulation is crucial for the survival of both the host and the pathogen. By studying the metabolic reactions of cells infected with different strains of Mtb, the authors were able to identify the specific host reactions that are targeted, and how these reactions help the pathogen survive. This finding provides a framework for understanding how both the host and the pathogen contribute to the pathology of TB.
Meiosis is a special kind of cell division that produces haploid gametes from diploid cells. To ensure proper division, the chromosomes must pair up and recombine. This process is regulated by proteins like ZHP-3, which is a protein that is required for crossover recombination and meiotic segregation.
The paper discusses a study that looked at the factors affecting the abundance and distribution of the mosquito Aedes albopictus in Rome, Italy. This mosquito is an invasive species that has spread worldwide in recent decades, including to temperate regions of Europe and the United States. In Rome, the mosquito has become a public health concern due to its ability to transmit exotic arboviruses and its aggressive daytime outdoor biting behavior. The study used two datasets to analyze the effects of climatic and socio-environmental variables on the mosquito's abundance and distribution. The results showed an association between highly anthropized habitats and high mosquito abundance in both metropolitan and sub-urban/rural areas. The study also found a bimodal seasonal dynamics with a second peak of abundance in autumn, due to heavy rains occurring in the preceding weeks in association with permissive temperatures. These findings provide useful indications to prioritize public mosquito control measures in temperate urban areas where nuisance, human-mosquito contact and risk of local arbovirus transmission are likely higher.
Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb), the bacteria that causes tuberculosis, has a unique cell envelope that is made up of mostly lipids. One group of lipids, called phthiocerol dimycocerosates (DIM), has been studied extensively because it is thought to be a virulence factor of Mtb. DIM are made of a mixture of long-chain β-diols esterified by multimethyl-branched fatty acids named mycocerosic acids. They are found near the surface of the bacilli and are thought to be part of the mycobacterial pseudo-outer membrane. DIM have been shown to play a role in cell wall permeability and many studies have implicated these molecules in the pathogenicity of Mtb. However, it is not clear how DIM mediate pathogenesis, whether they act as effectors or modify host immune responses. Recent studies have shown that DIM contribute to the initial growth of Mtb in mice by protecting it from the nitric oxide-dependent killing of macrophages and modulating the production of key inflammatory cytokines. This suggests that DIM may be involved in modulating the immune responses of murine macrophages, although the cellular and molecular mechanisms by which DIM participate in the cross-talk between Mtb and macrophages are unclear. Mycobacteria make use of the phagocytic machinery of macrophages to gain access to the interior of the cell and subvert phagosome maturation. At the interface between mycobacteria and macrophages, the complex outermost layer of the mycobacterial cell wall may play a role in facilitating host cell entry. DIM are located in the outer layer of Mtb cell envelope and therefore constitute potential candidates for modulating the initial step of entry into macrophages and for controlling the outcome of bacterial infection. In this study, the authors demonstrate the involvement of DIM in the receptor-dependent phagocytosis of Mtb through a mechanism involving plasma membrane reorganisation after bacteria recognition. This modification might enable Mtb to create a protective niche, by preventing phagosome acidification.
Researchers have developed a mathematical approach to describe the behavior of small neural networks with a few tens of neurons, which are an important intermediate level of brain organization. This approach allows for a systematic analysis of the local and global bifurcations of neural activity, and the formation of multiple branching solutions caused by spontaneous symmetry-breaking. This phenomenon is a finite-size effect that reveals previously unexplored differences between mesoscopic cortical circuits and their mean-field approximation. The authors found that the most important consequence of spontaneous symmetry-breaking is the ability of small neural networks to regulate their degree of functional heterogeneity, which may reduce the detrimental effect of noise correlations on cortical information processing.
In this study, researchers wanted to find out if Leishmania parasites are alive in the blood and other body parts of people who have dermal leishmaniasis. To do this, they used a special type of RNA called 7SLRNA, which is only made by living cells. They found that this RNA was present in the blood cells of people with leishmaniasis, as well as in normal skin and tonsil samples. This suggests that Leishmania parasites are alive and possibly spreading in people with this disease. The study shows that 7SLRNA is a good target for future research on leishmaniasis.
This study aimed to understand the relationship between chromatin features and DNA replication timing in Drosophila. The authors used a machine learning approach called Lasso to analyze a dataset of chromatin feature levels and DNA replication timing in three different cell types of Drosophila. The results showed that combinations of chromatin features are predictive of DNA replication timing. The authors then used a multivariate adaptive regression spline (MARS) to identify a set of features that predict DNA replication timing with high accuracy. The authors also found that the features H3K36me1, H3K27me3, H3K4me1, H3K9me2, and H2BUb are the most important predictors of DNA replication timing. Finally, the authors used these findings to develop a simple model of DNA replication timing that can be generalized to other cell types and potentially used to understand the regulation of DNA replication timing in other organisms.
Dengue fever is a disease caused by the Dengue virus (DENV), which is transmitted to humans through the bite of infected mosquitoes. The DENV virus has four different serotypes (DENV-1 to DENV-4), which can cause flu-like symptoms, severe dengue fever, or even death. The largest burden of dengue disease is in tropical and subtropical regions, with an estimated 390 million cases per year. We used a statistical framework to study the spread of DENV-1, DENV-2, and DENV-3 serotypes in Brazil by looking at complete genome sequences. Our analysis showed that new lineages of these viruses are introduced to Brazil every 7 to 10 years, most likely from the Caribbean region. We also found that the movement of humans and mosquitoes through air travel is a key factor in the spread of dengue viruses, rather than the infestation rates of the mosquito species Aedes aegypti or geographical distances.
The authors are studying how the neural code works in weakly electric fish. Weakly electric fish use electrical signals to sense their environment. They have three different types of sensory maps in their brain that receive input from different parts of their body and respond to different stimuli. The authors have found that all three types of sensory maps have nearly the same correlations between the activities of their neurons. The authors have also used a mathematical model to explain this result. They found that the amount of overlap between the receptive field of the neurons in each map does not determine the correlations. Instead, the authors suggest that the balance between the excitatory and inhibitory inputs to the neurons and the spiking nonlinearity of the neurons are important. The authors also found that the previously published experimental data on differences between the receptive field center-surround organization across the maps gives rise to similar average levels of correlations. Therefore, the authors propose that the similar levels of correlations observed experimentally arise because cells receive similar relative levels of positively and negatively correlated inputs, despite very different RF center-surround organizations.
Sensory neurons are known to show variable responses when they are exposed to the same stimulus repeatedly. These responses are often correlated with each other, but the exact nature of these correlations is not well understood. In this study, researchers investigated how noise correlations between pairs of sensory neurons affect the ability of the population to encode the stimulus. They found that when the noise and signal correlations between pairs of neurons have opposite signs, encoding performance improves relative to the case where the neurons are independent. However, this improvement is not a necessary condition for good coding performance, as a diverse set of correlation structures can enhance coding even when they do not satisfy this condition. The researchers also showed that the optimal correlation structures must lie on the boundary of the possible set of noise correlations. Finally, they identified conditions under which noise correlations can yield coding performance that is as good as if the neurons had deterministic responses.
In this study, the authors investigated how the presence of Pseudomonas aeruginosa affects the antibiotic susceptibility of Staphylococcus aureus. The authors found that P. aeruginosa can alter S. aureus's susceptibility to antibiotics in a strain-dependent manner. They identified three independent interactions responsible for antagonizing or potentiating antibiotic activity against S. aureus. These interactions included the LasA endopeptidase of P. aeruginosa, which potentiates lysis of S. aureus by vancomycin; the ability of P. aeruginosa to facilitate proton-motive force-independent tobramycin uptake, which is a form of potentiation; and the ability of P. aeruginosa to induce multidrug tolerance in S. aureus through respiratory inhibition and reduction of cellular ATP, which is a form of antagonism. The authors found that these factors can vary between clinical isolates and correspond to the capacity of each isolate to alter S. aureus antibiotic susceptibility. The authors also found that vancomycin treatment of a S. aureus mouse burn infection is potentiated by the presence of a LasA-producing P. aeruginosa population. The authors conclude that antibiotic susceptibility is complex and dependent not only on the genotype of the pathogen being targeted but also on interactions with other microorganisms in the infection environment. Consideration of these interactions will improve the treatment of polymicrobial infections.
Dengue fever is a common viral infection that affects millions of people worldwide. It can cause severe complications such as bleeding and plasma leakage, which are associated with a significant decrease in platelet count. Platelets play a critical role in blood clotting and inflammation. Previous research has shown that VWF, a protein involved in blood clotting, binds to platelets in dengue patients and contributes to platelet clearance. In this study, we found that VWF binding to platelets was associated with reduced surface sialic acid in dengue patients, and that this binding process could be inhibited by oseltamivir, a medication that blocks neuraminidase, the enzyme responsible for removing sialic acid. Our findings suggest that VWF binding and platelet desialylation play a role in dengue-associated thrombocytopenia.
This research looks at a type of gene arrangement called "bidirectional gene pairs" in the human genome. These gene pairs are made up of two genes that are next to each other and on opposite strands of DNA, with their transcription start sites being within 1,000 base pairs of each other. The region between their transcription start sites is called a "bidirectional promoter" and it helps control the expression of both genes. These promoters are found repeatedly in the human genome, with over 1,350 examples known. However, the specific biological function of this gene arrangement is not well understood. Researchers have developed a new algorithm to identify and map these promoters using data from a database of spliced expressed sequence tags (ESTs). They have also found evidence that a subset of these promoters, which control genes implicated in certain types of cancer, contain common transcription factor binding sites. This suggests that a disruption in the regulation of these promoters could play a role in the development of cancer.
This study examines the diversity of sex chromosomes in different types of flies. The authors used whole-genome analysis to investigate the sex chromosomes in 37 fly species from 22 different families. They found that the small dot chromosome is repeatedly used as the sex chromosome, possibly reflecting the ancestral karyotype of higher Diptera. The authors also identified species with undifferentiated sex chromosomes, others in which a different chromosome replaced the dot as a sex chromosome, and others with female heterogamety. Transcriptome analysis showed that dosage compensation has evolved multiple times in flies, consistently through up-regulation of the single X in males. However, the X chromosomes generally show a deficiency of genes with male-biased expression. These species thus provide a rich resource to study sex chromosome biology in a comparative manner and show that similar selective forces have shaped the unique evolution of sex chromosomes in diverse fly taxa.
This study aimed to investigate if there is a link between Zika virus (ZIKV) infection and microcephaly in the United States. The researchers tested archived blood samples from six mothers who gave birth to babies with microcephaly and 12 mothers who gave birth to healthy babies between 2009 and 2012 in Hawaii. They found that one mother with microcephaly delivered babies tested positive for ZIKV IgM antibody and three mothers with microcephaly had ZIKV IgG antibody. There was a trend towards significance with microcephaly for ZIKV IgG antibody positive mothers. They also found that mothers with microcephaly who were positive for ZIKV IgM antibody were more likely to deliver babies with microcephaly. These findings suggest that there may have been cases of ZIKV infection and microcephaly in the United States as early as 2009.
Buruli ulcer (BU) is a skin disease that affects humans and other animals. It is caused by a type of bacteria called Mycobacterium ulcerans (MU). MU can be found in the environment and it is not clear how it is transmitted to humans. To better understand the transmission of MU, researchers have studied the genetic diversity of the bacteria found in humans and the environment. They used a type of DNA analysis called Variable Number Tandem Repeat (VNTR) analysis to compare the genetic diversity of MU found in humans and in different water bodies. They also looked at small mammals in the environment to see if they could be reservoirs of MU. They found that MU was present in different types of water bodies and that there were different genetic types of MU found in humans and in the environment. They also found that small mammals could be susceptible to MU infection. The researchers suggest that MU may be transmitted to humans through contact with contaminated water bodies, and that humans may be more likely to become infected if they have contact with MU-contaminated water bodies on a regular basis. The researchers also suggest that small mammals may be a source of MU infection in humans. They suggest that the "OneHealth" approach, which looks at the health of humans, animals, and the environment all together, may be helpful in understanding and preventing the transmission of MU.
Alien species are introduced by humans to new environments, and the number of species introduced can vary over time and location. The causes of this variation are not well understood, but they likely involve a combination of human and environmental factors. To better understand the drivers of variation in alien species richness, we analyzed an extensive new database of alien bird species. We found that the locations of origin and introduction of alien birds, and their identities, were initially driven largely by European colonialism, but recent introductions were a wider phenomenon involving more species and countries, and driven in part by increasing economic activity. We found that, globally, alien bird species richness is currently highest at midlatitudes, and it is strongly determined by the number of species introduced (i.e., colonization pressure). Nevertheless, environmental drivers are also important, with native and alien species richness being strongly and consistently positively associated. Our results emphasize the importance of considering colonization pressure when analyzing alien species richness and highlight the likely ongoing threats to global environments from the introductions of species.
The nucleolus is a visible structure in the nucleus of cells responsible for the synthesis of ribosomes. Ribosomes are necessary for cells to grow and proliferate, and their formation is controlled by various factors. One such factor is a protein called UBF, which was first identified as a co-factor in RNA polymerase I (RPI) transcription. Previous studies have shown that UBF is essential for embryo development beyond morula stage and for the transcription of rRNA genes. However, it is unclear whether UBF is necessary for RPI transcription. In this study, the authors used gene deletion in mouse to confirm that UBF is essential for rRNA gene activity and for embryo development beyond morula stage. They also found that UBF defines the active chromatin conformation of both gene and enhancer sequences, and is required for the recruitment of SL1/TIF1B pre-initiation complex and the RPI-Rrn3/TIF1A complex. Unexpectedly, the arrest of rRNA synthesis did not suppress the transcription of other ribosome-related genes. The authors also observed the formation of a large sub-nuclear structure resembling the nucleolar precursor body (NPB) of oocytes and early embryos in cells lacking UBF. This NPB contained rRNA synthesis and processing factors but did not associate with the rRNA gene loci (NORs). Overall, this study provides insights into the role of UBF in RPI transcription, chromatin structure, and ribosome biogenesis.
In the provided article, the authors describe the role of Wingless (Wg) signaling in tissue patterning, including its overactivation in colorectal cancer. The article discusses a recent finding that replacing wild-type Wg with a membrane-tethered form of Wg in Drosophila resulted in viable adults with normal external morphology. However, the authors found that Wg tethering disrupted multiple important roles of Wg during adult intestinal development, including the regulation of target gene activation, boundary formation, stem cell proliferation, epithelial cell fate specification, muscle differentiation, gut folding, and signaling crosstalk. These findings support the requirement for the direct, long-range action of Wg in tissue patterning and suggest that its tethering could disrupt normal development and disease.
Group A streptococcus (GAS) is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, and is known to accumulate cell surface plasmin during disease initiation. However, the role of host activators of plasminogen in this process has not been well understood. In this study, the authors investigated the contribution of the urokinase-type plasminogen activator (uPA) to invasive GAS disease. They found that the absence of uPA resulted in a significant decrease in virulence of GAS. Furthermore, they discovered that host activators of plasminogen were sufficient to promote cell surface plasmin acquisition by GAS during incubation with plasminogen. These findings have significant implications for our understanding of GAS pathogenesis and research aimed at therapeutic targeting of plasminogen activation in invasive bacterial infections.
Scientists have discovered that a protein called CagL is a part of a specialized T4SS (type four secretion system) in the bacteria Helicobacter pylori, which causes gastritis and stomach cancer. The T4SS is required to inject a protein called CagA into the lining of the stomach. The study found that CagL binds to a specific receptor on the surface of gastric epithelial cells to allow for the injection of CagA. The study also found that CagL is necessary for the function of the T4SS, and that it works with two other proteins called CagI and CagH. All three proteins are required for the formation of pili, which are structures that help the bacteria to adhere to the surface of gastric epithelial cells. The study found that CagL and the other proteins contain a conserved C-terminal hexapeptide motif that is essential for the function of the T4SS. The findings of this study shed new light on the mechanisms by which H. pylori causes disease.
Bovine tuberculosis (bTB) is a disease that affects cattle and is caused by a type of bacteria called Mycobacterium bovis. It can cause a lot of damage to the agricultural industry worldwide, costing billions of dollars annually. One way to fight this disease is by vaccinating cattle, but the current vaccine, called BCG, is not very effective. Researchers are trying to make a better vaccine by improving upon BCG, but they need to find ways to know if the vaccine is working. One way they are trying to do this is by looking at the genes that are expressed by the cattle's immune system after being vaccinated. They found that some genes were more expressed in vaccinated-protected cattle than in vaccinated-unprotected or unvaccinated cattle. One of these genes was IL-22, which is a protein that helps the immune system fight off infections. They also found that the pathway related to this gene was the cytokine-cytokine receptor interaction pathway. They then confirmed that IL-22 was a good predictor of vaccine efficacy by testing it in an independent set of samples. This is important because it can help researchers know if their new vaccines are working and if they can be used to fight bTB in cattle.
In this study, the authors wanted to understand how microtubule organizing centers ( MTOCs ) organize and regulate microtubules in differentiated cells. They found that at the apical surface of intestinal epithelial cells in Caenorhabditis elegans , there is a non-centrosomal MTOC where both γ-TuRC and AIR-1 localize. However, only AIR-1 was required for the localization of γ-TuRC to the centrosome, but not to the apical ncMTOC. Despite this, microtubules remained organized at the apical ncMTOC upon co-depletion of γ-TuRC and AIR-1. The authors also discovered that MZT-1/MZT1 was a novel protein that was essential in C . elegans and localized to both the centrosome and the apical ncMTOC. However, MZT-1 was only required for the localization of γ-TuRC to the PCM and not to the centriole or the apical ncMTOC. Furthermore, they found that the removal of other known microtubule regulators did not disrupt apical microtubule organization. Finally, the authors found that GIP-1 was only required for the localization of other γ-TuRC components to the apical ncMTOC and not to the centrosome. Together, these results suggest that ncMTOCs may be composed of distinct populations of γ-TuRC-dependent and γ-TuRC-independent microtubules.
Humans are diploid organisms with 23 chromosome pairs, inherited from the mother and father. Most human genomes are sequenced using laboratory methods that do not explicitly phase, or distinguish between the two copies of each chromosome pair. We compared 11 different approaches to phasing human genomes, including laboratory-based methods and computational methods. Our analyses suggest that a hybrid approach combining computational methods with population-based data provides a fast and efficient way to generate highly accurate phase-resolved genomes. We found that the inclusion of parental genotype data within a population-based phasing strategy can significantly reduce phasing errors. We also identified DNA sequence signatures associated with phasing switch errors, which can inform the choice of computational methods and sequence depth for phasing.
The flagellar type-III secretion system utilizes the energy of the proton motive force and ATP hydrolysis to energize substrate unfolding and translocation, which allows bacteria to move, adhere, and invade host cells. We found that this type-III secretion system can still function in the absence of ATPase activity by mutations that increased the proton motive force and flagellar substrate levels. This indicates that ATPase activity is not essential for type-III protein export and that the flagellar type-III secretion system can function in the absence of the virulence-associated type-III ATPase. Our findings suggest that type-III protein secretion systems are more complex than previously thought and have the ability to operate without ATPase activity.
Bistability, a property in which a system can be in one of two stable states, is found in many biological systems, such as those involved in cell fate specification and cell cycle regulation. However, identifying bistable network topologies is difficult because of the high number of uncertain parameters that need to be considered. Chemical reaction network theory (CRNT) is a mathematical framework that can identify bistable network topologies without knowledge of parameter values. We applied CRNT to reaction network models representing a broad class of small gene regulatory networks consisting of two transcription factor-coding genes and their associated proteins. We found that 90% of the networks surveyed exhibited bistability, including 11 minimal networks. We further identified bistable modules in Saccharomyces cerevisiae using experimental protein-protein interaction, protein-DNA interaction, and gene expression data. Our results suggest that bistability is a common property of biological systems and that CRNT can be used to identify bistable network topologies and predict their properties without knowledge of parameter values.
Orofacial clefting is a common birth defect that can result from a combination of genetic and environmental factors. The condition can lead to missing or malformed parts of the lip, palate, or both. Researchers have identified mutations in a gene called HYAL2 that may cause orofacial clefting. This gene encodes an enzyme that breaks down a molecule called hyaluronan, which is important for the development of the heart and palate. The researchers found that mutations in the HYAL2 gene caused the enzyme to become unstable, leading to a decrease in the amount of the enzyme in the body. This, in turn, may cause the palate to not close properly during development, leading to orofacial clefting. The researchers also found that the same mutations in mice caused similar issues with the heart and hearing, which are also present in some people with orofacial clefting.
The inner ear hair cells need tip links to detect sound, which are made of cadherin 23 (CDH23) and protocadherin 15 (PCDH15). These links are subjected to sound-induced forces throughout an organism's life and can regenerate to restore hearing function. However, the molecular details of this process are unknown. In this study, researchers used a new microscopy technique to visualize the composition of these links, finding that they have at least two molecular compositions: PCDH15/CDH23 or PCDH15/PCDH15. The mature PCDH15/CDH23 composition is re-established later, concomitant with complete recovery of hearing function. This discovery provides a molecular mechanism for regeneration and maintenance of mechanosensory function in postmitotic auditory hair cells.
Dengue virus is the most common mosquito-borne virus, causing an estimated 100 million infections each year. These infections can range from mild dengue fever to more severe and potentially life-threatening forms of dengue hemorrhagic fever. At the critical phase of infection, around 5-7 days after the onset of fever, symptoms of dengue hemorrhagic fever become evident. However, the mechanisms that trigger the transition from dengue fever to dengue hemorrhagic fever at this stage are not well understood. To investigate these mechanisms, the authors analyzed the serum of adult dengue fever and dengue hemorrhagic fever patients at the critical and recovery phases of infection using a technique called mass spectrometry-based metabolomic profiling. They found that 29 metabolites were differentially expressed between the two groups at the critical phase of infection, including bile acids, purines, acylcarnitines, phospholipids, and amino acids. The authors also found that bile acids were significantly higher in the dengue hemorrhagic fever group and were associated with higher levels of liver enzymes, suggesting liver injury. Additionally, the authors found that uric acid, a natural antioxidant in the blood, was significantly lower in the dengue hemorrhagic fever group, which could lead to decreased antioxidant defense and increased oxidative stress. The authors concluded that their findings provide insights into the mechanisms of dengue hemorrhagic fever pathogenesis and may lead to the discovery of new therapeutic targets for dengue management.
Purine nucleotides are important in cellular metabolism, and a protein called GMPR helps convert GMP to IMP, which is needed to maintain the balance of purine nucleotides. While the function of GMPR has been studied in humans and bacteria, it hasn't been fully understood in parasitic protozoa such as Trypanosoma brucei, which causes African sleeping sickness. In this study, the authors identified GMPR in T. brucei and studied its function. They found that T. brucei GMPR was different from mammalian and bacterial GMPRs in that it had an insertion of a CBS domain, and it was influenced by monovalent cations, ribavirin, and purine nucleoside analogs. These findings suggest that the GMPR reaction in T. brucei is different from that in mammals and bacteria.
Sodium channels help in transmitting electrical signals in nerve cells. Drugs that block the activity of these channels are used to treat various diseases like epilepsy, pain, and arrhythmia. However, there is a lack of understanding about how these drugs work at the molecular level. Researchers used computer modeling to study the binding of two drugs, benzocaine and phenytoin, to the bacterial sodium channel NaChBac. They found that both drugs bind to two likely binding sites, one above the activation gate and one at the entrance to the lateral lipid-filled fenestrations. They also found that drugs can enter the channel through the fenestrations, which has long been proposed. The study provides important insights into the binding and action of these drugs at the molecular level.
The research article presents a study that investigates the role of MyD88 signaling in different cell types during intestinal infection with the bacterium Citrobacter rodentium. MyD88 signaling is important for activating immune responses against pathogens, but its cell type-specific contribution to the host response during intestinal infection is not well understood. To address this question, the researchers used a novel murine knock-in model that allows cell type-specific reactivation of functional MyD88 expression in otherwise MyD88-deficient mice. The study shows that functional MyD88 signaling in CD11c+ mononuclear phagocytes (MNP) is sufficient to activate innate immune responses and induce the early group 3 innate lymphoid cell (ILC3) response as well as the development of colonic Th17/Th1 cells in response to infection with C. rodentium. In contrast, restricting MyD88 signaling to other cell types, such as macrophages (MO), T cells or ILC3, did not induce efficient intestinal immune responses upon infection. The study also shows that functional expression of MyD88 in intestinal epithelial cells (IEC) also partially protected the mice during intestinal infection, which was associated with enhanced epithelial barrier integrity and increased expression of the antimicrobial peptide RegIIIγ and the acute phase protein SAA1 by epithelial cells. Together, the results suggest that MyD88 signaling in DC and IEC is both essential and sufficient to induce a full spectrum of host responses upon intestinal infection with C. rodentium.
Onchocerciasis is a parasitic disease that causes river blindness and is spread by blackfly bites. It can be eliminated through mass drug administration (MDA). The Ov16 antibody test is a diagnostic test used to determine if onchocerciasis transmission has been interrupted. This study used a mathematical model to analyze the relationship between the Ov16 antibody prevalence in children and the duration and coverage of MDA, mf prevalence in the population, and the probability of elimination. The study found that better understanding of the dynamics of Ov16 antibody responses is required for accurate interpretation of seroprevalence data and more precise estimation of the endpoint for MDA. The study also demonstrated that the endpoint for MDA will be dependent on baseline endemicity levels, which should be taken into account in guidelines for defining when to stop MDA.
Scientists have found that prion strains can change when they are grown in different environments. For example, when 22L prions were grown in cells in the presence of a drug called swainsonine, drug-resistant variants emerged. Scientists propose that prions are made up of many different types of prions that have different properties. They think that the fittest prions are the ones that survive in a particular environment. Scientists have found that prions become less resistant to swainsonine when they are grown in the absence of the drug. They also found that some prions that were originally swainsonine resistant became swainsonine sensitive when they were grown in cells for a long time. Scientists wanted to find out if it was possible to select for swainsonine-resistant prions even though RML prions, both when grown in the brain or in cells, are swainsonine sensitive. Scientists discovered that it was not possible to select swainsonine-resistant RML prions when they grew them in the PK1 cell line. However, in certain PK1 sublines, they were able to select swainsonine-resistant or even swainsonine-dependent populations. Once established, these populations could be grown indefinitely in PK1 cells in the absence of the drug. Scientists found that the misfolded prion protein associated with swainsonine-dependent prions was cleared more slowly in PK1 cells than the protein associated with swainsonine-sensitive prions. This suggests that likely structural differences of the misfolded prion protein are responsible for the properties of the prions. In summary, scientists have found that prions can adapt to their environment by changing their properties. These adaptations are likely due to changes in the structure of the misfolded prion protein.
In this study, the authors created a comprehensive map of all possible metabolisms that could potentially exist in a given set of environments. They used a computational method called flux balance analysis to predict the viability of each metabolism on each environment, and identified a total of 1024 different phenotypes. The authors found that viable metabolisms with any one phenotype typically form a single network of genotypes that extends far or all the way through genotype space. This suggests that evolutionary innovation in metabolisms is possible through small changes in genotype, and that the structure of metabolic genotype space is conducive to metabolic innovation. The authors suggest that this map could be used to study how changes in metabolic reactions lead to new metabolic phenotypes, and could also be used to identify new targets for drug development.
This study analyzes the genetic diversity and distribution of different haplogroups of Triatoma dimidiata, a vector of Chagas disease, across Mexico and Central America. It compares the genetic diversity and distribution of haplogroups 1, 2, and 3 to their different infection rates with Trypanosoma cruzi, a parasite causing Chagas disease, and the prevalence of different Trypanosoma cruzi Discrete Typing Units (DTUs) within each haplogroup. The study also analyzes the population structure of the T. dimidiata complex at different scales, including landscape, sub-regional, regional, and continental levels. The study provides evidence that haplogroup 1 has a significant difference in the distribution of DTUI and DTUVI infections compared to haplogroup 2 and 3. It also provides evidence for differential T. cruzi infection frequency and DTU specificity among haplogroups, which is important for understanding the vector capacity of T. dimidiata haplogroups. Overall, the study highlights the importance of analyzing the genetic diversity and distribution of T. dimidiata haplogroups at different scales to better understand the dynamics of Chagas disease transmission.
Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS) is a disease caused by a virus spread by rodents, such as rats and mice. This disease has occurred mainly in China, where it is a public health problem. In this study, researchers looked at the relationship between environmental factors, rodent species, and the occurrence of HFRS in Chenzhou, a city in Hunan Province, China. They used field surveillance data from rodent hosts for hantavirus, the environmental data from satellite images and meteorological stations, rodent-to-human transmission rates, and the impacts of the environment on the rodent community composition to determine this relationship. The study included 709 cases of HFRS. The researchers found that different rodent species played different roles across different land types. The rodent community composition was also associated with environmental variability. They also found that cultivated land was predicted to represent the highest risk for HFRS incidence. The study provides important information for the prevention and control of HFRS.
Costello syndrome (CS) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by postnatal growth retardation, short stature, developmental delay, and an increased risk of tumors. The majority of CS cases are caused by a mutation in the HRAS gene, which encodes a protein that helps control cell growth. One particular mutation in the HRAS gene, p. Gly12Val, is known to cause a severe form of CS. In this study, the authors discovered a new mutation in the HRAS gene that was causing CS in a 12-year-old boy. They found that this mutation caused exon 2 of the HRAS gene to be skipped when the gene was being processed in the body. They also discovered that this skipping was due to the disruption of two splicing regulatory elements in exon 2. They confirmed this finding by using genetically engineered mice and human cells. The authors then went on to show that a different type of genetic alteration, a splice-switching oligonucleotide, could cause the same skipping of exon 2 in human cells. This oligonucleotide could potentially be used in the future as a therapy for treating certain types of cancers that are caused by mutations in the HRAS gene.
This study shows that a protein called METTL3 is important for the development of the cerebellum in mice. METTL3 is part of a complex that adds a chemical group called m6A to RNA molecules. This modification helps control how long RNA molecules last and how they are spliced. Without METTL3, the developing cerebellum is smaller and there is more cell death. This is likely because the RNA molecules in the developing cerebellum have extended lifetimes and are spliced incorrectly, leading to problems with cell differentiation and survival. This study highlights the importance of m6A modifications in the development of the central nervous system.
This study looked at transcription factors, proteins that turn genes on or off, and how they work together in embryonic stem (ES) cells. These stem cells are like blank slates that can turn into any kind of cell in the body. The study found that some transcription factors bind to the same parts of the DNA in ES cells and in early embryos. They also found that the combination of several transcription factors binding to a part of the DNA is more likely to turn a gene on than when just one transcription factor binds to it. The study also found that some parts of the DNA that transcription factors bind to are used to turn genes on in many different types of cells and at different stages of development. This suggests that these parts of the DNA are important for basic cell functions and may be harder to change. Overall, this study provides new insights into how transcription factors work together to regulate gene expression in ES cells and early embryos.
Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) can be caused by a genetic abnormality called a reciprocal translocation. This translocation creates a fusion protein called AML1/ETO that causes AML by preventing blood cells from maturing properly. The fusion protein also affects the function of another protein called AML1, which is needed for blood cell development. AML1/ETO may also work with another protein called HEB to cause AML. In this study, researchers used advanced lab techniques to analyze how AML1/ETO binds to DNA and affects the function of other proteins. They found that AML1/ETO binds to DNA in a way that is similar to AML1, but it also affects HEB in a way that helps it bind to DNA more efficiently. This finding provides a better understanding of how AML1/ETO causes AML and suggests that it may be important to consider both AML1 and HEB when developing treatments for this type of leukemia.
Scientists have discovered that a protein called histone acetyltransferase HAT2 in the parasite Leishmania donovani is essential for the survival of the parasite. HAT2 regulates gene expression by activating certain genes at specific stages of the cell cycle. These findings provide new insights into the gene regulation mechanisms in Leishmania parasites.
The study investigates how people infer on the intentions of others and how their decision-making process is influenced by these inferences. The researchers used computational modeling to analyze behavioral data from an economic game where two players interacted with each other. One player made a decision based on probabilistic information displayed in a pie chart, while the other player gave an additional recommendation to the first player. The incentives of the second player to give helpful or misleading advice changed over time, which required the first player to detect these changes and adapt their decision-making accordingly. The researchers identified two components in the players' decision-making process: (1) how players updated their beliefs about the reasons for the advisor's behavior, and (2) how these updated beliefs influenced their actual decisions. They created a set of 12 different models to represent these two components and fitted these models to the players' behavior using Bayesian model inversion. The study found that the players inferred on the volatility of the advisors' intentions and used this information to optimize their predictions about the validity of the advice. The players were more likely to rely on the advisor's recommendations when they believed the advisors' intentions were currently stable. The study also found that the players' interpersonal reactivity index (IRI) scores, explicit ratings of the advisors' helpfulness, and the advisors' self-reports on their chosen strategy were predicted by the Bayesian framework presented in the study. Overall, the results suggest that humans use a hierarchical generative model to infer on the changing intentions of others, use this information to inform decision-making in social interactions, and integrate estimates of advice accuracy with non-social sources of information. The Bayesian framework presented in this study can be used to quantify individual differences in these mechanisms from simple behavioral readouts and may prove useful in future clinical studies of maladaptive social cognition.
Scrub typhus is a bacterial infection that is endemic in parts of Asia, including South Korea. It is usually a rural disease, but some cases have been seen in urban areas like Seoul. We found 88 cases of scrub typhus in Seoul between 2010 and 2013, and studied the clinical features of these patients. We also collected chigger mites from different locations in Seoul and found that the main vector of scrub typhus in the city is a type of chigger mite called Helenicula miyagawai. These mites were found in high numbers in the Gwanak mountain in southern Seoul. The patients who were infected with the bacteria that causes scrub typhus had mild clinical features. We identified the presence of indigenous urban scrub typhus in Seoul, and recommend that this disease be considered as one of the differential febrile diseases and a target for prevention in non-endemic areas.
The RNA interference (RNAi) pathway is a natural defense mechanism against viruses and transposons in living organisms. In this process, small RNA (sRNA) molecules guide the Ago protein to its target RNA, leading to its degradation. The stability of sRNA molecules in RNAi pathways is regulated by a process called methylation. In this study, the authors describe the effects of a protein called HENN-1 on the different RNAi pathways in the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans. They found that HENN-1 is involved in the 26G and 21U RNA pathways, but not the miRNA pathway. The stability of 21U RNA, the C. elegans piRNAs, is only mildly affected by loss of methylation, and introduction of artificial 21U target RNA does not further destabilize non-methylated 21U RNAs. In contrast, most 26G RNAs display reduced stability and respond to loss of HENN-1 by displaying increased 3′-uridylation frequencies. The authors also identified that specifically ERGO-1–bound 26G RNAs are modified by HENN-1, while ALG-3/ALG-4–bound 26G RNAs are not. The authors suggest that HENN-1 may be involved in the degradation of target RNA molecules by the Ago protein. They also found that loss of HENN-1 does not cause a significant change in global gene expression. However, the authors suggest that the effects on global gene expression are indirect and that HENN-1 may be involved in the process of RNAi. Overall, the study provides important insights into the function of the HENN-1 protein in the RNAi pathway.
This study investigates the role of Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 1α (HNF1α) and fucosyltransferase genes FUT6 and FUT8 in the human plasma N-glycan levels. It shows that HNF1α and its downstream target HNF4α regulate the expression of key fucosyltransferase and fucose biosynthesis genes. The study also shows that HNF1α is necessary and sufficient to drive the expression of these genes in hepatic cells. These findings reveal a new role for HNF1α as a master transcriptional regulator of multiple stages in the fucosylation process. The mechanisms have implications for the regulation of immunity, embryonic development, protein folding, and the development of cancer, coronary heart disease, and metabolic and inflammatory disorders. Glycosylation is a process that adds sugars, such as fucose, to proteins, which can change the structure and function of the proteins. However, it is not directly encoded by genes and the processes that regulate it are poorly understood. This study provides new insights into the genetic regulation of glycosylation, which has implications for the treatment of various diseases.
Centromeres are important regions of the genome that help connect the genome to the cytoskeleton, allowing chromosomes to move on the spindle during cell division. In some organisms, including plants, centromeric DNA does not play a key role in organizing functional kinetochores. Instead, centromeres are marked by specific epigenetic features, including a histone H3 variant called Centromeric Histone H3 (CENH3) and RNA molecules that help recruit and stabilize CENH3. In this study, researchers looked at a protein called Centromere Protein C (CENPC) that has a key role in centromere recognition and maintenance. They found that a region within CENPC, called exon 9–12, is responsible for binding both DNA and RNA. They also showed that RNA helps facilitate the binding of CENPC to DNA in vitro. These findings suggest that CENPC and RNA are part of a template that helps direct CENH3 to newly replicated centromere DNA. This is important because it provides a biochemical mechanism for the involvement of RNA in centromere specification, and it suggests that CENH3 and CENPC work together in a self-reinforcing process to replicate the content and position of centromeres.
The article explores the role of the placenta in determining postnatal body size, which may hold new possibilities for therapeutic interventions to prevent childhood obesity. Researchers have identified variants associated with birth weight (BW), childhood obesity (CO) and childhood BMI (CBMI) through genome-wide association studies (GWAS). Placenta eQTLs (gene expression quantitative trait loci) were then examined to determine if they contribute significantly to these anthropometry outcomes. The results showed that placental eQTLs are significantly enriched for BW, CO, and CBMI GWAS loci. Importantly, only placental eQTLs contribute significantly to both anthropometry outcomes at birth (BW) and childhood phenotypes (CO/CBMI). Eight, six, and one transcripts were found to colocalize with BW, CO, and CBMI risk loci, respectively. Overall, this study reveals that placental transcription in utero likely plays a key role in determining postnatal body size, and as such may hold new possibilities for therapeutic interventions to prevent childhood obesity.
The paper describes a study on post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL), a condition that occurs after successful treatment of visceral leishmaniasis (VL). PKDL is a skin condition that is not life-threatening but can be disfiguring, leading to social stigma for the affected individuals. The study was conducted in a VL-endemic area of West Bengal, India, to determine the prevalence of PKDL and to compare three methods for diagnosing PKDL: microscopic examination of skin lesions, rapid diagnostic test (RDT), and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test. The study found a prevalence of PKDL of 27.5% among those who had previously been treated for VL. PCR was found to be the most sensitive method for diagnosing PKDL, followed by microscopic examination and RDT. The study also looked at the pattern of regression of skin lesions following treatment, and found that while some lesions disappeared quickly, others took longer and some even reappeared after 1.5 years. The study concludes that a combination of active surveillance and molecular testing is necessary to accurately diagnose PKDL and that a well-designed study with a larger sample size is needed to determine whether PKDL patients are still infected after treatment and to determine the optimal length of treatment.
This is an important paper about how bacteria can change their behavior in response to signals from other bacteria. The paper focuses on a bacterium called Streptococcus pneumoniae, which causes pneumonia and other respiratory infections. The paper describes a system that allows bacteria to sense each other's presence and coordinate their behavior in response. This system is based on molecules called auto-inducers that are released by the bacteria and bind to their cells to activate certain genes. The paper explains how the bacteria use this system to coordinate their behavior in response to stress. It also describes how the bacteria use a system called competence to exchange genetic information. The paper explains how these two systems work together to allow bacteria to change their behavior in response to each other.
In this paper, the authors have developed a new method to study the process of translocation of HPV16 L2 protein from the trans-Golgi network (TGN) to the nucleus of the host cell. They used a system based on subcellular compartmentalization of the enzyme BirA and its cognate substrate to detect membrane translocation of L2-BirA from incoming virions. The authors found that L2 translocation requires transport to the TGN and is strictly dependent on entry into mitosis. Cell cycle arrest causes retention of L2/vDNA at the TGN; only release and progression past G2/M enables translocation across the limiting membrane and subsequent infection. Microscopy of EdU-labeled vDNA revealed a rapid and dramatic shift in vDNA localization during early mitosis. At late G2/early prophase, vDNA egresses from the TGN to a pericentriolar location, accumulating there through prometaphase where it begins to associate with condensed chromosomes. By metaphase and throughout anaphase, the vDNA is seen bound to the mitotic chromosomes, ensuring distribution into both daughter nuclei. Mutations in a newly defined chromatin binding region of L2 potently blocked translocation, suggesting that translocation is dependent on chromatin binding during prometaphase. These findings suggest that translocation is necessary for viral DNA to enter the nucleus and replicate, and that the tropism of HPV for mitotic basal keratinocytes is explained in part by the ability of HPV to functionally couple the penetration of limiting membranes to cellular mitosis.
The article presents a method to measure the transmissibility of one strain of a pathogen compared to another strain. This is important in several contexts, such as influenza strains competing for hosts in the human population, new influenza strains that have pandemic potential, and the potential impact of a neuraminidase inhibitor (NIA) on influenza transmission. The method is applied to data from experiments where animals are co-infected with a mixture of two strains, and the mixture is observed over time and over multiple generations of transmission. The article demonstrates the method using ferret transmission studies and provides an estimate of the size of the transmitted inoculum. The article also suggests how to optimize experimental design for assessing transmissibility and provides a mathematical framework for capturing key characteristics of transmission. Finally, the article provides an estimate of the number of successfully infecting units transferred from the donor to recipient.
The plant hormone abscisic acid ( ABA ) plays an important role in plants' growth and development as well as their response to various environmental stresses. Plants use both light and ABA as signals to control how they grow and develop. However, it is not well understood how plants use these two signals together to better adapt and survive. In this study, we found that BBX21, a protein that helps plants grow and develop in response to light, is also involved in ABA signaling. Our genetic data show that BBX21 may act upstream of several ABA INSENSITIVE ( ABI ) genes and ELONGATED HYPOCOTYL 5 ( HY5 ), a protein that helps plants grow and develop in response to light. We further show that BBX21 negatively regulates ABI5 expression by interfering with HY5 binding to the ABI5 promoter. In addition, ABI5 is a protein that directly activates its own expression. However, BBX21 negatively regulates this activity by directly interacting with ABI5. Our study shows that BBX21 helps plants coordinate the signals from light and ABA, and that BBX21, HY5, and ABI5 work together to help plants adapt and survive.
The Mediator is a complex of proteins that is associated with RNA polymerase II and is essential for transcription. The yeast Mediator has 25 subunits, which are organized into four modules: Head, Middle, Tail, and Kinase. The core Mediator (Head, Middle, and Tail) has a positive role in transcription, while the Kinase domain mainly functions in repression. Mediator interacts with gene-specific transcription factors and RNA polymerase II and mediates polymerase-activator interactions and formation of the pre-initiation complex. In addition to activated transcription, Mediator also stimulates basal transcription. Mediator subunits regulate adhesion in a distinct manner between yeasts S. cerevisiae and C. albicans.
The antibiotic resistance of bacteria in biofilms is much higher than that of their planktonic counterparts, including Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which causes many infections in humans. In this study, we used a complex, mixed population of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in biofilm and planktonic growth conditions, with and without tobramycin, to measure the contribution of each gene to antibiotic tolerance. We found that large sets of mutations contribute to antibiotic tolerance in the biofilm or planktonic state only. Our findings provide important insights into the differences between biofilm and planktonic antibiotic tolerance and offer a foundation for developing new therapeutics against biofilm-associated infections caused by P. aeruginosa.
Finding the best model to describe a complex system that has many interacting parts is difficult. There are many different ways to create such a model, and it can be hard to know which one is the best. Scientists often use mathematical models to help with this problem, but it can still be hard to decide which model is the best. In this paper, we present an algorithm called Flexible and Dynamic Algorithm for Model Selection (FAMoS) that can help with this problem. The algorithm works by searching through all the possible models and using a new method called non-local search to make sure that it doesn't get stuck in a local minimum. We tested the algorithm on simulated data and found that it works well and is flexible enough to handle different types of models. We also used the algorithm to analyze experimental data on the proliferation of T cells in different environments. We found that the proliferation of T cells is different in 2D suspension and 3D tissue-like cultures, which shows that our algorithm can find important differences in the data. Overall, our algorithm is a useful tool for data-driven analysis of complex systems.
Chagas disease is a severe illness caused by a parasite called Trypanosoma cruzi. The National Program for Chagas Disease was implemented in Bolivia in 2006 to reduce the number of infections by controlling vectors. In 2012, the treatment with benznidazole (BNZ) was started in school-age children living in areas with certified vector control. In this study, we conducted a 12-month follow-up of these children and took seven blood samples. We used serology, conventional diagnostic PCR (cPCR), and quantitative real-time PCR (qPCR) to test the effectiveness of the treatment. We also analyzed the levels of Th1/Th2/Th17 cytokines. After 12 months, we found that approximately 11% of the children showed non-reactive results on both cPCR and qPCR, 42% showed ambiguous results, and 47% showed reactive results. We also found that the levels of IL-17A were significantly higher in seropositive children before the treatment compared to age-matched seronegative children. However, these levels decreased to normal levels one year after the treatment. Moreover, we found that IL-17A levels were positively correlated to parasite counts detected by qPCR. Finally, we found that IL-17A levels of non-reactive subjects were significantly higher than those of reactive or ambiguous subjects, suggesting that IL-17A might be a useful biomarker for determining the reactivity to BNZ treatment.
The article describes the Correia element, a type of miniature inverted repeat transposable element found in the genome of Neisseria meningitidis, a bacterium that causes bacterial meningitis and septicemia. The article explains that the Correia element is a type of transposon that is responsible for some of the genetic variation in the bacterium. The article describes the various ways in which the Correia element can change gene expression patterns and alter host physiology. The article also explains that the Correia element has the potential to act as a promoter for gene expression, and provides examples of genes that are transcribed from the Correia element. The article discusses the importance of understanding the function of the Correia element in order to better understand the pathogenesis of meningococcal disease.
In filamentous fungi, development and secondary metabolism are closely linked. Two proteins, VeA and LaeA, have been shown to be central to coordinating these processes in a handful of fungi, such as the Eurotiomycetes Aspergillus spp. and the Sordariomycetes Acremonium chrysogenum and Fusarium spp. VeA is a positive regulator of sexual development and a negative regulator of asexual development. LaeA is a negative regulator of secondary metabolite production. In this study, the orthologs of VeA and LaeA in the plant pathogen Cochliobolus heterostrophus, ChVel1 and ChLae1, were identified. Their mutants were constructed to study their role in secondary metabolism and virulence. It was found that ChVel1 and ChLae1 regulate T-toxin production, virulence to the host, and oxidative stress tolerance. They also positively regulate sexual development and repress asexual development and expression of melanin biosynthesis genes. However, their regulation of extracellular siderophore production was not altered. These findings suggest that ChVel1 and ChLae1 are key regulatory proteins in C. heterostrophus that coordinate secondary metabolism and virulence.
Researchers used computer simulations to study how ions move through the selectivity filter of bacterial NavAb channels. They discovered that two or three potassium ions can block the entrance to the selectivity filter in the presence of an applied force pushing inward, but not when pushing outward. The block occurs in a local minimum on the free-energy landscape of two potassium ions. In contrast, three sodium ions can move together through the selectivity filter as a unit in a "knock-on" mechanism, and there is no local minimum for the block state of sodium ions. The researchers found that the work required to break the potassium block is equivalent to large applied potentials measured experimentally for bacterial Nav channels. This shows how including non-equilibrium factors in the simulations can provide more detailed information about ion selectivity mechanisms than crystal structures or equilibrium free-energy landscapes alone.
Rabies is a disease that affects the brain and is caused by a virus that spreads from animal to animal. There are two types of rabies: furious and paralytic. In furious rabies, the virus spreads rapidly to the brain, while in paralytic rabies, the virus spreads more slowly. To understand how the virus spreads in both forms of the disease, researchers have examined the brains of animals that have died from rabies. They have found that in paralytic rabies, there is less damage to the brain than in furious rabies. The researchers think that this may be because the virus spreads more slowly in paralytic rabies, giving the body time to respond and fight the infection before it gets to the brain.
Insulators are DNA sequences that regulate interactions between promoters and enhancers. They prevent inappropriate enhancer/promoter communication and are believed to play a key role in the genomic organization of transcriptional regulation. These insulators can be associated with the binding of certain proteins. In Drosophila, a protein called CTCF was recently identified as a new enhancer-blocking protein. The authors of this study used chromatin immunopurification coupled with genomic microarray analysis to identify CTCF binding sites in the Drosophila genome. They found that CTCF binding sites precisely match the locations of known insulator elements in the Bithorax complex. Furthermore, the authors identified three additional presumptive insulator elements based on the locations of CTCF binding sites between the regulatory regions of the Hox genes. They also found that the CTCF binding-site consensus sequence in Drosophila is similar to that found in vertebrates, which suggests that CTCF may have similar functions in both organisms. Overall, this study provides valuable insights into the role of CTCF in regulating gene expression in Drosophila.
The authors of the study have provided a detailed mechanism for an induced-fit process at atomic resolution. They used a slow, tight binding inhibitor-enzyme system, actinonin-peptide deformylase, to capture intermediate conformations and final bound complexes. The authors have shown that the free enzyme is in an open conformation, and actinonin induces transition of the enzyme into a closed conformation. There is no evidence for the occurrence of a closed conformation in the apostructure of the open enzyme, which makes the closed form fully compatible with an induced-fit model. Moreover, using several rationally designed point mutants of the enzyme, ligand-induced intermediate states were trapped. These conformations recapitulate physical states that the WT enzyme must pass through during its overall transition from the apo-enzyme to the E:I* complex. The authors propose that induced fit also contributes to efficient catalysis.
The thalamus is an important brain region that relays sensory information to the cerebral cortex. Most of the information that enters the thalamus comes from the sensory organs, but there is also feedback from the cortex to the thalamus. This feedback is thought to be important for controlling the overall gain and filtering of sensory information as it passes through the thalamus. However, the exact mechanisms by which the feedback from the cortex affects the thalamus are not well understood. In this study, we used computer simulations and experiments to study the impact of cortical feedback on the transfer of sensory information through the thalamus. We found that the transfer efficiency of sensory information depends on three main factors: the number of thalamic cells involved in the processing, the statistics of the cortical input, and the level of correlation between thalamic cells. Our results suggest that the transfer efficiency of thalamic cells could be selectively amplified when they become simultaneously desynchronized by the cortical feedback. This finding could have important implications for understanding how attention and awareness affect the processing of sensory information in the brain.
The biological roles of methylation beyond at the C5-position of cytosines in CpG dinucleotides are not well understood. We have found that the putative DNA demethylase NMAD-1 plays a critical role in regulating meiosis in C. elegans. NMAD-1 mutants have reduced fertility due to defective chromosomal segregation.
