R-pyocins are complexes that attach to the surface of bacterial cells and then insert their core structure through the cell membrane, causing the membrane to depolarize. S-pyocins are similar to E. coli colicins and kill cells by nucleic acid degradation, membrane damage, or inhibition of peptidoglycan synthesis. Putidacin A, or LlpABW, is a type of bacteriocin that was first identified in Pseudomonas putida. Additional genes encoding this type of bacteriocin were later found in other bacteria, including Pseudomonas fluorescens and Pseudomonas syringae. LlpABW is a protein with two domains that are related to a group of proteins called lectins. These domains are used by the protein to bind to the surface of other bacterial cells and kill them. The structure of this protein has been determined using X-ray crystallography. The protein has a unique structure that is different from other members of the lectin family. This structure is important for its ability to bind to and kill bacteria.
In this study, the authors have identified a novel protein complex that helps a cell called the "forespore" to survive during the process of spore formation. The forespore is surrounded by two membranes and is divided from the mother cell by a thick wall. Previously, it was known that the mother cell and forespore share an intercellular communication pathway to coordinate the developmental process. In this study, the authors showed that this communication pathway is made up of a protein complex that includes proteins from both the mother cell and the forespore. This protein complex is critical for maintaining the integrity of the forespore and is required for spore formation. The authors also discovered that some of the proteins in this complex share similarity with specialized secretion systems found in other bacteria. They further showed that the forespore uses these proteins to obtain nutrients from the mother cell through a secretion process. The authors concluded that the protein complex they identified in this study is an important part of the intercellular communication pathway in Bacillus subtilis and is critical for the survival of the forespore during the spore formation process.
A recent study used a new approach to identify genetic factors for bipolar disorder (BD), a mental disorder characterized by extreme mood swings. The researchers compared genetic data from 1,190 BD cases and 401 controls to those of 2,191 cases and 1,434 controls. They did not find any genome-wide significant associations with individual loci, but they did detect an association between the power to detect genetic effects and replication. They concluded that there is likely common genetic variation associated with BD near exons (genes' coding regions) that could be identified in larger studies.
This article presents a new way to analyze how different genes contribute to the growth of cancer cells. In the past, scientists have used a technique called "knockdown" to see how the loss of certain genes affects the growth of cancer cells. However, this technique has limitations and can be unreliable. To overcome these limitations, the authors of this article developed a new method that uses a "Proliferation Index" (PI) to measure how the expression levels of different genes are associated with the growth rate of cancer cells. The authors found that genes that are essential for cancer cell growth have a positive PI, while genes that are essential for non-cancerous cell growth have a negative PI. They also found that certain cellular processes, such as cell cycle and DNA replication, are positively associated with cancer proliferation, while other processes, such as cell migration, are negatively associated with it. These findings provide valuable information that could be used to develop new anti-cancer drugs.
The article describes a rare condition called cystic echinococcosis, which can affect the heart and vena cava. This is a parasitic disease that is caused by a tapeworm called Echinococcus granulosus. People become infected when they accidentally swallow the tapeworm eggs from contaminated food or water. The parasite then spreads throughout the body and can cause a variety of symptoms. The article reports on 11 patients who were diagnosed with cardiac and/or endovascular cystic echinococcosis over a period of 15 years. They experienced symptoms such as thoracic pain or dyspnea, but some patients were asymptomatic. The article also describes the different diagnostic methods that were used to diagnose and follow up on the patients, such as echocardiography, serology, electrocardiogram, chest X-ray, computed tomography/magnetic resonance imaging, and histology. The article reports that nine of the patients underwent cardiac surgery and nine received long-term antiparasitic treatment. One patient died intra-operatively due to cyst rupture and endovascular dissemination. Two other patients died 10 and 14 years after diagnosis, due to pulmonary embolism and cardiac failure, respectively. One patient was lost to follow-up. The article also describes the different complications that can arise from cystic echinococcosis, such as potentially lethal complications and chronic complications, and how they vary depending on the cyst location. The article concludes that CE should be included in the differential diagnosis of cardiovascular disease in patients from endemic areas, and it recommends a combination of surgical and medical management for these patients.
The Toll/interleukin-1 receptor ( TIR ) domain in Toll-like receptors ( TLRs ) is important for initiating and propagating the eukaryotic innate immune signaling cascade . In a recent study, the authors identified a new TIR-like protein in the bacterium Staphylococcus aureus, called TirS . They found that ectopic expression of TirS in eukaryotic cells inhibited TLR signaling by downregulating the NF-kB pathway through inhibition of TLR2 , TLR4 , TLR5 , and TLR9 . They also found that skin lesions induced by the S . aureus knockout tirS mutant increased in a mouse model compared with wild-type and restored strains, even though the tirS-mutant and wild-type strains did not differ in bacterial load. TirS was associated with lower neutrophil and macrophage activity, confirming a central role in virulence attenuation through local inflammatory responses . The authors also found that TirS was located within the staphylococcal chromosomal cassettes ( SCCs ) containing the fusC gene for fusidic acid resistance but not always carrying the mecA gene . They also found that sub-inhibitory concentration of fusidic acid increased tirS expression. The authors note that epidemiological studies identified no link between this effector and clinical presentation but showed a selective advantage with a SCCmec element with SCC fusC/tirS . They conclude that two key traits determining the success and spread of bacterial infections are linked.
The study by the authors explores the differences in embryonic development between mosquitoes and fruit flies. The authors compare gene expression data from the embryonic development of both species and identify genes that are expressed differently between them. One such group of genes is expressed specifically in the mosquito serosa, a tissue that is absent in fruit flies. The study also reveals a striking difference in the temporal expression of a subset of maternal genes. These findings suggest that the unique gene expression patterns between mosquitoes and fruit flies may be responsible for their distinct embryonic morphologies. The study provides a framework for identifying the genetic circuits underlying embryonic diversity.
The research aimed to investigate the presence of DNA from Haemophilus ducreyi and Treponema pallidum subsp . pertenue in the skin of asymptomatic children in Papua New Guinea. These bacteria are known to cause leg ulcers in children in certain parts of Africa and the Pacific Islands. The researchers performed a cross-sectional study and swabbed the skin of participants for H. ducreyi and T. p. pertenue DNA. They found that 16 out of 78 asymptomatic participants had H. ducreyi-PCR positivity. They also found that 9 out of 17 flies tested had H. ducreyi DNA. The results suggest that H. ducreyi may be ubiquitous in the environment and may contribute to the spread of the disease. The research highlights the need for further studies to understand the potential role of the environment and flies in the transmission of these bacteria.
Bioinformatics is a crucial aspect of biomedical research and healthcare, but there is disagreement in the field over what the essential knowledge base entails and how best to provide it. This report describes the current status of the core competencies developed by the Curriculum Task Force of the International Society of Computational Biology Education Committee, which aim to cut across many user personas and training programs. It includes a series of use cases illustrating how the competencies are being applied in diverse training contexts, such as bioinformatics engineer and user training. The report concludes with a consideration of remaining challenges and future plans, including engaging with more diverse populations to ensure the competencies are comprehensive and relevant to all users.
This study aims to understand the mechanisms behind the arrest and activation of the infectious form, known as L3i, of a parasitic nematode called Strongyloides stercoralis. The authors found that while many of the genes involved in L3i development are similar to those found in the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans, there are also several differences. They also identified specific pathways that may be involved in the regulation of L3i development in S. stercoralis. These findings could lead to new treatment and control strategies for the parasite.
Humans are often exposed to genotoxins from bacteria that can cause digestive cancers, including colibactin and Cytolethal Distending Toxin (CDT), which are produced by many pathogenic bacteria. Our study aimed to evaluate the effects of these genotoxins on nuclear remodeling and their role in cell survival. To do this, we used mouse models, coculture experiments with bacteria that produce CDT and colibactin, and cells from the liver, intestine, and stomach. Our results showed that CDT and colibactin cause nuclear remodeling, which is associated with the formation of deep cytoplasmic invaginations in the nucleus of giant cells. These structures, observed both in vitro and in vivo, are called nucleoplasmic reticulum (NR), which concentrate ribosomes, proteins involved in mRNA translation, polyadenylated RNA, and the main components of the complex mCRD involved in mRNA turnover. These structures are active sites of mRNA translation, correlated with a high degree of ploidy, and involve MAPK and calcium signaling. We found that the insulation and concentration of these adaptive ribonucleoprotein particles within the nucleus are dynamic, transient, and protect the cell until the genotoxic stress is relieved. Bacterial genotoxins-induced NR would be a privileged gateway for selected mRNA to be preferably transported therein for local translation. These findings provide new insights into the context of NR formation, which is a common feature of many cancers and appears not only in response to therapies-induced DNA damage but also earlier in response to genotoxic bacteria.
This study aimed to evaluate the bone deformation of the maxilla in patients who have had leprosy using 3D CT. Previous studies have only evaluated these deformities using visual grading, and no objective or morphometric evaluation has been performed. The maxilla is the bone that supports the structures of the external nose, so changes in the maxilla can affect the shape of the nose and face. There is a need to quantify the precise morphological changes in the maxilla in order to develop corrective treatments for facial deformities caused by leprosy. In this study, 3D CT images of the maxilla were reconstructed using VR and MPR in patients with a history of leprosy and control subjects. These findings were compared with maxillary deformities described in paleopathological studies. After standardization and comparison of leprotic and control data, we succeeded in quantifying the thickness of the maxillary bone defects that require reconstructive surgery.
Our ears pick up sounds in a world with a lot of background noise. To understand these sounds, the brain has to create representations of them that are not affected by background noise. Previous research shows that sounds are represented differently in different parts of the brain. In the peripheral auditory system, sounds are represented in terms of their physical properties, including the noise. In the higher auditory areas of the brain, sounds are represented in a way that is more context-independent and categorical. However, we know very little about the neural computations that are used to build these noise-invariant sound representations. We also know that individual auditory neurons change their responses depending on the context in which the sound is presented. In this study, we used complex synthetic and natural sounds, and recorded neural responses in the inferior colliculus and primary fields of the auditory cortex in anesthetized ferrets. We also created a model of the auditory nerve. We found that the strength of adaptation to the mean and contrast of stimulation increases as we move up the auditory pathway from the auditory nerve to the auditory cortex. To investigate whether this adaptation to stimulus statistics contributes to noise-tolerant sound representations, we presented complex sounds in the presence of background noise and used a decoding approach to measure how well these sounds could be reconstructed from the population responses. We found that noise tolerance of the population code increased as we moved up the auditory pathway, and was correlated with the strength of adaptation to stimulus statistics. This suggests that the increase in adaptation to sound statistics from auditory nerve to midbrain to cortex is an important stage in the construction of noise-invariant sound representations in the higher auditory brain.
Heat shock, a stress response, was analyzed using yeast as a model organism. Yeast's protein-protein interaction network was calculated based on changes in mRNA expression levels. The main finding was that heat shock caused a significant decrease in both the overlaps and connections of yeast interactome modules. The weighted diameter of the yeast interactome increased by 4.9-fold. Heat shock caused the yeast interactome to change from a globally connected organization to a multifocal organization. This partial disintegration of the global structure of the yeast interactome may be a general system-level adaptation mechanism to environmental changes.
Chagas disease is a serious health problem in Latin America and is caused by a parasite called Trypanosoma cruzi . It can lead to a wide range of complications, including heart disease and arrhythmias (irregular heartbeats). Amiodarone is a drug that is often used to treat arrhythmias, and there have been studies done to see if it is effective in patients with Chagas disease. This review looked at the available evidence from different studies, and it found that amiodarone can reduce ventricular arrhythmias in patients with Chagas cardiomyopathy. However, the review also found that amiodarone is associated with a number of adverse effects, including corneal microdeposits, gastrointestinal events, sinus bradycardia, dermatological events, and drug discontinuation. The review also found that there is no evidence that amiodarone can reduce sudden death or hospitalization in patients with Chagas disease. Overall, the review suggests that while amiodarone may be effective in reducing ventricular arrhythmias in patients with Chagas disease, the potential benefits and harms of using the drug should be carefully considered before making a decision.
Mosquito-borne diseases such as dengue fever, chikungunya, and Zika are more common during certain times of the year. Climate and human behavior are two factors that can influence seasonal patterns of these diseases. This study aimed to determine seasonal patterns of dengue fever in Ecuador using data from patients clinically diagnosed with the disease at two hospitals. The study found that dengue fever had a single peak in case diagnoses during mid-March. Public holidays did not significantly impact diagnoses, except for an increase in diagnoses on the day after Christmas. School schedules did not impact dengue diagnoses in school-aged children. The study also found that climate variables such as monthly total precipitation, an interaction between total precipitation and monthly absolute minimum temperature, an interaction between total precipitation and monthly precipitation days, and a three-way interaction between minimum temperature, total precipitation, and precipitation days were important predictors of dengue diagnoses. This study is significant because it is one of few reports from rural patients and one of very few studies utilizing daily disease reports. The findings can inform local disease prevention efforts, public health planning, and global and regional models of dengue fever trends.
A study found that expressing a picornavirus replication protein called RdRP in mice or human cells can trigger a long-lasting, powerful immune response that protects against many types of viruses. This immune response is mediated by the MDA5 pathway, a type of innate immune response that does not require prior knowledge of a virus. This protection against viruses did not harm the mice or make them sick. The researchers say this could be a way to protect people from many different types of viruses without causing autoimmune diseases.
We report a complete study of the infection dynamics of the plant RNA virus Tobacco etch virus (TEV) upon inoculation of different host plants (Nicotiana tabacum and Capsicum annuum) at different doses (viral RNA molecules). Our study reveals that the number of foci of primary infection in the inoculated leaf is dose-dependent, with lower doses resulting in less foci. Moreover, the number of foci of primary infection is also dose-dependent in systemically infected plants. The probability of systemic infection is approximately 1, and the size of the population of virus in the systemic tissues can be predicted from the number of foci of primary infection. The size of the population of virus in the systemic tissues is therefore very similar to that in the inoculated leaf. These results support the hypothesis that the infection process of TEV is independent of other infecting virions, and that the probability of each virus causing infection is independent of the presence of other viruses. We propose that the probability of infection is a fixed parameter of the host, and that each virus acts independently of the other viruses. Our study provides strong evidence for the independent-action hypothesis of micro-parasite infection, and this hypothesis appears to be valid for mono-partite plant RNA viruses. Our study also provides estimates of the population size of TEV in different hosts at different doses, and these estimates can be used to compare different plant RNA viruses. Our results suggest that the host plays a key role in determining the number of virions that cause primary infection and the subsequent systemic infection. Understanding the infection dynamics of plant RNA viruses is important for controlling plant diseases, and our study provides new insights into how plant RNA viruses infect their hosts.
In this paper, the authors propose a new statistical method called Sparse Bayesian Regression for mapping expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) across multiple tissues simultaneously. This method is an extension of the traditional approach of mapping eQTLs in individual tissues, which does not account for the similarities and differences in gene expression across tissues. The authors tested their method on a set of 2,000 genes in four tissues and found that their method was more powerful than traditional methods in revealing the true complexity of the eQTL landscape at the systems level. They also identified a two-eQTL model (cis/trans) for the Hopx gene that was experimentally validated and was not detected by conventional approaches. The authors also found evidence of common genetic regulation of gene expression across four tissues for about 27% of transcripts. These findings provide new insights into the genetic regulation of gene expression at the systems level. The generality of the modeling approach makes it adaptable to other model systems and humans, with broad application to analysis of multiple intermediate and whole-body phenotypes.
The article "Variable-delay, snap-action switching of the extrinsic apoptosis pathway" presents a mathematical model of the extrinsic cell death pathway, which is activated by TNF and TRAIL receptors. The model is based on the mass-action representation of known reaction pathways and has been trained against experimental data. The authors find that the duration of the delay before effector caspase activation is determined by initiator caspase-8 activity and the rates of reactions immediately downstream of the TRAIL receptor. The model also highlights the importance of interactions among Bcl-2 family members, partitioning of Smac from its binding partner XIAP, and the mechanics of pore assembly for snap-action control.
During pregnancy, a special barrier called the placenta protects the fetus from the mother's immune system and harmful pathogens. Bacteria that can get past this barrier, such as Listeria monocytogenes, provide a unique opportunity to understand how the placenta works. In this study, the authors looked at a specific protein called Internalin P (InlP) that is found in L. monocytogenes and that helps the bacteria cross the placenta. They found that InlP binds to a protein called human afadin, which is found in the placenta and helps cells stick together. They also found that InlP helps L. monocytogenes to cross the placental barrier by promoting something called transcytosis, which is when a bacterium moves from the basal side of an infected epithelial monolayer to the apical side. This means that InlP may help L. monocytogenes to infect the fetus. Overall, this study provides important information about how bacteria can cross the placental barrier and how the placenta protects the fetus.
In this study, the authors aimed to better understand the proteome of T. pallidum ssp. pallidum, the bacterial causative agent of syphilis, during infection. They used complementary mass spectrometry techniques to analyze three biological replicates of T. pallidum bacteria harvested from infected rabbits. The authors identified 6033 peptides that correspond to 557 unique T. pallidum proteins at a high level of confidence, representing 54% of the predicted proteome. They found that a total of 116 potential membrane proteins were identified, of which 16 have evidence supporting outer membrane localization. The authors also identified 8/12 proteins related to the paralogous tpr gene family, including TprB, TprC/D, TprE, TprG, TprH, TprI, and TprJ. They semi-quantified protein abundance using label-free spectral counting methods. The study provides the most comprehensive description of the global T. pallidum proteome to date and helps to improve our understanding of the pathogenicity of this enigmatic organism.
Protein Kinase A (PKA) is an important signaling molecule in eukaryotic cells. PKA is activated by the secondary messenger cAMP, which binds to two tandem domains within the regulatory subunit of PKA. Our study uses nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) to investigate the two-domain construct RIα (91–379) in its apo, cAMP2, and C-bound forms. Our comparative NMR analyses reveal that each apo CBD dynamically samples both active and inactive states independently of the adjacent CBD. The binding of cAMP selectively stabilizes the active conformation within each CBD and inter-CBD contacts, which require both cAMP and W260, a residue contributed by CBD-B. Our results support a model of double conformational selection in which CBD-B serves as a "gatekeeper" domain that controls the availability of W260 to cAMP bound to CBD-A. The study also reveals that both CBD-A and -B exhibit residual dynamics, even in the presence of cAMP, and that the two tandem CBDs exhibit different dynamics profiles. These findings suggest that conservation of structure does not necessarily imply conservation of dynamics and open new opportunities for selective targeting of CBDs for therapeutic purposes.
The study is about a protein called ISG15 that is involved in the antiviral innate immune response. ISG15 can be found in two forms: as a free molecule (intracellular and extracellular) or conjugated to target proteins (ISGylation). ISGylation occurs in a similar manner to the process of ubiquitination, which is also a reversible modification. The study looked at the proteomes of bone marrow-derived macrophages (BMDMs) that were either ISG15-deficient or ISG15-sufficient, and compared the proteomes after infection with vaccinia virus (VACV). The results showed that mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS) were altered in ISG15-deficient BMDMs treated with IFN. The study also found that ISG15-deficient macrophages had a robust proinflammatory cytokine expression pattern but did not produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) or nitric oxide (NO) in response to IFN treatment. Furthermore, NO release was higher in ISG15-sufficient macrophages than in ISG15-deficient macrophages following IFN treatment, and this was associated with a decrease in viral titer. In conclusion, the study highlights the important role of ISG15 in the dynamic functionality of mitochondria, specifically OXPHOS and mitophagy, which expands its role beyond antiviral defense.
The HIV-1 protein Vpu plays two roles in the virus's replication: it helps in the release of viral particles and it degrades the cellular receptor CD4. Vpu binds to a protein called βTrCP, which helps Vpu to degrade CD4. In this study, the authors found that Vpu is also subject to degradation by the proteasome, which is a complex made of enzymes that help to break down and recycle proteins. They found that Vpu is phosphorylated (which means that a chemical group is added to it) at the serine 61 position, which is next to the βTrCP-binding motif. They also found that this phosphorylation event is required for Vpu to be degraded by the proteasome. However, they did not find that this degradation was mediated by βTrCP, but rather by a different protein. They also found that this degradation decreased the efficiency of Vpu-mediated release of HIV-1 virions, which may help to balance the virus's dissemination and preservation of the infected cell reservoir.
Development is the process through which organisms grow and develop into adults. Tissues are organized in a way that allows them to pattern correctly even when environmental conditions change. There are different hypotheses about how tissue patterning is coordinated with the whole body during development. One hypothesis is that tissue patterning and whole-body development progress synchronously. This means that the rate of tissue patterning matches the rate of whole-body development. Another hypothesis is that tissue patterning is only coordinated with whole-body development at key developmental events, such as moulting. To test these hypotheses, researchers developed a staging scheme for the wing imaginal discs of Drosophila larvae using the expression of key patterning genes. They then used this scheme to explore how the progression of tissue patterning changes when developmental rate is altered either by changing temperature or by altering the timing of hormone synthesis. The researchers found that tissue patterning is coordinated with whole-body development at key developmental events. However, tissue patterning showed greater variability between events. This suggests that tissue patterning is not always coordinated with whole-body development and that it may be important for tissues to have the ability to pattern correctly even when developmental conditions change.
The paper investigates the function of Did2, an ESCRT regulator, in fungal hyphae. ESCRT is a complex protein that helps to recycle materials in the cell, including membranes and proteins. Did2 is important for endosomal transport in fungal hyphae, which are long, branching cells that can grow in many different directions. The authors show that Did2 is important for two processes: long-distance transport and endosomal maturation. Long-distance transport involves moving materials from one part of the cell to another, while endosomal maturation involves changing the properties of endosomes as they move through the cell. The authors suggest that Did2 may be important for coordinating these two processes. They also discuss the importance of Did2 for endosomal mRNP transport, which is the movement of mRNA from one part of the cell to another. Overall, the paper sheds light on the important role of ESCRT in endosomal transport and mRNA transport in fungal hyphae.
Riboswitches are RNA molecules that sense changes in the cell and regulate gene expression accordingly. They have been found in all kingdoms of life, and some even regulate in trans. Riboswitches consist of an aptamer and an expression platform, and many are similar but have a very high specificity and affinity for their ligands. The add riboswitch regulates translation by controlling the formation of a translation sequestrator, while the pbuE riboswitch regulates transcription by attenuating transcription. It has been observed that the add and pbuE riboswitches behave differently in their ligand binding properties. Adenine riboswitches can bind to adenine after transcription is completed, and this can still perform translation regulation. The transcription process dictates the RNA folding pathway, which is important for the regulatory activity of riboswitches. A riboswitch that operates under a kinetic regime requires the rate of ligand binding to be quicker than the rate of transcription, while a riboswitch that operates under a thermodynamic regime requires the rate of ligand binding to be slower than the rate of transcription. It is necessary to characterize more riboswitch representatives to gain a better understanding of their mechanisms of regulation.
The article describes a type of transcription initiation called "primer-dependent initiation" (PDI) that is widely found in bacteria, particularly during the stationary phase of growth. This type of initiation involves using a short oligoribonucleotide to initiate transcription instead of using a new RNA strand as a starting point. The article describes how PDI in Escherichia coli (E. coli) is involved in regulating the formation of biofilms, which are complex communities of microorganisms that form on surfaces. The article also describes how PDI occurs in another type of bacteria called Vibrio cholerae, and provides evidence that the pattern of PDI in this bacteria is similar to the pattern observed in E. coli. The authors propose that a growth phase-dependent process that generates specific oligoribonucleotides may be responsible for PDI in both E. coli and V. cholerae.
We have studied the effect of imbalance in the parental genome dosage in the endosperm of Arabidopsis seeds. Parental imbalance is an evolutionary phenomenon that occurs when two different species of plants are crossed and the resulting offspring is a hybrid of the two species. In this study, we found that increased dosage of the maternal genome caused a decrease in the expression of FIS2, while increased dosage of the paternal genome caused an increase in the expression of FIS2. This finding is surprising, as we expected that increased dosage of the maternal genome would increase the expression of FIS2, while increased dosage of the paternal genome would decrease the expression of FIS2. However, our results suggest that there may be complex interactions between the imprinted genes in the endosperm, which are not yet fully understood. Despite this, our study provides important insights into the complex mechanisms of imprinting in the endosperm.
This paper focuses on brain rhythms that can be recorded by EEG and MEG. These rhythms are caused by different frequencies of brain activity, which can be seen in the power spectrum. The power spectrum is like a map of brain rhythms, showing a non-oscillatory background with frequency bands superimposed on it. These frequency bands are evenly spaced, making it easier for different rhythms to coexist without affecting each other. Researchers have used mathematical tools to study how these rhythms are generated and how they interact with each other. In this paper, the researchers ask a different question: what do these rhythms tell us about the structure and function of the brain? To answer this question, they used mathematical techniques to create "virtual brains" that mimic the rhythms seen in real brains. They found that all the reconstructed virtual brains had similar features, such as certain types of connections between different parts of the brain. They also studied how these virtual brains are affected by diseases like epilepsy and schizophrenia, and found that the altered rhythms in diseased brains were also reflected in the structure and function of the virtual brains. This study provides important insights into how the brain works, and how diseases can affect it.
The study presents a genetic analysis of 1,374 unrelated Hispanic individuals from the Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis (MESA), including self-identification corresponding to Central America, Cuba, the Dominican Republic, Mexico, Puerto Rico, and South America. Using genome-wide genotyping data, the authors performed population structure analysis and identified four distinct subgroups: primarily Central/South American, the Dominican Republic and Cuba, Mexico, and Puerto Rico. The authors also performed genetic association analysis on triglyceride levels, using SNPs in the lipoprotein lipase and tribbles homolog 1 gene regions. The study demonstrated the importance of considering population substructure and genetic heterogeneity in genetic association studies performed in the United States Hispanic population. The authors suggest that stratified analysis offers better resolution to detect genetic loci in which SNP effects are limited to or much stronger within a single subgroup of Hispanics. The results of this study may have implications for genetic research on cardiovascular disease and other phenotypes in Hispanic populations.
The study shows that the Elongator complex, which is involved in histone acetylation, is required for transcriptional silencing and maintenance of genome stability. This is done in a pathway linked to DNA replication and DNA repair protein PCNA. The results suggest that the Elongator complex plays an important role in gene regulation and genome stability.
This research paper introduces a new method for automating the process of manually curating biomedical knowledge from publications. The current process is often time-consuming and expensive, as domain experts must carefully read and select articles to curate. The new method uses machine learning algorithms to classify and rank articles for curation, based on their relevance to the topic. The researchers collected previously curated publications and used them to train deep learning models, which were then applied to the real-world manual curation process of two external knowledge bases. The results showed that the new method outperformed the current query-based method in terms of precision and recall, without compromising the quality of the curated content. The new method is being implemented in production to help human curators focus on more challenging tasks and improve the overall efficiency of the knowledge base curation process.
The human heart is made up of specialized cells called cardiomyocytes that beat together to keep the heart pumping. These cells have an electrical system that controls their contractions, similar to how a computer uses electricity to run. This electrical system is made up of several different types of ion channels that control the flow of charged particles called ions in and out of the cells. Ion channels are like tiny gates that open and close in response to changes in the electrical charge inside the cell. Changes to the function of these ion channels can cause problems with the heart's electrical system, which can lead to abnormal heartbeats, or arrhythmias. There are several different types of arrhythmias, including a group called short QT syndrome, which can lead to life-threatening heart problems. In this study, researchers used computer models to study how changes in a particular type of ion channel called Kir2 .1 can affect the electrical system of the heart. They found that changes to Kir2 .1 channels can cause a type of short QT syndrome called variant 3, which can lead to atrial fibrillation. They also found that different changes to Kir2 .1 channels can cause different types of arrhythmias, and that treatment with certain drugs can help stop these arrhythmias. Overall, this study provides important information about the electrical system of the heart and how changes to ion channels can cause problems.
Chagas disease is a disease caused by a parasite (Trypanosoma cruzi) that can spread through several routes, including blood transfusions, organ transplants, ingestion of contaminated food or drinks, and congenital transmission. The disease is endemic in Central and South America, and it can lead to heart disease and death. The current study investigated whether adult adipose tissue-derived mesenchymal stromal cells (ASC) can reduce inflammation and heart damage in a mouse model of chagasic cardiomyopathy. The ASC were injected into mice 3 days after infection. The results showed that the ASC significantly reduced the number of parasites in the blood, which was followed by a decrease in inflammation and heart damage. In addition, the ASC caused a change in the response of lymphoid organs to the parasite, which led to a control of parasite burden. The study suggests that ASC may be a useful treatment for chagasic cardiomyopathy.
Leishmaniasis is a disease caused by parasites that infect and live in the skin of mammals. These parasites live in specialized compartments inside the cells called parasitophorous vacuoles (LPVs). Retro-2 is a chemical compound that has been shown to block the formation of these compartments and limit the growth of parasites inside the cells. This study aimed to investigate the effects of structural analogs of Retro-2cycl on the formation of LPVs and the growth of parasites. The analogs DHQZ 36 and DHQZ 36 .1 were found to be more effective in limiting the growth of parasites inside the cells than Retro-2cycl. These analogs also caused a reversal in the suppression of IL-6 release by infected cells after LPS activation. Moreover, they killed the parasites in axenic cultures, which is a desirable attribute for a drug to treat Leishmania infections. These studies validate and extend the published structure-activity relationship analyses of Retro-2cycl .
The nucleosome is a unit of genomic organization made up of DNA wrapped around a protein core. This can act to organize the DNA and keep it compact. The nucleosome may also regulate gene expression. The authors present a method to predict whether a transcription factor is sensitive to nucleosome regulation, and they use this method to identify a transcription factor called AML-1a that is sensitive to nucleosomes in a family of genes called the Ly49 genes. They then confirm that AML-1a is sensitive to nucleosomes in a cell line that naturally expresses the Ly49 genes. This suggests that nucleosome positioning may be involved in regulating the expression of the Ly49 genes.
The cell cycle, a process in which cells prepare to divide, is controlled by proteins called cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs). The activity of CDKs is regulated by a chemical process called phosphorylation, in which phosphate groups are added to certain proteins. Phosphorylation can be catalyzed by an enzyme called a CDK-activating kinase (CAK). In animals, the only known CAK for CDK2 and CDK1 is cyclin H-CDK7. In this study, the researchers used chemical-genetics to investigate the role of CDK7 in the activation of CDK4 and CDK6, which are important for cell cycle progression. They discovered that CDK7 is not the only CAK for CDK4 and CDK6. They also found that p21, a protein that regulates the cell cycle, is phosphorylated by CDK4 and CDK2, and that this phosphorylation is important for the activation of CDK4 and p21-dependent cell cycle progression.
The paper discusses the role of a protein called DUET in the process of meiosis in plants. Meiosis is the process by which haploid cells are produced for sexual reproduction. In yeast, a series of genes are activated in a specific order as meiosis progresses. However, the factors controlling this process are not well understood in multicellular eukaryotes. The authors of this paper found that DUET is required for proper meiotic gene expression in Arabidopsis. They discovered that DUET binds to H3K4me2, a type of histone modification, and that this binding is important for its function. The authors also found that DUET is expressed only at a specific stage of meiosis and that its targets are involved in meiotic cell cycle transitions and spindle organization. Overall, their findings suggest that DUET functions as a transcriptional regulator during male meiosis in plants.
Fragile X-associated Tremor/Ataxia Syndrome ( FXTAS ) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder affecting adult men who carry a premutation of the FMR1 gene, a gene that codes for a protein called FMRP. The premutation is a stretch of CGG repeats that is too large but not large enough to cause a full-blown mutation. Although the exact mechanism of how this premutation leads to FXTAS is not clear, it is known that it results in an increase in FMR1 mRNA and a decrease in FMRP. This study used a proteomic approach to identify proteins that interact with Pur α, a protein that has been implicated in FXTAS pathogenesis. The study identified 100 proteins that interact with Pur α, one of which is Rm62, a protein that is known to be involved in stress and immune responses. Further analysis revealed that fragile X premutation rCGG repeats can cause the nuclear accumulation of specific mRNAs, including Hsp70 and other stress response genes. This nuclear accumulation could impair the ability of these genes to be translated into proteins, leading to neuronal apoptosis. Overall, this study suggests that fragile X premutation rCGG repeats cause a deficit in the nuclear export of specific mRNAs, which could predispose neurons to apoptosis.
This article describes the importance of the extracellular matrix in the formation of biofilms, which are communities of bacteria that adhere to each other and to surfaces. The matrix is composed of a variety of substances, including polysaccharides, nucleic acids, and proteins. The authors focus on the polysaccharide Psl, which is produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a bacterium that forms biofilms on many different surfaces. The authors provide detailed information about the structure of Psl and show that it is important for the formation and maintenance of the P. aeruginosa biofilm matrix. They also show that the matrix can change during the development of the biofilm. The authors propose that P. aeruginosa may use programmed cell death and lysis to create a matrix-free area in the center of the microcolony, which is important for future seeding dispersal. This work provides important insights into the process of biofilm development and may help in the development of new strategies for controlling biofilm formation.
Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is a deadly cancer that is difficult to treat and has poor outcomes. To better understand the genetic makeup of PDAC, researchers are using patient-derived xenografts (PDX) and patient-derived organoids (PDO). These models are made by taking a patient's tumor and implanting it into a mouse or cell culture dish, respectively. However, no one has yet analyzed the full genetic profile of these models and compared them to the original patient tumor at the whole-genome level. In this study, researchers analyzed the genetic makeup of 16 pairs of tumors and their corresponding PDX and/or PDO. They found that while these models accurately recapitulate some of the genetic changes in the original tumor, such as mutations in known cancer drivers, they struggle to accurately represent the full range of genetic changes in the tumor, such as structural variations and copy number changes. Additionally, the researchers found that these models may be best suited for studying specific types of genetic changes, depending on their complexity. Overall, the researchers' findings suggest that while these models are useful tools for studying PDAC, they have some limitations that should be considered when interpreting their results.
In this study, researchers aimed to discover new genetic factors that contribute to breast cancer risk. They conducted a four-stage genome-wide association study (GWAS) in 19,091 cases and 20,606 controls of East Asian descent, including Chinese, Korean, and Japanese women. They identified 22 SNPs (single nucleotide polymorphisms) that may contribute to breast cancer risk. The top SNP, rs9485372, located near the TGF-β activated kinase gene, showed a consistent association with breast cancer risk across all four stages, with a P-value of 3.8×10-12 in the combined analysis of all samples. The adjusted odds ratios were 0.89 (0.85-0.94) and 0.80 (0.75-0.86) for the A/G and A/A genotypes, respectively, compared with the genotype G/G. Two other SNPs, rs9383951 and rs7107217, located in the ESR1 and 11q24.3 genes, respectively, also showed a consistent association with breast cancer risk in each of the four stages. This study provides strong evidence for a novel breast cancer susceptibility locus represented by rs9485372 near the TAB2 gene and identifies two possible susceptibility loci located in the ESR1 gene and 11q24.3, respectively.
Cryptococcal meningitis (CM) is a major cause of death worldwide, particularly in people with HIV/AIDS. Scientists have studied 230 isolates of the fungus Cryptococcus neoformans (Cn) from HIV-positive patients in South Africa and found that patients infected with a certain lineage of Cn called VNB had significantly worse survival than those infected with other lineages. This study highlights the importance of understanding the genetic diversity of Cn and how it may be related to patient outcomes.
A new study has discovered the last missing component of a signal transduction pathway in Candida albicans that regulates the pheromone response of the white cell phenotype. Through the construction of an overexpression library for 107 transcription factors and mutational analyses, the researchers found that the transcription factor Tec1 is the last component of this newly evolved signal transduction pathway. The elucidation of this pathway provides a unique perspective on how new signal transduction pathways may evolve and highlights the importance of identifying the origins of components in young signal transduction pathways for a deeper understanding of their evolution.
The genomic GC-content of bacteria varies dramatically, from less than 20% to more than 70%. This variation is generally attributed to differences in the mutation pattern of bacteria, but this theory has not been thoroughly tested. In this study, the authors examined patterns of synonymous polymorphism in 149 bacterial species to test this hypothesis. They found a large excess of synonymous GC→AT mutations over AT→GC mutations in all but the most AT-rich bacteria. This excess of GC→AT SNPs is inconsistent with mutation bias and suggests that there is selection to increase synonymous GC-content in many species. This is also evident in the correlation between the GC-content of the first two codon positions of protein coding genes and genomic GC-content. The authors conclude that there is selection on genomic base composition in many bacteria.
Scientists have developed a new approach for mapping the observed prevalence of soil-transmitted helminths (STH) in Kenya using a Bayesian space-time geostatistical model. They combined data from over 900 cross-sectional surveys conducted in Kenya between 1974 and 2009 to estimate the prevalence of hookworm, Ascaris lumbricoides, and Trichuris trichiura, and mapped the combined prevalence of infection. The model estimated that 2.8 million school-aged children live in districts that warrant mass treatment. The scientists suggest that the model can be used to map STH prevalence in other countries and help guide control efforts.
The article is about a study on the role of innate lymphocytes in immunity against tuberculosis. Innate lymphocytes are a subset of cells that serve as the first line of defense against infection and have a partially activated phenotype. These cells are also known as NK cells and γδ T cells. The article establishes an in vitro model to study the contribution of innate lymphocytes to immunity against Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb). The model involves the culture of splenocytes obtained from uninfected mice with Mtb-infected macrophages. The study shows that the culture secreted IFN-γ, stimulated NOS2 upregulation and NO production, and suppressed intracellular Mtb replication. The article identifies the cellular mechanism that mediates this innate effector function against the intracellular human pathogen Mtb. The findings of the study suggest that innate lymphocytes contribute to immunity against tuberculosis.
Protein assemblies are important in a wide range of biological processes, and covalent bonds can help to stabilize these assemblies. The formation of intra- or intermolecular ε- ( γ-glutamyl ) lysil cross-links is one example of how covalent bonds can be used to stabilize protein assemblies. The formation of these cross-links is catalyzed by transglutaminases ( TGases ). In many cases, the activity of TGases is tightly controlled. In this study, researchers investigated the activity of a TGase ( Tgl ) produced by the bacterial species Bacillus subtilis. Unlike other TGases, Tgl is produced in an active form and efficiently catalyzes amine incorporation and protein cross-linking in vitro with no known additional requirements. The researchers found that the activity of Tgl is spatially restricted to the surface of the developing spore. They also identified specific residues in Tgl that are crucial for its localization, and they showed that the first step in the reaction cycle, the interaction with Q-substrates and formation of an acyl-enzyme intermediate, is the determinant step in the localization of Tgl.
Opisthorchis viverrini is a parasite that can cause liver and bile duct diseases, including cholangiocarcinoma, a type of liver cancer. In Lao PDR, it is estimated that 2.5 million people are infected with this parasite, but there are not many studies about where this parasite is found. In this study, we aimed to find out where O. viverrini is found in southern Lao PDR and what factors increase the risk of infection. We used a survey to collect data on demographics, water supply, sanitation, and behavior in 51 villages in Champasack province. We also used satellite data to find out what environmental factors were associated with infection. We used a computer program to map the risk of O. viverrini infection and to identify risk factors. We found that the highest infection rates were in people who lived in the Mekong corridor and in those who ate fish from freshwater sources. We also found that the risk of infection was higher in people who did not have access to sanitation, were older, and belonged to the Lao Loum ethnic group.
The paper is about the mosquito larval habitats in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. The authors found that the majority of larval habitats in Dar es Salaam are drains, with aquatic habitats associated with agriculture having the highest proportion of Anopheles larvae presence and the second highest of Culex larvae presence. However, the majority of aquatic habitats were drains, and therefore, 43% (1,364/3,149) of all culicine and 33% (320/976) of all anopheline positive habitats were drains. The authors found that drains with stagnant water had 8.8 times higher odds of containing Anopheles and Culex larvae compared with drains where water was flowing at normal velocity. The authors concluded that drains are important sources of mosquito larval habitats for both LF and malaria vectors. They suggest that restoring and maintaining drains in Dar es Salaam has the potential to eliminate more than 40% of all potential mosquito larval habitats that are currently treated with larvicides by the UMCP.
This study investigated the role of lipid metabolism in dengue virus (DENV) replication. The authors found that the HMGCR enzyme, which is responsible for cholesterol synthesis, was activated in DENV-infected cells and this activation was mediated by the inactivation of AMPK. They also found that the cholesterol-rich ER compartments were important for replicative complex formation and that this process was disrupted by inhibition of HMGCR. The authors suggest that HMGCR activation and the disruption of replicative complex formation by HMGCR inhibition could be potential therapeutic targets for DENV infection.
In this article, the authors use molecular dynamics simulations to analyze how the 70S ribosome moves during the process of tRNA translocation. By observing the movement of groups of residues, the authors have identified collective rearrangements that are important for the function of the ribosome. By calculating the effective diffusion of these collective rearrangements, the authors were able to establish a link between experimental rates and the continuous energy landscape of the ribosome. This analysis provides a framework for understanding the physical-chemical properties that dictate the dynamics of the ribosome, and how these properties can be manipulated to control its function.
The genetic changes that occur in a type of cancer called medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) are not fully understood. We studied 84 MTC tumor samples and found that the most common mutation was in a gene called RET, which is a proto-oncogene. We also found mutations in other genes including NRAS, HRAS, KRAS, MET, BRAF, and ALK. Additionally, we performed tests to see if the gene ALK was rearranged. We found that 2 out of 98 cases were positive for ALK rearrangement. We then used DNA from these patients to identify the genomic breakpoint and the 5’ fusion partner of ALK. We discovered that 2 types of ALK fusions occurred: GLFPT1-ALK and EML4-ALK. We confirmed the GLFPT1-ALK fusion through additional PCR and Sanger sequencing. We found that 1 metastatic MTC case that had the EML4-ALK fusion showed a dramatic response to an ALK inhibitor. Our study suggests that EML4-ALK fusion may be a potential driver mutation and a valid target of ALK inhibitors. Moreover, the GLFPT1-ALK fusion may be a potential candidate for molecular target therapy.
Leishmaniasis is a serious disease caused by a parasite and spread by sand flies. It can be cured with medication and can even be eliminated in some areas. However, a significant challenge to this goal is the presence of "asymptomatic" cases. These are people who have the disease, but do not show any signs or symptoms. It is not clear how many people are asymptomatic, and what the long-term consequences of this condition are. The study aimed to determine the proportion of asymptomatic cases and their risk of developing the disease in a high-risk area in India. This was done by screening 2603 people in eight villages using a rapid diagnostic test. Of those screened, 185 people had antibodies against the parasite, and 79 of them did not have a history of the disease. These 79 people were considered asymptomatic cases. Over the course of the study, some of the asymptomatic cases developed symptoms of the disease, and some became seronegative (no longer showing positive results on the diagnostic test). The study found that the rate of transformation to symptomatic disease among asymptomatic cases was 10.39%, and the rate of sero-conversion was 80.52%. This suggests that asymptomatic cases play an important role in the spread of the disease, and that more attention needs to be paid to them in order to eliminate leishmaniasis.
We found that Ty1-mediated translocations were not randomly distributed in the genome, but rather targeted specific regions on four different chromosomes. Additionally, some of these translocations were formed through a process that does not require the homologous recombination proteins RAD52 or the endonuclease Rad1-Rad10. Finally, we found that defects in the acetylation of histone H3 lysine 56 (H3K56) resulted in an increase in both translocations and whole-chromosome duplications, as well as aneuploidy that often occurred simultaneously with GCRs. Our findings suggest that MLPA is a powerful technique for rapidly analyzing GCRs and could be used to identify new pathways that promote genome instability.
Protein docking is a critical computational problem in structural biology and drug discovery. We describe an underestimation-based algorithm called SDU (Semi-definite programming-based Underestimation) that is capable of finding the global minimum of a funnel-shaped free energy function approximating the free energy over regions of the conformational space. The SDU algorithm combines underestimation with biased sampling to guide the search process toward the global minimum. The algorithm was successfully applied to docking using a multistage docking procedure that decomposes the conformational space into separate regions defined by the clusters, where free energy attraction basins are believed to exist and the free energy landscape is assumed to be funnel-like. We compare the performance of SDU with that of a Monte Carlo-based algorithm and show that SDU is able to make substantially fewer function evaluations while maintaining a high level of accuracy.
